The influential but mostly unpublished work of Jack Morava in the early 1970s was concerned with the implications of this link.

Most geometric results in the theory, besides the classification of closed manifolds up to cobordism, rest on the notion of the bordism groups $\Omega_{*}(X)$ of a space $X$, first defined by Conner and Floyd [2]. $\Omega_{n}(X)$ is the group (under disjoint union) of equivalence classes of maps from closed $n$-dimensional manifolds (possibly with some additional structure such as an orientation or a stable complex structure)

to $X$. Two such maps $f_{i}: M_{i} \rightarrow X(i=1,2)$ are equivalent if there is a map $f: W \rightarrow X$ from a manifold whose boundary is $M_{1} \cup M_{2}$ with $f$ extending $f_{1}$ and $f_{2}$. It can be shown (Conner and Floyd [2]) that the functor $\Omega_{*}(-)$ is a generalized homology theory and that the spectrum representing it is the appropriate Thom spectrum for the manifolds in question. For example, if the manifolds are stably complex (see the beginning of Section 1) the bordism theory, denoted by $\Omega_{*}^{U}(-)$, coincides with $M U_{*}(-)$, the generalized homology theory represented by the spectrum $M U$, i.e., $\Omega_{n}^{U}(X)=\pi_{n}(M U \wedge X)$. The notation $\Omega_{*}(-)$ with no superscript usually denotes the oriented bordism group, while the unoriented bordism group is usually denoted by $N_{*}(-)$.

These bordism groups are usually computed by algebraic methods that use properties of the Thom spectra. Thom [1] showed that $M O$, the spectrum representing unoriented bordism, is a wedge of $\bmod$ (2) Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectra, so $N_{*}(X)$ is determined by $H_{*}(X ; \mathbf{Z} /(2))$. MSO (which represents oriented bordism) when localized at the prime 2 is known (Stong [1, p. 209]) to be a wedge of integral and $\bmod$ (2) Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectra, so $\Omega_{*}(X)_{(2)}$ is also determined by ordinary homology. Brown and Peterson [1] showed that when localized at any odd prime the spectra $M S O, M S U$, and $M S p$ as well as $M U$ are wedges of various suspensions of $B P$, so the corresponding bordism groups are all determined by $B P_{*}(X)$. Conner and Floyd [2] showed effectively that $B P_{*}(X)$ is determined by $H_{*}\left(X ; \mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\right)$ when the latter is torsion-free.

For certain spaces the bordism groups have interesting geometric interpretations. For example, $\Omega_{*}(B O)$ is the cobordism group of vector bundles over oriented manifolds. Since $H_{*}(B S O)$ has no odd torsion, it determines this group. If $X_{n}$ is the nth space in the $\Omega$-spectrum for $M S O$, then $\Omega_{*}\left(X_{n}\right)$ is the cobordism group of maps of codimension $n$ between oriented manifolds. The unoriented analog was treated by Stong [3] and the complex analog by Ravenel and Wilson [2].

For a finite group $G, \Omega_{*}(B G)$ is the cobordism group of oriented manifolds with free $G$-actions, the manifolds mapped to $B G$ being the orbit spaces. These groups were studied by Conner and Floyd [2] and Conner [4]. Among other things they computed $\Omega_{*}(B G)$ for cyclic $G$. In Landweber [6] it was shown that the map $M U_{*}(B G) \rightarrow H_{*}(B G)$ is onto iff $G$ has periodic cohomology. In Floyd [1] and tom Dieck [1] it is shown that the ideal of $\pi_{*}(M U)$ represented by manifolds on which an abelian $p$-group with $n$ cyclic summands can act without stationary points is the prime ideal $I_{n}$ defined below. The groups $B P_{*}(B G)$ for $G=(\mathbf{Z} /(p))^{n}$ have been computed by Johnson and Wilson [5].

We now turn to certain other spectra related to $M U$ and $B P$. These are constructed by means of either the Landweber exact functor theorem (Landweber [3]) or the Sullivan-Baas construction (Baas [1]), which we now describe. Dennis Sullivan (unpublished, circa 1969) wanted to construct "manifolds with singularities" (admittedly a contradiction in terms) with which any ordinary homology class could be represented; i.e., any element in $H_{*}(X ; \mathbf{Z})$ could be realized as the image of the fundamental homology class of such a "manifold" $M$ under some map $M \rightarrow X$. It was long known that not all homology classes were representable in this sense by ordinary manifolds, the question having been originally posed by Steenrod. (I heard Sullivan begin a lecture on the subject by saying that homology was like the weather; everybody talks about it but nobody does anything about it.)

In terms of spectra this nonrepresentability is due to the fact that $M U$ (if we want our manifolds to be stably complex) is not a wedge of Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectra. The Sullivan-Baas construction can be regarded as a way to get from $M U$ to $H$.

Let $y \in \pi_{k}(M U)$ be represented by a manifold $X$. A closed $n$-dimensional manifold with singularity of type $(y)(n>k)$ is a space $W$ of the form $A \cup(B \times C M)$, where $C M$ denotes the cone on a manifold $M$ representing $y, B$ is a closed $(n-k-1)$ dimensional manifold, $A$ is an $n$-dimensional manifold with boundary $B \times M$, and $A$ and $B \times C M$ are glued together along $B \times M$. It can be shown that the bordism group defined using such objects is a homology theory represented by a spectrum $C(y)$ which is the cofiber of

$$
\Sigma^{k} M U \xrightarrow{y} M U, \quad \text { so } \quad \pi_{*} C(Y)=\pi_{*}(M U) / y
$$

This construction can be iterated any number of times. Given a sequence $y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots$ of elements in $\pi_{*}(M U)$ we get spectra $C\left(y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots y_{n}\right)$ and cofibrations

$$
\Sigma^{\left|y_{n}\right|} C\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n-1}\right) \rightarrow C\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n-1}\right) \rightarrow C\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)
$$

If the sequence is regular, i.e., if $y_{n}$ is not a zero divisor in $\pi_{*}(M U) /\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n-1}\right)$, then each of the cofibrations will give a short exact sequence in homotopy, so we get

$$
\pi_{*}\left(C\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)\right)=\pi(M U) /\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)
$$

In this way one can kill off any regular ideal in $\pi_{*}(M U)$. In particular, one can get $H$ by killing $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right)$. Sullivan's idea was to use this to show that any homology class could be represented by the corresponding type of manifold with singularity. One could also get $B P$ by killing the kernel of the map $\pi_{*}(M U) \rightarrow$ $\pi_{*}(B P)$ and then localizing at $p$. This approach to $B P$ does not reflect the splitting of $M U_{(p)}$.

Much more delicate arguments are needed to show that the resulting spectra are multiplicative (Shimada and Yagita [1], Morava [1], Mironov [1]), and the proof only works at odd primes. Once they are multiplicative, it is immediate that they are orientable in the sense of 4.1.1.

The two most important cases of this construction are the Johnson-Wilson spectra $B P\langle n\rangle$ (Johnson and Wilson [2]) and the Morava $K$-theories $K(n)$ (Morava's account remains unpublished; see Johnson and Wilson [3]).
$B P\langle n\rangle$ is the spectrum obtained from $B P$ (one can start there instead of $M U$ since $B P$ itself is a product of the Sullivan-Baas construction) by killing $\left(v_{n+1}, v_{n+2}, \ldots\right) \subset \pi_{*}(B P)$. One gets

$$
\pi_{*}(B P\langle n\rangle)=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right]
$$

and

$$
H_{*}(B P\langle n\rangle, \mathbf{Z} /(p))=P_{*} \otimes E\left(\tau_{n+1}, \tau_{n+2}, \ldots\right)
$$

(It is an easy exercise using the methods of Section 3.1 to show that a connective spectrum with that homology must have the indicated homotopy.) One has fibrations

$$
\Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} B P\langle n\rangle \xrightarrow{v_{n}} B P\langle n\rangle \rightarrow B P\langle n-1\rangle
$$

$B P\langle 0\rangle$ is $H_{(p)}$ and $B P\langle 1\rangle$ is a summand of $b u_{(p)}$, the localization at $p$ of the spectrum representing connective complex $K$-theory. One can iterate the map

$$
v_{n}: \Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} B P\langle n\rangle \rightarrow B P\langle n\rangle
$$

and form the direct limit

$$
E(n)=\varliminf_{v_{n}} \Sigma^{-2 i\left(p^{n}-1\right)} B P\langle n\rangle
$$

$E(1)$ is a summand of periodic complex $K$-theory localized at $p$. Johnson and Wilson [2] showed that

$$
E(n)_{*}(X)=B P_{*}(X) \otimes_{B P_{*}} E(n)_{*}
$$

$E(n)$ can also be obtained by using the Landweber exact functor theorem below.
The $B P\langle n\rangle$ are interesting for two reasons. First, the fibrations mentioned above split unstably; i.e., if $B P\langle n\rangle_{k}$ is the $k$ th space in the $Q$-spectrum for $B P\langle n\rangle$ (i.e., the space whose homotopy starts in dimension $k$ ) then

$$
B P\langle n\rangle_{k} \simeq B P\langle n-1\rangle_{k} \times B P\langle n\rangle_{k+2\left(p^{n}-1\right)}
$$

for $k \leq 2\left(p^{n}-1\right) /(p-1)$ (Wilson [2]). This means that if $X$ is a finite complex then $B P_{*}(X)$ is determined by $B P\langle n\rangle_{*}(X)$ for an appropriate $n$ depending on the dimension of $X$.

The second application of $B P\langle n\rangle$ concerns $\operatorname{Hom} \operatorname{dim} B P_{*}(X)$, the projective dimension of $B P_{*}(X)$ as a module over $\pi_{*}(B P)$, known in some circles as the ugliness number. Johnson and Wilson [2] show that the map $B P_{*}(X) \rightarrow B P\langle n\rangle_{*}(X)$ is onto iff $\operatorname{Hom} \operatorname{dim} B P_{*}(X) \leq n+1$. The cases $n=0$ and $n=1$ of this were obtained earlier by Conner and Smith [3].

We now turn to the Morava $K$-theories $K(n)$. These spectra are periodic, i.e., $\Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} K(n)=K(n)$. Their connective analogs $k(n)$ are obtained from $B P$ by killing $\left(p, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-1}, v_{n+1}, v_{n+2}, \ldots\right)$. Thus one has $\pi_{*}(k(n))=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}\right]$ and $H_{*}(k(n), \mathbf{Z} /(p))=A /\left(Q_{n}\right)_{*}$. One has fibrations

$$
\Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} k(n) \xrightarrow{v_{n}} k(n) \rightarrow H \mathbf{Z} /(p)
$$

and one defines

$$
K(n)=\varliminf_{v_{n}} \Sigma^{-2 i\left(p^{n}-1\right)} k(n)
$$

$K(1)$ is a summand of $\bmod p$ complex $K$-theory and it is consistent to define $K(0)$ to be $H Q$, rational homology.

The coefficient ring $\pi_{*}(K(n))=\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[v_{n}, v_{n}^{-1}\right]$ is a graded field in the sense that every graded module over it is free. One has a Künneth isomorphism

$$
K(n)_{*}(X \times Y)=K(n)_{*}(X) \otimes_{\pi_{*}(K(n))} K(n)_{*}(Y)
$$

This makes $K(n)_{*}(-)$ much easier to compute with than any of the other theories mentioned here. In Ravenel and Wilson [3] we compute the Morava $K$-theories of all the Eilenberg-Mac Lane spaces, the case $n=1$ having been done by Anderson and Hodgkin [2]. We show that for a finite abelian group $G, K(n)_{*}(K(G, m))$ is finite-dimensional over $\pi_{*}(K(n))$ for all $m$ and $n$, and is isomorphic to $K(n)_{*}(\mathrm{pt})$ if $m>n . \quad K(n+1)^{*} K(\mathbf{Z}, m+2)$ for $m, n \geq 0$ is a power series ring on $\binom{m}{m}$ variables. In all cases the $K(n)$-theory is concentrated in even dimensions. These calculations enabled us to prove the conjecture of Conner and Floyd [2] which concerns $B P_{*}\left(B(\mathbf{Z} / p)^{n}\right)$.

To illustrate the relation between the $K(n)$ 's and $B P$ we must introduce some more theories. Let $I_{n}=\left(p, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-1}\right) \subset \pi_{*}(B P)$ (see 4.3.2) and let $P(n)$ be the spectrum obtained from $B P$ by killing $I_{n}$. Then one has fibrations

$$
\Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} P(n) \xrightarrow{v_{n}} P(n) \rightarrow P(n+1)
$$

and we define

$$
B(n)=\lim _{\frac{1}{v_{n}} \Sigma^{-2 i\left(p^{n}-1\right)} P(n)}
$$

$P(n)_{*}(X)$ is a module over $\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[v_{n}\right]$ and its torsion-free quotient maps monomorphically to $B(n)_{*}(X)$. In Johnson and Wilson [3] it is shown that $B(n)_{*}(X)$ is determined by $K(n)_{*}(X)$. In Würgler [2] it is shown that a certain completion of $B(n)$ splits into a wedge of suspensions of $K(n)$.

This splitting has the following algebraic antecedent. The formal group law associated with $K(n)$ (4.1.4) is essentially the standard height $n$ formal group law $F_{n}$ of A2.2.11, while $\pi_{*}(B(n))=\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[v_{n}, v_{n}^{-1}, v_{n+1}, \ldots\right]$ is the universal ring for all $p$-typical formal group laws of height $n$ (A2.2.8). In A2.2.12 it is shown that over the algebraic closure of $\mathbf{F}_{p}$ any height $n$ formal group law is isomorphic to the standard one. Heuristically this is why $B(n)_{*}(X)$ is determined by $K(n)_{*}(X)$.

This connection between $K(n)$ and height $n$ formal group laws also leads to a close relation between $K(n)_{*}(K(n))$ and the endomorphism ring of $F_{n}$ (A2.2.18). An account of $K(n)_{*}(K(n))$ is given in Yagita [1]. The reader should be warned that $K(n)_{*}(K(n))$ is not the Hopf algebroid $K(n)_{*} K(n)$ of Ravenel [5, 6], which is denoted herein by $\Sigma(n)$; in fact, $K(n)_{*}(K(n))=\Sigma(n) \otimes E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \ldots, \tau_{n-1}\right)$, where the $\tau_{i}$ are analogous to the $\tau_{i}$ in $A_{*}$.

Most of the above results on $K(n)$ (excluding the results about EilenbergMac Lane spaces) were known to Morava and communicated by him to the author in 1973.

The invariance of the $I_{n}$ (4.3.2) under the $B P$-operations makes it possible to construct the spectra $P(n), B(n)$, and $K(n)$ and to show that they are ring spectra for $p>2$ by more algebraic means, i.e., without using the Sullivan-Baas construction. This is done in Würgler [1], where the structure of $P(n)_{*}(P(n))$ is also obtained. $k(n)_{*}(k(n))$ is described in Yagita [2].

We now turn to the important work of Peter Landweber on the internal algebraic structure of $M U$ - and $B P$-theories. The starting point is the invariant prime ideal theorem 4.3.2, which first appeared in Landweber [4], although it was probably first proved by Morava. It states that the only prime ideals in $\pi_{*}(B P)$ which are invariant (A1.1.21), or, equivalently, which are subcomodules over $B P_{*}(B P)$, are the $I_{n}=\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n-1}\right)$ for $0 \leq n \leq \infty$. In Conner and Smith [3] it is shown that for a finite complex $X, B P_{*}(X)$ is finitely presented as a module over $\pi_{*}(B P)$. [The result there is stated in terms of $M U_{*}(X)$, but the two statements are equivalent.] From commutative algebra one knows that such a module over such a ring has a finite filtration in which each of the successive subquotients is isomorphic to the quotient of the ring by some prime ideal. Of course, as anyone who has contemplated the prospect of algebraic geometry knows, a ring such as $\pi_{*}(B P)$ has a very large number of prime ideals. However, Landweber [3] shows that the coaction of $B P_{*}(B P)$ implies that the filtration of $B P_{*}(X)$ [or of any $B P_{*}(B P)$ comodule which is finitely presented as a module over $\pi_{*}(B P)$ can be chosen so that each successive subquotient has the form $\pi_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ for some finite $n$. \{The corresponding statement about $M U_{*}(X)$ appeared earlier in Landweber [5].\} The submodules in the filtration can be taken to be subcomodules and $n$ (the number of generators of the prime ideal) never exceeds the projective dimension of the module. This useful result is known as the Landweber filtration theorem.

It leads to the Landweber exact functor theorem, which addresses the following question. For which $\pi_{*}(B P)$-modules $M$ is the functor $B P_{*}(-) \otimes_{\pi_{*}(B P)} M$ a generalized homology theory? Such a functor must be exact in the sense that it converts cofiber sequences into long exact sequences of modules. This will be the case if $M$ is flat, i.e., if $\operatorname{Tor}_{1}^{\pi_{*}(B P)}(M, N)=0$ for all modules $N$. However, in view of the filtration theorem it suffices for this Tor group to vanish only for $N=\pi_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ for all $n$. This weaker (than flatness) condition on $M$ can be made more explicit as follows. For each $n$, multiplication by $v_{n}$ in $M \otimes_{\pi_{*}(B P)} \pi_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ is monic. Thus Landweber [3] shows that any $M$ satisfying this condition gives a homology theory.

For example, the spectrum $E(n)$ mentioned above (in connection with JohnsonWilson spectra) can be so obtained since

$$
\pi_{*}(E(n))=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n}, v_{n}^{-1}\right]
$$

satisfies Landweber's condition. [Multiplication by $v_{i}$ is monic in $\pi_{*}(E(n))$ itself for $i \leq n$, while for $i>n, \pi_{*}(E(n)) \otimes_{\pi_{*}(B P)} \pi_{*}(B P) / I_{i}=0$ so the condition is vacuous.]

As remarked earlier, $E(1)$ is a summand of complex $K$-theory localized at $p$. The exact functor theorem can be formulated globally in terms of $M U$-theory and $\pi_{*}(K)$ [viewed as a $\pi_{*}(M U)$-module via the Todd genus $t d: \pi_{*}(M U) \rightarrow \mathbf{Z}$ ] satisfies the hypotheses. Thereby one recovers the Conner-Floyd isomorphism

$$
K_{*}(X)=M U_{*}(X) \otimes_{\pi_{*}(M U)} \pi_{*}(K)
$$

and similarly for cohomology. In other words, complex $K$-theory is determined by complex cobordism. This result was first obtained by Conner and Floyd [1], whose proof relied on an explicit $K$-theoretic orientation of a complex vector bundle. Using similar methods they were able to show that real $K$-theory is determined by symplectic cobordism.

Landweber's results have been generalized as follows. Let $J \subset \pi_{*}(B P)$ be an invariant regular ideal (see Landweber [7]), and let $B P J$ be the spectrum obtained by killing $J$; e.g., $P(n)$ above is $B P I_{n}$. Most of the algebra of $B P$-theory carries over to these spectra, which are studied systematically in a nice paper by Johnson and Yosimura [4]. The case $J=I_{n}$ was treated earlier by Yagita [3] and Yosimura [1]. The $\bmod I_{n}$ version of the exact functor enables one to get $K(n)$ from $P(n)$.

Johnson and Yosimura [4] also prove some important facts about $\pi_{*}(B P)$ modules $M$ which are comodules over $B P_{*}(B P)$. They show that if an element $m \in M$ is $v_{n}$-torsion (i.e., it is annihilated by some power of $v_{n}$ ) then it is $v_{n-1}$-torsion. If all of the primitive elements in $M$ [i.e., those with $\psi(m)=1 \otimes m$ ] are $v_{n}$-torsion, then so is every element, and, if none is, then $M$ is $v_{n}$-torsion free. If $M$ is a $v_{n-1}$-torsion module, then $v_{n}^{-1} M$ is still a comodule over $B P_{*}(B P)$. Finally, they show that $v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*}(X)=0$ if $E(n)_{*}(X)=0$.

This last result may have been prompted by an erroneous claim by the author that the spectrum $v_{n}^{-1} B P$ splits as a wedge of suspensions of $E(n)$. It is clear from the methods of Würgler [2] that one must complete the spectra in some way before such a splitting can occur. Certain completions of $M U$ are studied in Morava [2].

We now turn to the last topic of this section, the applications of $B P$-theory to unstable homotopy theory. This subject began with Steve Wilson's thesis (Wilson [1, 2]) in which he studied the spaces in the $\Omega$-spectra for $M U$ and $B P$. He obtained the splitting mentioned above (in connection with the Johnson-Wilson spectra) and showed that all of the spaces in question have torsion-free homology.

Both the homology and cohomology of each space are either an exterior algebra on odd-dimensional generators or a polynomial algebra on even-dimensional generators.

These spaces were studied more systematically in Ravenel and Wilson [2]. There we found it convenient to consider all of them simultaneously as a graded space. The $\bmod (p)$ homology of such an object is a bigraded coalgebra. The fact that this graded space represents a multiplicative homology theory implies that its homology is a ring object in the category of bigraded coalgebras; we call such an object a Hopf ring. We show that the one in question has a simple set of generators and relations which are determined by the structure of $M U^{*}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{\infty}\right)$, i.e., by $\pi_{*}(M U)$ and the associated formal group law. We obtain similar results for the value on this graded space of any complex oriented (4.1.1) generalized homology theory.

As mentioned earlier, the complex bordism of the graded space associated with $M U$ is the cobordism group of maps between stably complex manifolds. We show that it is a Hopf ring generated by maps from a manifold to a point and the linear embeddings of $\mathbf{C} P^{n}$ in $\mathbf{C} P^{n+1}$.

The Hopf ring point of view is also essential in Ravenel and Wilson [3], where we calculate $K(n)_{*}(K(G, m))$. We show that the Hopf ring $K(n)_{*}\left(K\left(\mathbf{Z} /\left(p^{j}\right),{ }^{*}\right)\right)$ is a certain type of free object on $K(n)_{*}\left(K\left(\mathbf{Z} /\left(p^{j}\right), 1\right)\right)$. The ordinary homology of $K\left(\mathbf{Z} /\left(p^{j}\right),{ }^{*}\right)$ can be described in similar terms and the methods of our paper may lead to simpler proofs of the classical theorems about it (see Wilson [3], section II.8).

Knowing the $B P$ homology of the spaces in the $B P$ spectrum is analogous to knowing the $\bmod (p)$ homology of the $\bmod (p)$ Eilenberg-Mac Lane spaces. This information, along with some ingenious formal machinery, is needed to construct the unstable Adams spectral sequence, i.e., a spectral sequence for computing the homotopy groups of a space $X$ rather than a spectrum. This was done in the $B P$ case by Bendersky, Curtis, and Miller [1]. Their spectral sequence is especially convenient for $X=S^{2 n+1}$. In that case they get an $E_{1}$-term which is a subcomplex of the usual $E_{1}$-term for the sphere spectrum, i.e., of the cobar complex of A1.2.11. Their $E_{2}$-term is Ext in an appropriate category. For $S^{2 n+1}$ they compute Ext ${ }^{1}$, which is a subgroup of the stable Ext ${ }^{1}$, and get some corresponding information about $\pi_{*}\left(S^{2 n+1}\right)$.

In Bendersky [2] the spectral sequence is applied to the special unitary groups $S U(n)$. In Bendersky, Curtis, and Ravenel [3] the $E_{2}$-terms for various spheres are related by an analog of the EHP sequence.

# 3. Some Calculations in $B P_{*}(B P)$ 

In this section we will prove the Morava-Landweber theorem (4.3.2), which classifies invariant prime ideals in $\pi_{*}(B P)$. Then we will derive several formulas in $B P_{*}(B P)$ (4.1.18 and 4.1.19). These results are rather technical. Some of them are more detailed than any of the applications in this book require and they are included here only for possible future reference. The reader is advised to refer to this material only when necessary.

Theorem 4.3.3 is a list of invariant regular ideals that will be needed in Chapter 5. Lemma 4.3.8 gives some generalizations of the Witt polynomials. They are

used to give more explicit formulas for the formal group law (4.3.9), the coproduct (4.3.13), and the right unit (4.3.18). We define certain elements, $b_{i, J}$ (4.3.14) and $c_{i, J}$ (4.3.19), which are used to give approximations (modulo certain prime ideals) of the coproduct (4.3.15) and right unit (4.3.20). Explicit examples of the right unit are given in 4.3.21. The coboundaries of $b_{i, J}$ and $c_{i, J}$ in the cobar complex are given in 4.3.22.

In 4.3.23 we define a filtration of $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ which leads to a May spectral sequence which will be used in Section 6.3. The structure of the resulting bigraded Hopf algebroid is given in 4.3.32-34.

From now on $\pi_{*}(B P)$ will be abbreviated by $B P_{*}$. Recall (A2.2.3) that we have two sets of generators for the ring $B P_{*}$ given by Hazewinkel [2] (A2.2.1) and Araki [1] (A2.2.2). The behavior of the right unit $\eta_{R}: B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*}(B P)$ on the Araki generators is given by A2.2.6, i.e.,

$$
\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \eta_{R}\left(v_{j}\right)^{p^{i}}=\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} v_{i} t_{j}^{p^{i}}
$$

For the Hazewinkel generators this formula is true only $\bmod (p)$.
This formula will enable us to define some invariant ideals in $B P_{*}$. In each case it will be easy to show that the ideal in question is independent of the choice of generators used. The most important result of this sort is the following.
4.3.2. Theorem (Morava [3], Landweber [4]). Let $I_{n}=\left(p, v_{1}, \ldots v_{n-1}\right) \subset B P_{*}$. (a) $I_{n}$ is invariant.
(b) For $n>0$,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}\right]
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}
$$

(c) $0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} B P_{*} / I_{n} \xrightarrow{v_{n}} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n+1} \rightarrow 0$ is a short exact sequence of comodules.
(d) The only invariant prime ideals in $B P_{*}$ are the $I_{n}$ for $0 \leq n \leq \infty$.

Proof. Part (a) follows by induction on $n$, using (c) for the inductive step. Part (c) is equivalent to the statement that

$$
v_{n} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)
$$

and is therefore a consequence of (b). For (d) suppose $J$ is an invariant prime ideal which properly contains some $I_{n}$. Then the smallest dimensional element of $J$ not in $I_{n}$ must be invariant modulo $I_{n}$, i.e., it must be in $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}\left(B P / I_{n}\right)\right)$, so by (b) it must be a power of $v_{n}$ (where $v_{0}=p$ ). Since $J$ is prime this element must be $v_{n}$ itself, so $J \supset I_{n+1}$. If this containment is proper the argument can be repeated. Hence, if $J$ is finitely generated, it is $I_{n}$ for some $n<\infty$. If $J$ is infinitely generated we have $J \supset I_{\infty}$, which is maximal, so (d) follows.

Hence it remains only to prove (b). It is clear from 4.3.1 that $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right) \equiv v_{n}$ $\bmod I_{n}$, so it suffices to show that $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ is no bigger than indicated. From 4.3.1 we see that in $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$,

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+j}\right) \equiv v_{n+j}+v_{n} t_{j}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p^{j}} t_{j} \quad \bmod \left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{j-1}\right)
$$

so the set $\left\{v_{n+j}, \eta_{R}\left(v_{n+j}\right) \mid j>0\right\} \cup\left\{v_{n}\right\}$ is algebraically independent. It follows that if $\eta_{R}(v)=v$ then $v$ must be a polynomial in $v_{n}$.

Now we will construct some invariant regular ideals in $B P_{*}$. Recall that an ideal $\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n-1}\right)$ is regular if $x_{i}$ is not a zero divisor in $B P_{*} /\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i-1}\right)$ for $0 \leq i<n$. This means that the sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i-1}\right) \xrightarrow{x_{i}} B P_{*} /\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i-1}\right) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

is exact. The regular sequence $\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, \ldots\right)$ is invariant if the above is a short exact sequence of comodules. Invariant regular ideals have been studied systematically by Landweber [7]. He shows that an invariant regular ideal with $n$ generators is primary with radical $I_{n}$, and that any invariant ideal with $n$ generators and radical $I_{n}$ is regular. Invariant ideals in general need not be regular, e.g., $I_{n}^{k}$ for $k>1$.
4.3.3. ThEOREM. Let $i_{1}, i_{2}, \ldots$ be a sequence of positive integers such that for each $n>0, i_{n+i}$ is divisible by the smallest power of $p$ not less than $i_{n}$, and let $k \geq 0$. Then for each $n>0$, the regular ideal $\left(p^{1+k}, v_{1}^{i_{1} p^{k}}, v_{2}^{i_{2} p^{2 k}}, \ldots, v_{n}^{i_{n} p^{k n}}\right)$ is invariant.

In order to prove this we will need the following.
4.3.4. Lemma. Let $B, A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots$ be ideals in a commutative ring. Then if

$$
x \equiv y \quad \bmod p B+\sum_{i} A_{i}
$$

then

$$
x^{p^{n}} \equiv y^{p^{n}} \quad \bmod p^{n+1} B+\sum_{k=0}^{n} p^{k} \sum_{i} A_{i}^{p^{n-k}}
$$

Proof. The case $n>1$ follows easily by induction on $n$ from the case $n=1$. For the latter suppose $x=y+p b+\sum a_{i}$, with $b \in B$ and $a_{i} \in A_{i}$. Then

$$
x^{p}=y^{p}+\sum_{0<j<p}\binom{p}{j} y^{p-j}\left(p b+\sum a_{i}\right)^{j}+\left(p b+\sum a_{i}\right)^{p}
$$

and we have

$$
\binom{p}{j} y^{p-j}\left(p b+\sum a_{i}\right)^{j} \in p^{2} B+p \sum A_{i}
$$

and

$$
\left(p b+\sum a_{i}\right)^{p} \in p^{2} B+p \sum A_{i}+\sum A_{i}^{p}
$$

Proof of 4.3.3. We have $v_{n} \equiv \eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right) \bmod I_{n}$, so we apply 4.3 .4 to the ring $B P_{*}(B P)$ by setting $B=(1), A_{i}=\left(v_{i}\right)$. Then we get

$$
v_{n}^{p^{m}} \equiv \eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)^{p^{m}} \quad \bmod \left(p^{m+1}\right)+\sum_{j=0}^{m} \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\left(p^{j} v_{i}^{m-j}\right)
$$

To prove the theorem we must show that the indicated power of $v_{n}$ is invariant modulo the ideal generated by the first $n$ elements. It suffices to replace this ideal by the smaller one obtained by replacing each of $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n-1}$ by the smallest power of $p$ not less than it, i.e., by an ideal of the form

$$
\left(p^{1+k}, v_{1}^{j_{1}}, v_{2}^{j_{2}}, \ldots, v_{n-1}^{j_{n-1}}\right)=I
$$

with $j_{t}=p^{t k+k_{t}}$ where $0 \leq k_{1} \leq k_{2} \cdots \leq k_{n-1}$. Then the hypothesis on $i_{n}$ is that it is divisible by $p^{k_{n-1}}$, so it suffices to assume that $i_{n}=p^{k_{n-1}}$. Hence we must show

$$
v_{n}^{j_{n-1} p^{k}} \equiv \eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)^{j_{n-1} p^{k}} \bmod I
$$

We have $v_{n} \equiv \eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right) \bmod I_{n}$, so we apply 4.3.4 to the ring $B P_{*}(B P)$ by setting $B=(1), A_{i}=\left(v_{i}\right)$. Then we get

$$
v_{n}^{p^{m}} \equiv \eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)^{p_{m}} \bmod \left(p^{m+1}\right)+\sum_{j=0}^{m} \sum_{i=0}^{n-1}\left(p^{j} v_{i}^{p^{m-j}}\right)
$$

We are interested in the case $m=k n+k_{n-1}$. Careful inspection shows that the indicated ideal in this case is contained in $I$.

Theorem 4.3.3 leads to a list of invariant regular ideals which one might hope is complete. Unfortunately, it is not. For example, it gives $\left\{\left(p^{k+1}, v^{i p^{k}}\right) \mid k \geq 0, i \geq 0\right\}$ as a list of $I_{2}$-primary regular ideals, and this list can be shown to be a complete for $p>2$, but at $p=2$ the ideal $\left(16, v_{1}^{4}+8 v_{1} v_{2}\right)$ is regular and invariant but not in the list. Similarly, for $p>2$ the ideal

$$
\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{2}+p-1}, v_{2}^{2 p^{2}}-2 v_{1}^{p^{2}} v_{2}^{p^{2}-p} v_{3}^{p}-2 v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} v_{2}^{2 p^{2}-p+1}\right)
$$

is invariant, regular, and not predicted by 4.3.3. This example and others like it were used by Miller and Wilson [3] to produce unexpected elements in $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}^{1}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ (see Section 5.2).

Now we will make the structure of $B P_{*}(B P)$ (4.1.19) more explicit. We start with the formal group law.

Recall the lemma of Witt (see, e.g., Lang [1, pp. 234-235]) which states that there are symmetric integral polynomials $w_{n}=w_{n}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right)$ of degree $p^{n}$ in any number of variables such that

$$
w_{0}=\sum x_{t} \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{t} x_{t}^{p^{n}}=\sum_{j} p^{j} w_{j}^{p^{n-j}}
$$

For example,

$$
w_{1}=\left(\sum\left(x_{t}^{p}\right)-\left(\sum x_{t}\right)^{p}\right) / p
$$

and for $p=2$ with two variables,

$$
w_{2}=-x_{1}^{3} x_{2}-2 x_{1}^{2} x_{2}^{2}-x_{1} x_{2}^{3}
$$

Witt's lemma can be restated as follows. Let $G$ be the formal group law with $\operatorname{logarithm} \sum_{i \geq 0} x^{p^{i}} / p^{i}$. Then

$$
\sum^{G} x_{t}=\sum^{G} w_{n}
$$

This formula is in some sense more explicit than the usual

$$
\log \left(\sum^{G} x_{t}\right)=\sum \log x_{t}
$$

We will derive a similar formula for the universal formal group law.
First we need some notation. Let $I=\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, \ldots, i_{m}\right)$ be a finite (possibly empty) sequence of positive integers. Let $|I|=m$ and $\|I\|=\sum i_{t}$. For positive integers $n$ let $\Pi(n)=p-p^{\left(p^{0}\right)}$ and define integers $\Pi(I)$ recursively by $\Pi(\phi)=1$ and $\Pi(I)=\Pi(\|I\|) \Pi\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{m-1}\right)$. Note that $\Pi(I) \equiv p^{|I|} \bmod p^{|I|+1}$. Given

sequences $I$ and $J$ let $I J$ denote the sequence $\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{m}, j_{1}, \ldots, j_{n}\right)$. Then we have $|I J|=|I|+|J|$ and $\|I J\|=\|I\|+\|J\|$. We will need the following analog of Witt's lemma (4.3.5), which we will prove at the end of this section.

# 4.3.8. Lemma. 

(a) For each sequence $I$ as above there is a symmetric polynomial of degree $p^{\|I\|}$ in any number of variables with coefficients in $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}, w_{I}=w_{I}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right)$ with $w_{\phi}=\sum_{t} x_{t}$ and

$$
\sum_{t} x_{t}^{p^{\|K\|}}=\sum_{I J=K} \frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}}
$$

(b) Let $w_{i}$ be the polynomial defined by 4.3.5. Then

$$
w_{I} \equiv w_{|I|}^{p^{\|I\|-|I|}} \quad \bmod (p)
$$

Now let $v_{i}$ be Araki's generator and define $v_{I}$ by $v_{\phi}=1$ and $v_{I}=v_{i_{1}}\left(v_{I^{\prime}}\right)^{\left(p^{\prime 1}\right)}$ where $I^{\prime}=\left(i_{2}, i_{3} \ldots\right)$. Hence $\operatorname{dim} v_{I}=2\left(p^{\|I\|}-1\right)$. Then our analog of 4.3 .7 is
4.3.9. ThEOREM. With notation as above,

$$
\sum_{t}^{F} x_{t}=\sum_{I}^{F} v_{I} w_{I}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\right)
$$

(An analogous formula and proof in terms of Hazewinkel's generators can be obtained, by replacing $\Pi(I)$ by $p^{|I|}$ throughout. This requires a different definition of $w_{J}$, which is still congruent to $w_{|J|}^{p^{\|I\|-|J|}}$ modulo $p$.)

Proof. Araki's formula (A2.2.2) is

$$
p \lambda_{n}=\sum_{0 \leq i \leq n} \lambda_{i} v_{n-i}^{p^{i}}
$$

which can be written as

$$
\Pi(n) \lambda_{n}=\sum_{0 \leq i<n} \lambda_{i} v_{n-i}^{p^{i}}
$$

By a simple exercise this gives

$$
\lambda_{n}=\sum_{\|I\|=n} \frac{v_{I}}{\Pi(I)}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\log (x)=\sum \frac{v_{I} x^{p^{\|I\|}}}{\Pi(I)}
$$

Therefore we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \left(\sum_{J}^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\right) & =\sum_{J} \log v_{J} w_{J} \\
& =\sum \frac{v_{I J}}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}} \\
& =\sum_{I, J} \frac{v_{K}}{\Pi(K)} \frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}} \quad(\text { where } K=I J) \\
& =\sum_{t, K} \frac{v_{K}}{\Pi(K)} x_{t}^{p^{\|K\|}} \quad \text { by } 4.3 .8 \\
& =\sum_{t} \log x_{t} \quad \text { by } 4.3 .10 \\
& =\log \sum_{t} x_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the structure formulas for $B P_{*}(B P)$ we encounter expressions of the form $\sum_{n, i}^{F} a_{n, i}$, where $a_{n, i}$ is in $B P_{*}(B P)$ or $B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P)$ (or more generally in some commutative graded $B P_{*}$ algebra $D$ ) and has dimension $2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$. We can use 4.3.9 to simplify such expressions in the following way.

Define subsets $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$ of $D$ as follows. $A_{n}=B_{n}=\phi$ for $n \leq 0$ and for $n>0, A_{n}=\left\{a_{n, i}\right\}$ while $B_{n}$ is defined recursively by

$$
B_{n}=A_{n} \cup \bigcup_{|J|>0}\left\{v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{n-\|J\|}\right)\right\}
$$

4.3.11. Lemma. With notation as above, $\sum_{n, i}^{F} a_{n, i}=\sum_{n>0}^{F} w_{\phi}\left(B_{n}\right)$.

Proof. We will show by induction on $m$ that the statement is true in dimensions $<2\left(p^{m}-1\right)$. Our inductive hypothesis is

$$
\sum^{F} a_{n, i}=\sum_{0<n<m}^{F} w_{\phi}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{\substack{n<m \\\|J\|+n \geq m}}^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{n \geq m}^{F} a_{n, i}
$$

which is trivial for $m=1$. The set of formal summands of dimension $2\left(p^{m}-1\right)$ on the right is $B_{m}$. By 4.3.9 the formal sum of these terms is $\sum^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{m}\right)$, so we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum^{F} a_{n, i} & =\sum_{0<n<m}^{F} w_{\phi}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{J}^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{m}\right)+_{F} \sum_{\substack{n<m \\
\|J\|+n>m}}^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{n>m}^{F} a_{n, i} \\
& =\sum_{0<n \leq m}^{F} w_{\phi}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{\substack{n \leq m \\
\|J\|+n>m}}^{F} v_{J} w_{J}\left(B_{n}\right)+_{F} \sum_{n>m}^{F} a_{n, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

which completes the inductive step and the proof.
Recall now the coproduct in $B P_{*}(B P)$ given by 4.1.18(e), i.e.,

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0} \log \left(\Delta\left(t_{i}\right)\right)=\sum_{i, j \geq 0} \log \left(t_{i} \otimes t_{j}^{p^{i}}\right)
$$

which can be rewritten as

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} \Delta\left(t_{i}\right)=\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes t_{j}^{p^{i}}
$$

To apply 4.3.11, let $M_{n}=\left\{t_{i} \otimes t_{n-i}^{p^{i}} \mid 0 \leq i \leq n\right\}$ ( $M$ here stands for Milnor since these terms are essentially Milnor's coproduct 3.1.1) and let

$$
\Delta_{n}=M_{n} \cup \bigcup_{|J|>0}\left\{v_{J} w_{J}\left(\Delta_{n-\|J\|}\right)\right\}
$$

Then we get from 4.3.11 and 4.3.12

# 4.3.13. ThEOREM. With notation as above, 

$$
\Delta\left(t_{n}\right)=w_{\phi}\left(\Delta_{n}\right) \in B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P)
$$

For future reference we make

### 4.3.14. Definition. In $B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P)$ let $b_{i, j}=w_{(j+1)}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)$.

For example,

$$
b_{1, j}=-\frac{1}{p-p^{\left(p^{j+1}\right)}} \sum_{0<i<p^{j+1}}\binom{p^{j+1}}{i} t_{1}^{i} \otimes t_{1}^{p^{j+1}-i}
$$

This $b_{i, j}$ can be regarded as an element of degree 2 in the cobar complex (A1.2.11) $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$. It will figure in subsequent calculations and we will give a formula for its coboundary (4.3.22) below.

If we reduce modulo $I_{n}, 4.3 .13$ simplifies as follows.
4.3.15. Corollary. In $B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ for $k \leq 2 n$

$$
\Delta\left(t_{k}\right)=\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k} t_{i} \otimes t_{k-i}^{p^{i}}+\sum_{0 \leq j \leq k-n-1} v_{n+j} b_{k-n-j, n+j-1}
$$

Now we will simplify the right unit formula 4.3.1. First we need a lemma. Define $t_{I}$ as wedefines $v_{I}$, replacing $v_{i}$ by $t_{i}$.
4.3.16. Lemma. In $B P_{*}(B P)$, for each $k \geq 0$

$$
\sum_{i,|I| \geq 0}^{F}\left[(-1)^{|I|}\right]\left(t_{I} t_{i}^{p^{\| I \mid}}\right)^{p^{k}}=\sum_{i,|I| \geq 0}^{F}\left[(-1)^{|I|}\right]\left(t_{i}\left(t_{I}\right)^{p^{i}}\right)^{p^{k}}=1
$$

It is shown in A2.2.5 that for $p>2,[-1](x)=-x$ for any $p$-typical formal group law, and a formulas for it are given for $p=2$ in terms of both the Hazewinkel generators of (A2.2.1) and the Araki generators of (A2.2.2). $[n](x)$ is defined in A2.1.19.

Proof. In the first expression, for each $I=\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, \ldots, i_{n}\right)$ with $n>0$, the expression $\left(t_{I}\right)^{p^{k}}$ appears twice: once as $\left(t_{I} t_{0}\right)^{p^{k}}$ and once as $\left(t_{I^{\prime}}\left(t_{i_{n}}\right)^{p^{\| I^{\prime \mid}}}\right)^{p^{k}}$ where $I^{\prime}=\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n-1}\right)$. These two terms have opposite formal sign and hence cancel, leaving 1 as the value of the first expression. The argument for the second expression is similar.

Now we need to use the conjugate formal group law $c(F)$ over $B P_{*}(B P)$, defined by the homomorphism $\eta_{R}: B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*}(B P)$. Its logarithm is

$$
\log _{c(F)}(x)=\sum_{i \geq 0} \eta_{R}\left(\lambda_{i}\right) x^{p^{i}}=\sum_{i, j \geq 0} \lambda_{i} t_{j}^{p^{i}} x^{p^{i+j}}
$$

An analog of 4.3.9 holds for $c(F)$ with $v_{I}$ replaced by $\eta_{R}\left(v_{I}\right)$.
The last equation in the proof of A2.2.6 reads

$$
\sum \lambda_{i} v_{j}^{p^{i}} t_{k}^{p^{i+j}}=\sum \lambda_{i} t_{j}^{p^{i}} \eta_{R}\left(v_{k}\right)^{p^{i+j}}=\sum \eta_{R}\left(\lambda_{i}\right) \eta_{R}\left(v_{j}\right)^{p^{i}}
$$

while 4.3.16 gives

$$
\sum \lambda_{i}=\sum(-1)^{|K|} \lambda_{i} t_{j}^{p^{i}} t_{K}^{p^{i+j}}
$$

Combining these and reindexing gives

$$
\sum(-1)^{|J|} \eta_{R}\left(\lambda_{i}\right)\left(t_{J}\left(v_{k} t_{l}^{p^{k}}\right)^{p^{\|J\|}}\right)^{p^{i}}=\sum \eta_{R}\left(\lambda_{i}\right) \eta_{R}\left(v_{j}\right)^{p^{i}}
$$

which is equivalent to

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{c(F)} \eta_{R}\left(v_{i}\right)=\sum_{|I|, j, k \geq 0}^{c(F)}\left[(-1)^{|I|}\right]_{c(F)}\left(t_{I}\left(v_{j} t_{k}^{p^{j}}\right)^{p^{\| J \mid}}\right)
$$

In A2.2.5 we show that for $p>2,[-1]_{c(F)}(x)=-x$, and for $p=2$,

$$
[-1]_{c(F)}(x)=x-_{c(F)} \sum_{i \geq 0}^{c(F)} \eta_{R}\left(v_{i}\right) x^{2^{i}}
$$

For $p>2$ we define finite subsets of $B P_{*}(B P)$ for $n>0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& N_{n}=\bigcup_{\|I\|+i+j=n}\left\{(-1)^{|I|} t^{I}\left(v_{j} t_{k}^{p^{i}}\right)^{p^{\| I \mid}}\right\} \\
& R_{n}=N_{n} \cup \bigcup_{\substack{\|J\|=i \\
0<i<n}}\left\{\eta_{R}\left(v_{J}\right) w_{J}\left(R_{n-i}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we get
4.3.18. ThEOREM. In $B P_{*}(B P)$ for $p>2$, we have $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)=w_{\phi}\left(R_{n}\right)$.

For $p=2$ we have to rewrite (4.3.17) as

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{c(F)} \eta_{R}\left(v_{i}\right)+_{c(F)} \sum_{\substack{|I| \leq k \geq 6 \\
|I| \text { odd }}}^{c(F)} t_{I}\left(v_{j} t_{k}^{p^{j}}\right)^{p^{\| J \mid}}=\sum_{\substack{|I| \leq k \geq 6 \\
|I| \text { even }}}^{c(F)} t_{I}\left(v_{j} t_{k}^{p^{j}}\right)^{p^{\| J \mid}}
$$

4.3.19. Definition. In $B P_{*}(B P), c_{i, J}=w_{J}\left(R_{i}\right)$. For $J=(j)$ this will be written as $c_{i, j}$.

Again we can simplify further by reducing modulo $I_{n}$.
4.3.20. Corollary. In $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ for $0<k \leq 2 n$,

$$
\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k} v_{n+i} t_{k-i}^{p^{n+i}}-\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+k-i}\right)^{p^{i}} t_{i}=\sum_{0 \leq j \leq k-n-1} v_{n+j} c_{k-j, n+j}
$$

(Note that the right-hand side vanishes if $k \leq n$.)

4.3.21. Corollary. In $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \eta_{R}\left(v_{n+1}\right)= v_{n+1}+v_{n} t_{1}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p} t_{1} \\
& \text { for } n \geq 1 ; \\
& \eta_{R}\left(v_{n+2}\right)= v_{n+2}+v_{n+1} t_{1}^{p^{n+1}}+v_{n} t_{2}^{p^{n}}-v_{n+1}^{p} t_{1}-v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{2} \\
& +v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p}-v_{n}^{p} t_{1}^{1+p^{n+1}} \\
& \text { for } n \geq 2 \text {; } \\
& \eta_{R}\left(v_{n+3}\right)= v_{n+3}+v_{n+2} t_{1}^{p^{n+2}}+v_{n+1} t_{2}^{p^{n+1}}+v_{n} t_{3}^{p^{n}}-v_{n+2}^{p} t_{1} \\
& -v_{n+1}^{p^{2}} t_{2}-v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{3}-v_{n+1}^{p} t_{1}^{1+p^{n+2}}-v_{n}^{p} t_{1} t_{2}^{p^{n+1}} \\
& -v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{2} t_{1}^{p^{n+2}}+v_{n+1}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p}+v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{1} t_{2}^{p}+v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{2} t_{1}^{p^{2}} \\
& +v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p+p^{n+2}}-v_{n}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p+p^{2}} \\
& \text { for } n \geq 3 \text {; } \\
& \eta_{R}\left(v_{3}\right)= v_{3}+v_{2} t_{1}^{p^{2}}+v_{1} t_{2}^{p}-v_{2}^{p} t_{1}-v_{1}^{p^{2}} t_{2}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1}^{1+p^{2}} \\
& +v_{1}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p}+v_{1} w_{1}\left(v_{2}, v_{1} t_{1}^{p},-v_{1}^{p} t_{1}\right) \\
& \text { for } n=1, p>2\left(\text { add } v_{1}^{5} t_{1}^{2} \text { for } p=2\right) \\
& \text { and } \quad \eta_{R}\left(v_{5}\right)= v_{5}+v_{4} t_{1}^{p^{4}}+v_{3} t_{2}^{p^{3}}+v_{2} t_{3}^{p^{2}}-v_{2}^{p} t_{1}-v_{3}^{p^{2}} t_{2}-v_{2}^{p^{3}} t_{3} \\
& -v_{3}^{p} t_{1}^{1+p^{4}}-v_{2}^{p} t_{1} t_{2}^{p^{3}}-v_{2}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{p^{2}} t_{2}+v_{3}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p}+v_{2}^{p^{2}} t_{1} t_{2}^{p} \\
& +v_{2}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{p^{2}} t_{2}+v_{2}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p+p^{2}}-v_{2}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{1+p+p^{2}} \\
& +v^{2} w_{1}\left(v_{3}, v_{2} t_{1}^{p^{2}},-v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{p}\right)^{p} \\
& \text { for } n=2, p>2\left(\text { add } v_{2}^{9} t_{1}^{4} \text { for } p=2\right) \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we will calculate the coboundaries of $b_{i, j}$ (4.3.14) and $c_{i, j}$ (4.3.19) in the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)(\mathrm{A} 1.2 .11)$.
4.3.22. ThEOREM. In $C\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ for $0<i \leq n$ and $0 \leq j$
(a) $d\left(b_{i, j}\right)=\sum_{0<k<i} b_{k, j} \otimes t_{i-k}^{p^{k+j+1}}-t_{k}^{p^{1+j}} \otimes b_{i-k, k+j}$ and (b) $d\left(c_{n+i, j+1}\right)=$ $\sum_{0 \leq k<i} v_{n+k}^{p^{1+j}} b_{i-k, n+k+j}-v_{n+k}^{p^{i+1+j-k}} b_{i-k, j}$.

Proof. (a) It suffices to assume $i=n$. Recall that in $C\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right), d\left(t_{i}\right)=$ $t_{i} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t_{i}-\Delta\left(t_{i}\right)$ and $d\left(v_{n+i}\right)=n_{R}\left(v_{n+i}\right)-v_{n+i} . \Delta\left(t_{2 n}\right)-1 \otimes t_{2 n}-t_{2 n} \otimes 1$, given by 4.3.13, is a coboundary and hence a cocycle. Calculating its coboundary term by term using 4.3.13 and 4.3.17 will give the desired formula for $d\left(b_{n, n-1}\right)$ and the result will follow. The details are straightforward and left to the reader.

For (b) we assume $i=n$ if $i+n$ is even and $i=n-1$ if $i+n$ is odd. Then we use the fact that $d\left(v_{2 n+i}\right)$ is a cocycle to get the desired formula, as in the proof of (a).

Now we will construct an increasing filtration on the Hopf algebroid $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$. We will use it in Section 6.3.

To do this we first define integers $d_{n, i}$ by

$$
d_{n, i}= \begin{cases}0 & \text { for } i \leq 0 \\ \max \left(i, p d_{n, i-n}\right) & \text { for } i>0\end{cases}
$$

We then set $\operatorname{deg} t_{i}^{p^{j}}=\operatorname{deg} v_{n+i}^{p^{j}}=d_{n, i}$ for $i, j \geq 0$. The subgroups $F_{r} \subset B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ are defined to be the smallest possible subgroups satisfying the above conditions.

The associated graded algebra $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ is defined by $E_{0}^{i} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}=$ $F_{i} / F_{i-1}$. Its structure is given by

# 4.3.23. Proposition. 

$$
E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}=T\left(t_{i, j}, v_{n+i, j}: i>0, j \geq 0\right)
$$

where $t_{i, j}$ and $v_{n+1, j}$ are elements corresponding to $t_{i}^{p^{i}}$ and $v_{n+1}^{p^{i}}$, respectively, $T(x)=R[x] /\left(x^{p}\right)$ and $R=\mathbf{Z}(p)\left[v_{n}\right]$.
4.3.24. Theorem. With the above filtration, $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ is a filtered Hopf algebroid, and $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ is a Hopf algebroid.

Proof. For a set of elements $X$ in $B_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ or $B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$, let $\operatorname{deg} X$ be the smallest integer $i$ such that $X \subset F_{i}$. It suffices to show then that $\operatorname{deg} \Delta_{i}=\operatorname{deg} R_{n+i}=d_{n, i}$. We do this by induction on $i$, the assertion being obvious for $i=1$.

First note that

$$
d_{n, a+b} \geq d_{n, a}+d_{n, b}
$$

and

$$
d_{n, a+b n} \geq p^{b} d_{n, a}
$$

It follows from 4.3.25 that $\operatorname{deg} M_{i}=\operatorname{deg} N_{n+i}=d_{n, i}$. It remains then to show that for $\|J\|<i$

$$
\operatorname{deg}\left(v_{J} w_{J}\left(\Delta_{i-\|J\|}\right)\right) \leq d_{n, i}
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{deg}\left(v_{J} w_{J}\left(R_{n+i-\|J\|}\right)\right) \leq d_{n, i}
$$

Since

$$
\operatorname{deg} w_{J}(X) \leq p^{|J|} \operatorname{deg} X
$$

both 4.3.27 and 4.3.28 reduce to showing

$$
d_{n, i} \geq \operatorname{deg} v_{J}+p^{|J|} d_{n, i-\|J\|}
$$

Now if $v_{J} \not \equiv 0 \bmod I_{n}$ we can write

$$
J=\left(n+j_{1}^{\prime}, m+j_{2}^{\prime}, \ldots, n+j_{l}^{\prime}\right)
$$

with $j_{t}^{\prime} \geq 0$, so

$$
|J|=l, \quad\|J\|=\ln +\sum_{t=1}^{l} j_{t}^{\prime}, \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{deg} v_{J}=\sum_{t=1}^{l} d_{n, j_{t}^{\prime}}
$$

If we set $k=\|J\|-n|J|$, then 4.3.25 implies

$$
d_{n, k} \geq \operatorname{deg} v_{J}
$$

However, by 4.3.25 and 4.3.26

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{n, i} & \geq d_{n, k}+d_{n, i-\|J\|+n|J|} \\
& \geq d_{n, k}+p^{|J|} d_{n, i-\|J\|}
\end{aligned}
$$

so 4.3.20 follows from 4.3.31.

We now turn to the Hopf algebroid structure of $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$. Let $\bar{M}_{i}, \bar{\Delta}_{i}$, $\bar{N}_{n+i}$, and $\bar{R}_{n+i}$ denote the associated graded analogs of $M_{i}, \Delta_{i}, N_{n+i}$, and $R_{n+i}$, respectively, with trivial elements deleted. (An element in one of the latter sets will correspond to a trivial element if its degree is less than $d_{n, i}$.) All we have to do is describe these subsets. Let $\bar{t}_{I}, \bar{v}_{I}$, and $\bar{w}_{I}(x)$ denote the associated graded elements corresponding to $t_{I}, v_{I}$, and $w_{I}(x)$, respectively.

# 4.3.32. LEMMA. 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{M}_{i} & =\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\bigcup_{0 \leq j \leq i}\left\{t_{j, 0} \otimes t_{i-j, j}\right\} & \text { for } i \leq m \\
\left\{t_{i, 0} \otimes 1,1 \otimes t_{i, 0}\right\} & \text { for } i>m
\end{array}\right. \\
\bar{N}_{n+i} & =\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\bigcup_{\|I\|+j+k=i}\left\{(-1)^{|I|} \bar{t}_{I} v_{j,\|I\|} t_{k, j+\|I\|}\right\} & \text { for } i \leq m \\
\left\{v_{n+i, 0}, v_{n} t_{i, n},-v_{n}^{p^{i}} t_{i, 0}\right\} & \text { for } i>m
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m=p n /(p-1)$.
Proof. This follows from the fact that equality holds in 4.3.25 if $a+b \leq m$.
4.3.33. LEMMA.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{\Delta}_{i}= \begin{cases}\bar{M}_{i} & \text { for } i<m \\
\bar{M}_{i} \cup\left\{v_{n} \overline{w_{1}^{p^{n-1}}\left(M_{i-n}\right)}\right\} & \text { for } i=m \\
\bar{M}_{i} \cup \bigcup_{\substack{\|J\|=n|J| \\
0<\|J\|<i \\
i-\|J\| \geq m-n}} \quad\left\{v_{J} \overline{w_{J}\left(\Delta_{i-n|J|}\right)}\right\} & \text { for } i>m\end{cases} \\
& \bar{R}_{n+i}= \begin{cases}\bar{N}_{n+i} & \text { for } i<m \\
\bar{N}_{n+i} \cup\left\{v_{n} \overline{w_{1}^{p^{n-1}}\left(R_{i-n}\right)}\right\} & \text { for } i=m \\
\bar{N}_{n+i} \cup \bigcup_{\substack{\|J\|=n|J| \\
0<\|J\|<i \\
i-\|J\| \geq m-n}} \quad \text { for } i>m\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

[Note that the case $i=m$ occurs only if $(p-1) \mid n$, and that the only J's we need to consider for $i>m$ are those of the form $(n, n, \ldots, n)$.]

Proof. We use the observation made in the proof of 4.3.32 along with the fact that equality holds in 4.3.26 if $a \geq m=n$.

Now both $\bar{R}_{n+i}$, and $\bar{\Delta}$, will consist only of the terms associated with those $J$ for which equality holds in 4.3.30. For $i>m$ this can occur only if $\operatorname{deg} v_{J}=0$, i.e., if $J=(n, n, \ldots, n)$; the condition $i-\|J\| \geq m-n$ is necessary to ensure that $d_{n, i}=p^{|J|} d_{n, i-n|J|}$. For $i \leq m$ we still need $i-\|J\| \geq m-n$. Since $\|J\| \geq n$ in all nontrivial terms, the only possibility is $J=(n)$ when $i=m$.

Now let $\Delta_{i, j}$ and $R_{n+i, j}$ be the subsets obtained from $\Delta_{i}$ and $R_{n+i}$, respectively, by raising each element to the $p^{j}$ th power. The corresponding subsets $\bar{\Delta}_{i, j}$ and $\bar{R}_{n+i, j}$ of the appropriate associated graded objects are related to $\bar{\Delta}_{i}$ and $\bar{R}_{n+i}$ in an obvious way. Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{w_{J}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)} & =\overline{w_{|J|}\left(\Delta_{i,\|J\|-|J|}\right)} \\
& =w_{|J|}\left(\bar{\Delta}_{i,\|J\|-|J|}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

4.3.34. ThEOREM. With $\bar{\Delta}_{i, j}$ and $\bar{R}_{n+i, j}$ as above, the Hopf algebroid structure of $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$, is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta\left(t_{i, j}\right) & =w_{0}\left(\bar{\Delta}_{i, j}\right) \\
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+i, j}\right) & =w_{0}\left(\bar{R}_{n+i, j}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

None of the $t_{i, j}$ for $i>1$ are primitive, so we could not get a Hopf algebroid with $\operatorname{deg} t_{i, j}<d_{n, i}$ once we have set $\operatorname{deg} t_{1, j}=1$.

Note finally that the structure of $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ depends in a very essential way on the prime $p$.

Theorem 4.3.34 implies that $E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ is cocommutative for $n=1$ and $p>2$. For any $n$ and $p$ we can use this filtration to construct a spectral sequence as in A1.3.9. The cocommutativity in the case above permits a complete, explicit determination of the $E_{2}$-term, and hence a very promising beginning for a computation of $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P / I_{1}\right)$. However, after investigating this method thoroughly we found the $E_{2}$-term to be inconveniently large and devised more efficient strategies for computing Ext, which will be described in Chapter 7. Conceivably the approach at hand could be more useful if one used a machine to do the bookkeeping. We leave the details to the interested reader.

Proof of 4.3.8. We will prove (a) and (b) simultaneously by induction on $m=|K|$. If $K^{\prime}=\left(1+k_{1}, k_{2}, \ldots, k_{m}\right)$ then it follows from (b) that

$$
w_{K^{\prime}} \equiv w_{K}^{p} \quad \bmod (p)
$$

Let $K^{\prime \prime}=\left(k_{1}+k_{2}, k_{3}, \ldots, k_{m}\right)$ and $K^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(k_{2}, k_{3}, \ldots, k_{m}\right)$. Then by the inductive hypothesis $w_{K^{\prime \prime}}$ and $w_{K^{\prime \prime \prime}}$ exist with

$$
w_{K^{\prime \prime}} \equiv w_{K^{\prime \prime \prime}}^{a_{1}} \quad \bmod (p)
$$

where $a_{1}=p^{k_{1}}$. Since $\|K\|=\left\|K^{\prime \prime}\right\|$ we have

$$
\sum_{I J=K} \frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p\|I\|}=\sum_{I J=K^{\prime \prime}} \frac{\Pi\left(K^{\prime \prime}\right)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{\|I\|}
$$

Expanding both sides partly we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Pi(K) w_{K}+\frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi\left(k_{1}\right)} w_{K^{\prime \prime \prime}}^{a_{1}}+\sum_{\substack{\mid I \mid \geq 2 \\
I J=K}} \frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{\|I\|} \\
& \quad=\Pi\left(K^{\prime \prime}\right) w_{K^{\prime \prime}}+\sum_{\substack{\mid I \mid \geq 1 \\
I J=K^{\prime \prime}}} \frac{\Pi\left(K^{\prime \prime}\right)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{\|I\|}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the same $w_{J}^{p^{\| I \mid}}$ occur on both sides, and one can use the definition of $\Pi(k)$ to show that they have the same coefficients so the sums cancel. The remaining terms give

$$
\Pi(K)\left(w_{K}+\frac{w_{K^{\prime \prime \prime}}^{a_{1}}}{\Pi\left(k_{1}\right)}\right)=\Pi\left(K^{\prime \prime}\right) w_{K^{\prime \prime}}
$$

Since $\Pi\left(k_{1}\right) \equiv p \bmod \left(p^{2}\right)$ and $w_{K^{\prime \prime}}=w_{k^{\prime \prime \prime}}^{a_{1}} \bmod (p)$, we get an integral expression when we solve for $w_{K}$.

This completes the proof of (a).

For (b) we have

$$
\sum x_{t}^{p\|K\|}=\Pi(K) w_{K}+\sum_{\substack{I J=K \\|I|>0}} \frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}}
$$

Since $\Pi(K) \equiv p^{|K|} \bmod \left(p^{1+|K|}\right)$ and $\Pi(I) \equiv p^{|I|} \bmod \left(p^{1+|I|}\right)$, we get $\Pi(K) / \Pi(I) \equiv p^{|J|} \bmod \left(p^{1+|J|}\right)$. By definition

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)}= & \Pi(\|K\|) \Pi\left(\|K\|-j_{|J|}\right) \cdots \Pi\left(\|I\|+j_{1}\right) \\
= & \left(p-p^{p^{\|K\|}}\right)\left(p-p^{p^{\|K\|-j_{|J|}}}\right) \cdots\left(p-p^{p^{\|I\|+j_{1}}}\right) \\
\equiv & p^{|J|} \quad \bmod \left(p^{|J|-1+p^{\|I\|+j_{1}}}\right) \\
\equiv p^{|J|} & \bmod \left(p^{|K|+1}\right) \quad \text { since } \\
|J|-1+p^{\|I\|+j_{1}} & \geq|J|-1+\|I\|+2 \\
& \geq|K|+1
\end{aligned}
$$

By the inductive hypothesis

$$
w_{J} \equiv w_{|J|}^{p^{\|J\|-|J|}} \bmod (p)
$$

so $w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}} \equiv w_{|J|}^{p^{\|K\|-|J|}} \bmod \left(p^{1+\|I\|}\right)$. Combining these two statements gives

$$
\frac{\Pi(K)}{\Pi(I)} w_{J}^{p^{\|I\|}} \equiv w_{|J|}^{\|K\|-|J|} \quad \bmod \left(p^{1+|K|}\right)
$$

Hence the defining equation for $w_{K}$ becomes

$$
\sum x_{t}^{p^{\|K\|}} \equiv p^{|K|} w_{K}+\sum_{\substack{I J=K \\|I|>0}} p^{|J|} w_{|J|}^{p^{\|K\|-|J|}} \bmod \left(p^{1+|K|}\right)
$$

Let $n=\|K\|-|K|$. Substituting $x_{t}^{p^{n}}$ for $x_{t}$ in 4.3.5 gives

$$
\sum x_{t}^{p^{\|K\|}}=p^{\|K\|} w_{|K|}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right)+\sum_{0 \leq j<|K|} p^{j} w_{j}^{p^{|K|-j}}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right)
$$

Since $w_{j}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right) \equiv w_{j}^{p^{n}} \bmod (p)$,

$$
w_{j}^{p^{|K|-j}}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right) \equiv w_{j}^{p^{n+|K|-j}} \bmod \left(p^{1+|K|-j}\right)
$$

so we get

$$
\sum x_{t}^{p^{\|K\|}} \equiv p^{|K|} w_{|K|}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right)+\sum_{0 \leq j<|K|} p^{j} w_{j}^{p^{\|K\|-j}} \bmod \left(p^{1+|K|}\right)
$$

Comparing this with the defining equation above gives

$$
w_{K} \equiv w_{|K|}\left(x_{t}^{p^{n}}\right) \equiv w_{|K|}^{p^{\|K\|-|K|}} \bmod (p)
$$

as claimed.

# 4. Beginning Calculations with the Adams-Novikov Spectral Sequence 

In this section we introduce the main object of interest in this book, the AdamsNovikov spectral sequence, i.e., the $B P_{*}$-Adams spectral sequence (2.2.4). There is a different $B P_{*}$-theory and hence a different Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for each prime $p$. One could consider the $M U_{*}$-Adams spectral sequence (as Novikov [1] did originally) and capture all primes at once, but there is no apparent advantage in doing so. Stable homotopy theory is a very local (in the arithmetic sense) subject. Even though the structure formulas for $B P_{*}(B P)$ are more complicated than those of $M U_{*}(M U)$ (both are given in Section 1) the former are easier to work with once one gets used to them. (Admittedly this adjustment has been difficult. We hope this book, in particular the results of Section 3, will make it easier.)

The Adams-Novikov spectral sequence was first constructed by Novikov [1] and the first systematic calculations at the primes 2 and 3 were done by Zahler [1]. In this section we will calculate the $E_{2}$-term for $t-s \leq 25$ at $p=2$ and for $t-s \leq\left(p^{2}+p\right) q$ for $p>2$, where $q=2 p-2$. In each case we will compute all the differentials and extensions and thereby find $\pi\left(S^{0}\right)$ through the indicated range. At $p=2$ this will be done by purely algebraic methods based on a comparison of the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence and Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}$-terms. At odd primes we will see that the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term sheds no light on the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence and one must compute differentials by other means. Fortunately, there is only one differential in this range and it is given by Toda $[\mathbf{2}, \mathbf{3}]$. The more extensive calculations of later chapters will show that in a much larger range all nontrivial differentials follow formally from the first one.

In Section 2.2 we developed the machinery necessary to set up the AdamsNovikov spectral sequence and we have
4.4.1. Adams-Novikov spectral sequence Theorem (Novikov [1]). For any spectrum $X$ there is a natural spectral sequence $E_{*}^{s *}(X)$ with $d_{r}: E_{r}^{s, t} \rightarrow$ $E_{r}^{s+r, t+r-1}$ such that
(a) $E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}(X)\right)$ and
(b) if $X$ is connective and p-local then $E_{\infty}^{* *}$ is the bigraded group associated with the following filtration of $\pi_{*}(X)$ : a map $f: S^{n} \rightarrow X$ has filtration $\geq s$ if it can be factored with s maps each of which becomes trivial after smashing the target with $B P$.

The fact that $B P_{*}(B P)$, unlike the Steenrod algebra, is concentrated in dimensions divisible by $q=2 p-2$ has the following consequence.
4.4.2. Proposition: Sparseness. Suppose $B P_{*}(X)$ is concentrated in dimensions divisible by $q=2 p-2$ (e.g., $X=S^{0}$ ). Then in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $X, E_{r}^{s, t}=0$ for all $r$ and $s$ except when $t$ is divisible by $q$. Consequently $d_{r}$ is nontrivial only if $r \equiv 1 \bmod (q)$ and $E_{m q+2}^{* *}=E_{m q+q+1}^{* *}$ for all $m \geq 0$.

For $p=2$ this leads to the "checkerboard phenomenon": $E_{r}^{s, t}=0$ if $t-s$ and $s$ do not have the same parity.

To compare the Adams spectral sequence and Adams-Novikov spectral sequence we will construct two trigraded spectral sequences converging to the Adams spectral sequence and Adams-Novikov spectral sequence $E_{2}$-terms. The former is a Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.15) for a certain Hopf algebra extension

involving the Steenrod algebra, while the latter arises from a filtration of $B P_{*}(B P)$ (A1.3.9). The point is that up to reindexing these two spectral sequences have the same $E_{2}$-term. Moreover, at odd primes (but not at $p=2$ ) the former spectral sequence collapses, which means that the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term when suitably reindexed is a trigraded $E_{2}$-term of a spectral sequence converging to the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term. It is reasonable to expect there to be a close relation between differentials in the trigraded filtration spectral sequence, which Miller [2] calls the "algebraic Novikov spectral sequence," and the differentials in the Adams spectral sequence. Miller [4] has shown that many Adams $d_{2}$ 's can be accounted for in this way. At any rate this indicates that at odd primes the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term has less information than the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term.

To be more specific, recall (3.1.1) that the dual Steenrod algebra $A_{*}$ as an algebra is

$$
A_{*}=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}
P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots\right) & \text { with } \quad \operatorname{dim} \xi_{i}=2^{i}-1 \text { for } p=2 \\
E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \ldots\right) \otimes P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots\right) & \text { with } \quad \operatorname{dim} \tau_{i}=2 p^{i}-1 \quad \text { and } \\
& \operatorname{dim} \xi_{i}=2 p^{i}-2 \quad \text { for } p>2
\end{array}\right.
$$

Let $P_{*} \subset A_{*}$ be $P\left(\xi_{1}^{2}, \xi_{2}^{2}, \ldots\right)$ for $p=2$ and $P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots\right)$ for $p>2$, and let $E_{*}=A_{*} \otimes_{P_{*}} \mathbf{Z} /(p)$, i.e. $E_{*}=E\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots\right)$ for $p=2$ and $E_{*}=E\left(\tau_{0}, \tau_{1}, \ldots\right)$ for $p>2$. Then we have

# 4.4.3. Theorem. With notation as above (a) 

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))=P\left(a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots\right)
$$

with $a_{i} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,2 p^{i}-1}$ represented in the cobar complex (A1.2.11) by $\left[\xi_{i}\right]$ for $p=2$ and $\left[\tau_{i}\right]$ for $p>2$,
(b) $P_{*} \rightarrow A_{*} \rightarrow E_{*}$ is an extension of Hopf algebras (A1.1.15) and there is a Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.15) converging to $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ with

$$
E_{2}^{s_{1}, s_{2}, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s_{1}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \operatorname{Ext}_{E_{*}}^{s_{2}, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z}(p)))
$$

and

$$
d_{r}: E_{r}^{s_{1}, s_{2}, t} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s_{1}+r, s_{2}-r+1, t}
$$

(c) the $P_{*}$-coaction on $\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ is given by

$$
\psi\left(a_{n}\right)= \begin{cases}\sum_{i} \xi_{n-i}^{2^{i+1}} \otimes a_{i} & \text { for } p=2 \\ \sum_{i} \xi_{n-i}^{p^{i}} \otimes a_{i} & \text { for } p>2, \quad \text { and }\end{cases}
$$

(d) for $p>2$ the Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence collapses from $E_{2}$ with no nontrivial extensions.

Proof. Everything is straightforward but (d). We can give $A_{*}$ a second grading based on the number of $\tau_{i}$ 's which are preserved by both the product and the coproduct (they do not preserve it at $p=2$ ). This translates to a grading of Ext by the number of $a_{i}$ 's which must be respected by the differentials, so the spectral sequence collapses.

For the algebraic Novikov spectral sequence, let $I=\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots\right) \subset B P_{*}$. We filter $B P_{*}(B P)$ by powers of $I$ and study the resulting spectral sequence (A1.3.9).

4.4.4. Algebraic Novikov SS Theorem (Novikov [1], Miller [2]). There is a spectral sequence converging to $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)$ with

$$
E_{1}^{s, m, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, t}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), I^{m} / I^{m+1}\right)
$$

and $d_{r}: E_{r}^{s, m, t} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s+1, r+m, t}$. The $E_{1}^{s * *}$ of this spectral sequence coincides with the $E_{2}^{s * *}$ of 4.4.3.

Proof. A1.3.9 gives a spectral sequence with

$$
E_{1}=\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} B P_{*}(B P)}\left(E_{0} B P_{*}, E_{0} B P_{*}\right)
$$

Now we have $B P_{*}(B P) / I=E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{E_{0} B P_{*}} \mathbf{Z} /(p)=P_{*}$. We apply the change-of-rings isomorphism A1.3.12 to the Hopf algebroid map $\left(E_{0} B P_{*}, E_{0} B P_{*}(B P)\right) \rightarrow$ $\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), P_{*}\right)$ and get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}} & \left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), E_{0} B P_{*}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} B P_{*}(B P)}\left(E_{0} B P_{*},\left(E_{0} B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{E_{0} B P_{*}} \mathbf{Z} /(p)\right) \square_{P_{*}} E_{0} B P_{*}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} B P_{*}(B P)}\left(E_{0} B P_{*}, P_{*} \square_{P_{*}} E_{0} B P_{*}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} B P_{*}(B P)}\left(E_{0} B P_{*}, E_{0} B P_{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The second statement follows from the fact that $E_{0} B P_{*}=\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$.
In order to use this spectral sequence we need to know its $E_{1}$-term. For $p>2$, 4.4.3(d) implies that it is the cohomology of the Steenrod algebra, i.e., the classical Adams $E_{2}$-term suitably reindexed. This has been calculated in various ranges by May [1], and Liulevicius [2], but we will compute it here from scratch. Theorem 4.4.3(d) fails for $p=2$ so we need another method, outlined in Miller [2] and used extensively by Aubry [1].

We start with $\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$. For $p=2$ we have $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{n}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(2), \mathbf{Z} /(2))=$ $\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, 2 t}(\mathbf{Z} /(2), \mathbf{Z}(2))$, so the latter is known if we know the former through half the range of dimensions being considered. For $p>2$ we will make the necessary calculation below.

Then we compute $\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$, by downward induction on $n$. To start the induction, observe that through any given finite range of dimensions $B P_{*} / I_{n} \simeq \mathbf{Z} /(p)$ for large enough $n$. For the inductive step we use the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{\operatorname{dim} v_{n}} E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

which leads to a Bockstein spectral sequence of the form

$$
P\left(a_{n}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right) \Rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), E_{0} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)
$$

The method we will use in this section differs only slightly from the above. We will compute the groups $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ by downward induction on $n$; these will be abbreviated by $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$. To start the induction we note that $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ for $t<2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$. For the inductive step we analyze the long exact sequence of Ext groups induced by the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{\operatorname{dim} v_{n}} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

either directly or via a Bockstein spectral sequence similar to 4.4.5. The long exact sequence and Bockstein spectral sequence are related as follows. The connecting homomorphism in the former has the form

$$
\delta_{n}: \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{s+1}\left(\Sigma^{2 p^{n}-2} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)
$$

The target is a module over $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ which is $\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}\right]$ for $n>0$ and $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$ for $n=0$ by 4.3.2. Assume for simplicity that $n>0$. For each $x \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$ there is a maximal $k$ such that $\delta_{n}(x)=v_{n}^{k} y$, i.e., such that $y \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ is not divisible by $v_{n}$. (This y is not unique but is only determined modulo elements annihilated by $v_{n}^{k}$.) Let $\bar{y} \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$ denote the image of $y$ under the reduction map $B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n+1}$ Then in the Bockstein spectral sequence there is a differential $d_{1+k}(x)=a_{n}^{1+k} \bar{y}$.

Now we will start the process by computing $\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ for $p>2$ and $t<\left(p^{2}+p+1\right) q$. In this range we have $P_{*}=P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}\right)$. We will apply the Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.15) to the Hopf algebra extension

$$
P\left(\xi_{1}\right) \rightarrow P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}\right) \rightarrow P\left(\xi_{2}\right)
$$

The $E_{2}$-term is $\operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{1}\right)}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{2}\right)}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))\right)$. The extension is cocentral (A1.1.15) so we have

$$
E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{1}\right)}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p)) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{2}\right)}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z}(p))
$$

By a routine calculation this is in our range of dimensions

$$
E\left(h_{10}, h_{11}, h_{12}, h_{20}, h_{21}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{10}, b_{11}, b_{20}\right)
$$

with

$$
h_{i, j} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{i}\right)}^{1,2 p^{i}\left(p^{i}-1\right)} \quad \text { and } \quad b_{i, j} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{P\left(\xi_{i}\right)}^{2,2 p^{j+1}\left(p^{i}-1\right)}
$$

The differentials are (up to sign) $d_{2}\left(h_{2, j}\right)=h_{1, j} h_{1, j+1}$ and $d_{3}\left(b_{20}\right)=h_{12} b_{10}-h_{11} b_{11}$ [compare 4.3.22(a)]. The result is
4.4.8. ThEOREM. For $p>2$ and $t<\left(p^{2}+p+1\right) q, \operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ is a free module over $P\left(b_{10}\right)$ on the following 10 generators: $1, h_{10}, h_{11}, g_{0}=\left\langle h_{11}, h_{10}, h_{10}\right\rangle$, $k_{0}=\left\langle h_{11}, h_{11}, h_{10}\right\rangle, h_{10} k_{0}= \pm h_{11} g_{0}, h_{12}, h_{10} h_{12}, b_{11}$, and $h_{10} b_{11}$. There is a multiplicative relation $h_{11} b_{11}=h_{12} b_{10}$ and (for $p=3$ ) $h_{11} k_{0}= \pm h_{10} b_{11}$.

The extra relation for $p=3$ follows easily from A1.4.6. For $p>3$ there is a corresponding Massey product relation $\left\langle k_{0}, h_{11}, \ldots, h_{11}\right\rangle=h_{10} b_{11}$ up to a nonzero scalar, where there are $p-2$ factors $h_{11}$.

The alert reader may observe that the restriction $t<\left(p^{2}+p+1\right) q$ is too severe to give us $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}$ for $t-s<\left(p^{2}+p\right) q$ because there are elements in this range with $s>q$, e.g., $b_{10}^{p}$. However, one sees easily that in a larger range all elements with $s>q$ are divisible by $b_{10}$ and this division gets us back into the range $t<\left(p^{2}+p+1\right) q$. One could make this more precise, derive some vanishing lines, and prove the following result.
4.4.9. ThEOREM. Let $p>2$.
(a) $\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))=0$ for $t-s<f(s)$ where

$$
f(s)= \begin{cases}\left(p^{2}-p-1\right) s & \text { for } s \text { even } \\ 2 p-3+\left(p^{2}-p-1\right)(s-1) & \text { for } s \text { odd }\end{cases}
$$

(b) Let $R_{*}=P_{*} /\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}\right)$. Then $\operatorname{Ext}_{R_{*}}^{s, t}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z}(p))=0$ for $t-s<g(s)$ where

$$
g(s)= \begin{cases}\left(p^{4}-p-1\right) s & \text { for } s \text { even } \\ 2 p^{3}-3+\left(p^{4}-p-1\right)(s-1) & \text { for } s \text { odd }\end{cases}
$$

(c) The map $P\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}\right) \rightarrow P_{*}$ induces an epimorphism in $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}$ for $(t-s)<h(s)$ and an isomorphism for $(t-s)<h(s-1)-1$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
h(s) & =2 p^{3}-3+f(s-1) \\
& = \begin{cases}2 p^{3}-3+\left(p^{2}-p-1\right)(s-1) & \text { for } s \text { odd } \\
2 p^{3}+2 p-6+\left(p^{2}-p-1\right)(s-2) & \text { for } s \text { even. }\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

This result is far more than we need, and we leave the details to the interested reader.

Now we start feeding in the generators $v_{n}$ inductively. In our range 4.4.8 gives us $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{3}\right)$. Each of the specified generators is easily seen to come from a cocycle in the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ so we have

$$
\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{3}\right) \otimes P\left(v_{2}\right)
$$

i.e., the Bockstein spectral sequence collapses in our range.

The passage to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)$ is far more complicated. The following formulas in $C\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)$ are relevant.

$$
\text { (a) } d\left(v_{2}\right)=v_{1} t_{1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1}
$$

and

$$
\text { (b) } d\left(t_{2}\right)=-t_{1}\left|t_{1}^{p}-v_{1} b_{10}\right.
$$

These follow immediately from 4.3.20 and 4.3.15. From 4.4.10(a) we get

$$
\text { (a) } \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{i}\right) \equiv i v_{2}^{i-1} h_{11} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}\right)
$$

and

$$
\text { (b) } \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p}\right) \equiv v_{1}^{p-1} h_{12} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{p}\right)
$$

Next we look at elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$. Clearly, $h_{10}, h_{11}$, and $h_{12}$ are in $\operatorname{ker} \delta_{i}$ as are $v_{2}^{i} h_{11}$ for $i<p-1$ by the above calculation. This leaves $v_{2}^{i} h_{10}$ for $1 \leq i \leq p-1$ and $v_{2}^{p-1} h_{11}$. For the former 4.4.10 gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
d\left(v_{2}^{i} t_{1}\right. & \left.+i v_{1} v_{2}^{i-1}\left(t_{1}^{1+p}-t_{2}\right)\right) \equiv i v_{1}^{2} v_{2}^{i-1} b_{10} \\
& +\binom{i}{2} v_{1}^{2} v_{2}^{i-1}\left(t_{1}^{2 p}\left|t_{1}-2 t_{1}^{p}\right| t_{2}+2 t_{1}^{p}\right| t_{1}^{1+p} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The expression in the second term is a multiple of $k_{0}$, so we have

$$
\delta\left(v_{2}^{i} h_{10}\right) \equiv i v_{1} v_{2}^{i-1} b_{10} \pm\binom{i}{2} v_{1} v_{2}^{i-2} k_{0} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{2}\right)
$$

To deal with $v_{2}^{p-1} h_{11}$ we use 4.4.10(a) to show

$$
d\left(\sum_{0<i<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{i} v_{2}^{p-i} v_{1}^{i-1} t_{1}^{p i}\right) \equiv \sum_{0<i<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{i} v_{1}^{p-1} t_{1}^{p i}\left|t_{1}^{p^{2}-p i} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{p}\right)\right.
$$

so

$$
\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p-1} h_{11}\right)= \pm v_{1}^{p-2} b_{11}
$$

This is a special case of 4.3.22(b).
Now we move on to the elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$. They are $h_{10} h_{12}, b_{11}, v_{2}^{i} b_{10}$, $v_{2}^{i} g_{0}$, and $v_{2}^{i} k_{0}$ for suitable $i$. The first two are clearly in $\operatorname{ker} \delta_{1}$. Equation 4.4.12

eliminates the need to consider $v_{2}^{i} b_{10}$ for $i<p-1$, so that leaves $v_{2}^{p-1} b_{10}, v_{2}^{i} g_{0}$, and $v_{2}^{i} k_{0}$. Routine calculation with 4.4.10 gives
(a) $\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{i} g_{0}\right) \equiv \pm\left(v_{2}^{i} h_{10} b_{10} \pm i v_{2}^{i-1} h_{10} k_{0}\right) \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{2}\right)$
and
(b) $\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{i} k_{0}\right) \equiv \pm v_{2}^{i} h_{11} b_{10} \quad \bmod \left(v_{1}^{2}\right)$.

We have to handle $v_{2}^{p-1} b_{10}$ more indirectly.
4.4.14. Lemma. $\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p-1} b_{10} \pm \frac{1}{2} v_{2}^{p-2} k_{0}\right)=c v_{1}^{p-3} h_{10} b_{11}$ for some nonzero $c \in$ $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$.

Proof. By 4.4.13, $v_{1}^{p-1} b_{11}=0$ in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)$, so $v_{1}^{p-1} h_{10} b_{11}=0$ and $v_{1}^{i} h_{10} b_{11}=\delta_{1}(x)$ for some $i<p-1$ and some $x \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$. The only remaining $x$ is the indicated one.

From 4.4.14 we get $\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p-1} h_{10} b_{10} \pm \frac{1}{2} v_{2}^{p-2} h_{10} k_{0}\right) \equiv 0 \bmod \left(v_{1}^{p-2}\right)$. All other elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ for $s \geq 3$ are divisible by $h_{10}$ or $b_{10}$ and they can all be accounted for in such a way that the above element, which we denote by $\bar{\phi}$, must be in $\operatorname{ker} \delta_{1}$. Hence $\delta_{1}$ is completely determined in our range.

Equivalently, we have computed all of the differentials in the Bockstein spectral sequence. However, there are some multiplicative extensions which still need to be worked out.
4.4.15. Theorem. For $p>2, \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)=P\left(v_{1}\right) \otimes E\left(h_{10}\right) \oplus M$, where $M$ is a free module over $P\left(b_{10}\right)$ on the following generators:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\beta_{i}=\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{i}\right), \quad h_{10} \beta_{i}, \quad \bar{\beta}_{i}=v_{1}^{-1} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{i} h_{10}\right) \quad \text { (e.g., } \bar{\beta}_{1}= \pm b_{10} \\
\text { and } h_{10} \bar{\beta}_{i} \quad \text { for } 1 \leq i \leq p-1 \\
\beta_{p / i}=v_{1}^{1-i} \delta_{i}\left(v_{2}^{p}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad h_{10} \beta_{p / i} \quad \text { for } 1 \leq i \leq p \\
\bar{\beta}_{p / i}=v_{1}^{2-i} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p-1} h_{11}\right) \quad \text { for } 2 \leq i \leq p \\
h_{10} \bar{\beta}_{p / i} \quad \text { for } 3 \leq i \leq p ; \quad \bar{\phi} \quad \text { and } \quad \beta_{1} \bar{\beta}_{p / p}
\end{gathered}
$$

Here $\delta_{1}$ is the connecting homomorphism for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{q} B P_{*} / I_{1} \xrightarrow{v_{1}} B P_{*} / I_{1} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{10} \beta_{i}=v_{1} \bar{\beta}_{i}, \quad v_{1} \beta_{i}=0, \quad v_{1}^{p} \beta_{p / p}=0 \\
& v_{1}^{p-1} \bar{\beta}_{p / p}=0, \quad \text { and } \quad v_{1}^{p-2} h_{10} \bar{\beta}_{p / p}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

(This description of the multiplicative structure is not complete.)
Proof. The additive structure of this Ext follows from the above calculations. The relations follow from the way the elements are defined.

Figure 4.4.16 illustrates this result for $p=5$. Horizontal lines indicate multiplication by $v_{1}$, and an arrow pointing to the right indicates that the element is free over $P\left(v_{1}\right)$. A diagonal line which increases $s$ and $t / q$ by one indicates multiplication by $h_{10}$ and one which increases $t / q$ by 4 indicates the Massey product operation $\left\langle-, h_{10}, h_{10}, h_{10}, h_{10}\right\rangle$. Thus two successive diagonal lines indicate multiplication by $b_{10}= \pm\left\langle h_{10}, h_{10}, h_{10}, h_{10}, h_{10}\right\rangle$. The broken line on the right indicates the limit of our calculation.

Now we have to consider the long exact sequence or Bockstein spectral sequence associated with

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{1} \rightarrow 0
$$

First we compute $\delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{i}\right)$. Since $d\left(v_{1}\right)=p t_{1}$ in $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ we have $d\left(v_{1}^{i}\right) \equiv i p v_{1}^{i-1} t_{1}$ $\bmod \left(i p^{2}\right)$, so

$$
\delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{i}\right) \equiv i v_{1}^{i-1} h_{10} \quad \bmod \left(i p^{2}\right)
$$

Moving on to $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)$ we need to compute $\delta_{0}$ on $\beta_{i}$ and $\beta_{p / i}$. The former can be handled most easily as follows. $\delta_{0}\left(\bar{\beta}_{i}\right)=0$ because there is no element in the appropriate grading in $\operatorname{Ext}^{3} . \delta_{0}$ is a derivation $\bmod (p)$ so $\delta_{0}\left(v_{1} \bar{\beta}_{i}\right)=h_{10} \bar{\beta}_{i}$. Since $v_{1} \bar{\beta}_{i}=h_{10} \beta_{i}$ we have $h_{10} \bar{\beta}_{i}=\delta_{0}\left(h_{10} \beta_{i}\right)=h_{10} \delta_{0}\left(\beta_{i}\right)$ so

$$
\delta_{0}\left(\beta_{i}\right)=\bar{\beta}_{i}
