Now $\beta_{p / p}=h_{12}-v_{1}^{p^{2}-p} h_{11}$ and $v_{1}^{p^{2}-p} h_{11}$ is cohomologous to $v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} h_{10}$, which by 4.4.16 is in $\operatorname{ker} \delta_{0}$. Hence

$$
\delta_{0}\left(\beta_{p / p}\right)=\delta_{0}\left(h_{12}\right)=b_{11}= \pm \bar{\beta}_{p / p}

It follows that

$$
\delta_{0}\left(\beta_{p / p-i}\right)=\delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{i} \beta_{p / p}\right)=i v_{1}^{i-1} h_{10} \beta_{p / p} \pm v_{1}^{i} \bar{\beta}_{p / p}
$$

This accounts for all elements in sight but $\delta_{0}\left(h_{10 \beta_{p / 1}}\right)$ which vanishes $\bmod (p)$. We will show that it is a unit multiple of $p \Phi$ below in 5.1.24.

Putting all this together gives
4.4.20. ThEOREM. For $p>2$ and $t-s \leq\left(p^{2}+p\right) q, \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is as follows. $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$ concentrated in dimension zero. $\operatorname{Ext}^{1, q t}=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)} /(p i)$ generated by $\bar{\alpha}_{i}=i^{-1} \delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{i}\right)$, where $\alpha_{1}=h_{10}$. For $p=5$ this is illustrated in Fig. 4.4.21, with notation similar to that of Fig. 4.4.16. It also shows differentials (long arrows originating at $\beta_{5 / 5}$ and $\beta_{1} \beta_{5 / 5}$ ), which we discuss now. By sparseness (4.4.2) $E_{2}=E_{2 p-1}$ and $d_{2 p-1}: E_{2 p-1}^{s, t} \rightarrow$ $E_{2 p-1}^{s+2 p-1, t-2 p+2}$. It is clear that in our range of dimensions $E_{2 p}=E_{\infty}$ because any higher (than $d_{2 p-1}$ ) differential would have a target whose filtration (the $s$ coordinate) would be too high. Naively, the first possible differential is $d_{2 p-1}\left(\alpha_{p^{2}-1}\right)=c \beta_{i}^{p}$. However, $d_{2 p-1}$ respects multiplication by $\alpha_{1}$ and $\alpha_{1} \alpha_{p^{2}-1}$ so $c \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p}=0$ and $c=0$. Alternatively one can show (see 5.3.7) that each element in Ext $^{1}$ is a permanent cycle.
4.4.22. ThEOREM (Toda [2, 3]). $d_{2 p-1}\left(\beta_{p / p}\right)=a \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p}$ for some nonzero $a \in$ $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$.

Toda shows that any $x \in \pi_{*}(S)$ of order $p$ must satisfy $\alpha_{1} x^{p}=0$. For $x=\beta_{1}$ this shows $\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p}=0$ in homotopy. Since it is nonzero in $E_{2}$ it must be killed by a differential and our calculation shows that $\beta_{p / p}$ is the only possible source for it. We do not know how to compute the coefficient $a$, but its value seems to be of little consequence.

Theorem 4.4.22 implies that $d_{2 p-1}\left(\beta_{1} \beta_{p / p}\right)=\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p+1}$. Inspection of 4.4.20 or 4.4.21 shows that there are no other nontrivial differentials.

Notice that the element $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p / p}$ survives to $E_{\infty}$ even though $\beta_{p / p}$ does not. Hence the corresponding homotopy element, usually denoted by $\varepsilon^{\prime}$, is indecomposable. It follows easily from the definition of Massey products (A1.4.1) that $\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}^{p}\right\rangle$ is defined in $E_{2 p}$, has trivial indeterminacy, and contains a unit multiple of $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p / p}$. It follows from 7.5 .4 that $\varepsilon^{\prime}$ is the corresponding Toda bracket. Using A1.4.6 we have

$$
\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{1}, \varepsilon^{\prime}\right\rangle=\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle \beta_{1}^{p}=\beta_{1}^{p+1}
$$

with $p-2 \alpha_{1}$ 's on the left and $p \alpha_{1}$ 's on the right.
Looking ahead we can see this phenomenon generalize as follows. For $1 \leq i \leq$ $p-1$ we have $d_{2 p-1}\left(\beta_{p / p}^{i}\right)=i a \alpha_{1} \beta_{p / p}^{p i-1}$. For $i \leq p-2$ this leads to $\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{(p)}\right\rangle$ [with $(i+1) \alpha_{1}$ 's] being a unit multiple of $\varepsilon^{(i)}=\alpha_{1} \beta_{p / p}^{i}$, and $\left\langle\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{1} \varepsilon^{(i)}\right\rangle$ [with $(p-i-1) \alpha_{1}$ 's] is a unit multiple of $\beta_{1}^{1+i p}$. In particular, $\alpha_{1} \varepsilon^{(p-2)}$ is a unit multiple of $\beta_{1}^{1+(p-2) p}$. Since $\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p}=0$ (4.4.22), $\beta_{1}^{p^{2}-p+1}=0$ since it is a unit multiple of $\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p} \varepsilon^{(p-2)}$. However, in the $E_{2}$-term all powers of $\beta_{1}$ are nonzero (Section 6.4), so $\beta_{1}^{p^{2}-p+1}$ must be killed by a differential, more precisely by $d_{(p-1) q+1}\left(\alpha_{1} \beta_{p / p}^{p-1}\right)$.

4.4.47. TheOrem. The elements in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ for $p=2$ listed in 4.4.37 behave in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence as follows. $d_{3}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{4 i+3}\right)=\bar{\alpha}_{1}^{3} \bar{\alpha}_{4 i+3}$ for $i \geq 0$ and $d_{3}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{4 i+2}\right)=\bar{\alpha}_{1}^{3} \bar{\alpha}_{4 i}$ for $i \geq 1$. Moreover the homotopy element corresponding to $\alpha_{4 i+2}=r \bar{\alpha}_{4 i+2}$ does not have order 2 ; twice it is $\bar{\alpha}_{1}^{2} \bar{\alpha}_{4 i}$ for $i \geq 1$ and $\bar{\alpha}_{1}^{3}$ for $i=0$.

As it happens, there are no other Adams-Novikov spectral sequence differentials in this range, although there are some nontrivial extensions.

These elements in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence $E_{\infty}$-term correspond to Adams elements near the vanishing line. The towers in dimensions congruent to $7 \bmod (8)$ correspond to the groups generated by $\bar{\alpha}_{4 i}$. Thus the order of $\bar{\alpha}_{4 i}$ determines how many elements in the tower survive to the Adams $E_{\infty}$-term. For example, the tower in dimension 15 generated by $h_{4}$ has 8 elements. $\bar{\alpha}_{8}$ has order $2^{5}$ so only the top elements can survive. From this we deduce $d_{3}\left(h_{0}^{i} h_{4}\right)=h_{0}^{i} d_{0}$ for

$i=1,2$ and either $d_{3}\left(h_{4}\right)=d_{0}$ or $d_{2}\left(h_{4}\right)=h_{0} h_{3}^{2}$. To determine which of these two occurs we consult the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence and see that $\beta_{3}$ and $\beta_{4 / 4}$ must be permanent so $\pi_{14}^{s}=\mathbf{Z} /(2) \oplus \mathbf{Z} /(2)$. If $d_{3}\left(h_{4}\right)=d_{0}$ the Adams spectral sequence would give $\pi_{14}^{s}=\mathbf{Z} /(4)$, so we must have $d_{2}\left(h_{4}\right)=h_{0} h_{3}^{2}$.

One can also show that $P^{i} c_{0}$ corresponds to $\alpha_{1} \bar{\alpha}_{4 i+4}$ for $i>1$ and this leads to a nontrivial multiplicative extension in the Adams spectral sequence. For example, the homotopy element corresponding to $P c_{0}$ is $\alpha_{1}$ times the one corresponding to $h_{0}^{3} h_{4}$.

# CHAPTER 5 

## The Chromatic Spectral Sequence

The spectral sequence of the title is a mechanism for organizing the AdamsNovikov $E_{2}$-term and ultimately $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ itself. The basic idea is this. If an element $x$ in the $E_{2}$-term, which we abbreviate by $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (see 5.1.1), is annihilated by a power of $p$, say $p^{i}$, then it is the image of some $x^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / p^{i}\right)$ under a suitable connecting homomorphism. In this latter group one has multiplication by a suitable power of $v_{1}$ (depending on $i$ ), say $v_{1}^{m}$. $x^{\prime}$ may or may not be annihilated by some power of $v_{1}^{m}$, say $v_{1}^{m j}$. If not, we say $x$ is $v_{1}$-periodic; otherwise $x^{\prime}$ is the image of some $x^{\prime \prime} \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\left(\left(p^{i}, v_{1}^{m j}\right)\right)\right.$ and we say it is $v_{1}$-torsion. In this new Ext group one has multiplication by $v_{2}^{n}$ for some $n$. If $x$ is $v_{1}$-torsion, it is either $v_{2}$-periodic or $v_{2}$-torsion depending on whether $x^{\prime \prime}$ is killed by some power of $v_{2}^{n}$. Iterating this procedure one obtains a complete filtration of the original Ext group in which the $n$th subgroup in the $v_{n}$-torsion and the $n$th subquotient is $v_{n}$-periodic. This is the chromatic filtration and it is associated with the chromatic spectral sequence of 5.1.8. The chromatic spectral sequence is like a spectrum in the astronomical sense in that it resolves stable homotopy into periodic components of various types.

Recently we have shown that this algebraic construction has a geometric origin, i.e., that there is a corresponding filtration of $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$. The chromatic spectral sequence is based on certain inductively defined short exact sequences of comodules 5.1.5. In Ravenel [9] we show that each of these can be realized by a cofibration

$$
N_{n} \rightarrow M_{n} \rightarrow N_{n+1}
$$

with $N_{0}=S^{0}$ so we get an inverse system

$$
S^{0} \leftarrow \Sigma^{-1} N_{1} \leftarrow \Sigma^{-2} N_{2} \leftarrow \cdots
$$

The filtration of $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ by the images of $\pi_{*}\left(\Sigma^{-n} N^{n}\right)$ is the one we want. Applying the Novikov Ext functor to this diagram yields the chromatic spectral sequence, and applying homotopy yields a geometric form of it. For more discussion of this and related problems see Ravenel [8].

The chromatic spectral sequence is useful computationally as well as conceptually. In 5.1.10 we introduce the chromatic cobar complex $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$. Even though it is larger than the already ponderous cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$, it is easier to work with because many cohomology classes (e.g., the Greek letter elements) have far simpler cocycle representatives in $C C$ than in $C$.

In Section 1 the basic properties of the chromatic spectral sequence are given, most notably the change-of-rings theorem 5.1.14, which equates certain Ext groups with the cohomology of certain Hopf algebras $\Sigma(n)$, the $n$th Morava stabilizer algebra. This isomorphism enables one to compute these groups and was the original motivation for the chromatic spectral sequence. These computations will be the

subject of the next chapter. Section 1 also contains various computations (5.1.205.1.22 and 5.1.24) which illustrate the use of the chromatic cobar complex.

In Section 2 we compute various Ext ${ }^{1}$ groups (5.2.6, 5.2.11, 5.2.14, and 5.2.17) and recover as a corollary the Hopf invariant one theorem (5.2.8), which says almost all elements in the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}^{1, *}$ are not permanent cycles. Our method of proof is to show they are not in the image of the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}^{1, *}$ after computing the latter.

In Section 3 we compute the $v_{1}$-periodic part of the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence and its relation to the $J$-homomorphism and the $\mu$-family of Adams [1]. The main result is 5.3.7, and the resulting pattern in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $p=2$ is illustrated in 5.3.8.

In Section 4 we describe Ext ${ }^{2}$ for all primes (5.4.5), referring to the original papers for the proofs, which we cannot improve upon. Corollaries are the nontriviality of $\gamma_{t},(5.4 .4)$ and a list of elements in the Adams spectral sequence $E_{2}^{2, *}$ which cannot be permanent cycles (5.4.7). This latter result is an analog of the Hopf invariant one theorem. The Adams spectral sequence elements not so excluded include the Arf invariant and $\eta_{j}$ families. These are discussed in 5.4.8-5.4.10.

In Section 5 we compile all known results about which elements in Ext ${ }^{2}$ are permanent cycles, i.e., about the $\beta$-family and its generalizations. We survey the relevant work of Smith and Oka for $p \geq 5$, Oka and Toda for $p=3$, and Davis and Mahowald for $p=2$.

In Section 6 we give some fragmentary results on Ext ${ }^{s}$ for $s \geq 3$. We describe some products of $\alpha$ 's and $\beta$ 's and their divisibility properties. We close the chapter by describing a possible obstruction to the existence of the $\delta$-family.

Since the appearance of the first edition, many computations related to the chromatic spectral sequence have been made by Shimomura. A list of some of them can be found in Shimomura [2]. A description of the first three columns of the chromatic spectral sequence (meaning the rational, $v_{1}$ - and $v_{2}$-periodic parts) for the sphere can be found in Shimomura and Wang [3] for $p=2$, in Shimomura and Wang [4] for $p=3$, and in Shimomura and Yabe [5] for $p \geq 5$. Analogous computations for the $\bmod p$ Moore spectrum can be found in Shimomura [6] for $p=2$, in Shimomura [7] for $p=3$ and in Shimomura [8] for $p \geq 5$.

# 1. The Algebraic Construction 

In this section we set up the chromatic spectral sequence converging to the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term, and use it to make some simple calculations involving Greek letter elements (1.3.17 and 1.3.19). The chromatic spectral sequence was originally formulated by Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1]. First we make the following abbreviation in notation, which will be in force throughout this chapter: given a $B P_{*}(B P)$ comodule $M$ (A1.1.2), we define

$$
\operatorname{Ext}(M)=\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)
$$

To motivate our construction recall the short exact sequence of comodules given by 4.3.2(c)

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{2\left(p^{n}-1\right)} B P_{*} / I_{n} \xrightarrow{v_{n}} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

and let

$$
\delta_{n}: \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{s+1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)
$$

denote the corresponding connecting homomorphism.
5.1.3. Definition. For $t, n>0$ let

$$
\alpha_{t}^{(n)}=\delta_{0} \delta_{1} \cdots \delta_{n-1}\left(v_{n}^{t}\right) \in \operatorname{Ext}^{n}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

Here $\alpha^{(n)}$ stands for the $n$th letter of the Greek alphabet. The status of these elements in $\pi_{*}^{Z}$ is described in 1.3.11, 1.3.15, and 1.3.18. The invariant prime ideals in $I_{n}$ in 5.1.2 can be replaced by invariant regular ideals, e.g., those provided by 4.3.3. In particular we have
5.1.4. Definition. $\alpha_{s p^{i} / i+1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, q s p^{i}}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (where $q=2 p-2$ ) is the image of $v_{1}^{s p^{i}}$ under the connecting homomorphism for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p^{i+1}} B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p^{i+1}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

We will see below that for $p>2$ these elements generate $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (5.2.6) and that they are nontrivial permanent cycles in $\operatorname{im} J$. We want to capture all of these elements from a single short exact sequence; those of 5.1.4 are related by the commutative diagram
![img-43.jpeg](img-43.jpeg)

Taking the direct limit we get

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow \mathbf{Q} \otimes B P_{*} \rightarrow \mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}_{(p)} \otimes B P_{*} \rightarrow 0
$$

we denote these three modules by $N^{0}, M^{0}$, and $N^{1}$, respectively. Similarly, the direct limit of the sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p^{i+1}\right) \xrightarrow{v_{1}^{p^{i+j}}} \Sigma^{-q p^{i+j}} B P_{*} /\left(p^{i+1}\right) \rightarrow \Sigma^{-1 p^{i+j}} B P_{*} /\left(p^{i+1}, v_{1}^{p^{i+j}}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

gives us

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p^{\infty}\right) \rightarrow v_{1}^{-1} B P_{*} /\left(p^{\infty}\right) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p^{\infty}, v_{1}^{\infty}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

and we denote these three modules by $N^{1}, M^{1}$, and $N^{2}$, respectively. More generally we construct short exact sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow N^{n} \rightarrow M^{n} \rightarrow N^{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

inductively by $M^{n}=v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} N^{n}$. Hence $N^{n}$ and $M^{n}$ are generated as $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$, modules by fractions $\frac{x}{y}$ where $x \in B P_{*}$ for $N^{n}$ and $v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*}$ for $M^{n}$ and $y$ is a monomial in the ideal $\left(p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}\right)$ of the subring $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-1}\right]$ of $B P_{*}$. The $B P_{*}$-module structure is such that $v x / y=0$ for $v \in B P_{*}$ if this fraction when reduced to lowest terms does not have its denominator in the above ideal. For example, the element $\frac{1}{p^{i} v_{1}^{i}} \in N^{2}$ is annihilated by the ideal $\left(p^{i}, v_{1}^{j}\right)$.
5.1.6. Lemma. 5.1.5 is a short exact sequence of $B P_{*}(B P)$-comodules.

Proof. Assume inductively that $N^{n}$ is a comodule and let $N^{\prime} \subset N^{n}$ be a finitely generated subcomodule. Then $N^{\prime}$ is annihilated by some invariant regular

ideal with $n$ generators given by 4.3.3. It follows from 4.3.3 that multiplication by some power of $v_{n}$, say $v_{n}^{k}$, is a comodule map, so

$$
v_{n}^{-1} N^{\prime}=\varliminf_{v_{n}^{k}} \Sigma^{-\operatorname{dim} v_{n}^{k i}} N^{\prime}
$$

is a comodule. Alternatively, $N^{\prime}$ is annihilated by some power of $I_{n}$, so multiplication by a suitable power of $v_{n}$ is a comodule map by Proposition 3.6 of Landweber [7] and $v_{n}^{-1} N^{\prime}$ is again a comodule. Taking the direct limit over all such $N^{\prime}$ gives us a unique comodule structure on $M^{n}$ and hence on the quotient $N^{n+1}$.
5.1.7. Definition. The chromatic resolution is the long exact sequence of comodules

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow M^{0} \xrightarrow{d_{e}} M^{1} \xrightarrow{d_{e}} \cdots
$$

obtained by splicing the short exact sequences of 5.1.5.
The associated resolution spectral sequence (A1.3.2) gives us
5.1.8. Proposition. There is a chromatic spectral sequence converging to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ with $E_{1}^{n, s}=\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M^{n}\right)$ and $d_{r}: E_{r}^{n, s} \rightarrow E_{r}^{n+r, s+1-r}$ where $d_{1}$ is the map induced by $d_{e}$ in 5.1.7.
5.1.9. Remark. There is a chromatic spectral sequence converging to $\operatorname{Ext}(F)$ where $F$ is any comodule which is flat as a $B P_{*}$-module, obtained by tensoring the resolution of 5.1 .7 with $F$.
5.1.10. Definition. The chromatic cobar complex $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is given by

$$
C C^{u}\left(B P_{*}\right)=\bigoplus_{s+n=u} C^{s}\left(M^{n}\right)
$$

where $C()$ is the cobar complex of A1.2.11, with $d(x)=d_{e}^{*}(x)+(-1)^{n} d_{i}(x)$ for $x \in C^{s}\left(M^{n}\right)$ where $d_{e}^{*}$ is the map induced by $d_{e}$ in 5.1.7 (the external component of d) and $d_{i}$ (the internal component) is the differential in the cobar complex $C\left(M_{n}\right)$.

It follows from 5.1.8 and A1.3.4 that $H\left(C C\left(B P_{*}\right)\right)=H\left(C\left(B P_{*}\right)\right)=\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. The embedding $B P_{*} \rightarrow M^{0}$ induces an embedding of the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ into the chromatic cobar complex $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$. Although $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is larger than $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$, we will see below that it is more convenient for certain calculations such as identifying the Greek letter elements of 5.1.3.

This entire construction can be generalized to $B P_{*} / I_{m}$ as follows.
5.1.11. Definition. Let $N_{m}^{0}=B P_{*} / I_{m}$ and define $B P_{*}$-modules $N_{m}^{n}$ and $M_{m}^{n}$ inductively by short exact sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow N_{m}^{n} \rightarrow M_{m}^{n} \rightarrow N_{m}^{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

where $M_{m}^{n}=v_{m+n}^{-1} B P_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} N_{m}^{n}$.
Lemma 5.1.6 can be generalized to show that these are comodules. Splicing them gives a long exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{m} \rightarrow M_{m}^{0} \xrightarrow{d_{e}} M_{m}^{1} \xrightarrow{d_{e}} \cdots
$$

and a chromatic spectral sequence as in 5.1.8. Moreover $B P_{*} / I_{m}$ can be replaced by any comodule $L$ having an increasing filtration $\left\{F_{i} L\right\}$ such that each subquotient

$F_{i} / F_{i-1}$ is a suspension of $B P_{*} / I_{m}$, e.g., $L=B P_{*} / I_{m}^{k}$. We leave the details to the interested reader.

Our main motivation here, besides the Greek letter construction, is the computability of $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$; it is essentially the cohomology of the automorphism group of a formal group law of height $n$ (1.4.3 and A2.2.18). This theory will be the subject of Chapter 6 . We will state the first major result now. We have $M_{n}^{0}=v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{n}$, which is a comodule algebra (A1.1.2), so $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ is a ring (A1.2.14). In particular it is a module over $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$. The following is an easy consequence of the Morava-Landweber theorem, 4.3.2.
5.1.12. Proposition. For $n>0, \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}, v_{n}^{-1}\right]$. We denote this ring by $K(n)_{*}$. [The case $n=0$ is covered by 5.2.1, so it is consistent to denote $\mathbf{Q}$ by $\left.K(0)_{*}.\right]$
5.1.13. Definition. Make $K(n)_{*}$ a $B P_{*}$-module by defining multiplication by $v_{i}$ to be trivial for $i \neq n$. Then let $\Sigma(n)=K(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} K(n)_{*}$.
$\Sigma(n)$, the $n$th Morava stabilizer algebra, is a Hopf algebroid which will be closely examined in the next chapter. It has previously been called $K(n)_{*} K(n)$, e.g., in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1], Miller and Ravenel [5], and Ravenel [5, 6]. $K(n)_{*}$ is also the coefficient ring of the $n$th Morava $K$-theory; see Section 4.2 for references. We have changed our notation to avoid confusion with $K(n)_{*}(K(n))$, which is $\Sigma(n)$ tensored with a certain exterior algebra.

The starting point of Chapter 6 is
5.1.14. Change-of-Rings Theorem (Miller and Ravenel [5]).

$$
\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}\right)
$$

We will also show (6.2.10)
5.1.15. Morava Vanishing Theorem. If $(p-1) \nmid n$ then $\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)=0$ for $s>n^{2}$.

Moreover this Ext satisfies a kind of Poincaré duality, e.g.,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}^{n^{2}-s}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)
$$

and it is essentially the cohomology of a certain $n$ stage nilpotent Lie algebra of rank $n^{2}$. If we replace $\Sigma(n)$ with a quotient by a sufficiently large finitely generated subalgebra, then this Lie algebra becomes abelian and the Ext [even if $(p-1)$ divides $n$ ] becomes an exterior algebra over $K(n)_{*}$ on $n^{2}$ generators of degree one.

To connect these groups with the chromatic spectral sequence we have
5.1.16. Lemma. There are short exact sequences of comodules

$$
0 \rightarrow M_{m+1}^{n-1} \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{\operatorname{dim} v_{m}} M_{m}^{n} \xrightarrow{v_{m}} M_{m}^{n} \rightarrow 0
$$

and Bockstein spectral sequences converging to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{m}^{n}\right)$ with

$$
E_{1}^{s, *}=\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M_{m+1}^{n-1}\right) \otimes P\left(a_{m}\right)
$$

where multiplication by $a_{m}$ in the Bockstein spectral sequence corresponds to division by $v_{m}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{m}^{n}\right)$. $d_{r}$ is not a derivation but if $d_{r}\left(a_{m}^{r} x\right)=y \neq 0$ then $d_{r}\left(a_{m}^{r+t} x\right)=$ $v_{m}^{t} y$.

Proof. The spectral sequence is that associated with the increasing filtration of $M_{m}^{n}$ defined by $F_{i} M_{m}^{n}=\operatorname{ker} v_{m}^{i}$ (see A1.3.9). Then $E^{0} M_{m}^{n}=M_{m+1}^{n-1} \otimes P\left(a_{m}\right)$.

Using 5.1.16 $n$ times we can in principle get from $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{0}^{n}\right)=$ $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{n}\right)$ and hence compute the chromatic $E_{1}$-term (5.1.8). In practice these computations can be difficult.
5.1.17. Remark. We will not actually use the Bockstein spectral sequence of 5.1.16 but will work directly with the long exact sequence

$$
\rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M_{m+1}^{n-1}\right) \xrightarrow{j} \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(M_{m}^{n}\right) \xrightarrow{v_{m}} \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(\Sigma^{-2 p^{m}+2} M_{m}^{n}\right) \xrightarrow{\delta} \operatorname{Ext}^{s+1}\left(M_{m+1}^{n-1}\right) \rightarrow \cdots
$$

by induction on $s$. Given an element $x \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{m+1}^{n-1}\right)$ which we know not to be in $\operatorname{im} \delta$, we try to divide $j(x)$ by $v_{m}$ as many times as possible. When we find an $x^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{m}^{n}\right)$ with $v_{m}^{\prime} x^{\prime}=j(x)$ and $\delta\left(x^{\prime}\right)=y \neq 0$ then we will know that $j(x)$ cannot be divided any further by $v_{m}$. Hence $\delta$ serves as reduction $\bmod I_{m+1}$. This state of affairs corresponds to $d_{r}\left(a_{m}^{\prime} x\right)=y$ in the Bockstein spectral sequence of 5.1.16. We will give a sample calculation with $\delta$ below (5.1.20).

We will now make some simple calculations with the chromatic spectral sequence starting with the Greek letter elements of 5.1.3. The short exact sequence of 5.1.2 maps to that of 5.1.5, i.e., we have a commutative diagram
![img-44.jpeg](img-44.jpeg)
with

$$
i\left(v_{n+1}^{t}\right)=\frac{v_{n+1}^{t}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n}}
$$

Hence $\alpha_{t}^{(n)}$ can be defined as the image of $i\left(v_{n}^{t}\right)$ under the composite of the connecting homomorphisms of 5.1.5, which we denote by $\alpha: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{n}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{n}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. On the other hand, the chromatic spectral sequence has a bottom edge homomorphism
![img-45.jpeg](img-45.jpeg)
which we denote by

$$
\kappa: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{n}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{n}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

$\kappa$ and $\alpha$ differ by sign, i.e.,
5.1.18. Proposition. $\kappa=(-1)^{[(n+1) / 2]} \alpha$, where $[x]$ is the largest integer not exceeding $x$.

Proof. The image $y_{0}$ of $i\left(v_{n}^{t}\right)$ in $M^{n}$ is an element in the chromatic complex (5.1.10) cohomologous to some class in the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$. Inductively we can find $x_{s} \in C^{*}\left(M^{n-s-1}\right)$, and $y_{s} \in C^{*}\left(M^{n-s}\right)$ such that $d_{e}\left(x_{s}\right)=y_{s}$ and $d_{i}\left(x_{s}\right)=y_{s+1}$. Moreover $y_{n} \in C^{n}\left(M^{0}\right)$ is the image of some $x_{n} \in C^{n}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. It follows from the definition of the connecting homomorphism that $x_{n}$ is a cocycle representing $\alpha\left(i\left(v_{n}^{t}\right)\right)=\alpha_{t}^{(n)}$. On the other hand, $y_{s}$ is cohomologous to $(-1)^{n-s} y_{s+1}$ in $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ by 5.1.10 and $\prod_{s=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{n-s}=(-1)^{[n+1 / 2]}$ so $x_{n}$ represents $(-1)^{[n+1 / 2]} \kappa\left(i\left(v_{n}^{t}\right)\right)$.

5.1.19. Definition. If $x \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{n}\right)$ is in the image of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{n}\right)$ (and hence gives a permanent cycle in the chromatic spectral sequence) and has the form

$$
\frac{v_{n}^{t}}{p^{i_{0}} v_{1}^{i_{1}} \cdots v_{n-1}^{i_{n-1}}} \bmod I_{n}
$$

(i.e., $x$ is the indicated fraction plus terms with larger annihilator ideals) then we denote $\alpha(x)$ by $\alpha_{t / i_{n-1}, \ldots, i_{0}}^{(n)}$; if for some $m<n, i_{k}=1$ for $k \leq m$ then we abbreviate $\alpha(x)$ by $\alpha_{t / i_{n-1}, \ldots, i_{m+1}}^{(n)}$.
5.1.20. Examples and Remarks. We will compute the image of $\beta_{t}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ for $p>2$ in two ways.
(a) We regard $\beta_{t}$ as an element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ and compute its image under connecting homomorphisms $\delta_{0}$ to $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$ and then $\delta_{1}$ to $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(M_{2}^{0}\right)$, which is $E_{1}^{0,2}$ in the chromatic spectral sequence for $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$. To compute $\delta_{0}$, we pick an element in $x \in M^{2}$ such that $p x=\beta_{t}$, and compute its coboundary in the cobar complex $C\left(M^{2}\right)$. The result is necessarily a cocycle of order $p$, so it can be pulled back to $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$. To compute $\delta_{1}$ on this element we take a representative in $C^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$, divide it by $v_{1}$, and compute its coboundary.

Specifically $\beta_{t}$ is $\frac{v_{2}^{t}}{p v_{1}} \in M^{2}$, so we need to compute the coboundary of $x=\frac{v_{2}^{t}}{p^{2} v_{1}}$. It is convenient to write $x$ as $\frac{v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{t}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}$, then the denominator is the product of elements generating an invariant regular ideal, which means that we need to compute $\eta_{R}$ on the numerator only. We have

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{p-1}\right) \equiv v_{1}^{p-1}-p v_{1}^{p-2} t_{1} \quad \bmod \left(p^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}^{t}\right) \equiv v_{2}^{t}+t v_{2}^{t-1}\left(v_{1} t_{1}^{p}+p t_{2}\right) \quad \bmod \left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, v_{1}^{2}\right)
$$

These give

$$
d\left(\frac{v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{t}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}\right)=\frac{-v_{2}^{t} t_{1}}{p v_{1}^{2}}+\frac{t v_{2}^{t-1}}{p v_{1}}\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{1+p}\right)
$$

This is an element of order $p$ in $C^{1}\left(M^{2}\right)$, so it is in the image of $C^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$. In this group the $p$ in the denominator is superfluous, since everything has order $p$, so we omit it. To compute $\delta_{1}$ we divide by $v_{1}$ and compute the coboundary; i.e., we need to find

$$
d\left(\frac{-v_{2}^{t} t_{1}}{v_{1}^{3}}+\frac{t v_{2}^{t-1}\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{1+p}\right)}{v_{1}^{2}}\right)
$$

Recall $(4.3 .15)$

$$
\Delta\left(t_{2}\right)=t_{2} \otimes 1+t_{1} \otimes t_{1}^{p}+1 \otimes t_{2}+v_{1} b_{10}
$$

where

$$
b_{10}=-\sum_{0<i<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{i} t_{1}^{i} \otimes t_{1}^{p-i}
$$

as in 4.3.14. From this we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
d\left(\frac{-v_{2}^{t} t_{1}}{v_{1}^{3}}+\frac{t v_{2}^{t-1}}{v_{1}^{2}}\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{1+p}\right)\right)= & \frac{-t v_{2}^{t-1} t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{1}}{v_{1}^{2}}-\binom{t}{2} \frac{v_{2}^{t-2}}{v_{1}} t_{1}^{2 p} \mid t_{1} \\
& +t(t-1) \frac{v_{2}^{t-2}}{t_{1}^{p}} \mid\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{1+p}\right) \\
& +t \frac{v_{2}^{t-1}}{v_{1}^{2}}\left(-v_{1} b_{10}+t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{1}\right) \\
= & \binom{t}{2} \frac{v_{2}^{t-2}}{v_{1}}\left(2 t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{2}-2 t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{1}^{1+p}-t_{1}^{2 p} \mid t_{1}\right) \\
& -t \frac{v_{2}^{t-1}}{v_{1}} b_{10}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will see below that $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(M_{2}^{0}\right)$ has generators $k_{0}$ represented by $2 t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{2}-2 t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{1}^{1+p}-$ $t_{1}^{2 p} \mid t_{1}$ and $b_{10}$. Hence the $\bmod I_{2}$ reduction of $-\beta_{t}$ is

$$
\binom{t}{2} v_{2}^{t-2} k_{0}+t v_{2}^{t-1} b_{1,0}
$$

(b) In the chromatic complex $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)(5.1 .10), \beta_{t} \in M^{2}$ is cohomologous to elements in $C^{1}\left(M^{1}\right)$ and $C^{2}\left(M^{0}\right)$. These three elements pull back to $N^{2}, C^{1}\left(N^{1}\right)$, and $C^{2}\left(N^{0}\right)$, respectively. In theory we could compute the element in $C^{2}\left(N^{0}\right)=$ $C^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ and reduce $\bmod I_{2}$, but this would be very laborious. Most of the terms of the element in $C^{0}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ are trivial $\bmod I_{2}$, so we want to avoid computing them in the first place. The passage from $C^{0}\left(N^{2}\right)$ to $C^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is based on the four-term exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow M^{0} \rightarrow M^{1} \rightarrow N^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

Since $\frac{v_{2}^{t}}{p v_{1}} \in N^{2}$ is in the image of $\Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} / I_{2}$, we can replace this sequence with

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} \xrightarrow{v_{1}} \Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} / I_{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} / I_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

We are going to map the first $B P_{*}$ to $B P_{*} / I_{2}$; we can extend this to a map of sequences to

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{2} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, v_{1}^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{v_{1}} \Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{3}\right) \rightarrow \Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} / I_{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

which is the identity on the last comodule. [The reader may be tempted to replace the middle map by

$$
B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, v_{1}\right) \xrightarrow{v_{1}} \Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2}\right)
$$

but $B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, v_{1}\right)$ is not a comodule.] This sequence tells us which terms we can ignore when computing in the chromatic complex, as we will see below.

Specifically we find (ignoring signs) that $\frac{v_{2}^{t}}{p v_{1}} \in M^{2}$ is cohomologous to

$$
\frac{t v_{2}^{t-1} t_{1}^{p}}{p}+\left(\frac{t}{2}\right) \frac{v_{1} v_{2}^{t-2}}{p} t_{1}^{2 p}+\text { higher terms. }
$$

Note that the first two terms are divisible by $v_{1}$ and $v_{1}^{2}$ respectively in the image of $C^{1}\left(\Sigma^{-q} B P_{*} /(p)\right)$ in $C^{1}\left(M^{1}\right)$. The higher terms are divisible by $v_{1}^{3}$ and can therefore be ignored.

In the next step we will need to work $\bmod I_{2}^{2}$ in the image of $C^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ in $C^{2}\left(M^{0}\right)$ via multiplication by $p$. From the first term above we get

$$
t(t-1) v_{2}^{t-2} t_{2} \mid t_{1}^{p}+t v_{2}^{t-1} b_{10}
$$

while the second term gives

$$
\binom{t}{2} v_{2}^{t-2} t_{1} \mid t_{1}^{2 p}
$$

and their sum represents the same element obtained in (a).
Our next result is

# 5.1.21. Proposition. For $n \geq 3$, 

$$
\alpha_{1}^{(n)}=(-1)^{n} \alpha_{1} \alpha_{p-1}^{(n-1)}
$$

For $n=3$ this gives $\gamma_{1}=-\alpha_{1} \beta_{p-1}$. In the controversy over the nontriviality of $\gamma_{1}$ (cf. the paragraph following 1.3.18) the relevant stem was known to be generated by $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p-1}$, so what follows is an easy way (given all of our machinery) to show $\gamma_{1} \neq 0$.

Proof of 5.1.2. $\alpha_{1}$ is easily seen to be represented by $t_{1}$ in $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$, while $\alpha_{1}^{(n)}$ and $\alpha_{p-1}^{(n-1)}$ are represented by

$$
(-1)^{[n+1 / 2]} \frac{v_{n}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}} \in M^{n} \quad \text { and } \quad(-1)^{[n / 2]} \frac{v_{n-1}^{p-1}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-2}} \in M^{n-1}
$$

respectively. Hence $(-1)^{n} \alpha_{1} \alpha_{p-1}^{(n-1)}=-\alpha_{p-1}^{(n-1)} \alpha_{1}$ is represented by

$$
(-1)^{[n / 2]} \frac{v_{n-1}^{p-1} t_{1}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-2}} \in C^{1}\left(M^{n-1}\right) \subset C C^{n}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

and it suffices to show that this element is cohomologous to $\frac{(-1)^{[n+1 / 2]} v_{n}}{\left(p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}\right)}$ in $C C\left(B P_{*}\right)$.

Now consider

$$
x=\frac{v_{n-1}^{-1} v_{n}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-2}}-\frac{v_{n-1}^{p}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-3} v_{n-2}^{1+p}} \in M^{n-1}
$$

Clearly

$$
d_{e}(x)=\frac{v_{n}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}}
$$

To compute $d_{i}(x)$ we need to know $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n-1}^{-1} v_{n}\right) \bmod I_{n-1}$ and $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n-1}^{p}\right)$ $\bmod \left(p, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-3}, v_{n-2}^{1+p}\right)$ since $d_{i}(x)=\eta_{R}(x)-x$. We know

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right) \equiv v_{n}+v_{n-1} t_{1}^{p^{n-1}}-v_{n-1}^{p} t_{1} \quad \bmod I_{n-1}
$$

by 4.3.21, so

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n-1}^{p}\right) \equiv v_{n-1}^{p}+v_{n-2}^{p} t_{1}^{p^{n-1}}-v_{n-2}^{p^{2}} t_{1}^{p} \quad \bmod I_{n-2}
$$

Hence

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n-1}^{-1} v_{n}\right)-v_{n-1}^{-1} v_{n} \equiv t_{1}^{p^{n-1}}-v_{n-1}^{p-1} t_{1} \quad \bmod I_{n-1}
$$

and

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n-1}^{p}\right)-v_{n-1}^{p} \equiv v_{n-2}^{p} t_{1}^{p^{n-1}} \quad \bmod \left(p, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-3}, v_{n-2}^{1+p}\right)
$$

It follows that

$$
d_{i}(x)=\frac{-v_{n-1}^{p-1} t_{1}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-2}}
$$

so

$$
d(x)=\frac{v_{n}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}}+(-1)^{n} \frac{v_{n-1}^{p-1} t_{1}}{p v_{1} \cdots v_{n-2}}
$$

and a simple sign calculation gives the result.
For $p=2$ 5.1.21 says $\alpha_{1}^{(n)}=\alpha_{1}^{n-2} \alpha_{1}^{(2)}$ for $n \geq 2$. We will show that each of these elements vanishes and that they are killed by higher differentials $\left(d_{n-1}\right)$ in the chromatic spectral sequence. We do not know if there are nontrivial $d_{r}$ 's for all $r \geq 2$ for odd primes.
5.1.22. TheOREM. In the chromatic spectral sequence for $p=2$ there are elements $x_{n} \in E_{n-1}^{1, n-2}$ for $n \geq 2$ such that

$$
d_{n-1}\left(x_{n}\right)=\frac{v_{n}}{2 v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}} \in E_{n-1}^{n, 0}
$$

Proof. Fortunately we need not worry about signs this time. Equation 4.3.1 gives $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}\right)=v_{1}-2 t_{1}$ and $\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right) \equiv v_{2}+v_{1} t_{1}^{2}+v_{1}^{2} t_{1} \bmod (2)$. We find then that

$$
x_{2}=\frac{v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}}{8}
$$

has the desired property. For $n>2$ we represented $x_{n}$ by

$$
\frac{\left.\left[\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{3}+v_{1}^{-1} v_{2} t_{1}\right)\right] t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}\right]}{2} \in C^{n-2}\left(M^{1}\right)
$$

with $n-3 t_{1}$ 's. To compute $d_{n-1}\left(x_{n}\right)$ let

$$
\tilde{x}_{n}=x_{n}+\sum_{i=1}^{n-2} \frac{\left(v_{i+1}^{2}-v_{i}^{2} v_{i+1}^{-1} v_{i+2}\right) t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}}{2 v_{1} \cdots v_{i-1} v_{i}^{3}} \in C C\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

where the $i$ th term has $(n-2-i) t_{1}$ 's. Then one computes

$$
d\left(\tilde{x}_{n}\right)=\frac{v_{n}}{2 v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}}
$$

so

$$
d_{n-1}\left(x_{n}\right)=\frac{v_{n}}{2 v_{1} \cdots v_{n-1}}
$$

unless this element is killed by an earlier differential, in which case $x_{n}$, would represent a nontrivial element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{n-1,2 n}\left(B P_{*}\right)$, which is trivial by 5.1.23 below.

# 5.1.23. Edge Theorem. 

(a) For all primes $p \operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(B P_{*}\right)=0$ for $t<2 s$,
(b) for $p=2 \operatorname{Ext}^{s, 2 s}\left(B P_{*}\right)=\mathbf{Z} /(2)$ for $s \geq 1$, and
(c) for $p=2 \operatorname{Ext}^{s, 2 s+2}\left(B P_{*}\right)=0$ for $s \geq 2$.

Proof. We use the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*}\right)$ of A1.2.11. Part (a) follows from the fact that $C^{s, t}$ for $t<2 s . C^{s, 2 s}$ is spanned by $t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}$ while $C^{s, 2 s+2}$ is spanned by $v_{1} t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}$ and $e_{j}=t_{1}|\cdots t_{1}| t_{1}^{2} \mid t_{1} \cdots t_{1}$ with $t_{1}^{2}$ in the $j$ th position, $1 \leq j \leq s$. Since $d\left(t_{1}^{3}\right)=-3 t_{1}\left|t_{1}^{2}-3 t_{1}^{2}\right| t_{1}$, the $e_{j}$ 's differ by a coboundary up to sign. Part (b) follows from

$$
d\left(e_{1}\right)=2 t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}=-d\left(v_{1} t_{1}|\cdots| t_{1}\right)
$$

and (c) follows from

$$
d\left(t_{2}\left|t_{1}\right| \cdots\left|t_{1}\right)=-v_{1} t_{1}\right| \cdots\left|t_{1}-e_{1}\right.
$$

We conclude this section by tying up some loose ends in Section 4.4. For $p>2$ we need
5.1.24. Lemma. For odd primes, $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p}$ is divisible by $p$ but not by $p^{2}$. (This gives the first element of order $p^{2}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(B P_{s}\right)$ for $s \geq 2$.)

Proof. Up to sign $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p}$ is represented by $\frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p v_{1}}$. Now $\frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p^{2} v_{1}}$ is not a cocycle, but if we can get a cocycle by adding a term of order $p$ then we will have the desired divisibility. It is more convenient to write this element as $\frac{v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}$; then the factors of the denominator form an invariant sequence [i.e., $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{p}\right) \equiv v_{1}^{p} \bmod \left(p^{2}\right)$ ], so to compute the coboundary it suffices to compute $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}\right) \bmod \left(p^{2}, v_{1}^{p}\right)$. We find

$$
d\left(\frac{v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{p}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}} t_{1}\right)=\frac{-v_{2}^{p} t_{1} \mid t_{1}}{p v_{1}^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} d\left(\frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{2}}{p v_{1}^{2}}\right)
$$

so the desired cocycle is

$$
\frac{v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{2}}{p v_{1}^{2}}
$$

This divisibility will be generalized in (5.6.2).
To show that $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p}$ is not divisible by $p^{2}$ we compute the $\bmod (p)$ reduction of our cocycle. More precisely we compute its image under the connecting homomorphism associated with

$$
0 \rightarrow M_{1}^{1} \rightarrow M_{0}^{2} \xrightarrow{p} M_{0}^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

(see 5.1.16). To do this we divide by $p$ and compute the coboundary. Our divided (by $p$ ) cocycle is

$$
\frac{v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p^{3} v_{1}^{p^{2}}}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{v_{1}^{p-2} v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{2}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}
$$

and its coboundary is

$$
\frac{v_{2}^{p}\left(t_{1}^{2} \mid t_{1}+t_{1} \mid t_{1}^{2}\right)}{p v_{1}^{3}}+\frac{v_{2}^{p-1} t_{2} \mid t_{1}}{p v_{1}}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{v_{2}^{p-1} t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{1}^{2}}{p v_{1}}-\frac{v_{2}^{p-1} t_{1}^{1+p} \mid t_{1}}{p v_{1}}
$$

We can eliminate the first term by adding $\frac{1}{3} \frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{2}}{p v_{1}^{3}}$ (even if $p=3$ ). For $p>3$ the resulting element in $C^{2}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$ is

$$
\frac{v_{2}^{p-1}\left(t_{2}\left|t_{1}-t_{1}^{1+p}\right| t_{1}-t_{1}^{p} \mid t_{2}\right)}{v_{1}}
$$

Reducing this $\bmod I_{2}$ in a similar fashion gives a unit multiple of $\bar{\phi}$ in 4.1.14. For $p=3$ we add $\frac{-v_{2} t_{2}^{2}}{3 v_{1}^{2}}$ to the divided cocycle and get

$$
\frac{v_{2}^{p-1}\left(t_{2} \mid t_{1}-\cdots\right)}{v_{1}}+\frac{v_{2}}{v_{1}}\left(t_{1}^{3} \mid t_{1}^{6}+t_{1}^{6} \mid t_{1}^{3}\right)
$$

which still gives a nonzero element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$.
For $p=2$ we need to prove 4.4 .38 and 4.4.40, i.e.,

5.1.25. Lemma. In the notation of 4.4 .32 for $p=2$ (a) $\delta_{0}\left(\beta_{3}\right) \equiv \beta_{2 / 2}^{2}+\eta_{1}$ $\bmod (2)$
(b) $\delta_{0}\left(\eta_{2}\right) \equiv c_{0} \bmod (2)$.

Proof. For (a) we have

$$
d\left(\frac{v_{1} v_{2}^{3}}{4 v_{1}^{2}}+\frac{v_{2} v_{3}}{2 v_{1}^{2}}\right)=\frac{v_{2}^{2} t_{1}^{4}}{2 v_{1}^{2}}+\frac{v_{3} t_{1}^{2}+v_{2} t_{2}^{2}+v_{2}^{2} t_{2}+v_{2} t_{1}^{6}}{2 v_{1}}
$$

which gives the result.
For (b) we use Massey products. We have $\eta_{2}\left\langle\eta_{1}, v_{1}, \beta_{1}\right\rangle$ so by A1.4.11 we have $\delta_{0}\left(\eta_{2}\right) \equiv\left\langle\eta_{1}, h_{10}, \beta_{1}\right\rangle \bmod (2)$. Hence we have to equate this product with $c_{0}$, which by 4.4.31 is represented by $\frac{x_{22}}{v_{1}}$, where $x_{22}$ is defined by 4.4.25. To expedite this calculation we will use a generalization of Massey products not given in A1.4 but fully described by May [3]. We regard $\eta_{1}$ as an element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$, and $h_{10}$, and $\beta_{1}$ as elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{1}\right)$ and use the pairing $M_{1}^{1} \otimes B P_{*} / I_{1} \rightarrow M_{1}^{1}$ to define the product. Hence the cocycles representing $\eta_{1}, h_{10}$ and $\beta_{1}$ are

$$
\frac{v_{3} t_{1}^{2}+v_{2}\left(t_{2}^{2}+t_{1}^{6}\right)+v_{2}^{2} t_{2}}{v_{1}}, \quad t_{1}, \quad \text { and } \quad t_{1}^{2}+v_{1} t_{1}
$$

respectively. The cochains whose coboundaries are the two successive products are

$$
\frac{v_{3}\left(t_{2}+t_{1}^{3}\right)+v_{2}\left(t_{3}+t_{1} t_{2}^{2}+t_{1}^{4} t_{2}+t_{1}^{7}\right)+v_{2}^{2}\left(t_{1}^{4}+t_{1} t_{2}\right)}{v_{1}} \text { and } t_{2}
$$

If we alter the resulting cochain representative of the Massey product by the coboundary of

$$
\frac{v_{3} t_{1}^{2} t_{2}+v_{2}\left(t_{2}^{3}+t_{2} t_{1}^{6}+t_{1}^{9}\right)+v_{2}^{2}\left(t_{1}^{6}+t_{2}^{2}\right)}{v_{1}}+\frac{v_{2}^{4}\left(t_{2}+t_{1}^{3}\right)}{v_{1}^{4}}+\frac{v_{2}^{5} t_{1}}{v_{1}^{5}}
$$

we get the desired result.

# 2. $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ and Hopf Invariant One 

In this section we compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ for all $n$. For $n>0$ our main results are 5.2.14 and 5.2.17. For $n=0$ this group is $E_{2}^{1, *}$ in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence and is given in 5.2.6. In 5.2.8 we will compute its image in the classical Adams spectral sequence, thereby obtaining proofs of the essential content of the Hopf invariant one theorems 1.2.12 and 1.2.14. More precisely, we will prove that the specified $h_{i}$ 's are not permanent cycles, but we will not compute $d_{2}\left(h_{i}\right)$. The computation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ is originally due to Novikov [1] for $n=0$ and to Miller and Wilson [3] for $n>0$ (except for $n=1$ and $p \geq 2$ ).

To compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ with the chromatic spectral sequence we need to know $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M^{0}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$. For the former we have
5.2.1. ThEOREM. (a) $\operatorname{Ext}^{*, t}\left(M^{0}\right)= \begin{cases}\mathbf{Q} & \text { if } s=t=0 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}$
(b) $\operatorname{Ext}^{0, t}\left(B P_{*}\right)= \begin{cases}\mathbf{Z}_{(p)} & \text { if } t=0 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}$

Proof. (a) Since $M^{0}=\mathbf{Q} \otimes B P_{*}$, we have $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{0}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}(A, A)$ where $A=M^{0}$ and $\Gamma=\mathbf{Q} \otimes B P_{*}(B P)$. Since $t_{n}$ is a rational multiple of $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)-v_{n}$ modulo decomposables, $\Gamma$ is generated by the image of $\eta_{R}$ and $\eta_{L}$ and is therefore

a unicursal Hopf algebroid (A1.1.11). Let $\bar{v}_{n}=\eta_{R}\left(v_{n}\right)$, so $\Gamma=A\left[\bar{v}_{1}, \bar{v}_{2}, \ldots\right]$. The coproduct in $\Gamma$ is given by $\Delta\left(v_{n}\right)=v_{n} \otimes 1$ and $\Delta\left(\bar{v}_{n}\right)=1 \otimes \bar{v}_{n}$. The map $\eta_{R}: A \rightarrow$ $\Gamma=A \otimes_{A} \Gamma$ makes $A$ a right $\Gamma$-comodule. Let $R$ be the complex $\Gamma \otimes E\left(y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots\right)$ where $E\left(y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots\right)$ is an exterior algebra on generators $y_{i}$ of degree 1 and dimension $2\left(p^{i}-1\right)$. Let the coboundary $d$ be a derivation with $d\left(y_{n}\right)=d\left(\bar{v}_{n}\right)=0$ and $d\left(v_{n}\right)=y_{n}$. Then $R$ is easily seen to be acyclic with $H^{0}(R)=A$. Hence $R$ is a suitable resolution for computing $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}(A, A)$ (A1.2.4). We have $\operatorname{Hom}_{\Gamma}(A, R)=$ $A \otimes E\left(y_{1}, \ldots\right)$ and this complex is easily seen to be acyclic and gives the indicated Ext groups for $M^{0}$.

For (b) $\operatorname{Ext}^{0} B P_{*}=\operatorname{ker} d_{e} \subset \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{0}^{0}\right)$ and $d_{e}(x) \neq 0$ if $x$ is a unit multiple of a negative power of $p$.

To get at $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{1}\right)$ we start with

# 5.2.2. THEOREM. 

(a) For $p>2, \operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)=K(1)_{*} \otimes E\left(h_{0}\right)$ where $h_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, q}$ is represented by $t_{1}$ in $C^{1}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$ (see 5.1.12) and $q=2 p-2$ as usual.
(b) For $p=2, \operatorname{Ext}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)=K(1)_{*} \otimes P\left(h_{0}\right) \otimes E\left(\rho_{1}\right)$, where $h_{0}$ is as above and $\rho_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,0}$ is represented by $v_{1}^{-3}\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{3}\right)+v_{1}^{-4} v_{2} t_{1}$.

This will be proved below as 6.3.21.
Now we use the method of 5.1.17 to find $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$; in the next section we will compute all of $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{1}\right)$ in this way. From 4.3.3 we have $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{p^{i}}\right) \equiv v_{1}^{p^{i}} \bmod \left(p^{i+1}\right)$, so $\frac{v_{1}^{s p^{i}}}{p^{i+1}} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$. For $p$ odd we have

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{s p^{i}}\right) \equiv v_{1}^{s p^{i}}+s p^{i+1} v_{1}^{s p^{i}-1} t_{1} \quad \bmod \left(p^{i+2}\right)
$$

so in 5.1.17 we have

$$
\delta\left(\frac{v_{1}^{s p^{i}}}{p^{i+1}}\right)=s v_{1}^{s p^{i}-1} h_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)
$$

for $p \nmid s$, and we can read off the structure of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$ below.
For $p=2$, 5.2.3 fails for $i>0$, e.g.,

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right)=v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1} t_{1}+4 t_{1}^{2} \quad \bmod (8)
$$

The element $t_{1}^{2}+v_{1} t_{1} \in C^{1}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$ is the coboundary of $v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}$, so

$$
\alpha_{2 / 3}=\frac{\left(v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}\right)}{8} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)
$$

i.e., we can divide by at least one more power of $p$ than in the odd primary case. In order to show that further division by 2 is not possible we need to show that $\alpha_{2 / 3}$ has a nontrivial image under $\delta(5.1 .17)$. This in turn requires a formula for $\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right)$ $\bmod (4)$. From 4.3.1 we get

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right)=v_{2}+13 v_{1} t_{1}^{2}-3 v_{1}^{2} t_{1}-14 t_{2}-4 t_{1}^{3}
$$

[This formula, as well as $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}\right)=v_{1}-2 t_{1}$, are in terms of the $v_{i}$ defined by Araki's formula A2.2.2. Using Hazewinkel's generators defined by A2.2.1 gives $\eta_{R}\left(v_{1}\right)=v_{1}+2 t_{1}$ and $\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right)=v_{2}-5 v_{1} t_{1}^{2}-3 v_{1}^{2} t_{1}+2 t_{2}-4 t_{1}^{3}$.]

Let $x_{1,1}=v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}$. Then 5.2 .4 gives

$$
\eta_{R}\left(x_{1,1}\right) \equiv x_{1,1}+8\left(v_{1}^{-1} t_{2}+v_{1}^{-1} t_{1}^{3}+v_{1}^{-2} v_{2} t_{1}\right) \quad \bmod (16)
$$

so $\delta\left(\alpha_{2 / 3}\right)=v_{1}^{2} \rho_{1} \neq 0 \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$.

5.2.6. THEOREM.
(a) For $p$ odd

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0, t}\left(M^{1}\right)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } q \nmid t \text { where } q=2 p-2 \\ \mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}_{(p)} & \text { if } t=0 \\ \mathbf{Z} /\left(p^{i+1}\right) & \text { if } t=s p^{i} q \text { and } p \nmid s\end{cases}
$$

These groups are generated by

$$
\frac{v_{1}^{s p^{i}}}{p^{i+1}} \in M^{1}
$$

(b) For $p$ odd

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{1, t}\left(B P_{*}\right)= \begin{cases}\operatorname{Ext}^{0, t}\left(M^{1}\right) & \text { if } t>0 \\ 0 & \text { if } t=0\end{cases}
$$

(c) For $p=2$

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0, t}\left(M^{1}\right)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } t \text { is odd } \\ \mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}_{(2)} & \text { if } t=0 \\ \mathbf{Z} /(2) & \text { if } t \equiv 2 \bmod 4 \\ \mathbf{Z} /\left(2^{i+3}\right) & \text { if } t=2^{i+2} s \text { for odd } s\end{cases}
$$

These groups are generated by $\frac{v_{1}^{s}}{2}$ and $\frac{x_{1,1}^{2^{i+1}}}{2^{i+3}} \in M^{1}$ where $x_{1,1}$ is as in 5.2.5.
(d) For $p=2$

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{1, t}\left(B P_{*}\right)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } t \leq 0 \\ \operatorname{Ext}^{0, t}\left(M^{1}\right) & \text { if } t>0 \text { and } t \neq 4 \\ \mathbf{Z} /(4) & \text { if } t=4\end{cases}
$$

and $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,4}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is generated by $\alpha_{2,2}= \pm \frac{v_{1}^{2}}{4}$.
We will see in the next section (5.3.7) that in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $p>2$, each element of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is a permanent cycle detecting an element in the image of the $J$-homomorphism (1.1.13). For $p=2$ the generators of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,2 t}$ are permanent cycles for $t \equiv 0$ and $1 \bmod (4)$ while for $t \equiv 2$ and 3 the generators support nontrivial $d_{3}$ 's (except when $t=2$ ) and the elements of order 4 in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,8 t+4}$ are permanent cycles. The generators of $E_{4}^{1,4 t}=E_{\infty}^{1,4 t}$ detect elements in $\operatorname{im} J$ for all $t>0$.

Proof of 5.2.6. Part (a) was sketched above. We get $\mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$ in dimension zero because $1 / p^{i}$ is a cocycle for all $i>0$. For (b) the chromatic spectral sequence gives a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow E_{\infty}^{1,0} \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right) \rightarrow E_{\infty}^{0,1} \rightarrow 0
$$

and $E_{\infty}^{0,1}$ by 5.2.1. $E_{\infty}^{1,0}=E_{2}^{1,0}=\operatorname{ker} d_{e} / \operatorname{im} d_{e}$. An element in $E_{1}^{1,0}=\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$ has a nontrivial image under $d_{e}$ iff it has terms involving negative powers of $v_{1}$, so $\operatorname{ker} d_{e} \subset E_{1}^{1,0}$ is the subgroup of elements in nonnegative dimensions. The zerodimensional summand $\mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$ is the image of $d_{e}$, so $E_{2}^{1,0}=\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is as stated.

For (c) the computation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$ is more complicated for $p=2$ since 5.2.3 no longer holds. From 5.2.5 we get

$$
\eta_{R}\left(x_{1,1}^{2^{i} s}\right) \equiv x_{1,1}^{2^{i} s}+2^{i+3} x_{1,1}^{2^{i} s-1}\left(v_{1}^{-1} t_{2}+v_{1}^{-1} t_{1}^{3}+v_{1}^{-2} v_{2} t_{1}\right) \quad \bmod \left(2^{i+4}\right)
$$

for odd $s$, from which we deduce that $\frac{x_{1}^{2^{i} s}}{2^{i+3}}$ is a cocycle whose image under $\delta$ (see 5.1.17) is $v_{1}^{2^{i+1} s} \rho_{1}$. Equation 5.2 .3 does hold for $p=2$ when $i=0$, so $\operatorname{Ext}^{0,2 s}\left(M_{1}^{0}\right)$ is generated by $\frac{v_{1}^{s}}{2}$ for odd $s$. This completes the proof of (c).

For (d) we proceed as in (b) and the situation in nonpositive dimensions is the same. We need to compute $d_{e}\left(\frac{x_{1,1}^{2^{i} s}}{2^{i+3}}\right)$. Since $x_{1,1}=v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}$, we have

$$
\frac{x_{1,1}^{2^{i} s}}{2^{i+3}}=\frac{v_{1}^{2^{i+1} s}+2^{i+2} v_{1}^{2^{i} s-3} v_{2}}{2^{i+3}}
$$

For $2^{i} s=1$ (but for no $2^{i} s>1$ ) this expression has a negative power of $v_{1}$ and we get

$$
d_{e}\left(\frac{x_{1,1}}{8}\right)=\frac{v_{2}}{2 v_{1}} \in M^{2}
$$

This gives a chromatic $d_{1}$ (compare 5.1.21) and accounts for the discrepancy between $\operatorname{Ext}^{0,4}\left(M^{1}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,4}\left(B P_{*}\right)$.

Now we turn to the Hopf invariant one problem. Theorems 1.2.12 and 1.2.14 say which elements of filtration 1 in the classical Adams spectral sequence are permanent cycles. We can derive these results from our computation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ as follows. The map $B P \rightarrow H /(p)$ induces a map $\Phi$ from the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence to the Adams spectral sequence. Since both spectral sequences converge to the same thing there is essentially a one-to-one correspondence between their $E_{\infty^{-}}$ terms. A nontrivial permanent cycle in the Adams spectral sequence of filtration $s$ corresponds to one in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence of filtration $\leq s$.

To see this consider $B P_{*}$ and $\bmod (p)$ Adams resolutions (2.2.1 and 2.1.3)
![img-46.jpeg](img-46.jpeg)
where the vertical maps are the ones inducing $\Phi$. An element $x \in \pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ has Adams filtration $s$ if it is in $\operatorname{im} \pi_{*}\left(Y_{s}\right)$ but not in $\operatorname{im} \pi_{*}\left(Y_{s+1}\right)$. Hence it is not in $\operatorname{im} \pi_{*}\left(X_{s+1}\right)$ and its Novikov filtration is at most $s$.

We are concerned with permanent cycles with Adams filtration 1 and hence of Novikov filtration 0 or 1 . Since $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is trivial in positive dimensions [5.2.1(b)] it suffices to prove

# 5.2.8. ThEOREM. The image of 

$$
\Phi: \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{1}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))
$$

is generated by $h_{1}, h_{2}$, and $h_{3}$, for $p=2$ and by $h_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, q}$ for $p>2$. (These elements are permanent cycles; cf. 1.2.11 and 1.2.13.)

Proof. Recall that $A_{*}=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots\right] \otimes E\left(e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots\right)$ with

$$
\Delta\left(t_{n}\right)=\sum_{0 \leq i \leq n} t_{i} \otimes t_{n-i}^{p^{i}} \quad \text { and } \quad \Delta\left(e_{n}\right)=1 \otimes e_{n}+\sum_{1 \leq i \leq n} e_{i} \otimes t_{n-i}^{p^{i}}
$$

where $t_{0}=1$. Here $t_{n}$ and $e_{n}$ are the conjugates of Milnor's $\xi_{n}$ and $\tau_{n}$ (3.1.1). The map $B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow A_{*}$ sends $t_{n} \in B P_{*}(B P)$ to $t_{n} \in A_{*}$.

Now recall the $I$-adic filtration of 4.4.4. We can extend it to the comodules $M^{n}$ and $N^{n}$ by saying that a monomial fraction $\frac{v^{i}}{v^{j}}$ is in $F^{k}$ iff the sum of the exponents in the numerator exceeds that for the denominator by at least $k$. (This $k$ may be negative and there is no $k$ such that $F^{k} M^{n}=M^{n}$ or $F^{k} N^{n}=N^{n}$. However, there is such a $k$ for any finitely generated subcomodule of $M^{n}$ or $N^{n}$.) For each $k \in \mathbf{Z}$ the sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow F^{k} N^{n} \rightarrow F^{k} M^{n} \rightarrow F^{k} N^{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

is exact. It follows that $\alpha: \operatorname{Ext}^{s}\left(N^{n}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{s+n}\left(B P_{*}\right)(5.1 .18)$ preserves the $I$-adic filtration and that if $x \in F^{1} \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{1}\right)$ then $\Phi \alpha(x)=0$.

Easy inspection of 5.2 .6 shows that the only elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$ not in $F^{1}$ are $\alpha_{1}$ and, for $p=2, \alpha_{2 / 2}$, and $\alpha_{4 / 4}$, and the result follows.

Now we turn to the computation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ for $n>0$; it is a module over $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ which is $\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}\right]$ by 4.3.2. We denote this ring by $k(n)_{*}$. It is a principal ideal domain and $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ has finite type so the latter is a direct sum of cyclic modules, i.e., of free modules and modules of the form $k(n)_{*} /\left(v_{n}^{i}\right)$ for various $i>0$. We call these the $v_{n}$-torsion free and $v_{n}$-torsion summands, respectively. The rank of the former is obtained by inverting $v_{n}$, i.e., by computing $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$. The submodule of the $v_{n}$-torsion which is annihilated by $v_{n}$ is precisely the image of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)=k(n+1)_{*}$ under the connecting homomorphism for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{\operatorname{dim} v_{n}} B P_{*} / I_{n} \xrightarrow{v_{n}} B P_{*} / I_{n} \rightarrow B P_{*} / I_{n+1} \rightarrow 0
$$

We could take these elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ and see how far they can be divided by $v_{n}$ by analyzing the long exact sequence for 5.2.9, assuming we know enough about $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$ to recognize nontrivial images of elements of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ when we see them. This approach was taken by Miller and Wilson [3].

The chromatic spectral sequence approach is superficially different but one ends up having to make the same calculation either way. From the chromatic spectral sequence for $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ (5.1.11) we get a short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow E_{\infty}^{1,0} \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right) \rightarrow E_{\infty}^{0,1} \rightarrow 0
$$

where $E_{\infty}^{1,0}=E_{2}^{1,0}$ is a subquotient of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n+1}^{1}\right)$ and is the $v_{n}$-torsion summand, while $E_{\infty}^{0,1}=E_{3}^{0,1} \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ is the $v_{n}$-torsion free quotient. To get at $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n+1}^{1}\right)$ we study the long exact sequence for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow M_{n+1}^{0} \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{\operatorname{dim} v_{n}} M_{n}^{1} \xrightarrow{v_{n}} M_{n}^{1} \rightarrow 0
$$

as in 5.1.17; this requires knowledge of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n+1}^{0}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n+1}^{0}\right)$. To determine the subgroup $E_{\infty}^{0,1}$ of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ we need the explicit representatives of generators of the latter constructed by Moreira $[\mathbf{1}, \mathbf{3}]$.

The following result (to be proved later as 6.3.12) then is relevant to both $E_{\infty}^{0,1}$ and $E_{\infty}^{1,0}$ in 5.2.10.

5.2.11. ThEOREM. $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ for $n>0$ is the $K(n)_{*}$-vector space generated by $h_{i} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, p^{i} q}$ for $0 \leq i \leq n-1$ represented by $t_{1}^{p^{i}}, \zeta_{n} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,0}$ (for $n \geq 2$ )represented for $n=2$ by $v_{2}^{-1} t_{2}+v_{2}^{-p}\left(t_{2}^{p}-t_{1}^{p^{2}+p}\right)-v_{2}^{-1-p} v_{3} t_{1}^{p}$, and (if $p=2$ and $n \geq 1$ ) $\rho_{n} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,0} .\left(\zeta_{n}\right.$ and $\rho_{n}$ will be defined in 6.3.11).
5.2.12. REMARK. For $i \geq n, h_{i}$ does not appear in this list because the equation

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+1}\right) \equiv v_{n+1}+v_{n} t_{1}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p} t_{1} \quad \bmod I_{n}
$$

leads to a cohomology between $h_{n+i}$ and $v_{n}^{\left(p-1\right) p^{i}} h_{i}$.
Now we will describe $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n}^{1}\right)$ and $E_{\infty}^{1,0}$. The groups are $v_{n}$-torsion modules. The submodule of the former annihilated by $v_{n}$ is generated by $\left\{\frac{v_{n+1}^{i}}{v_{n}}: t \in \mathbf{Z}\right\}$. Only those elements with $t>0$ will appear in $E_{\infty}^{1,0}$; if $t=0$ the element is in $\operatorname{im} d_{1}$, and $\operatorname{ker} d_{1}$ is generated by those elements with $t \geq 0$. We need to see how many times we can divide by $v_{n}$ and (still have a cocycle). An easy calculation shows that if $t=s p^{i}$ with $p \nmid s$, then $\frac{v_{n+1}^{i}}{v_{n}^{p i}}$ is a cocycle whose image in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n+1}^{0}\right)$ is $s v_{n+1}^{(s-1) p^{i}} h_{n+i}$, but by 5.2 .12 these are not linearly independent, so this is not the best possible divisibility result. For example, for $n=1$ we find that

$$
\frac{v_{2}^{p^{2}}}{v_{1}^{1+p^{2}}}-\frac{v_{2}^{p^{2}-p+1}}{v_{1}^{2}}-\frac{v_{2}^{-p} v_{3}^{p}}{v_{1}}
$$

is a cocycle.
The general result is this.
5.2.13. ThEOREM. As a $k(n)_{*}$-module, $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n}^{1}\right)$ is the direct sum of
(i) the cyclic submodules generated by $\frac{x_{n+1, i}^{i}}{v_{n}^{p n+1, i}}$ for $i \geq 0, p \nmid s$; and
(ii) $K(n)_{*} / k(n)_{*}$, generated by $\frac{1}{v_{n}^{i}}$ for $j \geq 1$.

The $x_{n, i}$ are defined as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1,0}=v_{1} \\
& x_{1,1}=v_{1}^{p} \quad \text { if } p>2 \quad \text { and } \quad v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2} \quad \text { if } p=2, \\
& x_{1, i}=x_{1, i-1}^{p} \quad \text { for } \quad i \geq 2, \\
& x_{2,0}=v_{2} \\
& x_{2,1}=v_{2}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} v_{2}^{-1} v_{3} \\
& x_{2,2}=x_{2,1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} v_{2}^{p^{2}-p+1}-v_{1}^{p^{2}+p-1} v_{2}^{p^{2}-2 p} v_{3} \\
& x_{2, i}=x_{2, i-1}^{2} \quad \text { for } i \geq 3 \quad \text { if } p=2
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
x_{2, i-1}^{p}-2 v_{1}^{b_{2, i}} v_{2}^{(p-1) p^{i-1}+1} \quad \text { for } i \geq 3 \quad \text { if } p>2
$$

where

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
b_{2, i}=(p+1)\left(p^{i-1}-1\right) \\
x_{n, 0}=v_{n} & \text { for } \quad n>2 \\
x_{n, 1}=v_{n}^{p}-v_{n-1}^{p} v_{n}^{-1} v_{n+1} & \\
x_{n, i}=x_{n, i-1}^{p} & \text { for } \quad i>1 \quad \text { and } \quad i \not \equiv 1 \quad \bmod (n-1) \\
x_{n, i}=x_{n, i-1}^{p}-v_{n-1}^{b_{n, 1}} v_{n}^{p^{i}-p^{i-1}+1} & \text { for } \quad i>1, \quad \text { and } \quad i \equiv 1 \quad \bmod (n-1)
\end{array}
$$

where

$$
b_{n, i}=\frac{\left(p^{i-1}-1\right)\left(p^{n}-1\right)}{p^{n-1}-1} \quad \text { for } \quad i \equiv 1 \quad \bmod (n-1)
$$

The $a_{n, i}$ are defined by

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
a_{1,0}=1 & \\
a_{1, i}=i+2 & \text { for } p=2 \quad \text { and } \quad i \geq 1 \\
a_{i, 1}=i+1 & \text { for } p>2 \quad \text { and } \quad i \geq 1 \\
a_{2,0}=1, & \\
a_{2, i}=p^{i}+p^{i-1}-1 & \text { for } p>2 \quad \text { and } \quad i \geq 1 \quad \text { or } p=2 \quad \text { and } \quad i=1 \\
a_{2, i}=3 \cdot 2^{i-1} & \text { for } p=2 \text { and } i>1 \\
a_{n, 0}=1 & \text { for } n>2 \\
a_{n, 1}=p, & \\
a_{n, i}=p a_{n, i-1} & \text { for } i>1 \quad \text { and } \quad i \not \equiv 1 \quad \bmod (n-1)
\end{array}
$$

and

$$
a_{n, i}=p a_{n, i}+p-1 \quad \text { for } i>1 \quad \text { and } \quad i \equiv 1 \quad \bmod (n-1)
$$

This is Theorem 5.10 of Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1], to which we refer the reader for the proof.

Now we need to compute the subquotient $E_{2}^{1,0}$ of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{n}^{1}\right)$. It is clear that the summand of (ii) above is in the image of $d_{1}$ and that ker $d_{1}$ is generated by elements of the form $\frac{x_{n+1, i}^{i}}{v_{1}^{i}}$ for $s \geq 0$. Certain of these elements for $s>0$ are not in ker $d_{1}$; e.g., we saw in 5.2 .6 that $d_{1}\left(\frac{x_{1, i}}{8}\right) \neq 0$. More generally we find $d_{1}\left(\frac{x_{n+1, i_{s}}}{v_{n}^{i}}\right) \neq 0$ iff $s=1$ and $p^{i}<j \leq a_{n+1, i}$ (see Miller and Wilson [3]), so we have
5.2.14. Corollary. The $v_{n}$-torsion summand of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ is generated by the elements listed in 5.2.13(i) for $s>0$ with (when $s=1$ ) $\frac{x_{n+1, i}}{v_{n}^{i}} \quad$ replaced by $\frac{x_{n+1, i}}{v_{n}^{0}}$.

Now we consider the $k(n)_{*}$-free summand $E_{\infty}^{0,1} \subset \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$. We assume $n>1$ ( $n=1$ is the subject of 5.2 .2 ); 5.2.11 tells us that $E_{\infty}^{0,1}$ has rank $n+1$ for $p>2$ and $n+2$ for $p=2$. We need to determine the image of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$. To show that an element in the former is not divisible by $v_{n}$ we must show that it has a nontrivial image in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$. The elements $h_{i} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{n}^{0}\right)$ clearly are in the image of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ and have nontrivial images in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$. The elements $\zeta_{n}$ and $\rho_{n}$ are more complicated. The formula given in 5.2.11 for $\zeta_{2}$ shows

that $v_{2}^{1+p} \zeta_{2}$ pulls back to $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ and projects to $v_{3} h_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{3}\right)$. This element figures in the proof of 5.2.13 and in the computation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ to be described in Section 4.

The formula of Moreira [1] for a representative of $\zeta_{n}$ is

$$
T_{n}=\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq k \leq n} u_{2 n-k}^{p^{k-i}} t_{j}^{p^{n-i}} c\left(t_{k-j}\right)^{p^{n-i+j}}
$$

where the $u_{n+i} \in M_{n}^{0}$ are defined by

$$
u_{n}=v_{n}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{0 \leq i \leq k} u_{n+i} v_{n+k-i}^{p^{i}}=0 \quad \text { for } k>0
$$

One sees from 5.2.16 that $u_{n+i-1} v_{n}^{\left(p^{i}-1\right) /(p-1)} \in B P_{*} / I_{n}$ so $\widehat{T}_{n}=v_{n}^{\left(p^{n}-1\right) /(p-1)} T_{n} \in$ $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$. In 5.2.15 the largest power of $v_{n}^{-1}$ occurs in the term with $i=j=$ $k=1$; in $T_{n}$ this term is $v_{n}^{\left(p^{n}-1\right) /(p-1)} u_{2 n-1} t_{1}^{p^{n-1}}$ and its image in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$ is $(-1)^{n+1} v_{n+1}^{\left(p^{n-1}-1\right) /(p-1)} h_{n-1}$.

The formula of Moreira [3] for a representative $U_{n}$ of $\rho_{n}$ is very complicated and we will not reproduce it. From it one sees that $v_{n}^{2^{2 n}-1+2^{n-1}} U_{n} \in B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ reduces to $v_{n+1}^{2^{2 n-1}-1} t_{1}^{2^{n-1}} \in B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n+1}$.

Combining these results gives
5.2.17. Theorem. The $k(n)_{*}$-free quotient $E_{\infty}^{0,1}$ of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ for $n \geq 1$ is generated by $h_{i} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, p^{i} q}$ for $0 \leq i \leq n-1, \hat{\zeta}=v_{n}^{\left(p^{n}-1\right) /(p-1)} \zeta_{n}$, and (for $p=2) \hat{\rho}_{n}=v_{n}^{2^{2 n}+2^{n-1}-1} \rho_{n}$. The imagas of $\hat{\zeta}_{n}$ and $\hat{\rho}_{n}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n+1}\right)$ are $(-1)^{n+1} v_{n+1}^{\left(p^{n-1}-1\right) /(p-1)} h_{n-1}$ and $v_{n+1}^{2^{2 n-1}-1} h_{n-1}$, respectively.

# 3. $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{1}\right)$ and the $J$-Homomorphism 

In this section we complete the calculation of $\operatorname{Ext}\left(M^{1}\right)$ begun with 5.2.6 and describe the behavior of the resulting elements in the chromatic spectral sequence and then in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. Then we will show that the elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (and, for $p=2, \operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{3}$ ) detect the image of the homomorphism $J: \pi_{*}(S O) \rightarrow \pi_{*}^{2}(1.1 .12)$. This proof will include a discussion of Bernoulli numbers. Then we will compare these elements in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence with corresponding elements in the Adams spectral sequence.

The $\theta$ we want is the one defining the multiplicative formal group law (A2.1.4) $x+y+x y$. An easy calculation shows $\exp (z)=e^{z}-1$ so

This denominator $j_{2 k}$ is computable by a theorem of von Staudt proved in 1845; references are given in Milnor and Stasheff [5]. The result is that $p \mid j_{2 k}$ iff $(p-1) \mid 2 k$ and that if $p^{i}$ is the highest power of such a prime which divides $2 k$ then $p^{i+1}$ is the highest power of $p$ dividing $j_{2 k}$.
