Our strategy for proving (b) is to make lowdimensional computations by brute force (more precisely by comparison with the Adams spectral sequence) and then transport this information to higher dimensions by means of a map $\alpha: \Sigma^{8} M(2) \rightarrow M(2)$ which induces multiplication by $v_{1}^{4}$ in $B P$ homology. [For an odd prime $p$ there is a map $\alpha: \Sigma^{q} M(p) \rightarrow M(p)$ inducing multiplication by $v_{1} . v_{1}^{4}$ is the smallest power of $v_{1}$ for which such a map exists at $p=2$.]

To prove (a), recall (5.2.2) that $\operatorname{Ext}\left(v_{1}^{-1} B P_{*} /(2)\right)=K(1)_{*}\left[h_{0}, \rho_{1}\right] /\left(\rho_{1}^{2}\right)$ with $h_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,2}$ and $\rho_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,0}$. We will determine the image of $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} /(2)\right)$ in this group. The element $u$ maps to $v_{1}^{4} \rho_{1}$. [Our representative of $u$ differs from that of $v_{1}^{4} \rho_{1}$ given in 5.2 .2 by an element in the kernel of this map. We choose this $u$ because it is the $\bmod (2)$ reduction of $y_{4} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,8}\left(B P_{*}\right)$.] It is clear that the image contains the summand described in (a). If the image contains $v_{1}^{-1} h_{0}^{s}$ or $v_{1}^{4-t} h_{0}^{2} \rho_{1}$ for any $t>0$, then it also contains that element times any positive power of $h_{0}$. One can show then that such a family of elements in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} /(2)\right)$ would contradict the edge theorem, 5.1.23.

To prove (b) we need some simple facts about $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ in dimensions $\leq 8$ which can be read off the Adams spectral sequence (3.2.11). First we have $\eta^{3}=4 \nu$ in $\pi_{3}\left(S^{0}\right)$. This means $h_{0}^{3} x$ must be killed by a differential in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $M(2)$ for any permanent cycle $x$. Hence we get $d_{3}\left(v_{1}^{2}\right)=h_{0}^{3}$ and $d_{3}\left(v_{1}^{3}\right)=v_{1} h_{0}^{3}$. Next, if we did not have $\pi_{2}(M(2))=\mathbf{Z} /(4)$ then $v_{1} \in \pi_{1}(M(2))$ would extend to a map $\Sigma^{2}(M(2)) \rightarrow M(2)$ and by iterating it we could show that all powers of $v_{1}$ are permanent cycles, contradicting the above.

Now suppose we can show that $v_{1}^{4}$ and $u$ are permanent cycles representing elements of order 2 in $\pi_{*}(M(2))$, i.e., maps $S^{n} \rightarrow M(2)$ which extend to self-maps $\Sigma^{n} M(2) \rightarrow M(2)$. Then we can iterate the resulting $\alpha: \Sigma^{8} M(2) \rightarrow M(2)$ and compare with the map extending $u$ to generalize the low-results above to all of (b).

A simple calculation with the Adams spectral sequence shows that $\pi_{7}(M(2))$ and $\pi_{8}(M(2))$ both have exponent 2 and contain elements representing $u$ and $v_{1}^{4}$, respectively, so we have both the desired self-maps.

# 4. $\mathrm{Ext}^{2}$ and the Thom Reduction 

In this section we will describe $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ and what is known about its behavior in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. We will not give all the details of the calculation; they can be found in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1] for odd primes and in Shimomura [1] for $p=2$. The main problem is to compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ and the map $d_{e}^{*}$ from it to $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{3}\right)$. From this will follow (5.4.4) that the $\gamma_{t} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ are nontrivial for all $t>0$ if $p$ is odd. (We are using the notation of 5.1.19.) They are known to be permanent cycles for $p \geq 7$ (1.3.18).

We will also study the map $\Phi$ from $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ to $E_{2}^{2, *}$ of the Adams spectral sequence as in 5.2 .8 to show that most of the elements in the latter group, since they are not $\operatorname{im} \Phi$, cannot be permanent cycles (5.4.7). The result is that $\operatorname{im} \Phi$ is generated by

$$
\left\{\Phi\left(\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}-1}\right), \Phi\left(\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}}\right): n \geq 1\right\}
$$

and a certain finite number of other generators. It is known that for $p=2$ the $\Phi\left(\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}-1}\right)$ are permenet cycles. They are the $\eta_{n+2} \in \Pi_{p^{n+2}}^{\#}$ constructed by Mahowald [6] using Brown-Gitler spectra. For odd primes it follows that some element closely resembling $\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}-i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq p^{n}-1$ is a nontrivial permanent cycle (5.4.9) and there is a similar more complicated result for $p=2$ (5.4.10).

For $p=2, \Phi\left(\beta_{2^{n} / 2^{n}}\right)=b_{n+1}^{2}$ is known to be a permanent cycle iff there is a framed $\left(2^{n+2}-2\right)$-manifold with Kervaire invariant one (Browder [1]), and such are known to exist for $0 \leq n \leq 4$ (Barratt et al. [2]). The resulting element in $\pi_{2^{i+1}-2}$ is known as $\theta_{j}$ and its existence is perhaps the greatest outstanding problem in homotopy theory. It is known to have certain ramifications in the EHP sequence (1.5.29).

For odd primes the situation with $\Phi\left(\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}}\right)$ is quite different. We showed in Ravenel [7] that this element is not a permanent cycle for $p \geq 5$ and $n \geq 1$, and that $\beta_{p^{n} / p^{n}}$ itself is not a permanent cycle in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $p \geq 3$ and $n \geq 1$; see 6.4.1.

To compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ with the chromatic spectral sequence we need to know $E_{\infty}^{0,2}$, $E_{\infty}^{1,1}$, and $E_{\infty}^{0}$. The first vanishes by 5.2.1; the second is given by 5.3.5 for $p>2$ and 5.3.6 for $p=2$. For odd primes $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M^{1}\right)=E_{1}^{1,1}$ vanishes in positive dimensions; for $p=2$ it gives elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ which are products of $\alpha_{1}$ with generators in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. The main problem then is to compute $E_{1}^{0,2}=\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$. We use the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow M_{1}^{1} \rightarrow M^{2} \xrightarrow{p} M^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

and our knowledge of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$ (5.2.13). The method of 5.1.17 requires us to recognize nontrivial elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$. This group is not completely known but we have enough information about it to compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$. We know $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{2}^{0}\right)$ by 5.2.11, and in proving 5.2.13 one determines the image of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$ in it. Hence we know all the elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(M_{1}^{1}\right)$ which are annihilated by $v_{1}$, so any other element whose product with some $v_{1}^{i}$ is one of these must be nontrivial.

To describe $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ we need some notation from 5.2.13. We treat the odd primary case first. There we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{2,0}=v_{2} \\
& x_{2,1}=v_{2}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} v_{2}^{-1} v_{3} \\
& x_{2,2}=x_{2,1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} v_{2}^{p^{2}-p+1}-v_{1}^{p^{2}+p-1} v_{2}^{p^{2}-2 p} v_{3}, \quad \text { and } \\
& x_{2, i}=x_{2, i-1}^{p}-2 v_{1}^{b_{2, i}} v_{2}^{(p-1) p^{i-1}+1} \quad \text { for } i \geq 3
\end{aligned}
$$

where $b_{2, i}=(p+1)\left(p^{i-1}-1\right)$. Also $a_{2,0}=1$ and $a_{2, i}=p^{i}+p^{i-1}-1$ for $i \geq 1$. Then
5.4.1. ThEOREM (Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1]). For odd primes $p, \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ is the direct sum of cyclic p-groups generated by
(i) $\frac{x_{2, i}^{s}}{p^{k+1} v_{1}^{s}}$ with $p \nmid s, j \geq 1, k \geq 0$ such that $p^{k} \mid j$ and $j \leq a_{2, i-k}$ and either $p^{k+1} \nmid j$ or $a_{i-k-1}<j$; and
(ii) $\frac{1}{p^{k+1} v_{1}^{s}}$ for $k \geq 0, p^{k} \mid j$, and $j \geq 1$.

Note that $s$ may be negative.

For $p=2$ we define $x_{2, i}$ as above for $0 \leq i \leq 2, x_{2, i}=x_{2, i-1}^{2}$ for $i \geq 3, a_{2,0}=1$, $a_{2,1}=2$, and $a_{2, i}=3 \cdot 2^{i-1}$ for $i \geq 2$. We also need $x_{1,0}=v_{1}, x_{1,1}=v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}$, and $x_{1, i}=x_{1, i-1}^{2}$ for $i \geq 2$. In the following theorem we will describe elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ as fractions with denominators involving $x_{1, i}$, i.e., with denominators which are not monomials. These expressions are to be read as shorthand for sums of fractions with monomial denominators. For example, in $\frac{1}{8 x_{1,1}}$ we multiply numerator and denominator by $x_{1,1}$ to get $\frac{x_{1,1}}{8 x_{1,1}^{2}}$. Now $x_{1,1}^{2} \equiv v_{1}^{4} \bmod (8)$ so we have

$$
\frac{1}{8 x_{1,1}}=\frac{v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}}{8 v_{1}^{4}}=\frac{1}{8 v_{1}^{2}}+\frac{v_{2}}{2 v_{1}^{5}}
$$

5.4.2. ThEOREM (Shimomura [1]). For $p=2, \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{2}\right)$ is the direct sum of cyclic 2-groups generated by
(i) $\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 v_{1}}, \frac{x_{2,1}^{2}}{2 v_{1}^{2}}, \frac{x_{2,2}^{2}}{2 v_{1}^{2}}$, and $\frac{x_{2,2}^{2}}{8 x_{11}}$ for $s$ odd, $j=1$ or 2 and $k=1,3,4,5$, or $6(k=2$ is excluded because $\beta_{4 s / 2}$ is divisible by 2 );
(ii) $\frac{x_{2, i}^{2}}{2 v_{1}^{2}}$ for $s$ odd, $i \geq 3, j \leq a_{2, i}$, and either $j$ is odd or $a_{2, i-1}<j$;
(iii) $\frac{x_{2, j}^{2}}{2^{k+1} v_{1}^{2} x^{k}}$ for $s$ odd, $j, k \geq 1, i \geq 3$, and $a_{2, i-k-1}<j 2^{k} \leq a_{2, i-k}$;
(iv) $\frac{x_{2, i}^{2}}{2^{k+2} x_{1, k}^{2}}$ for $s$ odd $i \geq 3, k \geq 1$, $j$ odd and $\geq 1$, and $2^{k} j \leq a_{2, i-k-1}$; and
(v) $\frac{1}{2 v_{1}^{2}}, \frac{1}{2^{k+2} x_{1, k}^{2}}$ for $j$ odd and $\geq 1$ and $k \geq 1$.

This result and the subsequent calculation of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ for $p=2$ were obtained independently by S. A. Mitchell.

These two results give us $E_{1}^{2,0}$ in the chromatic spectral sequence. The image of $d_{1}$ is the summand of 5.4.1(ii) and 5.4.2(v) and, for $p=2$, the summand generated by $\beta_{1}$; this is the same $d_{1}$ that we needed to find $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (5.2.6). We know that $\operatorname{im} d_{2}=0$ since its source, $E_{2}^{0,1}$, is trivial by 5.2.1. The problem then is to compute $d_{1}: E_{1}^{2,0} \rightarrow E_{1}^{3,0}$. Clearly it is nontrivial on all the generators with negative exponent $s$. The following result is proved for $p>2$ as lemma 7.2 in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1] and for $p=2$ in section 4 of Shimomura [1].
5.4.3. Lemma. In the chromatic spectral sequence, $d_{1}: E_{1}^{2,0} \rightarrow E_{1}^{3,0}$ is trivial on all of the generators listed in 5.4.1 and 5.4.2 except the following:
(i) all generators with $s<0$;
(ii) $\frac{x_{2, i}}{p v_{1}^{2}}$ with $p^{i}<j \leq a_{2, i}$, and $i \geq 2$, the image of this generator being $\frac{-v_{2}^{p^{i-1}}}{p v_{1}^{j-p^{i}} v_{2}^{p^{i-1}}} ;$ and
(iii) (for $p=2$ only) $\frac{x_{2,2}}{8 x_{1,1}}$, whose image is $\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 v_{1} v_{2}}$.

From this one easily read off both the structure of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ and the kernel of $\alpha: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{3}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$, i.e., which Greek letter elements of the $\gamma$-family are trivial. We treat the latter case first. The kernel of $\alpha$ consists of $\operatorname{im} d_{1} \oplus \operatorname{im} d_{2} \oplus \operatorname{im} d_{3}$. For $p=2$ we know that $\gamma_{1} \in \operatorname{im} d_{2}$ by 5.1.22. $d_{2}$ for $p>2$ and $d_{3}$ for all primes are trivial because $E_{2}^{1,1}$ (in positive dimensions) and $E_{3}^{0,2}$ are trivial by 5.3.5 and 5.2.1, respectively.
5.4.4. Corollary. The kernel of $\alpha: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{3}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (5.1.18) is generated by $\gamma_{p^{i} / p^{i}, j}$ for $i \geq 1$ with $1 \geq j \geq p^{i}-1$ for $p>2$ and $1 \leq j \leq p^{i}$ for $p=2$;

and (for $p=2$ only) $\gamma_{1}$ and $\gamma_{2}$. In particular $0 \neq \gamma_{t} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ for all $t>0$ if $p>2$ and for all $t>2$ if $p=2$.
5.4.5. Corollary.
(a) For $p$ odd, $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is the direct sum of cyclic p-groups generated by $\beta_{s p^{i} / j, 1+\phi(i, j)}$ for $s \geq 1, p \nmid s, j \geq 1, i \geq 0$, and $\phi(i, j) \geq 0$ where $\phi(i, j)$ is the largest integer $k$ such that $p^{k} \mid j$ and

$$
j \leq \begin{cases}a_{2, i-k} & \text { if } s>1 \text { or } k>0 \\ p^{i} & \text { if } s=1 \text { and } k=0\end{cases}
$$

This generator has order $p^{1+\phi(i, j)}$ and internal dimension $2\left(p^{2}-1\right) s p^{i}-2(p-1) j$. It is the image under $\alpha$ (5.1.18) of the element $\frac{x_{2, i}^{s}}{p^{1+\phi(i, j)} v_{1}^{t}}$ of 5.4.1.
(b) For $p=2, \operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is the direct sum of cyclic 2-groups generated by $\alpha_{1} \bar{\alpha}_{t}$, where $\bar{\alpha}_{t}$ generates $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,2 t}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ for $t \geq 1$ and $t \neq 2$ (see 5.2.6), and by $\beta_{s 2^{i} / j, 1+\phi(i, j)}$ for $s \geq 1$, $s$ odd, $j \geq 1, i \geq 0$, and $\phi(i, j) \geq 0$ where

$$
\phi(i, j)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } 2 \mid j \text { and } a_{2, i-1}<j \leq a_{2, i} \\ 0 & \text { if } j \text { is odd and } j \leq a_{2, i} \\ 2 & \text { if } j=2 \text { and } i=2 \\ k \geq 2 & \text { if } j \equiv 2^{k-1} \bmod \left(2^{k}\right), j \leq a_{2, i-k}, \text { and } i \geq 3 \\ k \geq 1 & \text { if } 2^{k} \mid j, a_{2, i-k-1}<j \leq a_{2, i-k}, \text { and } i \geq 3 \\ -1 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

unless $s=1$, in which case $a_{2, i}$ is replaced by $2^{i}$ in cases above where $\phi(i, j)=0$, $\phi(2,2)=1$, and $\beta_{1}$ is omitted. The order, internal dimension, and definition of this generator are as in (a).

For example when $p=2, i=3$ and $s$ is odd with $s>1$, we have generators

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\beta_{8 s / j, 2} & =\frac{x_{2,2}^{2 s}}{4 v_{1}^{j}} & \text { for } j=2,4,6 \\
\beta_{8 s / j} & =\frac{x_{2,2}^{2 s}}{2 v_{1}^{j}} & \text { for } 1 \leq j \leq 12 \text { and } j \neq 2,4,6
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

but $\beta_{8 / j}$ is not defined for $9 \leq j \leq 12$. Similarly when $p>2, i=4$ and $s$ is prime to $p$ with $s>1$, we have generators

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\beta_{p^{4} s / p^{2}, 3} & =\frac{x_{2,4}^{s}}{p^{3} v_{1}^{p^{2}}} \\
\beta_{p^{4} s / j, 2} & =\frac{x_{2,4}^{s}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{j}} & \text { for } p \mid j, j \neq p^{2} \text { and } j \leq p^{3}+p^{2}-1 \\
\beta_{p^{4} s / j} & =\frac{x_{2,4}^{s}}{p v_{1}^{j}} & \text { for other } j \leq p^{4}+p^{3}-1
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

but $\beta_{p^{4} / j}$ is not defined for $p^{4}<j \leq p^{4}+p^{3}-1$.
Next we study the Thom reduction map $\Phi$ from $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ to $E_{2}^{2, *}$ in the classical Adams spectral sequence. This map on Ext ${ }^{1}$ was discussed in 5.2.8. The group $E_{2}^{2, *}$ was given in 3.4.1 and 3.4.2. The result is

5.4.6. Theorem. The generators of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ listed in 5.4.5 map to zero under the Thom reduction map $\Phi: \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ with the following exceptions.
(a) (S. A. Mitchell). For $p=2$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(\alpha_{1}^{2}\right) & =h_{1}^{2}, \quad \Phi\left(\alpha_{1} \alpha_{4 / 4}\right)=h_{1} h_{3} \\
\Phi\left(\beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}}\right) & =h_{j+1}^{2} \quad \text { for } j \geq 1 \\
\Phi\left(\beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}-1}\right) & =h_{1} h_{j+2} \quad \text { for } j \geq 2 \\
\Phi\left(\beta_{4 / 2,2}\right) & =h_{2} h_{4} \quad \text { and } \quad \Phi\left(\beta_{8 / 6,2}\right)=h_{2} h_{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) (Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1]). For $p>2 \Phi\left(\beta_{p^{j} / p^{j}}\right)=-b_{j}$ for $j \geq 0$; $\Phi\left(\beta_{p^{j} / p^{j}-1}\right)=h_{0} h_{j+1}$ for $j \geq 1$, and $\Phi\left(\beta_{2}\right)= \pm k_{0}$.

Proof. We use the method of 5.2.8. For (a) we have to consider elements of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(N^{1}\right)$ as well as $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{2}\right)$. Recall (5.3.6) that the former is spanned by $\frac{v_{1}^{i} \rho_{1}}{2}$ for odd $s \geq 5$ and $\frac{v_{1}^{i} t_{1}}{2}$ for odd $s \geq 1$. We are looking for elements with $I$-adic filtration $\geq 0$, and the filtrations of $t_{1}$ and $\rho_{1}$ are 0 and -4 , respectively. Hence we need to consider only $\frac{v_{1}^{2} \rho_{1}}{2}$ and $\frac{v_{1} t_{1}}{2}$, which give the first two cases of (a).

The remaining cases come from $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{2}\right)$. The filtration of $x_{2, i}$ is $p^{i}$ so $\beta_{i / j, k}$ has filtration $i-j-k$, and this number is positive in all cases except those indicated above. We will compute $\Phi\left(\beta_{2 / 2}\right)$ and $\Phi\left(\beta_{4 / 2,2}\right)$, leaving the other cases of (a) and (b) to the reader. [The computation of $\Phi\left(\beta_{1}\right)$ and $\Phi\left(\beta_{2}\right)$ for $p>2$ were essentially done in 5.1.20.] Using the method of 5.1.20(a), we find that $\beta_{2 / 2}$ reduces to $\frac{v_{2} t_{1}^{2}}{v_{1}} \bmod (2)$, which in turn reduces to $t_{1}^{2} \mid t_{1}^{2} \bmod I_{2}$, which maps under $\Phi$ to $h_{2}^{2}$. Similarly, $\beta_{4 / 2,2}$ reduces to $\frac{v_{2}^{4} t_{1}^{4}}{v_{1}}+\frac{v_{2}^{4}\left(t_{1}^{2}+v_{1} t_{1}\right)}{v_{1}^{2}} \bmod (2)$ and to $v_{2}^{2} t_{1}^{2}\left|t_{1}^{2}+t_{1}^{8}\right| t_{1}^{2} \bmod I_{2}$, which maps under $\Phi$ to $h_{2} h_{4}$.

This result limits the number of elements in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{2}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ which can be permanent cycles. As remarked above (5.2.8), any such element must correspond to one having Novikov filtration $\leq 2$. Theorem 5.4.6 tells us which elements in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)^{2}$ map nontrivially to the Adams spectral sequence. Now we need to see which elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ correspond to elements of Adams filtration 2. This amounts to looking for elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(N^{1}\right)$ with $I$-adic filtration 1. From 5.2.8 we see that $\alpha_{2 / 2}$ and $\alpha_{4 / 4}$ for $p=2$ have $I$-adic filtration 0 , so $\alpha_{2}$ and $\alpha_{4 / 3}$ have filtration 1 and correspond to $h_{0} h_{2}$ and $h_{0} h_{3}$, respectively. More generally, $\alpha_{t}$ for all primes has filtration $t-1$ and therefore corresponds to an element with Adams filtration $\geq t$. Hence we get
5.4.7. Corollary. Of the generators of $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{*}}^{2}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z}(p))$ listed in 3.4.1 and 3.4.2, the only ones which can be permanent cycles in the Adams spectral sequence are
(a) for $p=2, h_{0}^{2}, h_{0} h_{2}, h_{0} h_{3}, h_{j}^{2}$ for $j \geq 1, h_{1} h_{j}$ for $j \geq 3, h_{2} h_{4}$, and $h_{2} h_{5}$; and
(b) for $p>2, a_{0}^{2}, b_{j}$ for $j \geq 0, a_{1}, a_{0} h_{1}$ for $p=3, h_{0} h_{j}$ for $j \geq 2$, and $k_{0}$.

Part (a) was essentially proved by Mahowald and Tangora [8], although their list included $h_{3} h_{6}$. In Barratt, Mahowald, and Tangora [1] it was shown that $h_{2} h_{5}$ is not a permanent cycle. It can be shown that $d_{3}\left(\beta_{8 / 6,2}\right) \neq 0$, while $\beta_{4 / 2,2}$ is a

permanent cycle. The elements $h_{0}^{2}, h_{0} h_{2}, h_{0} h_{3}$ for $p=2$ and $a_{0}^{2}, a_{1}, a_{0} h_{1}(p=3)$ for odd primes are easily seen to be permanent cycles detecting elements in $\operatorname{im} J$.

This leaves two infinite families to be considered: the $b_{j}$ (or $h_{j+1}^{2}$ for $p=2$ ) for $j \geq 0$ and the $h_{0} h_{j}$ (or $h_{1} h_{j+1}$ for $p=2$ ) for $j \geq 1$. These are dealt with in 3.4.4 and 4.4.22. In Section 6.4 we will generalize the latter to
5.4.8. ThEOREM. (a) In the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $p \geq 3$,

$$
d_{2 p-1}\left(\beta_{p^{j} / p^{j}}\right) \equiv \alpha_{1} \beta_{p^{j-1} / p^{j-1}}^{p} \neq 0
$$

modulo a certain indeterminacy for $j \geq 1$.
(b) In the Adams spectral sequence for $p \geq 5, b_{j}$ is not a permanent cycle for $j \geq 1$.

The restriction on $p$ in 5.4.8(b) is essential; we will see (6.4.11) that $b_{2}$ is a permanent cycle for $p=3$.

The proof of 3.4.4(b) does not reveal which element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ detects the constructed homotopy element. 5.4.5 implies that $\operatorname{Ext}^{2 .\left(1+p^{j}\right) q}$ is a $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$ vector space of rank $[j / 2]$; i.e., it is spanned by elements of the form $\delta_{0}(x)$ for $x \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right)$. (This group is described in 5.2.14 and 5.2.17.) The $x$ that we want must satisfy $v_{1}^{p^{j-1}-2} x=\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p^{j}}\right)$. ( $\delta_{0}$ and $\delta_{1}$ are defined in 5.1.2.) The fact that the homotopy class has order $p$, along with 2.3.4, means that $x$ itself [as well as $\left.\delta_{0}(x)\right]$ is a permanent cycle, i.e., that the map $f: S^{m} \rightarrow S^{0}$ for $m=q\left(1+p^{j}\right)-3$ given by 3.3.4(d) fits into the diagram
![img-50.jpeg](img-50.jpeg)
where $M(p)$ denotes the $\bmod (p)$ Moore spectrum and the vertical maps are inclusion of the bottom cell and projection onto the top cell. Now $\tilde{f}$ can be composed with any iterate of the map $\alpha: \Sigma^{q} M(p) \rightarrow M(p)$ inducing multiplication by $v_{1}$ in $B P$-homology, and the result is a map $S^{m+q i} \rightarrow S^{0}$ detected by $\delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{i} x\right)$. This gives
5.4.9. ThEOREM. (R. Cohen [3]) Let $\zeta_{j-1} \in \pi_{m-1}^{S}$ be the element given by 3.4.4(d), where $m=\left(1+p^{j}\right) q-2$. It is detected by an element $y_{j-1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{3,2+m}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ congruent to $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p^{j-1} / p^{j-1}}$ modulo elements of higher I-adic filtration (i.e., modulo $\operatorname{ker} \Phi$ ). Moreover for $j \geq 3$ and $0<i<p^{j-1}-p^{j-2}-p^{j-3} \zeta_{j-1, i} \in\left\langle\zeta_{j-1}, p, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle \subset$ $\pi_{m-1+q i}^{S}$, obtained as above, is nontrivial and detected by an element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{3,2+m+q i}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ congruent to $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p^{j-1} / p^{j-1}-i}$.

The range of $i$ in 5.4.9(b) is smaller than in (a) because $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p^{j} / p^{j-1}+p^{j-2}}=0$ for $j \geq 2$. To see this compute the coboundary of $\frac{v_{1} v_{2}^{p^{j}}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{i p+1 / p^{j-2}}}$.

The analogous results for $p=2$ are more complicated. $\eta_{j} \in \pi_{2^{j}}^{S}$ is not known to have order 2 , so we cannot extend it to a map $\Sigma^{2^{j}} M(2) \rightarrow S^{0}$ and compose with elements in $\pi_{*}(M(2))$ as we did in the odd primary case above. In fact, there is reason to believe the order of $\eta_{j}$ is 4 rather than 2 . To illustrate the results one might expect, suppose $\beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}}$ is a permanent cycle represented by an element of order 2. (This would imply that the Kervaire invariant element $\theta_{j+1}$ exists; see

1.5.29.) Then we get a map $f: \Sigma^{2^{j+2}-2} M(2) \rightarrow S^{0}$ which we can compose with the elements of $\pi_{*}(M(2))$ given by 5.3.13. In particular, $f v_{1}^{4 k}$ would represent $\beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}-4 k}$, which is nontrivial for $k<2^{j-2}, f v_{1}$ would represent $\beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}-1}$ (i.e., would be closely related to $\eta_{j+2}$ ), and $2 f v_{1}$ would represent $\alpha_{1}^{2} \beta_{2^{j} / 2^{j}}$, leading us to expect $\eta_{j+2}$ to have order 4 . Since the elements of 5.3 .13 have filtration $\leq 3$, the composites with $f$ would have filtration $\leq 5$. Hence their nontriviality in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is not obvious.

Now 5.3.13 describes 12 families of elements in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} /(2)\right)$ (each family has the form $\left\{v_{1}^{4 k} x: k \geq 0\right\}$ ) which are nontrivial permanent cycles: the six shown in 5.3.14 and their products with $u$. Since we do not know $\theta_{j+1}$ exists we cannot show that these are permanent cycles directly. However, five of them $\left(v_{1} \alpha_{1}, v_{1} \alpha_{1}^{2}, u v_{1}\right.$ $u v_{1} \alpha_{1}$, and $u v_{1} \alpha_{1}^{2}$ ) can be obtained by composing $v_{1}$ with $\bmod (2)$ reductions of permanent cycles in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$, and hence correspond to compositions of $\eta_{j+1}$ with elements in $\pi_{*}^{S}$. Four of these five families have been shown to be nontrivial by Mahowald [10] without use of the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence.
5.4.10. TheOREM (Mahowald [10]). Let $\mu_{8 k+1} \in \pi_{8 k-1}^{S}$ be the generator constructed by Adams [1] and detected by $\alpha_{4 k+1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,8 k+2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$, and let $\rho_{k} \in \pi_{8 k-1}^{S}$ be a generator of $\operatorname{im} J$ detected by a generator $y_{4 k}$ of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1,8 k}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. Then for $0<k<2^{j-4}$ the compositions $\mu_{8 k+1} \eta_{j}, \eta \mu_{8 k+1} \eta_{j}, \rho_{k} \eta_{j}$, and $\eta \rho_{k} \eta_{j}$ are essential. They are detected in the Adams spectral sequence respectively by $P^{k} h_{1}^{2} h_{j}, P^{k} h_{1}^{3} h_{j}$, $P^{k-1} c_{0} h_{j}$, and $P^{k-1} c_{0} h_{1} h_{j}$.

This result provides a strong counterexample to the "doomsday conjecture", which says that for each $s \geq 0$, only finitely many elements of $E_{2}^{s, s}$ are permanent cycles (e.g., 1.5.29 is false). This is true for $s=0$ and 1 by the Hopf invariant one theorem, 1.2.12, but 5.4.10 shows it is false for each $s \geq 2$.

# 5. Periodic Families in $\mathrm{Ext}^{2}$ 

This section is a survey of results of other authors concerning which elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ are nontrivial permanent cycles. These theorems constitute nearly all of what is known about systematic phenomena in the stable homotopy groups of spheres.

First we will consider elements various types of $\beta$ 's. The main result is 5.5.5. Proofs in this area tend to break down at the primes 2 and 3. These difficulties can sometimes be sidestepped by replacing the sphere with a suitable torsion-free finite complex. This is the subject of 5.5.6 $(p=3)$ and 5.5.7 $(p=2)$.

In 5.5.8 we will treat decomposable elements in Ext ${ }^{2}$.
The proof of Smith [1] that $\beta_{t}$ is a permanent cycle for $p \geq 5$ is a model for all results of this type, the idea being to show that the algebraic construction of $\beta_{t}$ can be realized geometrically. There are two steps here. First, show that the first two short exact sequences of 5.1.2 can be realized by cofiber sequences, so there is a spectrum $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ with $B P_{*}\left(M\left(p, v_{1}\right)\right)=B P_{*} / I_{2}$, denoted elsewhere by $V(1)$. [Generally if $I=\left(q_{0}, q_{1}, \ldots, q_{n-1}\right) \in B P_{*}$ is an invariant regular ideal and there is a finite spectrum $X$ with $B P_{*}(X)=B P_{*} / I$ then we will denote $X$ by $M\left(q_{0}, \ldots, q_{n-1}\right)$.] This step is quite easy for any odd prime and we leave the details to the reader. It cannot be done for $p=2$. Easy calculations (e.g., 5.3.13) show that the map $S^{2} \rightarrow M(2)$ realizing $v_{1}$ does not have order 2 and hence does not extend to the required map $\Sigma^{2} M(2) \rightarrow M(2)$. Alternatively, one could

show that $H^{*}\left(M\left(2, v_{1}\right) ; \mathbf{Z} /(2)\right)$, if it existed, would contradict the Adem relation $S q^{2} S q^{2}=S q^{3} S q^{1}$.

The second step, which fails for $p=3$, is to show that for all $t>0, v_{1}^{t} \in$ $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ is a permanent cycle in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$. Then 2.3.4 tells us that $\beta_{t}=\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{t}\right)$ detects the composite

$$
S^{2 t\left(p^{2}-1\right)} \xrightarrow{v_{2}^{t}} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow \Sigma^{q+1} M(p) \rightarrow S^{q+2}
$$

where $q=2 p-2$ as usual. One way to do this is to show that the third short exact sequence of 5.1.2 can be realized, i.e., that there is a map $\beta: \Sigma^{2\left(p^{2}-1\right)} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow$ $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ realizing multiplication by $v_{2}$. This self-map can be iterated $t$ times and composed with inclusion of the bottom cell to realize $v_{2}^{t}$. To construct $\beta$ one must first show that $v_{2}$ is a permanent cycle in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$. One could then show that the resulting map $S^{2\left(p^{2}-1\right)} \rightarrow M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ extends cell by cell to all of $\Sigma^{2\left(p^{2}-1\right)} M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ by obstruction theory. However, this would be unnecessary if one knew that $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ were a ring spectrum, which it is for $p \geq 5$ but not for $p=3$. Then one could smash $v_{2}$ with the identity on $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ and compose with the multiplication, giving

$$
\Sigma^{2\left(p^{2}-1\right)} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \wedge M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow M\left(p, v_{1}\right)
$$

which is the desired map $\beta$.
Showing that $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum, i.e., constructing the multiplication map, also involves obstruction theory, but in lower dimensions than above.

We will now describe this calculation in detail and say what goes wrong for $p=3$. We need to know $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$ for $t-s \leq 2\left(p^{2}-1\right)$. This deviates from $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{P_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))$ only by the class $v_{2} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0,2\left(p^{2}-1\right)}$. It follows from 4.4.8 that there are five generators in lower dimensions, namely $1 \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0,0}$, $h_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, q}, b_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2, p q}, h_{0} b_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{3(p+1) q}, h_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1, p q}$, and $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}=0$ for $t-s=2\left(p^{2}-1\right)-1$ so $v_{2}$ is a permanent cycle for any odd prime.

To show $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum we need to extend the inclusion $S^{0} \rightarrow$ $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ to a suitable map from $X=M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \wedge M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$. We now assume $p=5$ for simplicity. Then $X$ has cells in dimensions $0,1,2,9,10,11,18,19$, and 20 , so obstructions occur in $\operatorname{Ext}^{s, t}$ for $t-s$ one less than any of these numbers. The only one of these groups which is nontrivial is $\operatorname{Ext}^{0,0}=\mathbf{Z} /(p)$. In this case the obstruction is $p$ times the generator (since the 1-cells in $X$ are attached by maps of degree $p$ ), which is clearly zero. Hence for $p \geq 5 M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum and we have the desired self-map $\beta$ needed to construct the $\beta_{t}$ 's.

However, for $p=3$ obstructions occur in dimensions 10 and 11, where the Ext groups are nonzero. There is no direct method known for calculating an obstruction of this type when it lies in a nontrivial group. In Toda [1] it is shown that the nontriviality of one of these obstructions follows from the nonassociativity of the multiplication of $M(3)$.

We will sketch another proof now. If $M\left(3, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum then each $\beta_{t}$ is a permanent cycle, but we will show that $\beta_{4}$ is not. In $\operatorname{Ext}^{6,84}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ one has $\beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{4}$ and $\beta_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{2}$. These elements are actually linearly independent, but we do not need this fact now. It follows from 4.4.22 that $d_{5}\left(\beta_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{2}\right)= \pm \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{4} \beta_{3 / 3} \neq 0$. The nontriviality of this element can be shown by computing the cohomology of $P_{*}$ in this range.

Now $\beta_{2}^{3} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{6,84}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is a permanent cycle since $\beta_{2}$ is. If we can show

$$
\beta_{2}^{3}= \pm \beta_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{2} \pm \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{4}
$$

then $\beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{4}$ and hence $\beta_{4}$ will have to support a nontrivial $d_{5}$. We can prove 5.5 .1 by reducing to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right)$. By 5.1.20 the images of $\beta_{1}, \beta_{2}$, and $\beta_{4}$ in this group are $\pm b_{10}, \pm v_{2} b_{10} \pm k_{0}$, and $\pm v_{2}^{3} b_{10}$, respectively, and the image of $\beta_{3 / 3}$ is easily seen to be $\pm b_{11}$. Hence the images of $\beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{4}, \beta_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{2}$, and $\beta_{2}^{3}$ are $\pm v_{2}^{3} b_{10}^{3}, \pm b_{10} b_{11}^{2}$ and $\pm v_{2}^{3} b_{10}^{3} \pm k_{0}^{3}$ respectively. Thus 5.5 .1 will follow if we can show $k_{0}^{3}= \pm b_{10} b_{11}^{2}$. (At any larger prime $p$ we would have $k_{0}^{p}=0$.) $k_{0}$ is the Massey product $\pm\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle$. Using A1.4.6 we have up to sign

$$
\begin{aligned}
k_{0}^{2} & =\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle \\
& =\left\langle h_{0}\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle \\
& =\left\langle\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{1}\right\rangle h_{1}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle \\
& =\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle h_{1}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle \\
& =g_{0} b_{11}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
k_{0}^{3} & =\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{1}\right\rangle b_{11} \\
& =\left\langle h_{0}\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{1}\right\rangle, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle b_{11} \\
& =\left\langle\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{0}\right\rangle h_{1}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle b_{11} \\
& =\left\langle h_{0}, h_{0}, h_{0}\right\rangle\left\langle h_{1}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle b_{11} \\
& =b_{10} b_{11}^{2} \quad \text { as claimed. }
\end{aligned}
$$

5.5.2. ThEOREM (Smith [1]). Let $p \geq 5$
(a) $\beta_{t} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2, q((p+1) t-1)}$ is a nontrivial permanent cycle in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for all $t>0$.
(b) There is a map $\beta: \Sigma^{2\left(p^{2}-1\right)} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ inducing multiplication by $v_{2}$ in $B P$-homology. $\beta_{t}$ detects the composite

$$
S^{2 t\left(p^{2}-1\right)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 t\left(p^{2}-1\right)} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \xrightarrow{\beta^{t}} M\left(p, v_{1}\right) \rightarrow S^{2 p}
$$

(c) $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum.
5.5.3. ThEOREM (Behrens and Pemmaraju [1]). (a) For $p=3$ the complex $V(1)$ admits a self-map realizing multiplication by $v_{2}^{9}$ in $B P$-homology.
(b) The element $\beta_{t} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2, q((p+1) t-1)}$ is a nontrivial permanent cycle in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $t$ congruent to $0,1,2,5$, or 6 modlulo 9.

To realize more general elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ one must replace $I_{2}$ in the above construction by an invariant regular ideal. For example a self-map $\beta$ of $M\left(p^{2}, v_{1}^{p}\right)$ inducing multiplication by $v_{2}^{p^{2}}$ (such a map does not exist) would show that $\beta_{t p^{2} / p, 2}$ is a permanent cycle for each $t>0$. Moreover we could compose $\beta^{t}$ on the left with maps other than the inclusion of the bottom cell to get more permanent cycles. $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, v_{1}^{p}\right)\right)$ contains $p v_{1}^{i}$ for $0 \leq i<p$, and each of these is a permanent cycle and using it we could show that $\beta_{t p^{2} / p-i}$ is a permanent cycle.

It is easy to construct $M\left(p^{i+1}, v_{1}^{s p^{i}}\right)$ for $s>0$ and $p$ odd. Showing that it is a ring spectrum and constructing the appropriate self-map is much harder. The following result is a useful step.
5.5.4. ThEOREM. (a) (Mahowald [11]). $M\left(4, v_{1}^{4 t}\right)$ is a ring spectrum for $t>0$.
(b) (Oka [7]). $M\left(2^{i+2}, v_{1}^{2^{i} t}+2^{i+1} t v_{1}^{2^{i} t-3} v_{2}\right)$ is a ring spectrum for $i \geq 2$ and $t \geq 2$.
(c) (Oka [7]). For $p>2, M\left(p^{i+1} v_{1}^{p^{i} t}\right)$ is a ring spectrum for $i \geq 0$ and $t \geq 2$ [Recall $M\left(p, v_{1}\right)$ is a ring spectrum for $p \geq 5$ by 5.5.2(c).]

Note that $M\left(p^{i}, v_{1}^{j}\right)$ is not unique; the theorem means that there is a finite ring spectrum with the indicated $B P$-homology.

Hence we have a large number of four-cell ring spectra available, but it is still hard to show that the relevant power of $v_{2}$ is a permanent cycle in $\mathrm{Ext}^{0}$.

From 5.3.13 one can construct a map $\Sigma^{48 t-4} X \rightarrow \Sigma^{48 t-10} M(2)$ which is $v_{1} \eta^{2}$ on the bottom cell and such that the top cell is detected by $v_{1}^{3} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} /(2)\right)$. Now compose this with the extension of $\beta_{8 t / 4} \Sigma^{48 t-10} M(2) \rightarrow S^{0}$ given by 5.5.4(a). The resulting map $g: \Sigma^{48 t-4} X \rightarrow S^{0}$ is $\alpha_{1}^{2} \beta_{8 t / 3}$ on the bottom cell and the top cell is detected by $\beta_{8 t}$. Hence this map agrees with $f$ modulo higher Novikov filtration. If $\alpha_{1}^{2} \beta_{8 t / 3} \neq 0 \in \operatorname{Ext}^{4}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ it follows that the bottom cell on $f$ is detected by that element. [It is likely that $\alpha_{1}^{3} \beta_{8 t / 3}=0$ (this is true for $t=1$ ), so the differential on $\beta_{8 t}$ is not a $d_{3}$.]
(c) As in (b) Mahowald [12] shows the projection of $\beta_{8 t+1}$ in $\pi_{48 t}^{S}$ is nontrivial. To show that $\alpha_{1} \alpha_{4 / 4} \beta_{8 t / 3}$ detects our element if it is nontrivial we need to make a low-dimensional computation in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $M\left(2, v_{1}^{4}\right)$ where we find that $v_{1}^{3} v_{2} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0,12}\left(B P_{*} /\left(2, v_{1}^{4}\right)\right)$ supports a differential hitting $v_{1} \alpha_{4 / 4} \alpha_{1}^{2} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{3,14}$. It follows that ${ }_{1} \sigma \eta \in \pi_{11}\left(M\left(2, v_{1}^{4}\right)\right)$ extends to a map

$\Sigma^{10} X \rightarrow M\left(2, v_{1}^{4}\right)$ with the top cell detected by $v_{2} v_{1}^{3}$. Suspending $48 t-10$ times and composing with the extension of $\beta_{8 t / 4}$ to $\Sigma^{48 t-10} M\left(2, v_{1}^{4}\right)$ gives the result.

Now we consider products of elements in Ext ${ }^{1}$.
5.5.8. Theorem. Let $\bar{\alpha}_{t}$ be a generator of $\operatorname{Ext}^{1, q t}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (see 5.2.6).
(a) (Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1]). For $p>2, \bar{\alpha}_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{t}=0$ for all $s, t>0$.
(b) For $p=2$
(i) If $s$ or $t$ is odd and neither is 2 then $\bar{\alpha}_{1} \bar{\alpha}_{t}=\alpha_{1} \bar{\alpha}_{s+t-1} \neq 0$.
(ii) $\bar{\alpha}_{2}^{2}=\beta_{2 / 2}$.
(iii) $\bar{\alpha}_{4}^{2}=\beta_{4 / 4}+\beta_{3}$.
(Presumably, all other products of this sort vanish.)
In an earlier version (iii) read $\bar{\alpha}_{4}^{2}=\beta_{4 / 4}$ instead of the above. This error was brought to my attention by Hans-Werner Henn in 2016.

Proof. Part (a) is given in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1] as theorem 8.18. The method used is similar to the proof of (b) below.

For (b)(i) assume first that $s$ and $t$ are both odd. Then $\bar{\alpha}_{s}=\frac{v_{1}^{s}}{2}$ and the $\bmod (2)$ reduction of $\bar{\alpha}_{t}$ is $v_{1}^{t-1} t_{1}$. Hence $\bar{\alpha}_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{t}=\frac{v_{1}^{s+t-1}}{2} t_{1}=\bar{\alpha}_{s+t-1} \bar{\alpha}_{1}$.

For $s$ odd and $t=2$ we have

$$
\alpha_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{2}=\frac{v_{1}^{s}}{2}\left(t_{1}^{2}+v t_{1}\right)=d\left(\frac{v_{1}^{s-t} v_{2}}{2}\right) \quad \text { so } \quad \bar{\alpha}_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{2}=0
$$

For $t$ even and $t>2$, recall that

$$
\bar{\alpha}_{t}=\frac{x^{t / 2}}{4 t} \quad \text { where } \quad x=v_{1}^{2}-4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}
$$

and

$$
d(x)=8 \rho
$$

where

$$
\rho \equiv v_{1}^{-2} v_{2} t_{1}-v_{1}^{-1}\left(t_{2}+t_{1}^{3}\right)+2\left(v_{1} t_{1}+v_{1}^{-2} t_{1}^{4}+v_{1}^{-2} t_{1} t_{2}+v_{1}^{-3} v_{2} t_{1}^{3}\right) \quad \bmod (4)
$$

Hence for even $t>2$ the $\bmod (2)$ reduction of $\bar{\alpha}_{t}$ is $v_{1}^{t-2} \rho$ and for odd $s$

$$
\bar{\alpha}_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{t}=\frac{v_{1}^{s+t-2}}{2} \rho=\frac{v_{1} x^{(s+t-1) / 2}}{2} \rho
$$

Since

$$
d\left(\frac{v_{1} x^{(s+t+1) / 2}}{2^{3}(s+t+1)}\right)=\frac{v_{1}}{2} x^{(s+t-1) / 2} \rho+\frac{x^{(s+t+1) / 2} t_{1}}{2^{2}(s+t+1)}
$$

so $\bar{\alpha}_{s} \bar{\alpha}_{t}=\bar{\alpha}_{1} \bar{\alpha}_{s+t-1}$ as claimed.
For (ii) we have $\bar{\alpha}_{2}^{2}=\frac{v_{1}^{2}\left(t_{1}^{2}+v_{1} t_{1}\right)}{4}$. The coboundary of $\frac{v_{1}^{4}}{2^{5}}+\frac{v_{1}^{-2} v_{2}^{2}}{2}$ shows this is cohomologous to $\beta_{2 / 2}$.

For (iii) we have $\alpha_{4 / 4}^{2} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2,16}$ which is $(\mathbf{Z} /(2))^{3}$ generated by $\alpha_{1} \alpha_{7}, \beta_{3}$, and $\beta_{4 / 4} . \alpha_{1} \alpha_{7}$ is not a permanent cycle (5.3.7) so $\alpha_{4 / 4}^{2}$ must be a linear combination of $\beta_{4 / 4}$ and $\beta_{3}$. Their reductions $\bmod I_{2}, t_{1}^{4} \mid t_{1}^{4}$ and $v_{2} t_{1}^{4} \mid t_{1}$, are linearly independent so it suffices to compute $\alpha_{4 / 4}^{2} \bmod I_{2}$. The $\bmod I_{2}$ reduction of $\alpha_{4 / 4}$ is $t_{1}^{4}+v_{2} t_{1}$, so the result follows.

# 6. Elements in Ext ${ }^{3}$ and Beyond 

We begin by considering products of elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ with those in Ext ${ }^{1}$ and Ext ${ }^{2}$. If $x$ and $y$ are two such elements known to be permanent cycles, then the nontriviality of $x y$ in Ext implies that the corresponding product in homotopy is nontrivial, but if $x y=0$ then the homotopy product could still be nontrivial and represent an element in a higher Ext group. The same is true of relations among and divisibility of products of permanent cycles; they suggest but do not imply (without further argument) similar results in homotopy.

Ideally one should have a description of the subalgebra of $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ generated by Ext ${ }^{1}$ and Ext ${ }^{2}$ for all primes $p$. Our results are limited to odd primes and fall into three types (see also 5.5.8). First we describe the subgroup of Ext ${ }^{3}$ generated by products of elements in Ext ${ }^{1}$ with elements of order $p$ in Ext ${ }^{2}$ (5.6.1). Second we note that certain of these products are divisible by nontrivial powers of $p(5.6 .2)$. These two results are due to Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1], to which we refer for most of the proofs.

Our third result is due to Oka and Shimomura [9] and concerns products of certain elements in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ (5.4.4-5.4.7). They show further that in certain cases when a product of permanent cycles is trivial in Ext ${ }^{4}$, then the corresponding product in homotopy is also trivial.

This brings us to $\gamma$ 's and $\delta$ 's. Toda [1] showed that $\gamma_{t}$ is a permanent cycle for $p \geq 7$ (1.3.18), but left open the case $p=5$. In Section 7.5 we will make calculations to show that $\gamma_{3}$ does not exist. We sketch the argument here. As remarked in Section 4.4, 4.4.22 implies that $d_{33}\left(\alpha_{1} \beta_{5 / 5}^{4}\right)=\beta_{1}^{21}$ (up to a nonzero scalar). Calculations show that $\alpha_{1} \beta_{5 / 5}^{4}$ is a linear combination of $\beta_{1}^{3} \gamma_{3}$ and $\beta_{1}\left\langle\alpha_{1} \beta_{3}, \beta_{4}, \gamma_{2}\right\rangle$. Hence if the latter can be shown to be a permanent cycle then we must have $d_{33}\left(\gamma_{3}\right)=\beta_{1}^{18}$. Each of the factors in the above Massey product is a permanent cycle, so it suffices to show that the products $\alpha_{1} \beta_{3} \beta_{4} \in \pi_{323}\left(S^{0}\right)$ and $\beta_{4} \gamma_{2} \in \pi_{619}\left(S^{0}\right)$ both vanish. Our calculation shows that both of these stems have trivial 5-torsion.

To construct $\delta_{t}$ one could proceed as in the proof of 5.5.2. For $p \geq 7$ there is a finite complex $V(3)$ with $B P_{*}(V(3))=B P_{*} / I_{4}$. According to Toda [1] it is a ring spectrum for $p \geq 11$. Hence there is a self-map realizing multiplication by $v_{4}$ iff there is a corresponding element in $\pi_{*}(V(3))$. We will show (5.6.13) that the group $\operatorname{Ext}^{2 p-1,2\left(p^{4}+p-2\right)}\left(B P_{*} / I_{4}\right)$ is nonzero for all $p \geq 3$, so it is possible that $d_{2 p-1}\left(v_{4}\right) \neq 0$.

The following result was proved in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1] as theorem 8.6.
5.6.1. ThEOREM. Let $m \geq 0, p \nmid s, s \geq 1,1 \leq j \leq a_{2, m}$ (where $a_{2, m}$ is as in 5.4.1) for $s>1$ and $1 \leq j \leq p^{m}$ for $s=1$. Then $\alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{m} / j} \neq 0$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ iff one of the following conditions holds
(i) $j=1$ and either $s \not \equiv-1 \bmod (p)$ or $s \equiv-1 \bmod \left(p^{m+2}\right)$.
(ii) $j=1$ and $s=p-1$.
(iii) $j>1+a_{2, m-\nu(j-1)-1}$.

In case (ii), we have $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p-1}=-\gamma_{1}$ and for $m \geq 1,2 \alpha_{1} \beta_{(p-1) p^{m}}=-\gamma_{p^{m} / p^{m}, p^{m}}$. The onfy linear relations among these classes are

$$
\alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{2} / p+2}=s \alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{2}-1}
$$

and

$$
\alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{2 m+2} / 2+a_{2, m+1}}=2 s \alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{2 m+2}-p^{m}} \quad \text { for } \quad m \geq 1
$$

This result implies that some of these products vanish and therefore certain Massey products (A1.4.1) are defined. For example, $\alpha_{1} \beta_{(t p-1) p^{m}}=0$ if $t>1$ and $p^{m+2} \nmid t$ so we have Massey products such as $\left\langle\beta_{2 p-1}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle$ represented up to nonzero scalar multiplication by

$$
\frac{v_{2}^{2 p} t_{1}}{p v_{1}^{1+p}}+\frac{v_{2}^{2 p-1} t_{1}^{2}-2 v_{2}^{p-1} v_{3} t_{1}}{p v_{1}}
$$

This product has order $p^{2}$ but many others do not. For example, $\alpha_{1} \beta_{p / 2}=0$ and $\left\langle\beta_{p / 2}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle$ is represented by

$$
\frac{2 v_{1}^{p-1} v_{2}^{p} t_{1}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}-\frac{v_{2}^{p} t_{1}^{2}}{p v_{1}^{2}}
$$

which has order $p^{2}$ and $p\left\langle\beta_{p / 2}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle=\alpha_{1} \beta_{p}$ up to nonzero scalar multiplication. Similarly, one can show

$$
\alpha_{1} \beta_{p^{2}}=p\left\langle\beta_{p^{2} / 2}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle=p^{2}\left\langle\beta_{p^{2} / 3}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}\right\rangle
$$

The following results were 2.8(c) and 8.17 in Miller, Ravenel, and Wilson [1].
5.6.2. Theorem. With notation as in 5.6.1, if $\alpha_{1} \beta_{s p^{m} / j} \neq 0$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$, then it is divisible by at least $p^{i}$ whenever $0<i \leq m$ and $j \geq a_{2, m-i}$.
5.6.3. Theorem. With notation as above and with $t$ prime to $p$, $\alpha_{s p^{k} / k+1} \beta_{t p^{m} / j}=s \alpha_{1} \beta_{t p^{m} / j-s p^{k}+1}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{3}\left(B P_{*}\right)$.

Now we consider products of elements in $\mathrm{Ext}^{2}$, which are studied in Oka and Shimomura [9].
5.6.4. Theorem. For $p \geq 3$ we have $i j \beta_{s} \beta_{t}=s t \beta_{i} \beta_{j}$ in $\mathrm{Ext}^{4}$ for $i+j=s+t$.

Proof. To compute $\beta_{s} \beta_{t}$ we need the $\bmod I_{2}$ reduction of $\beta_{t}$, which was computed in 5.1.20. Hence we find $\beta_{s} \beta_{t}$ is represented by

$$
\frac{-t v_{2}^{s+t-1} b_{10}+\binom{t}{2} v_{2}^{s+t-2} k_{0}}{p v_{1}}
$$

Now let

$$
u_{m}=\frac{v_{2}^{m} v_{1}^{p-1} t_{1}^{p}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p}}-\frac{v_{2}^{m} t_{2}}{p v_{1}^{2}}+\frac{k v_{2}^{k-1}}{p v_{1}}\left(t_{1}^{p} t_{2}-t_{1}^{2 p+1}\right)
$$

A routine computation gives

$$
d\left(\frac{t}{2} u_{s+t-1}\right)=\frac{s v_{2}^{s+t-1} b_{10}}{p v_{1}}-\frac{s}{2}(s+t-1) v_{2}^{s+t-2} k_{0}
$$

and hence $\beta_{s} \beta_{t}$ is represented by $-\frac{s t}{2} \frac{v_{2}^{s+t-2} k_{0}}{p v_{1}}$ and the result follows.
The analogous result in homotopy for $p \geq 5$ was first proved by Toda [7]. The next three results are 6.1, A, and B of Oka and Shimomura [9].

5.6.5. ThEOREM. For $p \geq 3$ the following relations hold in $\operatorname{Ext}^{4}$ for $s, t>0$.
(i) $\beta_{s} \beta_{t p^{k} / r}=0$ for $k \geq 1, t \geq 2$ and $r<a_{2, k}$.
(ii) $\beta_{s} \beta_{t p^{2} / p, 2}=\beta_{s+t\left(p^{2}-p\right)} \beta_{t p / p}$.
(iii) For $t, k \geq 2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{2} \beta_{t p^{k} / a_{2, k}} & =\beta_{s+(t p-1)\left(p^{k-1}-p\right)} \beta_{t p^{2} / a_{2,2}} \\
& =(t / 2) \beta_{s+(t p-1) p^{k-1}-(2 p-1) p} \beta_{2 p^{2} / a_{2,2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

5.6.6. ThEOREM. For $p \geq 5,0<r \leq p$, with $r \leq p-1$ if $t=1$, the element $\beta_{s} \beta_{t p / r}$ is trivial in $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ if one of the following conditions holds.
(i) $r \leq p-2$.
(ii) $r=p-1$ and $s \not \equiv-1 \bmod (p)$.
(iii) $r=p-1$ or $p$ and $t \equiv 0 \bmod (p)$.
5.6.7. Theorem. For $p \geq 5, s \not \equiv 0$ or $1, t \not \equiv 0 \bmod (p)$, and $t \geq 2$, the elements $\beta_{s} \beta_{t p / p}$ and $\beta_{s} \beta_{t p^{2} / p, 2}$ are nontrivial.

Now we will display the obstruction to the existence of $V(4)$, i.e., a nontrivial element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2 p-1,2\left(p^{2}+p-2\right)}\left(B P_{*} / I_{4}\right)$. This group is isomorphic to the corresponding Ext group for $P_{*}=P\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots\right]$, the dual to the algebra of Steenrod reduced powers. To compute this Ext we use a method described in Section 3.5. Let $P(1)_{*}=P /\left(t_{1}^{p^{2}}, t_{2}^{p}, t_{3}, \ldots\right)$, the dual to the algebra generated by $P^{1}$ and $P^{p}$. We will give $P_{*}$ a decreasing filtration so that $P(1)_{*}$ is a subalgebra of $E_{0} P_{*}$. We let $t_{1}, t_{2} \in F_{0}$, and $t_{i}^{p^{2}}, t_{i+1}^{p}, t_{i+2} \in F^{\left(p^{i}-1\right) /(p-1)}$ for $i \geq 1$. Then as an algebra we have

$$
E_{0} P_{*}=P(1)_{*} \otimes T\left(t_{i+2,0}, t_{i+1,1}\right) \otimes P\left(t_{i, 2}\right)
$$

where $i \geq 1, t_{i, j}$ corresponds to $t_{i}^{p^{j}}$, and $T$ denotes the truncated polynomial algebra of height $p$. Let $R$ denote the tensor product of the second two factors in 5.6.8. Then

$$
P(1)_{*} \rightarrow E_{0} P_{*} \rightarrow R
$$

is an extension of Hopf algebras (A1.1.5) for which there is a Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.14) converging to

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} P_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))
$$

with

$$
E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{P(1)_{*}}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \operatorname{Ext}_{R}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))\right)
$$

The filtration of $P_{*}$ gives a spectral sequence (A1.3.9) converging to

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{P^{*}}(Z /(p), Z /(p))
$$

with

$$
E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{E_{0} P_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), \mathbf{Z} /(p))
$$

In the range of dimensions we need to consider, i.e., for $t-s \leq 2\left(p^{4}-1\right) E x t_{R}$ is easy to compute. We leave it to the reader to show that it is the cohomology of the differential $P(1)_{*}$-comodule algebra

$$
E\left(h_{12}, h_{21}, h_{30}, h_{13}, h_{22}, h_{31}, h_{40}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{12}, b_{21}, b_{30}\right)
$$

with $d\left(h_{22}\right)=h_{12} h_{13}, d\left(h_{31}\right)=h_{21} h_{13}$, and $d\left(h_{40}\right)=h_{30} h_{13}$. In our range this cohomology is

$$
E\left(h_{12}, h_{21}, h_{30}, h_{13}\right) / h_{13}\left(h_{12}, h_{21}, h_{30}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{12}, b_{21}, b_{30}\right)
$$

where the nontrivial action of $P(1)$ is given by

$$
P^{1} h_{30}=h_{21}, \quad P^{p} h_{21}=h_{12}, \quad \text { and } \quad P^{p} b_{30}=b_{21}
$$

We will not give all of the details of the calculations since our aim is merely to find a generator of $\operatorname{Ext}_{*}^{2 p-1,2\left(p^{2}+p-2\right)}$. The element in question is

$$
b_{30}^{p-3} h_{11} h_{20} h_{12} h_{21} h_{30}
$$

We leave it to the interested reader to decipher this notation and verify that it is a nontrivial cocycle.

# CHAPTER 6 

## Morava Stabilizer Algebras

In this chapter we develop the theory which is the mainspring of the chromatic spectral sequence. Let $K(n)_{*}=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{n}, v_{n}^{-1}\right]$ have the $B P_{*}$-module structure obtained by sending all $v_{i}$, with $i \neq n$ to 0 . Then define $\Sigma(n)$ to be the Hopf algebra $K(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} K(n)_{*}$. We will describe this explicitly as a $K(n)_{*}$-algebra below. Its relevance to the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence is the isomorphism $(6.1 .1)$

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}\right)
$$

which is input needed for the chromatic spectral sequence machinery described in Section 5.1. In combination with 6.2.4, this is the result promised in 1.4.9. Since $\Sigma(n)$ is much smaller than $B P_{*}(B P)$, this result is a great computational aid. We will prove it along with some generalizations in Section 1, following Miller and Ravenel [5] and Morava [2].

In Section 2 we study $\Sigma(n)$, the $n$th Morava stabilizer algebra. We will show (6.2.5) that it is closely related to the $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$-group algebra of a pro- $p$-group $S_{n}$ (6.2.3 and 6.2.4). $S_{n}$ is the strict automorphism group [i.e., the group of automorphisms $f(x)$ having leading term $x$ ] of the height $n$ formal group law $F_{n}$ (see A2.2.18 for a description of the corresponding endomorphism ring). We use general theorems from the cohomology of profinite groups to show $S_{n}$ is either $p$-periodic (if $(p-1) \mid n$ ) or has cohomological dimension $n^{2}(6.2 .10)$.

In Section 3 we study this cohomology in more detail. The filtration of 4.3.24 leads to a May spectral sequence studied in 6.3.3 and 6.3.4. Then we compute $H^{1}$ (6.3.12) and $H^{2}$ (6.3.14) for all $n$ and $p$. The section concludes with computations of the full cohomology for $n=1(6.3 .21), n=2$ and $p>3(6.3 .22), n=2$ and $p=3(6.3 .24), n=2$ and $p=2(6.3 .27)$, and $n=3, p>3(6.3 .32)$.

The last two sections concern applications of this theory. In Section 4 we consider certain elements $\beta_{p^{\prime} / p^{\prime}}$ in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ for $p>2$ analogous to the Kervaire invariant elements $\beta_{2^{\prime} / 2^{\prime}}$ for $p=2$. We show (6.4.1) that these elements are not permanent cycles in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. A crucial step in the proof uses the fact that $S_{p-1}$ has a subgroup of order $p$ to detect a lot of elements in Ext. Theorem 6.4.1 provides a test that must be passed by any program to prove the Kervaire invariant conjecture: it must not generalize to odd primes!

In Section 5 we construct ring spectra $T(m)$ satisfying $B P_{*}(T(m))=$ $B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right]$ as comodules. The algebraic properties of these spectra will be exploited in the next chapter. We will show (6.5.5, 6.5.6, 6.5.11, and 6.5.12) that its Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term has nice properties.

## 1. The Change-of-Rings Isomorphism

Our first objective is to prove

6.1.1. Theorem (Miller and Ravenel [5]). Let $M$ be a $B P_{*}(B P)$-comodule annihilated by $I_{n}=\left(p, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n-1}\right)$, and let $\bar{M}=M \otimes_{B P_{*}} K(n)_{*}$. Then there is a natural isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, v_{n}^{-1} M\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, \bar{M}\right)
$$

Here $v_{n}^{-1} M$ denotes $v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} M$, which is a comodule (even though $v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*}$ is not) by 5.1.6.

This result can be generalized in two ways. Let

$$
E(n)_{*}=v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} /\left(v_{n+i}: i>0\right)
$$

and

$$
E(n)_{*}(E(n))=E(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} E(n)_{*}
$$

It can be shown, using the exact functor theorem of Landweber [3], that $E(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(X)$ is a homology theory on $X$ represented by a spectrum $E(n)$ with $\pi_{*}(E(n))=E(n)_{*}$, and with $E(n)_{*}(E(n))$ being the object defined above. We can generalize 6.1.1 by replacing $\Sigma(n)$ with $E(n)_{*}(E(n))$ and relaxing the hypothesis on $M$ to the condition that it be $I_{n}$-nil, i.e., that each element (but not necessarily the entire comodule) be annihilated by some power of $I_{n}$. For example, $N^{n}$ of Section 5.1 is $I_{n}$-nil. Then we have
6.1.2. Theorem (Miller and Ravenel [5]). Let $M$ be $I_{n}$-nil and let $\bar{M}=M \otimes_{B P_{*}} E(n)_{*}$. Then there is a natural isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, v_{n}^{-1} M\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{E(n)_{*}(E(n))}\left(E(n)_{*}, \bar{M}\right)
$$

There is another variation due to Morava [2]. Regard $B P_{*}$ as a $\mathbf{Z} / 2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$ graded object and consider the homomorphism $\theta: B P_{*} \rightarrow \mathbf{Z} /(p)$ given by $\theta\left(v_{n}\right)=1$ and $\theta\left(v_{i}\right)=0$ for $i \neq n$. Let $I \subset B P_{*}$ be $\operatorname{ker} \theta$ and let $V_{\theta}$ and $V T_{\theta}$ denote the $I$-adic completions of $B P_{*}$ and $B P_{*}(B P)$. Let $E_{\theta}=V_{\theta}\left(v_{n+i}: i>0\right)$ and $E H_{\theta}=E_{\theta} \otimes_{V_{\theta}} V T_{\theta} \otimes_{V_{\theta}} E_{\theta}$.
6.1.3. Theorem (Morava [2]). With notation as above there is a natural isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{V T_{\theta}}\left(V_{\theta}, M\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{E H_{\theta}}\left(E_{\theta}, \bar{M}\right)
$$

where $M$ is a $V T_{\theta}$-comodule and $\bar{M}=M \otimes_{V_{\theta}} E_{\theta}$.
Of these three results only 6.1.1 is relevant to our purposes so we will not prove the others in detail. However, Morava's proof is more illuminating than that of Miller and Ravenel [5] so we will sketch it first.

Morava's argument rests on careful analysis of the functors represented by the Hopf algebroids $V T_{\theta}$ and $E H_{\theta}$. First we need some general nonsense.

Recall that a groupoid is a small category in which every morphism is invertible. Recall that a Hopf algebroid $(A, \Gamma)$ over $K$ is a cogroupoid object in the category of commutative $K$-algebras; i.e., it represents a covariant groupoid-valued functor. Let $\alpha, \beta: \mathbf{G} \rightarrow \mathbf{H}$ be maps (functors) from the groupoid $\mathbf{G}$ to the groupoid $\mathbf{H}$. Since $\mathbf{G}$ is a category it has a set of objects, $O b(\mathbf{G})$, and a set of morphisms, $\operatorname{Mor}(\mathbf{G})$, and similarly for $\mathbf{H}$.

6.1.4. Definition. The functors $\alpha, \beta: G \rightarrow H$ are equivalent if there is a map $\theta: O b(\mathbf{G}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Mor}(\mathbf{H})$ such that for any morphism $g: g_{1} \rightarrow g_{2}$ in $\mathbf{G}$ the diagram
![img-51.jpeg](img-51.jpeg)
commutes. Two maps of Hopf algebroids $a, b:(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(B, \Sigma)$ are naturally equivalent if the corresponding natural transformations of groupoid-valued functors are naturally equivalent in the above sense. Two Hopf algebroids $(A, \Gamma)$ and $(B, \Sigma)$ are equivalent if there are maps $f:(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(B, \Sigma)$ and $h:(B, \Sigma) \rightarrow(A, \Gamma)$ such that $h f$ and $f h$ are naturally equivalent to the appropriate identity maps.

Now we will show that a Hopf algebroid equivalence induces an isomorphism of certain Ext groups. Given a map $f:(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(B, \Sigma)$ and a left $\Gamma$-comodule $M$, define a $\Sigma$-comodule $f^{*}(M)$ to be $B \otimes_{A} M$ with coactions

$$
B \otimes_{A} M \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} \Gamma \otimes_{A} M \rightarrow B \otimes_{B} \Sigma \otimes_{A} M=\Sigma \otimes_{B} B \otimes_{A} M
$$

6.1.5. Lemma. Let $f:(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(B, \Sigma)$ a Hopf algebroid equivalence. Then there is a natural isomorphism $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}(A, M) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma}\left(B, f^{*}(M)\right)$ for any $\Gamma$-comodule $M$.

Proof. It suffices to show that equivalent maps induce the same homomorphisms of Ext groups. An equivalence between the maps $a, b:(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(B, \Sigma)$ is a homomorphism $\phi: \Gamma \rightarrow B$ with suitable properties, including $\phi \eta_{R}=a$ and $\phi \eta_{L}=b$. Since $\eta_{R}$ and $\eta_{L}$ are related by the conjugation in $\Gamma$, it follows that the two $A$-module structures on $B$ are isomorphic and that $a^{*}(M)$ is naturally isomorphic to $b^{*}(M)$. We denote them interchangeably by $M^{\prime}$. The maps $a$ and $b$ induce maps of cobar complexes (A1.2.11) $C_{\Gamma}(M) \rightarrow C_{\Sigma}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$. A tedious routine verification shows that $\phi$ induces the required chain homotopy.

Now we consider the functors represented by $V T_{\theta}$ and $E H_{\theta}$. Recall that an Artin local ring is a commutative ring with a single maximal ideal satisfying the descending chain condition, i.e., the maximal ideal is nilpotent. If $A$ is such a ring with finite residue field $k$ then it is $W(k)$-module, where $W(k)$ is the Witt ring of A2.2.16. Let $\operatorname{Art}_{\theta}$ denote the category of $\mathbf{Z} /\left(2\left(p^{n}-1\right)\right)$-graded Artin local rings whose residue field is an $\mathbf{F}_{p}$-algebra. Now let $m_{\theta}=\operatorname{ker} \theta \subset B P_{*}$. Then $B P_{*} / m_{\theta}^{n}$ with the cyclic grading is is object in $\mathbf{A r t}_{\theta}$, so $V_{\theta}=\varliminf_{s} B P_{*} / m_{\theta}^{n}$ is an inverse limit of such objects as is $V T_{\theta}$. For any $A \in \operatorname{Art}_{\theta}$, we can consider $\operatorname{Hom}^{c}\left(V T_{\theta}, A\right)$, the set of continuous ring homomorphisms from $V T_{\theta}$ to $A$. It is a groupoid-valued functor on $\operatorname{Art}_{\theta}$ pro-represented by $V T_{\theta}$. (We have to say "pro-represented" rather than "represented" because $V T_{\theta}$ is not in $\mathbf{A r t}_{\theta}$.)
6.1.6. Proposition. $V T_{\theta}$ pro-represents the functor lifts $_{\theta}$ from $\mathbf{A r t}_{\theta}$ to the category of groupoids, defined as follows. Let $A \in \operatorname{Art}_{\theta}$ have residue field $k$. The objects in lifts $_{\theta}(A)$ are p-typical liftings to $A$ of the formal group law over $k$ induced by the composite $B P_{*} \xrightarrow{\theta} \mathbf{F}_{p} \rightarrow k$, and morphisms in lifts $(A)$ are strict isomorphisms between such liftings.
6.1.7. Definition. Let $m_{A} \subset A$ be the maximal ideal for $A \in \operatorname{Art}_{\theta}$. Given a homomorphism $f: F \rightarrow G$ of formal group laws over $A$, let $\tilde{f}: \widetilde{F} \rightarrow \widetilde{G}$ denote their reductions $\bmod m_{A} . f$ is $a*$-isomorphism if $\tilde{f}(x)=x$.

6.1.8. Lemma. Let $F$ and $G$ be objects in lifts $_{\theta}(A)$. Then the map $\operatorname{Hom}(F, G) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}(\bar{F}, \bar{G})$ is injective.

Proof. Suppose $\bar{f}=0$, i.e., $f(x)=0 \bmod m_{A}$. We will show that $f(x) \equiv 0$ $\bmod m_{A}^{r}$ implies $f(x) \equiv 0 \bmod m_{A}^{r+1}$ for any $r>0$, so $f(x)=0$ since $m_{A}$ is nilpotent. We have

$$
G(f(x), f(y)) \equiv f(x)+f(y) \quad \bmod m_{A}^{2 r}
$$

since

$$
G(x, y) \equiv x+y \quad \bmod (x, y)^{2}
$$

Consequently,

$$
[p]_{G}(f(x)) \equiv p f(x) \quad \bmod m_{A}^{2 r} \equiv 0 \quad \bmod m_{A}^{r+1}
$$

since $p \in m_{A}$. On the other hand

$$
[p]_{G}(f(x))=f([p]_{F}(x))
$$

and we know $[p]_{F}(x) \equiv x^{p^{n}} \bmod m_{A}$ by A2.2.4. Hence $f([p]_{F}(x)) \equiv 0 \bmod m_{A}^{r+1}$ gives the desired congruence $f(x) \equiv 0 \bmod m_{A}^{r+1}$.

Now suppose $f_{1}, f_{2}: F \rightarrow G$ are $*$-isomorphisms (6.1.7) as is $g: G \rightarrow F$. Then $g f_{1}=g f_{2}$ by 6.1 .8 so $f_{1}=f_{2}$; i.e. $*$-isomorphisms are unique. Hence we can make
6.1.9. Definition. lifts $_{\theta}^{*}(A)$ is the groupoid of $*$-isomorphism classes of objects in lifts $_{\theta} A$.
6.1.10. Lemma. The functors lifts $_{\theta}$ and lifts $_{\theta}^{*}$ are naturally equivalent.

Proof. There is an obvious natural transformation $\alpha$ : lifts $_{\theta} \rightarrow$ lifts $_{\theta}^{*}$, and we need to define $\beta$ : lifts $_{\theta}^{*} \rightarrow$ lifts $_{\theta}$, of each $*$-isomorphism class. Having done this, $\alpha \beta$ will be the identity on lifts $_{\theta}^{*}$ and we will have to prove $\beta \alpha$ is equivalent (6.1.4) to the identity on lifts $\theta$.

The construction of $\beta$ is essentially due to Lubin and Tate [3]. Suppose $G_{1} \in$ lifts $_{\theta}(A)$ is induced by $\theta_{1}: B P_{*} \rightarrow A$. Using A2.1.26 and A2.2.6 one can show that there is a unique $G_{2} \in \operatorname{lifts}_{\theta}(A) *$-isomorphic to $G_{1}$ and induced by $\theta_{2}$ satisfying $\theta\left(v_{n+i}\right)=0$ for all $i>0$. We leave the details to the interested reader. As remarked above, the $*$-isomorphism from $G_{1}$ to $G_{2}$ is unique. The verification that $\beta \alpha$ is equivalent to the identity is straightforward.

To prove 6.1.3, it follows from 6.1.5 and 6.1.10 that it suffices to show $E H_{\theta}$ pro-represents lifts ${ }_{\theta}^{*}$. In the proof of 6.1.10 it was claimed that any suitable formal group law over $A$ is canonically $*$-isomorphic to one induced by $\theta: B P_{*} \rightarrow A$ which is such that it factors through $E_{\theta}$. In the same way it is clear that the morphism set of lifts $_{\theta}^{*}(A)$ is represented by $E H_{\theta}$, so 6.1.3 follows.

Now we turn to the proof of 6.1.1. We have a map $B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow \Sigma(n)$ and we need to show that it satisfies the hypotheses of the general change-of-rings isomorphism theorem A1.3.12, i.e., of A1.1.19. These conditions are
(i) the map $\Gamma^{\prime}=B P_{*}(B P) \otimes_{B P_{*}} K(n)_{*} \rightarrow \Sigma(n)$ is onto and
(ii) $\quad \Gamma^{\prime} \square_{\Sigma(n)} K(n)_{*}$ is a $K(n)_{*}$-summand of $\Gamma^{\prime}$.

Part (i) follows immediately from the definition $\Sigma(n)=K(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} \Gamma^{\prime}$. Part (ii) is more difficult. We prefer to replace it with its conjugate,

(ii) $K(n)_{*} \square_{\Sigma(n)} K(n)_{*}(B P)$ is a $K(n)_{*}$ summand of $K(n)_{*} B P$ which is defined to be $K(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P)$. Let $B(n)_{*}$ denote $v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{n}$. Then the right $B P_{*}$ module structure on $K(n)_{*}(B P)$ induces a right $B(n)_{*}$ - module structure.
6.1.12. Lemma. There is a map

$$
K(n)_{*} B P \rightarrow \Sigma(n) \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} B(n)_{*}
$$

which is an isomorphism of $\Sigma(n)$-comodules and of $B(n)_{*}$-modules, and which carries 1 to 1 .

Proof. Our proof is a counting argument, and in order to meet requirements of connectivity and finiteness, we pass to suitable "valuation rings". Thus let

$$
\begin{aligned}
k(0)_{*} & =\mathbf{Z}_{(p)} \subset K(0)_{*} \\
k(n)_{*} & =\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[v_{n}\right] \subset K(n)_{*}, \quad n>0 \\
k(n)_{*} B P & =k(n)_{*} \otimes_{B P_{*}} B P_{*}(B P) \subset K(n)_{*} B P \\
b(n)_{*} & =k(n)_{*}\left[u_{1}, u_{2}, \ldots\right] \subset B(n)_{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $u_{k}=v_{n}^{-1} v_{n+k}$.
It follows from A2.2.6 that in $k(n)_{*} B P$,

$$
\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+k}\right) \equiv v_{n} t_{k}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p^{k}} t_{k} \quad \bmod \left(\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+1}\right), \ldots, \eta_{R}\left(v_{n+k-1}\right)\right)
$$

Hence $\eta_{R}: B P_{*} \rightarrow k(n)_{*} B P$ factors through an algebra map $b(n)_{*} \rightarrow k(n)_{*} B P$. It is clear from 6.1.13 that as a right $b(n)_{*}$-module, $k(n)_{*} B P$ is free on generators $t^{\alpha}=t_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} t_{2}^{\alpha_{2}} \ldots$ where $0 \leq \alpha_{i}<p^{n}$ and all but finitely many $\alpha_{i}$ are 0 ; in particular, it is of finite type over $b(n)_{*}$.

Now define

$$
\sigma(n)=k(n)_{*} B P \otimes_{b(n)_{*}} k(n)_{*} \subset \Sigma(n)
$$

by the above remarks $\sigma(n)=k(n)_{*}\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots\right] /\left(t_{k}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p^{k}-1} t_{k}: k \geq 1\right)$ as an algebra. $\left(k(n)_{*}, \sigma(n)\right)$ is clearly a sub-Hopf algebroid of $\left(K(n)_{*}, \Sigma(n)\right)$, so $\sigma(n)$ is a Hopf algebra over the principal ideal domain $k(n)_{*}$.

The natural map $B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow \sigma(n)$ makes $B P_{*}(B P)$ a left $\sigma(n)$-comodule, and this induces a left $\sigma(n)$-comodule structure on $k(n)_{*} B P$. We will show that the latter is an extended left $\sigma(n)$-comodule.

Define a $b(n)_{*}$-linear map $f: k(n)_{*} B P \rightarrow b(n)_{*}$ by

$$
f\left(t^{\alpha}\right)= \begin{cases}1 & \text { if } \alpha=(0,0, \ldots) \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

Then $f$ satisfies the equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \bar{\eta}_{R} & =i d: b(n)_{*} \rightarrow b(n)_{*} \\
f \otimes_{b(n)_{*}} k(n)_{*} & =\varepsilon: \sigma(n) \rightarrow k(n)_{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now let $\tilde{f}$ be the $\sigma(n)$-comodule map lifting $f$ :
