Since $\psi \bar{\eta}_{R}(x)=1 \otimes \bar{\eta}_{R}(x), \psi$ is $b(n)_{*}$-linear, so $\tilde{f}$ is too. We claim $\tilde{f}$ is an isomorphism. Since both sides are free of finite type over $b(n)_{*}$ it suffices to prove that $\tilde{f} \otimes_{b(n)_{*}} k(n)$ is an isomorphism. But 6.1.14 is then reduced to
![img-53.jpeg](img-53.jpeg)
so the claim follows from unitarity of $\Delta$.
Now the map $K(n)_{*} \otimes_{k(n)_{*}} \tilde{f}$ satisfies the requirements of the lemma.
6.1.15. Corollary. $\bar{\eta}_{R}: B(n)_{*} \rightarrow K(n)_{*} \square_{\Sigma(n)} K(n)_{*} B P$ is an isomorphism of $B(n)_{*}$-modules.

Proof. The natural isomorphism

$$
B(n)_{*} \rightarrow K(n)_{*} \square_{\Sigma(n)}\left(\Sigma(n) \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} B(n)_{*}\right)
$$

is $B(n)_{*}$-linear and carries 1 to 1 . Hence
![img-54.jpeg](img-54.jpeg)
commutes, and $\bar{\eta}_{R}$ is an isomorphism.
Hence 6.1.11(ii) follows from the fact that $K(n)_{*}$ is a summand of $\Sigma(n)$, and 6.1.1 is proved. From the proof of 6.1.12 we get an explicit description of $\Sigma(n)$, namely

# 6.1.16. Corollary. As an algebra 

$$
\Sigma(n)=K(n)_{*}\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots\right] /\left(v_{n} t_{i}^{p^{n}}-v_{n}^{p^{i}} t_{i}: i>0\right)
$$

Its coproduct is inherited from $B P_{*}(B P)$, i.e., a suitable reduction of 4.3.13 holds.

## 2. The Structure of $\Sigma(n)$

To study $\Sigma(n)$ it is convenient to pass to the corresponding object graded over $\mathbf{Z} / 2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$. Make $\mathbf{F}_{p}$ a $K(n)_{*}$-module by sending $v_{n}$ to 1 , and let $S(n)=$ $\Sigma(n) \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} \mathbf{F}_{p}$. For a $\Sigma(n)$-comodule $M$ let $\bar{M}=M \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} \mathbf{F}_{p}$, which is easily seen to be an $S(n)$-comodule. The categories of $\Sigma(n)$ - and $S(n)$-comodules are equivalent and we have

### 6.2.1. Proposition. For a $\Sigma(n)$-comodule $M$,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, M\right) \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} \mathbf{F}_{p} \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{S(n)}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p}, \bar{M}\right)
$$

We will see below (6.2.5) that if we regard $S(n)$ and $\bar{M}$ as graded merely over $\mathbf{Z} /(2)$, there is a way to recover the grading over $\mathbf{Z} / 2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$. If $M$ is concentrated in even dimensions (which it is in most applications) then we can regard $\bar{M}$ and $S(n)$ as ungraded objects. Our first major result is that $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$ (ungraded) is the continuous linear dual of the $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$-group algebra of a certain profinite group $S_{n}$ to be defined presently.
6.2.2. Definition. The topological linear dual $S(n)^{*}$ of $S(n)$ is as follows. [In Ravenel [5] $S(n)^{*}$ and $S(n)$ are denoted by $S(n)$ and $S(n)_{*}$, respectively.] Let $S(n)_{(i)}$ be the sub-Hopf algebra of $S(n)$ generated by $\left\{t, \ldots, t_{i}\right\}$. It is a vector space of rank $p^{n i}$ and $S(n)=\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim } S(n)_{(i)}$. Then $S(n)^{*}=\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim } \operatorname{Hom}\left(S(n)_{(i)}, \mathbf{F}_{p}\right)$, equipped with the inverse limit topology. The product and coproduct in $S(n)$ give maps of $S(n)^{*}$ to and from the completed tensor product

$$
S(n)^{*} \widehat{\otimes} S(n)^{*}=\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim } \operatorname{Hom}\left(S(n)_{(i)} \otimes S(n)_{j}, \mathbf{F}_{p}\right)
$$

To define the group $S_{n}$ recall the $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$-algebra $E_{n}$ of A2.2.17, the endomorphism ring of a height $n$ formal group law. It is a free $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$-algebra of rank $n^{2}$ generated by $\omega$ and $S$, where $\omega$ is a primitive $\left(p^{n}-1\right)$ th root of units, $S \omega=\omega^{p} S$, and $S^{n}=p$. $S_{n} \subset E_{n}^{ \pm}$, is the group of units congruent to $1 \bmod (S)$, the maximal ideal in $E_{n} . S_{n}$ is a profinite group, so its group algebra $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\left[S_{n}\right]$ has a topology and is a profinite Hopf algebra. $S_{n}$ is also a $p$-adic Lie group; such groups are studied by Lazard [4].
6.2.3. ThEOREM. $S(n)^{*} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q} \cong \mathbf{F}_{q}\left[S_{n}\right]$ as profinite Hopf algebras, where $q=p^{n}$, $S_{n}$ is as above, and we disregard the grading on $S(n)^{*}$.

Proof. First we will show $S(n)^{*} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$, is a group algebra. According to Sweedler [1], Proposition 3.2.1, a cocommutative Hopf algebra is a group algebra iff it has a basis of group-like elements, i.e., of elements $x$ satisfying $\Delta x=x \otimes x$. This is equivalent to the existence of a dual basis of idempotent elements $\{y\}$ satisfying $y_{i}^{2}=y_{i}$, and $y_{i} y_{j}=0$ for $i \neq j$. Since $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$, is a tensor product of algebras of the form $R=\mathbf{F}_{q}[t] /\left(t^{q}-t\right)$, it suffices to find such a basis for $R$. Let $a \in \mathbf{F}_{q}^{\times}$be a generator and let

$$
r_{i}= \begin{cases}-\sum_{0<j<q}\left(a^{i} t\right)^{j} & \text { for } 0<i<q \\ 1-t^{q-1} & \text { for } i=0\end{cases}
$$

Then $\left\{r_{i}\right\}$ is such a basis, so $S(n)^{*} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$, is a group algebra.
Note that tensoring with $\mathbf{F}_{q}$ cannot be avoided, as the basis of $R$ is not defined over $\mathbf{F}_{p}$.

For the moment let $G_{n}$ denote the group satisfying $\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[G_{n}\right] \cong S(n)^{*} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$. To get at it we define a completed left $S(n)$-comodule structure on $\mathbf{F}_{q}[[x]]$, thereby defining a left $G_{n}$-action. Then we will show that it coincides with the action of $S_{n}$ as formal group law automorphisms given by A2.2.18.

We now define the comodule structure map

$$
\psi: \mathbf{F}_{q}[[x]] \rightarrow S(n) \widehat{\otimes} \mathbf{F}_{q}[[x]]
$$

to be an algebra homomorphism given by

$$
\psi(x)=\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes x^{p^{i}}
$$

where $t_{0}=1$ as usual. To verify that this makes sense we must show that the following diagram commutes.
![img-55.jpeg](img-55.jpeg)
for which we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\Delta \otimes 1) \psi(x) & =(\Delta \otimes 1) \sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes x^{p^{i}} \\
& =\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F}\left(\sum_{j-k=i} t_{j} \otimes t_{k}^{p^{i}}\right) \otimes x^{p^{i}} \\
& =\sum_{j, k \geq 0}^{F} t_{j} \otimes t_{k}^{p^{j}} \otimes x^{p^{j+k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

This can be seen by inserting $x$ as a dummy variable in 4.3.12. We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
(1 \otimes \psi) \psi(x) & =(1 \otimes \psi)\left(\sum_{j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes x^{p^{i}}\right) \\
& =\sum_{j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes\left(\sum_{j \geq 0}^{F} t_{j} \otimes x^{p^{i}}\right)^{p^{i}} \\
& =\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes t_{j}^{p^{i}} \otimes x^{p^{i+j}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equality follows from the fact that $F\left(x^{p}, y^{p}\right)=F(x, y)^{p}$. The linearity of $\psi$ follows from A2.2.21(b), so $\psi$ defines an $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$-comodule structure on $\mathbf{F}_{q}[[x]]$.

We can regard the $t_{i}$, as continuous $\mathbf{F}_{q}$-valued functions on $G_{n}$ and define an action of $G_{n}$ on the algebra $\mathbf{F}_{q}[[x]]$ by

$$
g(x)=\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} t_{i}(g) x^{p^{i}}
$$

for $g \in G_{n}$. Hence $G(x)=x$ iff $g=1$, so our representation is faithful.
We can embed $G_{n}$ in the set of all power series of the form $\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} a_{i} x^{p^{i}}$ which is $E_{n}$ by A2.2.21 so the result follows.
6.2.4. Corollary. If $M$ is an ungraded $S(n)$-comodule, then 6.2 .3 gives a continuous $S_{n}$-action on $M \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$, and

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{S(n)}^{*}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p}, M\right) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}=H_{c}^{*}\left(G_{n}, M \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}\right)
$$

where $H_{c}^{*}$ denotes continuous group cohomology.
To recover the grading on $S(n) \otimes M$, we have an action of the cyclic group of order $q-1$ generated by $\bar{\omega}^{i} \omega^{i}$ via conjugation in $E_{n}$.
6.2.5. Proposition. The eigenspace of $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$ with eigenvalue $\bar{\omega}^{i}$ is the component $S(n)_{2 i} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$ of degree $2 i$.

Proof. The eigenspace decomposition is multiplicative in the sense that if $x$ and $y$ are in the eigenspaces with eigenvalues $\bar{\omega}^{i}$ and $\bar{\omega}^{j}$, respectively, the $x y$ is in the eigenspace with eigenvalue $\bar{\omega}^{i+j}$. Hence it suffices to show that $t_{k}$ is in the eigenspace with eigenvalue $\bar{\omega}^{p^{k}-1}$.

To see this we compute the conjugation of $t_{k} S^{k} \in E_{n}$ by $\omega$ and we have $\omega^{-1}\left(t_{k} S^{k}\right) \omega=\omega^{-1} t_{k} \omega^{p^{k}} S^{k}=\omega^{p^{k}-1} t_{k} S^{k}$.

Corollary 6.2.4 enables us to apply certain results from group cohomology theory to our situation. First we give a matrix representation of $E_{n}$ over $W\left(\mathbf{F}_{q}\right)$.
6.2.6. Proposition. Let $e=\sum_{0 \leq i<n} e_{i} S^{i}$ with $e_{i} \in W\left(\mathbf{F}_{q}\right)$ be an element of $E_{n}$. Define an $n \times n$ matrix $\left(e_{i, j}\right)$ over $W\left(\mathbf{F}_{q}\right)$ by

$$
e_{i+1, j+1}= \begin{cases}e_{j-i}^{\sigma^{i}} & \text { for } i \leq j \\ p e_{j+n-i}^{\sigma^{j}} & \text { for } i>j\end{cases}
$$

Then (a) this defines a faithful representation of $E_{n}$; (b) the determinant $\left|e_{i, j}\right|$ lies in $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$.

Proof. Part (a) is straightforward. For (b) it suffices to check that $\omega$ and $S$ give determinants in $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$.

We can now define homomorphisms $c: \mathbf{Z}_{p} \rightarrow S_{n}$ and $d: S_{n} \rightarrow \mathbf{Z}_{p}$ for $p>2$, and $c: \mathbf{Z}_{2}^{\times} \rightarrow S_{n}$ and $d: \mathbf{Z}_{2}^{\times}$for $p=2$ by identifying $S_{n}$ with the appropriate matrix group. ( $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$ is to be regarded here as a subgroup of $\mathbf{Z}_{p}^{\times}$.) Let $d$ be the determinant for all primes. For $p>2$ let $c(x)=\exp (p x) I$, where $I$ is the $n \times n$ identity matrix and $x \in \mathbf{Z}_{p}$; for $p=2$ let $c(x)=x I$ for $x \in \mathbf{Z}_{2}^{\times}$.
6.2.7. ThEOREM. Let $S_{n}^{1}=\operatorname{ker} d$.
(a) If $p>2$ and $p \nmid n$ then $S_{n} \cong \mathbf{Z}_{p} \oplus S_{n}^{1}$.
(b) If $p=2$ and $n$ is odd then $S_{n} \cong S_{n}^{1} \oplus \mathbf{Z}_{2}^{\times}$.

Proof. In both cases one sees that $\operatorname{im} c$ lies in the center of $S_{n}$ (in fact $\operatorname{im} c$ is the center of $S_{n}$ ) and is therefore a normal subgroup. The composition $d c$ is multiplication by $n$ which is an isomorphism for $p \nmid n$, so we have the desired splitting.

We now describe an analogous splitting for $S(n)$. Let $A^{*}=\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[\mathbf{Z}_{p}\right]$ for $p>2$ and $A^{*}=\mathbf{F}_{2}\left[\mathbf{Z}_{2}^{\times}\right]$for $p=2$. Let $A_{*}$ be the continuous linear dual of $A$.
6.2.8. Proposition. As an algebra $A=\mathbf{F}_{p}\left[u_{1}, u_{2}, \ldots\right] /\left(u_{i}-u_{i}^{p}\right)$. The coproduct $\Delta$ is given by

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{G} \Delta\left(u_{i}\right)=\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{G} u_{i} \otimes u_{j}
$$

where $u_{0}=1$ and $G$ is the formal group law with

$$
\log _{G}(X)=\sum \frac{x^{p^{i}}}{p^{i}}
$$

Proof. Since $A \cong \mathbf{F}_{p}\left[S_{1}\right]$, this follows immediately from 6.2.3.
We can define Hopf algebra homomorphisms $c_{*}: S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q} \rightarrow A \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$ and $d_{*}: A \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q} \rightarrow S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$ dual to the group homomorphisms $c$ and $d$ defined above.

6.2.9. ThEOREM. There exist maps $c_{*}: S(n) \rightarrow A$ and $d_{*}: A \rightarrow S(n)$ corresponding to those defined above, and for $p \nmid n, S(n) \cong A \otimes B$, where $B \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$, is the continuous linear dual of $\mathbf{F}_{q}\left[S_{n}^{1}\right]$, where $S_{n}^{1}$, is defined in 6.2.7.

Proof. We can define $c_{*}$ explicitly by

$$
c_{*} t_{i}= \begin{cases}u_{i / n} & \text { if } n \mid i \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

It is straightforward to check that this is a homomorphism corresponding to the $c_{*}$ defined above. In lieu of defining $d_{*}$ explicitly we observe that the determinant of $\sum_{i \geq 0} t_{i} S^{i}$, where $t_{i} \in W\left(\mathbf{F}_{q}\right)$ and $t_{i}=t_{i}^{q}$, is a power series in $p$ whose coefficients are polynomials in the $t_{i}$ over $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$. It follows that $d_{*}$ can be defined over $\mathbf{F}_{p}$. The splitting then follows as in 6.2.7.

Our next result concerns the size of $\operatorname{Ext}_{S(n)}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p}, \mathbf{F}_{p}\right)$, which we abbreviate by $H^{*}(S(n))$.
6.2.10. THEOREM.
(a) $H^{*}(S(n))$ is finitely generated as an algebra.
(b) If $(p-1) \nmid n$, then $H^{i}(S(n))=0$ for $i>n^{2}$ and $H^{i}(S(n))=H^{n^{2}-i}(S(n))$ for $0 \leq i \leq n^{2}$, i.e., $H^{*}(S(n))$ satisfies Poincaré duality.
(c) If $(p-1) \mid n$, then $H^{*}(S(n))$ is p-periodic, i.e., there is some $x \in H^{i}(S(n))$ such that $H^{*}(S(n))$ above some finite dimension is a finitely generated free module over $\mathbf{F}_{p}[x]$.

We will prove 6.2.10(a) below as a consequence of the open subgroup theorem (6.3.6), which states that every sufficiently small open subgroup of $S_{n}$ has the same cohomology as $\mathbf{Z}_{p}^{n^{2}}$. Then (c) and the statement in (b) of finite cohomological dimension are equivalent to saying that the Krull dimension of $H^{*}(S(n))$ is 1 or 0 , respectively. Recall that the Krull dimension of a Noetherian ring $R$ is the largest $d$ such that there is an ascending chain $p_{0} \subset p_{1} \subset \cdots \subset p_{d}$ of nonunit prime ideals in $R$. Roughly speaking, $d$ is the number of generators of the largest polynomial algebra contained in $R$. Thus $d=0$ iff every element in $R$ is nilpotent, which in view of (a) implies (b). If $d=1$ and $R$ is a graded $\mathbf{F}_{p}$-algebra, then every element in $R$ has a power in $\mathbf{F}_{p}[x]$ for a fixed $x \in R . R$ is a module over $\mathbf{F}_{p}[x]$, which is a principal ideal domain. Since $H^{*}(S(n))$ is graded and finitely generated, it is a direct sum of cyclic modules over $\mathbf{F}_{p}[x]$. More specifically it is a direct sum of a torsion module (where each element is annilhilated by some power of $x$ ) and a free module. Since it is finitely generated, the torsion must be confined to low dimensions, and $H^{*}(S(n))$ is therefore a free $\mathbf{F}_{p}[x]$-module in high dimensions, so (a) implies (c).

The following result helps determine the Krull dimension.
6.2.11. TheOREM (Quillen [3]). For a profinite group $G$ the Krull dimension of $H^{*}\left(G ; \mathbf{F}_{p}\right)$ is the maximal rank of an elementary abelian p-subgroup of $G$, i.e., subgroup isomorphic to $(\mathbf{Z} /(p))^{d}$.

To determine the maximal elementary abelian subgroup of $S_{n}$, we use the fact that $D_{n}=E_{n} \otimes \mathbf{Q}$ is a division algebra over $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$ (A2.2.17), so if $G \subset S_{n}$ is abelian, then the $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$-vector space in $D_{n}$ spanned by the elements of $G$ is a subfield $K \subset D_{n}$. Hence the elements of $G$ are all roots of unity, $G$ is cyclic, and the Krull dimension is 0 or 1 .

6.2.12. ThEOREM. $A$ degree $m$ extension $K$ of $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$ embeds in $D_{n}$ iff $m \mid n$.

Proof. See Serre [1, p. 202] or Cassels and Fröhlich [1, p. 138].
By 6.2.11 $H^{*}(S(n))$ has Krull dimension 1 iff $S_{n}$ contains $p$ th roots of unity. Since the field $K$ obtained by adjoining such roots to $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$ has degree $p-1$, 6.2.12 gives 6.2.10(c) and the finite cohomological dimension statement in (b). For the rest of (b) we rely on theorem V.2.5.8 of Lazard [4], which says that if $S_{n}$ (being an analytic pro- $p$-group of dimension $n^{2}$ ) has finite cohomological dimension, then that dimension is $n^{2}$ and Poincaré duality is satisfied.

The following result identifies some Hopf algebra quotients of $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$. These are related to the graded Hopf algebras $\Sigma_{A}(n)$ discussed in Ravenel [10]. More precisely, $S(d, f)_{a}$ is a nongraded form of $\Sigma_{A}(d / f)$, where $A$ is the ring of integers in an extension $K$ (depending on $a$ ) of $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$ of degree $f n / d$ and residue degree $f$.
6.2.13. TheOREM. Let $a \in \overline{\mathbf{F}}_{p}$ be a $\left(p^{n}-1\right)$ th root of unity, let $d$ divide $n$, and let $f$ divide $d$. Then there is a Hopf algebra

$$
S(d, f)_{a}=\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\left[t_{f}, t_{2 f}, \ldots\right] /\left(t_{i f}^{p^{d}}-a_{i} t_{i f}: i>0\right)
$$

where $a_{i}=a^{p^{i d}-1}$, and a surjective homomorphism

$$
\theta: S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}} \rightarrow S(d, f)_{a}
$$

given by

$$
t_{i} \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
t_{i} & \text { if } f \mid i \\
0 & \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

The coproduct on $S(d, f)_{a}$ is determined by the one on $S(n)$. This Hopf algebra is cocommutative when $f=d$.

Proof. We first show that the algebra structure on $S(d, f)_{a}$ is compatible with that on $S(n)$. The relation $t_{i f}^{p^{d}}=a_{i} t_{i f}$ implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
t_{i f}^{p^{2 d}} & =\left(a_{i} t_{i f}\right)^{p^{d}}=a_{i}^{\left(p^{2 d}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f}=a^{\left(p^{i d}-1\right)\left(p^{2 d}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f} \\
t_{i f}^{p^{3 d}} & =a^{\left(p^{i d}-1\right)\left(p^{3 d}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f} \\
& \vdots \\
t_{i f}^{p^{n}} & =a^{\left(p^{i d}-1\right)\left(p^{n}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f}=t_{i f}
\end{aligned}
$$

so $\theta$ exists as an algebra map.
For the coproduct in $S(n)$ we have

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} \Delta\left(t_{i}\right) x^{p^{i}}=\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i} \otimes t_{j}^{p^{i}} x^{p^{i+j}}
$$

(where $x$ is a dummy variable) which induces

$$
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} \Delta\left(t_{i f}\right) x^{p^{i f}}=\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i f} \otimes t_{j f}^{p^{i f}} x^{p^{(i+j) f}}
$$

in $S(d, f)_{a}$. We need to show that this is compatible with the multiplicative relations. We can write $i f=k d+\ell f$ with $0 \leq \ell f<d$, so we can rewrite the above

as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i \geq 0}^{F} \Delta\left(t_{i f}\right) x^{p^{i f}} & =\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} t_{i f} \otimes t_{j f}^{k d+\ell f} x^{p^{(i+j) f}} \\
& =\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} a_{j}^{p^{\ell f}\left(p^{k d}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f} \otimes t_{j f}^{p^{\ell f}} x^{p^{(i+j) f}} \\
& =\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} a^{p^{i f}\left(p^{j d}-1\right)\left(p^{k d}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f} \otimes t_{j f}^{p^{\ell f}} x^{p^{(i+j) f}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which gives a well defined coproduct in $S(d, f)_{a}$.
If $f=d$ then the right hand side simplifies to

$$
\sum_{i, j \geq 0}^{F} a^{\left(p^{i d}-1\right)\left(p^{i f}-1\right) /\left(p^{d}-1\right)} t_{i f} \otimes t_{j f} x^{p^{(i+j) f}}
$$

which is cocommutative as claimed.

# 3. The Cohomology of $\Sigma(n)$ 

In this section we will use a spectral sequence (A1.3.9) based on the filtration of $\Sigma(n)$ induced by the one on $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ given in 4.3.24. We have
6.3.1. ThEOREM. Define integers $d_{n, i}$ by

$$
d_{n, i}= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } i \leq 0 \\ \max \left(i, p d_{n, i-n}\right) & \text { for } i>0\end{cases}
$$

Then there is a unique increasing filtration of the Hopf algebra $S(n)$ with $\operatorname{deg} t_{i}^{p^{i}}=d_{n, i}$ for $0 \leq j<n$.

The following is a partial description of the coproduct in the associated graded object $E^{0} S(n)$. For large $i$ we need only partial information about the coproduct on $t_{i, j}$ in order to prove Theorem 6.3.3. I am grateful to Agnes Beaudry for finding an error in an earlier version of the following.
6.3.2. ThEOREM. Let $E^{0} S(n)$ denote the associated bigraded Hopf algebra. Its algebra structure is

$$
E^{0} S(n)=T\left(t_{i, j}: i>0, \quad j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)\right)
$$

where $T(\cdot)$ denotes the truncated polynomial algebra of height $p$ on the indicated elements and $t_{i, j}$ corresponds to $t_{i}^{p^{i}}$. The coproduct is induced by the one given in 4.3.34. Explicitly, let $m=p n /(p-1)$. Then

$$
\Delta\left(t_{i, j}\right)= \begin{cases}\sum_{0 \leq k \leq i} t_{k, j} \otimes t_{i-k, k+j} & \text { if } i<m \\ \sum_{0 \leq k \leq i} t_{k, j} \otimes t_{i-k, k+j}+\bar{b}_{i-n, j+n-1} & \text { if } i=m \\ t_{i, j} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t_{i, j}+\bar{b}_{i-n, j+n-1} & \\ \bmod \left(t_{k, \ell}: k \leq i-n-1\right) & \text { if } i>m\end{cases}
$$

where $t_{0, j}=1$ and $\bar{b}_{i, j}$ corresponds to the $b_{i, j}$ of 4.3.14.

As in the case of the Steenrod algebra, the dual object $E_{0} S(n)^{*}$ is primitively generated and is the universal enveloping algebra of a restricted Lie algebra $L(n)$. $L(n)$ has basis $\left\{x_{i, j}: i>0, j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)\right\}$, where $x_{i, j}$ is dual to $t_{i, j}$.
6.3.3. Theorem. $E_{0} S(n)^{*}$ is the restricted enveloping algebra on primitives $x_{i, j}$ with bracket

$$
\left[x_{i, j}, x_{k, l}\right]= \begin{cases}\delta_{i+j}^{l} x_{i+k, j}-\delta_{k+1}^{j} x_{i+k, l} & \text { for } i+k \leq m \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $m$ is the largest integer not exceeding $p n /(p-1)$, and $\delta_{t}^{s}=1$ iff $s \equiv t \bmod (n)$ and $\delta_{t}^{s}=0$ otherwise. The restriction $\xi$ is given by

$$
\xi\left(x_{i, j}\right)= \begin{cases}x_{i+n, j+1} & \text { if } i>n /(p-1) \\ & \text { or } i=n /(p-1) \text { and } p>2 \\ x_{2 n, j}+x_{2 n, j+1} & \text { if } i=n \text { and } p=2 \\ 0 & \text { if } i<n / p-1 .\end{cases}
$$

The formula for the restriction was given incorrectly in the first edition, and this error led to an incorrect description in 6.3.24 of the multiplicative structure of $H^{*}(S(2))$ for $p=3$. The correct description is due to Henn [1] and will be given below. The corrected restriction formula was given to me privately by Ethan Devinatz.

Proof of 6.3.3. The formula for the bracket can be derived from 6.3.2 as follows. The primitive $x_{i, j}$ is dual to $t_{i, j}$. The bracket has the form

$$
\left[x_{i, j}, x_{k, l}\right]=\sum_{m, n} c_{i, j, k, \ell}^{a, b} x_{a, b}
$$

where the coefficient $c_{i, j, k, \ell}^{a, b}$ is nonzero only if the coproduct expansion on $t_{a, b}$ contains a term of the form $t_{i, j} \otimes t_{k, \ell}$ or $t_{k, \ell} \otimes t_{i, j}$. This can happen only when the the two expressions have the same bidegree. This means that

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{n, a} & =d_{n, i}+d_{n, k} \\
\text { and } \quad 2 p^{b}\left(p^{a}-1\right) & \equiv 2 p^{j}\left(p^{i}-1\right)+2 p^{\ell}\left(p^{k}-1\right) \quad \bmod 2\left(p^{n}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This happens only when $a=i+k \leq m$ and $b=j$ or $\ell$. Inspection of the coproduct formula leads to indicated Lie bracket.

The restriction requires more care. For finding the restriction on $x_{i, j}$ it suffices to work in the subalgebra of $E_{0} S(n)^{*}$ generated by $x_{k, \ell}$ for $k \geq i$.

It is also dual to passing to the quotient of $E^{0} S(n)$ obtained by killing $t_{k, \ell}$ for $k<i$. Hence description of $\Delta\left(t_{i, j}\right)$ for $i>m$ given in 6.3.2 is sufficient for our purposes.

When $i>m$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta\left(t_{i, j}\right) & =t_{i, j} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t_{i, j}+\widetilde{b}_{i-n, j-1} \\
& =t_{i, j} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t_{i, j}-\sum_{0<\ell<p} p^{-1}\binom{p}{\ell} t_{i-n, j-1}^{\ell} \otimes t_{i-n, j-1}^{p-\ell}
\end{aligned}
$$

so for $i>n /(p-1)$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\Delta\left(t_{i+n, j+1}\right) \equiv t_{i+n, j+1} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t_{i+n, j+1}-\sum_{0<\ell<p} p^{-1}\binom{p}{\ell} t_{i, j}^{\ell} \otimes t_{i, j}^{p-\ell} \\
\bmod \left(t_{k, \ell}: k \leq i-1\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

For brevity let $B=E^{0} S(n) /\left(t_{k, \ell}: k \leq i-1\right)$ and let $\bar{B}=B / \mathbf{F}_{p}$ denote the unit coideal, the dual of the augmentation ideal in $B^{*}$.

It follows that under the reduced iterated coproduct

$$
B \xrightarrow{\Delta^{p-1}} B^{\otimes p} \longrightarrow \bar{B}^{\otimes p}
$$

we have

$$
t_{i+n, j+1} \mapsto t_{i, j} \otimes t_{i, j} \otimes \cdots \otimes t_{i, j}
$$

which leads to the desired value of $\xi\left(x_{i, j}\right)$ for $i>n /(p-1)$. The argument for $i=n / p-1$ and $p$ odd is similar.

For the case $p=2$ and $i=n, 6.3 .2$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta\left(t_{2 n, j}\right)= & \sum_{0 \leq k \leq 2 n} t_{k, j} \otimes t_{2 n-k, k+j}+\widetilde{b}_{n, j-1} \\
= & t_{n, j-1} \otimes t_{n, j-1}+\sum_{0 \leq k \leq 2 n} t_{k, j} \otimes t_{2 n-k, k+j} \\
= & t_{n, j-1} \otimes t_{n, j-1}+t_{n, j} \otimes t_{n, j} \\
& \quad+\sum_{0 \leq k<n}\left(t_{k, j} \otimes t_{2 n-k, j+k}+t_{2 n-k, j} \otimes t_{k, j-k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the formula for $\xi\left(x_{n, j}\right)$ follows.
For $i<n /(p-1)$ there are no terms in $\Delta\left(t_{i+n, k}\right)$ for any $k$ that would lead to a nontrivial restriction on $x_{i, j}$.

Recall that Theorem 6.2.3 identifies $S(n)^{*} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{q}$ with the group ring $\mathbf{F}_{q}\left[S_{n}\right]$ and that $S_{n}$ is the group of units in the $\mathbf{Z}_{p}$-algebra $E_{n}$ congruent to 1 modulo the maximal ideal $(S)$. Killing the first few $t_{i}$ s in $S(n)$ as we did in the proof above corresponds to replacing the group $S_{n}$ by the subgroup of units congruent to 1 modulo a power of $(S)$.

Let $L(n)$ be the Lie algebra without restriction with basis $x_{i, j}$ and bracket as above. We now recall the main results of May [2].
6.3.4. ThEOREM. There are spectral sequences
(a) $E_{2}=H^{*}(L(n)) \otimes P\left(b_{i, j}\right) \Rightarrow H^{*}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$,
(b) $E_{2}=H^{*}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right) \Rightarrow H^{*}(S(n))$,
where $b_{i, j} \in H^{2 p d_{i}}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$ with internal degree $2 p^{j+1}\left(p^{i}-1\right)$ and $P(\cdot)$ is the polynomial algebra on the indicated generators.

Now let $L(n, k)$ be the quotient of $L(n)$ obtained by setting $x_{i, j}=0$ for $i>k$. Then our first result is
6.3.5. ThEOREM. The $E_{2}$-term of the first May spectral sequence [6.3.4(a)] may be replaced by $H^{*}(L(n, m)) \otimes P\left(b_{i, j}: i \leq m-n\right)$, where $m=[p n /(p-1)]$ as before.

Proof. By 6.3.3 $L(n)$ is the product of $L(n, m)$ and an abelian Lie algebra, so

$$
H^{*}(L(n)) \cong H^{*}(L(n, m)) \otimes E\left(h_{i, j}: i>m\right)
$$

where $E(\cdot)$ denotes the exterior algebra on the indicated generators and $h_{i, j} \in$ $H^{1} L(n)$ is the element corresponding to $x_{i, j}$. It also follows from 6.3.4 that the appropriate differential will send $h_{i, j}$ to $-b_{i-n, j-1}$ for $i>m$. It follows that the entire spectral sequence decomposes as a tensor product of two spectral sequences, one with the $E_{2}$-term indicated in the statement of the theorem, and the other having $E_{2}=E\left(h_{i, j}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{i-n, j}\right)$ with $i>m$ and $E_{\infty}=\mathbf{F}_{p}$.

If $n<p-1$ then 6.3.5 gives a spectral sequence whose $E_{2}$-term is $H^{*}(L(n, n))$, showing that $H^{*}(S(n))$ has cohomological dimension $n^{2}$ as claimed in 6.2.10(b).

In Ravenel [6] we claimed erroneously that the spectral sequence of 6.3.4(b) collapses for $n<p-1$. The argument given there is incorrect. For example, we have reason to believe that for $p=11, n=9$ the element

$$
\left(h_{1,0} h_{2,0} \cdots h_{7,0}\right)\left(h_{2,8} h_{3,7} \cdots h_{7,3}\right)
$$

supports a differential that hits a nonzero multiple of

$$
h_{1,0} h_{2,0}\left(h_{1,8} h_{2,7} \cdots h_{6,3}\right)\left(h_{2,1} h_{3,1} \cdots h_{6,1}\right)
$$

We know of no counterexample for smaller $n$ or $p$.
Now we will prove 6.2.10(a), i.e., that $H^{*}(S(n))$ is finitely generated as an algebra. For motivation, the following is a special case of a result in Lazard [4].
6.3.6. Open Subgroup Theorem. Every sufficiently small open subgroup of $S_{n}$ is cohomologically abelian in the sense that it has the same cohomology as $\mathbf{Z}_{p}^{n^{2}}$, i.e., an exterior algebra on $n^{2}$ generators.

We will give a Hopf algebra theoretic proof of this for a cofinal set of open subgroups, namely the subgroups of elements in $E_{n}$ congruent to 1 modulo $\left(S^{i}\right)$ for various $i>0$. The corresponding quotient group (which is finite) is dual the subalgebra of $S(n)$ generated by $\left\{t_{k}: k<i\right\}$. Hence the $i$ th subgroup is dual to $S(n) /\left(t_{k}: k<i\right)$, which we denote by $S(n, i)$.

The filtration of 6.3.1 induces one on $S(n, i)$ and analogs of the succeeding four theorems hold for it.
6.3.7. ThEOREM. If $i \geq n$ and $p>2$, or $i>n$ and $p=2$, then

$$
H^{*}(S(n, i))=E\left(h_{k, j}: i \leq k<i+n, j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)\right)
$$

Proof. The condition on $i$ is equivalent to $i>n-1$ and $i>m / 2$, where as before $m=p n /(p-1)$. In the analog of 6.3 .3 we have $i, k>m / 2$ so $i+k>m$ so the Lie algebra is abelian. We also see that the restriction $\xi$ is injective, so the spectral sequence of 6.3 .5 has the $E_{2}$-term claimed to be $H^{*}(S(n, i))$. This spectral sequence collapses because $h_{k, j}$ corresponds to $t_{k}^{p^{2}} \in S(n, i)$, which is primitive for each $k$ and $j$.

Proof of 6.2.10(a). Let $A(i)$ be the Hopf algebra corresponding to the quotient of $S_{n}$ by the $i$ th congruence subgroup, so we have a Hopf algebra extension (A1.1.15)

$$
A(i) \rightarrow S(n) \rightarrow S(n, i)
$$

The corresponding Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.14) has

$$
E_{2}=\operatorname{Ext}_{A(i)}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p}, H^{*}(S(n, i))\right)
$$

and converges to $H^{*}(S(n))$ with $d_{r}: E_{r} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s+r, t-r+1}$. Each $E_{r}$-term is finitely generated since $A(i)$ and $H^{*}(S(n, i))$ are finite-dimensional for $i>m / 2$. Moreover, $E_{n^{2}}=E_{\infty}$, so $E_{\infty}$ and $H^{*}(S(n))$ are finitely generated.

Now we continue with the computation of $H^{*}(S(n))$. Theorem 6.3.5 indicates the necessity of computing $H^{*}(L(n, k))$ for $k \leq m$, and this may be done with the Koszul complex, i.e.,
6.3.8. Theorem. $H^{*}(L(n, k))$ for $k \leq m$ is the cohomology of the exterior complex $E\left(h_{i, j}\right)$ on one-dimensional generators $h_{i, j}$ with $i \leq k$ and $j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)$, with coboundary

$$
d\left(h_{i, j}\right)=\sum_{0<s<i} h_{s, j} h_{i-s, s+j}
$$

The element $h_{i, j}$ corresponds to the element $x_{i, j}$ and therefore has filtration degree $i$ and internal degree $2 p^{j}\left(p^{i}-1\right)$.

Proof. This follows from standard facts about the cohomology of Lie algebras (Cartan and Eilenberg [1, XII, Section 7]).

Since $L(n, k)$ is nilpotent its cohomology can be computed with a sequence of change-of-rings spectral sequences analogous to A1.3.14.
6.3.9. ThEOREM. There are spectral sequences with

$$
E_{2}=E\left(h_{k, j}\right) \otimes H^{*}(L(n, k-1)) \Rightarrow H^{*}(L(n, k))
$$

and $E_{3}=E_{\infty}$.
Proof. The spectral sequence is that of Hochschild-Serre (see Cartan and Eilenberg [1, pp. 349-351] for the extension of Lie algebras

$$
A(n, k) \rightarrow L(n, k) \rightarrow L(n, k-1)
$$

where $A(n, k)$ is the abelian Lie algebra on $x_{k, j}$. Hence $H^{*}(A(n, k))=E\left(h_{k, j}\right)$. The $E_{2}$-term, $H^{*}(L,(n, k-1), H^{*}(A(n, k))$ is isomorphic to the indicated tensor product since the extension is central.

For the second statement, recall that the spectral sequence can be constructed by filtering the complex of 6.3 .8 in the obvious way. Inspection of this filtered complex shows that $E_{3}=E_{\infty}$.

In addition to the spectral sequence of 6.3.4(a), there is an alternative method of computing $H^{( } * E_{0} S(n)^{*}$ ). Define $\tilde{L}(n, k)$ for $k \leq m$ to be the quotient of $P E_{0} S(n)^{*}$ by the restricted sub-Lie algebra generated by the elements $x_{i, j}$ for $k<i \leq m$, and define $F(n, k)$ to be the kernel of the extension

$$
0 \rightarrow F(n, k) \rightarrow \tilde{L}(n, k) \rightarrow \tilde{L}(n, k-1) \rightarrow 0
$$

Let $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(n, k))$ denote the cohomology of the restricted enveloping algebra of $\tilde{L}(n, k)$. Then we have
6.3.10. ThEOREM. There are change-of-rings spectral sequences converging to $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(n, k))$ with

$$
E_{2}=H^{*}(F(n, k)) \otimes H^{*}(\tilde{L}(n, k-1))
$$

where

$$
H^{*}(F(n, k))= \begin{cases}E\left(h_{k, j}\right) & \text { for } k>m-n \\ E\left(h_{k, j}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{k, j}\right) & \text { for } k \leq m-n\end{cases}
$$

and $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(n, m))=H^{*}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$.
Proof. Again the spectral sequence is that given in Theorem XVI.6.1 of Cartan and Eilenberg [1]. As before, the extension is cocentral, so the $E_{2}$-term is the indicated tensor product. The structure of $H^{*}(F(n, k))$ follows from 6.3.3 and the last statement is a consequence of 6.3.5.

We begin the computation of $H^{1}(S(n))$ with:
6.3.11. Lemma. $H^{1}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)=H^{1}\left(E^{0} S(n)\right)$ is generated by

$$
\zeta_{n}=\sum_{j} h_{n, j} \quad \text { and } \quad \rho_{n}=\sum_{j} h_{2 n, j} \quad \text { for } p=2
$$

and for $n>1, h_{1, j}$ for each $j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)$.
Proof. By 6.3.4(a) and $6.3 .5 H^{1}\left(E_{0} S(n)\right)=H^{1} L(n, m)$ ). The indicated elements are nontrivial cycles by 6.3.8. It follows from 6.3.3 that $L(n, m)$ can have no other generators since $\left[x_{1, j}, x_{i-1, j+1}\right]=x_{i, j}-\delta_{i+j}^{j} x_{i, j+1}$.

In order to pass to $H^{1}(S(n))$ we need to produce primitive elements in $S(n)_{*}$ corresponding to $\zeta_{n}$ and $\rho_{n}$ (the primitive $t_{1}^{p^{i}}$ corresponds to $h_{1, j}$ ). We will do this with the help of the determinant of a certain matrix. Recall from (6.2.3) that $S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$ was isomorphic to the dual group ring of $S_{m}$ which has a certain faithful representation over $W\left(\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right)(6.2 .6)$. The determinant of this representation gave a homomorphism of $S(n)$ into $\mathbf{Z}_{p}^{\times}$, the multiplicative group of units in the $p$-adic integers. We will see that in $H^{1}$ this map gives us $\zeta_{n}$ and $\rho_{n}$.

More precisely, let $M=\left(m_{i, j}\right)$ be the $n$ by $n$ matrix over $\mathbf{Z}_{p}\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots\right] /\left(t_{i}-t_{i}^{p^{n}}\right)$ given by

$$
m_{i, j}= \begin{cases}\sum_{k \geq 0} p^{k} t_{k n+j-i}^{p^{i}} & \text { for } i \leq j \\ \sum_{k \geq 0} p^{k+1} t_{k n+j-i}^{p^{i}} & \text { for } i>j\end{cases}
$$

where $t_{0}=1$.
Now define $T_{n} \in S(n)_{*}$ to be the $\bmod (p)$ reduction $p^{-1}(\operatorname{det} M-1)$ and for $p=2$ define $U_{n} \in S(n)_{*}$ to be the $\bmod (2)$ reduction of $\frac{1}{8}\left(\operatorname{det} M^{2}-1\right)$. Then we have
6.3.12. Theorem. The elements $T_{n} \in S(n)$ and, for $p=2, U_{n} \in S(n)$ are primitive and represent the elements $\zeta_{n}$ and $\rho_{n}+\zeta_{n} \in H^{1}(S(n))$, respectively. Hence $H^{1}(S(n))$ is generated by these elements and for $n>1$ by the $h_{1, j}$ for $j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)$.

Proof. The statement that $T_{n}$ and $U_{n}$ are primitive follows from 6.2.6. That they represent $\zeta_{n}$ and $\rho_{n}+\zeta_{n}$ follows from the fact that

$$
T_{n} \equiv \sum_{j} t_{n}^{p^{j}} \quad \bmod \left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{n-1}\right)
$$

and

$$
U_{n} \equiv \sum_{j} t_{2 n}^{2^{j}}+t_{n}^{2^{j}} \quad \bmod \left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{n-1}\right)
$$

# EXAMPLES. 

$$
\begin{gathered}
T_{1}=t_{1}, \quad U_{1}=t_{1}+t_{2}, \quad T_{2}=t_{2}+t_{2}^{p}-t_{1}^{1+p} \\
U_{2}=t_{4}+t_{4}^{2}+t_{1} t_{3}^{2}+t_{1}^{2} t_{3}+t_{1}^{3} t_{2}+t_{1}^{3} t_{2}^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
T_{3}=t_{3}+t_{3}^{p}+t_{3}^{p^{2}}+t_{1}^{1+p+p^{2}}-t_{1} t_{2}^{p}-t_{1}^{p} t_{2}^{p^{2}}-t_{1}^{p^{2}} t_{2}
$$

Moreira [1, 3] has found primitive elements in $B P_{*}(B P) / I_{n}$ which reduce to our $T_{n}$. The following result is a corollary of 6.2.7.
6.3.13. Proposition. If $p \nmid n$, then $H^{*}(S(n))$ decomposes as a tensor product of an appropriate subalgebra with $E\left(\zeta_{n}\right)$ for $p>2$ and $P\left(\zeta_{n}\right) \otimes E\left(\rho_{n}\right)$ for $p=2$.

We now turn to the computation of $H^{2}(S(n))$ for $n>2$. We will compute all of $H^{*} S((n))$ for $n=2$ below.

### 6.3.14. THEOREM. Let $n>2$

(a) For $p=2, H^{2}(S(n))$ is generated as a vector space by the elements $\zeta_{n}^{2}$, $\rho_{n} \zeta_{n}, \zeta_{n}, \zeta_{n} h_{1, j}, \rho_{n} h_{1, j}$, and $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ for $i \neq j \pm 1$, where $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}=h_{1, j} h_{1, i}$ and $h_{1, i}^{2} \neq 0$.
(b) For $p>2, H^{2}(S(n))$ is generated by the elements

$$
\zeta_{n} h_{1, i}, b_{1, i}, g_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i}\right\rangle, \quad k_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i}\right\rangle
$$

and $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ for $i \neq j \pm 1$, where $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}+h_{1, j} h_{1, i}=0$.
Both statements require a sequence of lemmas. We treat the case $p=2$ first.
6.3.15. Lemma. Let $p=2$ and $n>2$.
(a) $H^{1}(L(n, 2))$ is generated by $h_{1, i}$ for $i \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)$.
(b) $H^{2}(L(n, 2))$ is generated by the elements $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ for $i \neq j \pm 1, g_{i}, k_{i}$, and $e_{3, i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i+2}\right\rangle$. The latter elements are represented by $h_{1, i} h_{2, i}$, $h_{1, i+1} h_{2, i}$, and $h_{1, i} h_{2, i+1}+h_{2, i} h_{1, i+2}$, respectively.
(c) $e_{3, i} h_{1, i+1}=h_{1, i} e_{3, i+1}+e_{3, i} h_{1, i} h_{1, i+3}=0$, and these are the only relations among the elements $h_{1, i} e_{3, j}$.

Proof. We use the spectral sequence of 6.3 .9 with $E_{2}=E\left(h_{1, i}, h_{2, i}\right)$ and $d_{2}\left(h_{2, i}\right)=h_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}$. All three statements can be verified by inspection.
6.3.16. Lemma. Let $p=2, n>2$, and $2<k \leq 2 n$.
(a) $H^{1}(L(n, k))$ is generated by the elements $h_{1, i}$ along with $\zeta_{n}$ for $k \geq n$ and $\rho_{n}$ for $k=2 n$.
(b) $H^{2}(L(n, k))$ is generated by products of elements in $H^{1}(L(n, k))$ subject to $h_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}=0$, along with

$$
\begin{gathered}
g_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}\right\rangle, \quad k_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i+1}\right\rangle \\
\alpha_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i+2}, h_{1, i+1}\right\rangle, \quad \text { and } \\
e_{k+1, i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, \ldots, h_{1, i+k}\right\rangle
\end{gathered}
$$

The last two families of elements can be represented by $h_{3, i} h_{1, i+1}+h_{2, i} h_{2, i+1}$ and $\Sigma_{s} h_{s, i} h_{k+1-s, i+1}$ respectively.
(c) $h_{1, i} e_{k+1, i+1}+e_{k+1, i} h_{1, i+1+k}=0$ and no other relations hold among products of the $e_{k+1, i}$ with elements of $H^{1}$.

Proof. Again we use 6.3.9 and argue by induction on $k$, using 6.3.15 to start the induction. We have $E_{2}=E\left(h_{k, i}\right) \otimes H^{*}(L(n, k-1))$ with $d_{2}\left(h_{k, i}\right)=e_{k, i}$. The existence of the $\alpha_{i}$ follows from the relation $e_{3, i} h_{1, i+1}=0$ in $H^{3}(L(n, 2))$ and that of $e_{k+1, i}$ from $h_{1, i} e_{k, i+1} h_{1, i+k}=0$ in $H^{3}(L(n, k-1))$. The relation (c) for $k<2$ is formal; it follows from a Massey product identity A1.4.6 or can be verified by direct calculation in the complex of 6.3.8. No combination of these products can be in the image of $d_{2}$ for degree reasons.
6.3.17. Let $p=2$ and $n>2$. Then $H^{2}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$ is generated by the elements $\rho_{n} \zeta_{n}, \rho_{n} h_{1, i}, \zeta_{n} h_{1, i}, h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ for $i \neq j \pm 1, \alpha_{i}$, and $h_{i, j}^{2}=b_{i, j}$ for $1 \leq i \leq n, j \in$ $\mathbf{Z} /(n)$.

Proof. We use the modified first May spectral sequence of 6.3.5. We have $m=2 n$ and $H^{2}(L(n, m))$ is given by 6.3.16. By easy direct computation one sees that $d_{2}\left(g_{i}\right)=b_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}$ and $d_{2}\left(k_{i}\right)=h_{1, i} b_{1, i+1}$. We will show that $d_{2}\left(e_{2 n+1, i}\right)=$ $h_{1, i} b_{n, i}+h_{1, i+n} b_{n, i-1}$.

$$
\Delta\left(t_{2 n+1}\right)=\sum t_{j} \otimes t_{2 n+1-j}^{p^{\prime}}+b_{n+1, n-1}
$$

modulo terms of lower filtration by 4.3.15. Then by 4.3.22

$$
d\left(b_{n+1, n-1}\right)=t_{1} \otimes b_{n, n}+b_{n, n-1} \otimes t_{1}
$$

modulo terms of lower filtration and the nontriviality of $d_{2}\left(e_{2 n+1, i}\right)$ follows.
Proof of 6.3.14(a). We now consider the second May spectral sequence (6.3.4(b)). By 4.3.22 we have $d_{2}\left(b_{i, j}\right)=h_{1, j+1} b_{i-1, j+1}+h_{1, i+j} b_{i-1, j} \neq 0$ for $i>1$. The remaining elements of $H^{2} E_{0} S(n)$ survive either for degree reasons or by 6.3.12.

For $p>2$ we need an analogous sequence of lemmas. We leave the proofs to the reader.
6.3.18. Lemma. Let $n>2$ and $p>2$.
(a) $H^{1}(L(n, 2))$ is generated by $h_{1, i}$.
(b) $H^{2}(L(n, 2))$ is generated by the elements $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ (with $h_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}=0$ ). $g_{i}=h_{1, i} h_{2, i}, k_{i}=h_{1, i+1} h_{2, i}$ and $e_{3, i}=h_{1, i} h_{2, i+1} h_{2, i} h_{1, i+2}$.
(c) The only relations among the elements $h_{1, i} e_{3, j}$ are $h_{1, i} e_{3, i+1}-e_{3, i} h_{1, i+3}=0$.
6.3.19. Lemma. Let $n>2, p>2$, and $2<k \leq m$. Then
(a) $H^{1}(L(n, k))$ is generated by $h_{1, i}$ and, for $k \geq n, \zeta_{n}$.
(b) $H^{2}(L(n, k))$ is generated by $h_{1, i} h_{1, j}$ (with $h_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}=0$ ), $g_{i}, h_{i}$,

$$
e_{k+1, i}=\sum_{0<j<k+1} h_{j, i} h_{k+1-j, i+j}
$$

and, for $k \geq n, \zeta_{n} h_{1, i}$.
(c) The only relations among products of elements in $H^{1}$ with the $e_{k+1, i}$ are $h_{1, i} e_{k+1, i+1}-e_{k+1, i} h_{1, k+1}=0$.
6.3.20. Lemma. Let $n>2$ and $p>2$. Then $H^{2}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$ is generated by the elements $b_{i, j}$ for $i \leq m-n$ and by the elements of $H^{2}(L(n, m))$.

Proof of 6.3.14(b). Again we look at the spectral sequence of 6.3.4(b). By arguments similar to those for $p=2$ one can show that

$$
d_{p}\left(b_{i, j}\right)=h_{1, i+j} b_{i-1, j}-h_{1, j+1} b_{i-1, j+1} \quad \text { for } i>1
$$

and

$$
d_{s}\left(e_{m+1, i}\right)=h_{1, m+1+i-n} b_{m-n, i-1}-h_{1, i} b_{m-n, j} \quad \text { where } s=1+p n-(p-1) m
$$

and the remaining elements of $H^{2}\left(E_{0} S(n)^{*}\right)$ survive as before.
Now we will compute $H^{*}(S(n))$ at all primes for $n \leq 2$ and at $p>3$ for $n=3$.

# 6.3.21. THEOREM. 

(a) $H^{*}(S(1))=P\left(h_{1,0}\right) \otimes E\left(\rho_{1}\right)$ for $p=2$;
(b) $H^{*}(S(1))=E\left(h_{1,0}\right)$ for $p>2$
[note that $S(1)$ is commutative and that $\zeta_{1}=h_{1,0}$ ].
Proof. This follows immediately from 6.3.3, 6.3.5, and routine calculation.
6.3.22. THEOREM. For $p>3, H^{*}(S(2))$ is the tensor product of $E\left(\zeta_{2}\right)$ with the subalgebra with basis $\left\{1, h_{1,0}, h_{1,1}, g_{0}, g_{1}, g_{0} h_{1,1}\right\}$ where

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{i} & =\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i}\right\rangle \\
h_{1,0} g_{1} & =g_{0} h_{1,1}, \quad h_{1,0} g_{0}=h_{1,1} g_{1}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
h_{1,0} h_{1,1}=h_{1,0}^{2}=h_{1,1}^{2}=0
$$

In particular, the Poincaré series is $(1+t)^{2}\left(1+t+t^{2}\right)$.
Proof. The computation of $H^{*}(L(2,2))$ by 6.3 .8 or 6.3 .9 is elementary, and there are no algebra extension problems for the spectral sequences of 6.3.9 or 6.3.4(b).

We will now compute $H^{*}(S(2))$ for $p=3$. Our description of it in the first edition was incorrect, as was pointed out by Henn [1]. The computation given here is influenced by Henn but self-contained. Henn showed that there are two conjugacy classes of subgroups of order 3 in the group $S_{2}$. In each case the centralizer is the group of units congruent to one modulo the maximal ideal in the ring of integers of an embedded copy of the field $K=\mathbf{Q}_{3}[\zeta]$, where $\zeta$ is a primitive cube root of unity. Let $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ denote these two centralizers. Henn showed that the resulting map

$$
H^{*}\left(S_{2}\right) \rightarrow H^{*}\left(C_{1}\right) \oplus H^{*}\left(C_{2}\right)
$$

is a monomorphism.
We will describe this map in Hopf algebraic terms. Choose a fourth root of unity $i \in \mathbf{F}_{9}$, let $a= \pm i$, and consider the two quotients

$$
\overline{S(2)}{ }_{+}=S(1,1)_{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \overline{S(2)}{ }_{-}=S(1,1)_{-i}
$$

where $S(1,1)_{a}$ is the quotient of $S(2) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9}$ described in 6.2.13. Henn's map is presumably equivalent to

$$
H^{*}(S(2)) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9} \rightarrow H^{*}\left(\overline{S(2)}{ }_{+}\right) \oplus H^{*}\left(\overline{S(2)}{ }_{-}\right)
$$

In any case we will show that this map is a monomorphism.

We have the following reduced coproducts in $\overline{S(2)}_{ \pm}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{t}_{1} \mapsto 0 \\
& \bar{t}_{2} \mapsto a \bar{t}_{1} \otimes \bar{t}_{1} \\
& \bar{t}_{3} \mapsto \bar{t}_{1} \otimes \bar{t}_{2}+\bar{t}_{2} \otimes \bar{t}_{1}-a^{3}\left(\bar{t}_{1}^{2} \otimes \bar{t}_{1}+\bar{t}_{1} \otimes \bar{t}_{1}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that $\bar{t}_{2}+a \bar{t}_{1}^{2}$ and $\bar{t}_{3}-\bar{t}_{1} \bar{t}_{2}$ are primitive. The filtration of 6.3.1 induces one on $\overline{S(2)}{ }_{ \pm}$, and the methods of this section lead to

$$
H^{*}\left(\overline{S(2)}{ }_{ \pm}\right)=E\left(\bar{h}_{1,0}, \bar{h}_{2,0}, \bar{h}_{3,0}\right) \otimes P\left(\bar{b}_{1,0}\right)
$$

with the evident notation.
6.3.24. ThEOREM. For $p=3, H^{*}(S(2))$ is a free module over

$$
E\left(\zeta_{2}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{1,0}\right)
$$

on the generators

$$
\left\{1, h_{1,0}, h_{1,1}, b_{1,1}, \xi, a_{0}, a_{1}, b_{1,1} \xi\right\}
$$

where the elements $\xi \in H^{2}$ and $a_{0}, a_{1} \in H^{3}$ will be defined below. The algebra structure is indicated in the following multiplication table.

| 1 | $h_{1,0}$ | $h_{1,1}$ | $b_{1,1}$ | $\xi$ | $a_{0}$ | $a_{1}$ |
| :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: |
| $h_{1,0}$ | 0 | 0 | $-b_{1,0} h_{1,1}$ | 0 | $-b_{1,1} \xi$ | $-b_{1,0} \xi$ |
| $h_{1,1}$ |  | 0 | $b_{1,0} h_{1,0}$ | 0 | $-b_{1,0} \xi$ | $b_{1,1} \xi$ |
| $b_{1,1}$ |  |  | $-b_{1,0}^{2}$ | $b_{1,1} \xi$ | $-b_{1,0} a_{1}$ | $b_{1,0} a_{0}$ |
| $\xi$ |  |  |  | 0 | 0 | 0 |
| $a_{0}$ |  |  |  |  | 0 | 0 |
| $a_{1}$ |  |  |  |  |  | 0 |

In particular, the Poincaré series is

$$
(1+t)^{2}\left(1+t^{2}\right) /(1-t)
$$

Moreover the map of (6.3.23) is a monomorphism.
Proof. Our basic tools are the spectral sequences of 6.3.10 and some Massey product identities from A1.4. We have $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,1)) \cong E\left(h_{1,0}, h_{1,1}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{1,0}, b_{1,1}\right)$, and a spectral sequence converging to $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$ with $E_{2}=E\left(\zeta_{2}, \eta\right) \otimes H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,1))$, where

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\zeta_{2}=h_{2,0}+h_{2,1}, & \eta= & h_{2,1}-h_{2,0} \\
d_{2}\left(\zeta_{2}\right)=0, & d_{2}(\eta) & =h_{1,0} h_{1,1}
\end{array}
$$

and $E_{3}=E_{\infty}$. Hence $E_{\infty}$ is a free module over $E\left(\zeta_{2}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{1,0}, b_{1,1}\right)$ on generators

$$
\left\{1, h_{1,0}, h_{1,1}, g_{0}, g_{1}, h_{1,0} g_{1}=h_{1,1} g_{0},\right\}
$$

where $g_{i}=\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i+1}, h_{1, i}\right\rangle$. This determines the additive structure of $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$, but there are some nontrivial extensions in the multiplicative structure. We know by 6.3.13 that we can factor out $E\left(\zeta_{2}\right)$, and we can write $b_{1, i}$ as the Massey product $-\left\langle h_{1, i}, h_{1, i}, h_{1, i}\right\rangle$. Then by A1.4.6 we have $h_{1, i} g_{i}=-b_{1, i} h_{1, i+1}, g_{i}^{2}=-b_{1, i} g_{i+1}$, $g_{i} g_{i+1}=b_{1, i} b_{1, i+1}$. These facts along with the usual $h_{1, i}^{2}=h_{1,0} h_{1,1}=0$ determine $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$ as an algebra.

This algebra structure allows us to embed $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$ in the ring

$$
R=E\left(\zeta_{2}, h_{1,0}, h_{1,1}\right) \otimes P\left(s_{0}, s_{1}\right) /\left(h_{1,0} h_{1,1}, h_{1,0} s_{1}-h_{1,1} s_{0}\right)
$$

by sending $\zeta_{2}$ and $h_{1, i}$ to themselves and

$$
\begin{aligned}
b_{1, i} & \mapsto-s_{i}^{3} \\
g_{0} & \mapsto s_{0}^{2} s_{1} \\
g_{1} & \mapsto s_{0} s_{1}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the cohomological degree of $s_{i}$ is $2 / 3$, and $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$ maps isomorphically to the subring of $R$ consisting of elements of integral cohomological degree.

Next we have the spectral sequence of 6.3.10 converging to

$$
H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,3)) \cong H^{*}\left(E^{0} S(2)\right)
$$

with $E_{2}=E\left(h_{3,0}, h_{3,1}\right) \otimes H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$, and $d_{2}\left(h_{3, i}\right)=g_{i}-b_{1, i+1}$. We will see shortly that $E_{3}=E_{\infty}$ for formal reasons. Tensoring this over $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2))$ with $R$ gives a spectral sequence with

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{2} & =E\left(h_{3,0}, h_{3,1}\right) \otimes R \\
\text { and } \quad d_{2}\left(h_{3,0}\right) & =s_{1}\left(s_{0}^{2}+s_{1}^{2}\right) \\
d_{2}\left(h_{3,1}\right) & =s_{0}\left(s_{0}^{2}+s_{1}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This can be simplified by tensoring with $\mathbf{F}_{9}$ (which contains $i=\sqrt{-1}$ ) and defining

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
x_{0}=h_{1,0}+i h_{1,1} & x_{1}=h_{1,0}-i h_{1,1} \\
y_{0}=s_{0}+i s_{1} & y_{1}=s_{0}-i s_{1} \\
z_{0}=i h_{3,0}+h_{3,1} & z_{1}=-i h_{3,0}+h_{3,1}
\end{array}
$$

The Galois group of $\mathbf{F}_{9}$ over $\mathbf{F}_{3}$ acts here by conjugating scalars and permuting the two subscripts. Then we have

$$
R \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9}=E\left(\zeta_{2}, x_{0}, x_{1}\right) \otimes P\left(y_{0}, y_{1}\right) /\left(x_{0} x_{1}, x_{0} y_{1}-x_{1} y_{0}\right)
$$

where the cohomological degrees of $x_{i}$ and $y_{i}$ are 1 and $2 / 3$ respectively. In the spectral sequence we have

$$
d_{2}\left(z_{0}\right)=y_{0}^{2} y_{1} \quad \text { and } \quad d_{2}\left(z_{1}\right)=y_{0} y_{1}^{2}
$$

The image of $H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2)) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9}$ in $R \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9}$ is a free module over the ring

$$
B=E\left(\zeta_{2}\right) \otimes P\left(y_{0}^{3}, y_{1}^{3}\right)
$$

on the following set of six generators.

$$
C=\left\{1, x_{0}, x_{1}, y_{0}^{2} y_{1}, y_{0} y_{1}^{2}, x_{0} y_{0} y_{1}^{2}=x_{1} y_{0}^{2} y_{1}\right\}
$$

Hence the image of $E\left(h_{3,0}, h_{3,1}\right) \otimes H^{*}(\tilde{L}(2,2)) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{9}$ is a free $B$-module on the set

$$
\left\{1, z_{0}, z_{1}, z_{0} z_{1}\right\} \otimes C
$$

but it is convenient to replace this basis by the set of elements listed in the following table.

| 1 | $z_{0}$ | $z_{1}$ | $z_{0} z_{1}$ |
| :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: |
| $x_{0}$ | $x_{0} z_{0}$ | $\beta=x_{0} z_{1}-x_{1} z_{0}$ | $-x_{0} z_{0} z_{1}$ |
| $x_{1}$ | $\delta=-x_{1} z_{0}-x_{0} z_{1}$ | $x_{1} z_{1}$ | $x_{1} z_{0} z_{1}$ |

This basis is Galois invariant up to sign, i.e., the Galois image of each basis element is another basis element. The elements $1, x_{0} y_{0} y_{1}^{2}, \delta$, and $\gamma$ are self-conjugate, while $\beta, \varepsilon, z_{0} z_{1}$ and $x_{0} y_{0} y_{1}^{2} z_{0} z_{1}$ are antiself-conjugate. The remaining elements form eight conjugate pairs.

In the spectral sequence the following twelve differentials (listed as six Poincaré dual pairs) are easily derived from (6.3.25) and account for each of these 24 basis elements.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d_{2}\left(z_{0}\right)=y_{0}^{2} y_{1} \quad d_{2}\left(x_{1} z_{0} z_{1}\right)=x_{1} \varepsilon \\

& d_{2}(\gamma)=y_{0}^{3} y_{1}^{3}(1) \quad d_{2}\left(x_{0} y_{0} y_{1}^{2} z_{0} z_{1}\right)=y_{0}^{3} y_{1}^{3}(\beta)

The only nontrivial products among these six elements are

# 4. The Odd Primary Kervaire Invariant Elements 

The object of this section is to apply the machinery above to show that the Adams-Novikov element $\beta_{p^{i} / p^{i}} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2}$ (see 5.1.19) is not a permanent cycle for $p>2$ and $i>0$. This holds for the corresponding Adams element $b_{i}$ (4.3.2) for $p>3$ and $i>0$; by 5.4 .6 we know $\beta_{p^{i} / p^{i}}$ maps to $b_{i}$. The latter corresponds to the secondary cohomology operation associated with the Adem relation $P^{(p-1) p^{i}} P^{p^{i}}=$ $\cdots$. The analogous relation for $p=2$ is $S q^{2^{i}} S q^{2^{i}}=\cdots$, which leads to the element $h_{i}^{2}$, which is related to the Kervaire invariant by Browder's theorem, hence the title of the section. To stress this analogy we will denote $\beta_{p^{i} / p^{i}}$ by $\theta_{i}$.

We know by direct calculation (e.g., 4.4.20) that $\theta_{0}$ is a permanent cycle corresponding to the first element in coker $J$. By Toda's theorem (4.4.22) we know $\theta_{1}$ is not a permanent cycle; instead we have $d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{1}\right)=\alpha_{1} \theta_{0}^{p}$ (up to nonzero scalar multiplication) and this is the first nontrivial differential in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. Our main result is
6.4.1. Odd Primary Kervaire Invariant Theorem. In the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $p>2 d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i+1}\right) \equiv \alpha_{1} \theta_{i}^{p} \bmod \operatorname{ker} \theta_{0}^{\alpha_{i}}$ (up to nonzero scalar multiplication) where $a_{i}=p\left(p^{i}-1\right) /(p-1)$ and $\alpha_{1} \theta_{i}^{p}$ is nonzero modulo this indeterminacy.

Our corresponding result about the Adams spectral sequence fails for $p=3$, where $b_{2}$ is a permanent cycle even though $b_{1}$ is not.
6.4.2. ThEOREM. In the Adams spectral sequence for $p \geq 5 b_{i}$ is not a permanent cycle for $i \geq 1$.

From 6.4.1 we can derive the nonexistence of certain finite complexes which would be useful for constructing homotopy elements with Novikov filtration 2.
6.4.3. ThEOREM. There is no connective spectrum $X$ such that

$$
B P_{*}(X)=B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{\varrho^{i}}, v_{2}^{\varrho^{i}}\right)
$$

for $i>0$ and $p>2$.
Proof. Using methods developed by Smith [1], one can show that such an $X$ must be an 8 -cell complex and that there must be cofibrations

(i) $\Sigma^{2 p^{\prime}\left(p^{2}-1\right)} Y \xrightarrow{f} Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$,
(ii) $\Sigma^{2 p^{\prime}(p-1)} V(0) \xrightarrow{g} V(0) \rightarrow Y$,
(iii) $\Sigma^{2 p^{\prime}(p-1)} V(0) \xrightarrow{g^{\prime}} V(0) \rightarrow Y^{\prime}$,
where $V(0)$ is the $\bmod (p)$ Moore spectrum, $g$ and $g^{\prime}$ induce multiplication by $v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}$ in $B P_{*}(V(0))=B P_{*} /(p)$, and $f$ induces multiplication by $v_{2}^{p^{\prime}}$ in

$$
B P_{*}(Y)=B P_{*}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)=B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}\right)
$$

$V(0)$ and the maps $g, g^{\prime}$ certainly exist; e.g., Smith showed that there is a map

$$
\alpha: \Sigma^{2(p-1)} V(0) \rightarrow V(0)
$$

which includes multiplication by $v_{1}$, hence $\alpha^{p^{\prime}}$ induces multiplication by $v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}$, but it may not be the only map that does so.

Hence we have to show that the existence of $f$ leads to a contradiction. Consider the composite

$$
S^{2 p^{\prime}\left(p^{2}-1\right)} \xrightarrow{j} \Sigma^{2 p^{\prime}\left(p^{2}-1\right)} Y \xrightarrow{f} Y^{\prime} \xrightarrow{k} S^{2+2 p^{\prime}(p-1)}
$$

where $j$ is the inclusion of the bottom cell and $k$ is the collapse onto the top cell. We will show that the resulting element in $\pi_{2 p^{\prime+1}(p-1)-2}^{s}$ would be detected in the Novikov spectral sequence by $\theta_{i}$, thus contradicting 6.4.1. The cofibrations (ii) and (iii) induce the following short exact sequence of $B P^{*}$ modules

$$
0 \rightarrow \Sigma^{2 p^{\prime}(p-1)} B P_{*} /(p) \xrightarrow{v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}} B P_{*} /(p) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

and the cofibration

$$
S^{0} \xrightarrow{p} S^{0} \rightarrow V(0)
$$

induces

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*} /(p) \rightarrow 0
$$

Hence we get connecting homomorphisms

$$
\delta_{1}: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}\right)\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right)
$$

and

$$
\delta_{0}: \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

The element $f j \in \pi_{2 p^{\prime}\left(p^{2}-1\right)}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ is detected by $v_{2}^{p^{\prime}} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{\prime}}\right)\right)$. We know (5.1.19) that

$$
\theta_{i}=\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p^{\prime}}\right) \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

detects the element $k f j \in \pi_{2 p^{\prime+1}(p-1)-2}^{S}$.
The statement in 6.4.1 that $\alpha_{1} \theta_{i}^{p}$ is nonzero modulo the indeterminacy is a corollary of the following result, which relies heavily on the results of the previous three sections.
6.4.4. Detection Theorem. In the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term for $p>2$ let $\theta^{I}$ be a monomial in the $\theta_{i}$. Then each $\theta^{I}$ and $\alpha_{1} \theta^{I}$ is nontrivial.

We are not asserting that these monomials are linearly independent, which indeed they are not. Certain relations among them will be used below to prove 6.4.1. Assuming 6.4.4, we have

Proof of 6.4.1. We begin with a computation in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right)$. We use the symbol $\theta_{i}$ to denote the $\bmod p$ reduction of the $\theta_{i}$ defined above in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$. We also let $h_{i}$ denote the element $-\left[t_{1}^{p^{i}}\right]$. In the cobar construction we have

$$
d\left[t_{2}\right]=-\left[t_{1} \mid t_{1}^{p}\right]+v_{1} \sum_{0<j<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{j}\left[t_{1}^{j} \mid t_{1}^{p-j}\right]
$$

so

$$
v_{1} \theta_{0}=-h_{0} h_{1}
$$

May [5] developed a general theory of Steenrod operations which is applicable to this Ext group (see A1.5). His operations are similar to the classical ones in ordinary cohomology, except for the fact that $P^{0} \neq 1$. Rather we have $P^{0}\left(h_{i}\right)=h_{i+1}$ and $P^{0}\left(\theta_{i}\right)=\theta_{i+1}$. We also have $\beta P^{0}\left(h_{i}\right)=\theta_{i}, \beta P^{0}\left(\theta_{i}\right)=0, \beta P^{0}\left(v_{1}\right)=0, P^{1}\left(\theta_{i}\right)=\theta_{i}^{p}$ and the Cartan formula implies that $P^{p^{j}}\left(\theta_{i}^{p^{j}}\right)=\theta_{i}^{p^{j+1}}$. Applying $\beta P^{0}$ to (6.4.6) gives

$$
0=\theta_{0} h_{2}-h_{1} \theta_{1}
$$

If we apply the operation $P^{p^{i-1}} P^{p^{i-2}} \cdots P^{1}$ to (6.4.5) we get

$$
h_{1+i} \theta_{1}^{p^{i}}=h_{2+i} \theta_{0}^{p^{i}}
$$

Now associated with the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*} /(p) \rightarrow 0
$$

there is a connecting homomorphism

$$
\delta: \operatorname{Ext}^{s, *}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{s+1, *}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

with $\delta\left(h_{i+1}\right)=\theta_{i}$. Applying $\delta$ to 6.4 .7 gives

$$
\theta_{i} \theta_{1}^{p^{i}}=\theta_{i+1} \theta_{0}^{p^{i}} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{\left(B P_{*} B P_{*}\right)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)
$$

We can now prove the theorem by induction on $i$, using 4.4.22 to start the induction. We have for $i>0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i+1}\right) \theta_{0}^{p^{i}} & =d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i+1} \theta_{0}^{p^{i}}\right) \\
& =d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i} \theta_{1}^{p^{i}}\right) \\
& =d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i}\right) \theta_{1}^{p^{i}} \\
& \equiv h_{0} \theta_{i-1}^{p} \theta_{1}^{p^{i}} \bmod \operatorname{ker} \theta_{0}^{a_{i-1}} \\
& \equiv h_{0}\left(\theta_{i-1} \theta_{1}^{p^{i-1}}\right)^{p} \\
& \equiv h_{0}\left(\theta_{i} \theta_{0}^{p^{i-1}}\right)^{p} \\
& \equiv h_{0} \theta_{i}^{p} \theta_{0}^{p^{i}}
\end{aligned}
$$

so

$$
d_{2 p-1}\left(\theta_{i+1}\right) \equiv h_{0} \theta_{i}^{p} \quad \bmod \operatorname{ker} \theta_{0}^{a_{i}}
$$

We now turn to the proof of 6.4.4. We map $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Ext}\left(v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)$ with $n=p-1$. By 6.1.1 this group is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}\right)$, which is essentially the cohomology of the profinite group $S_{n}$ by 6.2.4. By $6.2 .12 S_{n}$ has a subgroup of order $p$ since the field $K$ obtained by adjoining $p$ th roots of unity to $\mathbf{Q}_{p}$ has degree $p-1$. We will show that the elements of 6.4.4 have nontrivial images under the resulting map to the cohomology of $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$. In other words, we will consider the composite

$$
B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow \Sigma(n) \rightarrow S(n) \otimes \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}} \rightarrow C
$$

where $C$ is the linear dual of the group ring $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}[\mathbf{Z} /(p)]$.
6.4.9. Lemma. Let $C$ be as above. As a Hopf algebra

$$
C=\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}[t] /\left(t^{p}-t\right) \quad \text { with } \quad \Delta t=t \otimes 1+1 \otimes t
$$

Proof. As a Hopf algebra we have $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}[\mathbf{Z} /(p)]=\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}[u] /\left(u^{p}-1\right)$ with $\Delta u=$ $u \otimes u$, where $u$ corresponds to a generator of the group $\mathbf{Z} /(p)$. We define an element $t \in C$ by its Kronecker pairing $\left\langle u^{i}, t\right\rangle=i$. Since the product in $C$ is dual to the coproduct in the group algebra, we have

$$
\left\langle u^{i}, t^{k}\right\rangle=\left\langle\Delta\left(u^{i}\right), t \otimes t^{k-1}\right\rangle=\left\langle u^{i}, t\right\rangle\left\langle u^{i}, t^{k-1}\right\rangle
$$

so by induction on $k$

$$
\left\langle u^{i}, t^{k}\right\rangle=i^{k}
$$

We also have $\left\langle u^{i}, 1\right\rangle=1$.
We show that $\left\{1, t, t^{2}, \ldots, t^{p-1}\right\}$ is a basis for $C$ by relating it to the dual basis of the group algebra. Define $x_{j} \in C$ by

$$
x_{j}=\sum_{0<k<p}(j t)^{k}
$$

for $0<j<p$ and $x_{0}=1+\sum_{0<j<p} x_{j}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle u^{i}, x_{j}\right\rangle & =\left\langle u^{i}, \sum_{0<k<p}(j t)^{k}\right\rangle=\sum_{0<k<p} j^{k} i^{k} \\
& =\sum_{0<k<p}(i j)^{k}= \begin{cases}-1 & \text { if } i j=1 \bmod p \\
0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\left\langle u^{i}, x_{0}\right\rangle=\left\langle u^{i}, 1+\sum_{0<j<p} x_{j}\right\rangle= \begin{cases}1 & \text { if } i=0 \\ 0 & i \neq 0\end{cases}
$$

so $\left\{x_{0},-x_{1},-x_{2}, \ldots,-x_{p-1}\right\}$ is the dual basis up to permutation.
Moreover, 6.4.10 implies that $t^{p}=t$ so $C$ has the desired algebra structure.
For the coalgebra structure we use the fact that the coproduct in $C$ is dual the product in the group algebra. We have

$$
\left\langle u^{i} \otimes u^{j}, t \otimes 1+1 \otimes t\right\rangle=i+j
$$

and

$$
\left\langle u^{i} \otimes u^{j}, \Delta(t)\right\rangle=\left\langle u^{i+j}, t\right\rangle=i+j
$$

so $\Delta t=t \otimes 1+1 \otimes t$.

To proceed with the proof of 6.4.4; we now show that under the epimorphism

$$
f: \Sigma(n) \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}} \rightarrow C \quad(\text { where } n=p-1), \quad f\left(t_{1}\right) \neq 0
$$

From the proof of 6.2.3, $t_{1}$ can be regarded as a continuous function from $S_{n}$ to $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$. It follows then that the nontriviality of $f\left(t_{1}\right)$ is equivalent to the nonvanishing of the function $t_{1}$ on the nontrivial element of order $p$ in $S_{n}$. Suppose $x \in S_{p-1}$ is such an element. We can write

$$
x=1+\sum_{i>0} e_{i} S^{i}
$$

with $e_{i} \in W\left(\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right)$ and $e_{i}^{p^{n}}=e_{i}$. Recalling that $S^{p-1}=p$, we compute

$$
1=x^{p} \equiv 1+p e_{1} S+\left(e_{1} S\right)^{p} \bmod (S)^{1+p}
$$

and

$$
\left(e_{1} S\right)^{p} \equiv e_{1}^{\left(p^{p}-1\right) /(p-1)} S^{p} \quad \bmod (S)^{1+p}
$$

so it follows that

$$
e_{1}+e_{1}^{\left(p^{p}-1\right) /(p-1)} \equiv 0 \quad \bmod (p)
$$

[Remember that $t_{1}(x)$ is the $\bmod (p)$ reduction of $e_{1}$.] Clearly, one solution to this equation is $e_{1} \equiv 0 \bmod (p)$ and hence $e_{1}=0$. We exclude this possibility by showing that it implies that $x=1$. Suppose inductively that $e_{i}=0$ for $i<k$. Then $x \equiv 1+e_{k} S^{k} \bmod \left(S^{k+1}\right)$ and $x^{p} \equiv 1+p e_{k} S^{k} \bmod \left(S^{k+p}\right)$ so $e_{k} \equiv 0 \bmod (p)$. Since $e_{k}^{p^{n}}-e_{k}=0$, this implies $e_{k}=0$.

Hence, $f$ is a map of Hopf algebras, $f\left(t_{1}\right)$ primitive, so $f\left(t_{1}\right)=c t$ where $c \in \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$ is nonzero. Now recall that

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{C}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}, \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right)=H^{*}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p) ; \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right)=E(h) \otimes P(b)
$$

where $E()$ and $P()$ denote exterior and polynomial algebras over $\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}$, respectively, $h=[t] \in H^{1}$, and

$$
b=\sum_{0<j<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{j}\left[t^{j} \mid t^{p-j}\right] \in H^{2}
$$

Let $f^{*}$ denote the composition

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right) & \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}\left(v_{n}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{n}\right) \\
& \xrightarrow{\cong} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{C}\left(\mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}, \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right) \xrightarrow{\cong} H^{*}\left(\mathbf{Z} /(p) ; \mathbf{F}_{p^{n}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then it follows that $f^{*}\left(h_{0}\right)=-c h$ and $f^{*}\left(b_{i}\right)=-c^{p^{i+1}} b$ and 6.4.4 is proved.
Note that the scalar $c$ must satisfy $1+c^{\left(p^{p}-p\right) /(p-1)}=0$. Since $c^{p^{p-1}-1}=1$, the equation is equivalent to $1+c^{\left(p^{p-1}-1\right) /(p-1)}=0$. It follows that $c=w^{(p-1) / 2}$ for some generator $w$ of $\mathbf{F}_{p^{p-1}}^{+}$, so $c$ is not contained in any proper subfield of $\mathbf{F}_{p^{p-1}}$. Hence tensoring with this field is essential to the construction of the detecting map $f$.

Now we examine the corresponding situation in the Adams spectral sequence. The relations used to prove 6.4.1 (apart from the assertion of nontriviality) are also valid here, but the machinery used to prove 6.4 .4 is, of course, not available. Indeed the monomials vanish in some cases. The following result was first proved by May [1].
6.4.11. Proposition. For $p=3, h_{0} b_{1}^{3}=0$ in $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{3}}(\mathbf{Z} /(3), \mathbf{Z} /(3))$; i.e., $b_{2}$ cannot support the expected nontrivial differential.

Proof. We use a certain Massey product identity (A1.4.6) and very simple facts about $\operatorname{Ext}_{A_{3}}(\mathbf{Z} /(3), \mathbf{Z} /(3))$ to show $h_{0} b_{1}^{2}=0$. We have

$$
h_{0} b_{1}^{2}=-h_{0}\left\langle h_{1}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle b_{1}=-\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle h_{1} b_{1}
$$

By (6.4.7) $h_{1} b_{1}=h_{2} b_{0}$, so

$$
h_{0} b_{1}^{2}=-\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{1}\right\rangle h_{2} b_{0}=-\left\langle h_{1}, h_{0}, h_{1}\right\rangle h_{2} b_{0}=-h_{1}\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}\right\rangle b_{0}
$$

The element $\left\langle h_{0}, h_{1}, h_{2}\right\rangle$ is represented in the cobar construction by $\xi_{1}^{9} \mid \xi_{2}+\xi_{2}^{3} \mid \xi_{1}$, which is the coboundary of $\xi_{3}$, so $h_{0} b_{1}^{2}=0$.

The case of $b_{2}$ at $p=3$ is rather peculiar. One can show in the AdamsNovikov spectral sequence that $d_{5}\left(\beta_{7}\right)= \pm \alpha_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{3}$. (This follows from the facts that $d_{5}\left(\beta_{4}\right)= \pm \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{3 / 3}, \beta_{4}^{2}= \pm \beta_{1} \beta_{7}, \beta_{4} \beta_{3 / 3}= \pm \beta_{1} \beta_{6 / 3}$, and $\beta_{3 / 3}^{3}= \pm \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3}$. We leave the details to the reader.) Hence $\beta_{9 / 9} \pm \beta_{7}$ is a permanent cycle mapping to $b_{2}$. The elements $\beta_{7}$ and $\alpha_{1} \beta_{3 / 3}^{3}= \pm \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{2} \beta_{6 / 3}$ correspond to Adams elements in filtrations 8 and 10 which are linked by a differential. We do not know the fate of the $b_{i}$ at $p=3$ for $i>2$.

To prove 6.4.2 we will need two lemmas.
6.4.12. Lemma. For $p \geq 3$
(i) $\operatorname{Ext}^{2, q p^{i+2}}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ is generated by the $[(i+3) / 2]$ elements $\beta_{a_{i, j} / p^{i+3-2 j}}$, where $j=1,2, \ldots,[(i+3) / 2], a_{i, j}=\left(p^{i+2}+p^{i+3-2 j}\right) /(p+1)$, and $[(i+3) / 2]$ is the largest integer $\leq(i+3) / 2$. Each of these elements has order $p$.
(i) Each of these elements except $\beta_{p^{i+1} / p^{i+1}}$ reduces to zero in

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{2, q p^{i+2}}\left(B P^{*} / I_{3}\right)
$$

6.4.13. Lemma. For $p \geq 5$, any element of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2, q p^{i+2}}\left(B P_{*}\right)($ for $i \geq 0)$ which maps to $b_{i+1}$ in the Adams $E_{2}$-term supports a nontrivial differential $d_{2 p-1}$.

We have seen above that 6.4 .13 is false for $p=3$.
Theorem 6.4.2 follows immediately from 6.4.13 because a permanent cycle in the Adams spectral sequence of filtration 2 must correspond to one in the AdamsNovikov spectral sequence of filtration $\leq 2$. By sparseness (4.4.2) the Novikov filtration must also be 2 , but 6.4.13 says that no element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ mapping to $b_{i}$ for $i \geq 1$ can be a permanent cycle.

Proof of 6.4.12. Part (i) can be read off from the description of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2, *}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ given in 5.4.5.

To prove (ii) we recall the definition of the elements in question. We have short exact sequences of $B P_{*}(B P)$-comodules

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow B P_{*} \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} /(p) \rightarrow 0 \\
& 0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /(p) \xrightarrow{v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}} B P_{*} /(p) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}\right) \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\delta_{0}$ and $\delta_{1}$, denote the respective connecting homomorphisms. Then we have $v_{2}^{\delta_{1, j}} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*} B P}^{0}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{i+3-2 j}\right)\right)$ and $\beta_{\alpha_{i, j} p^{i+3-2 j}}=\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{\alpha_{1, j}}\right)$. The element $\beta_{p^{i+1} / p^{i+1}}$ the above element for $j=1$ ) can be shown to be $b_{i+1}$ as follows. The right unit formula 4.3.21 gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right) & \equiv v_{2}+v_{1} t_{1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1} \quad \bmod (p) \\
\delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p^{i+1}}\right) & =t_{1}^{p^{i+2}}-v_{1}^{p^{i+2}-p^{i+1}} t_{1}^{p^{i+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\delta_{0}\left(t_{1}^{p^{i+2}}\right)=b_{i+1}$. Moreover 6.4.16 implies that in $\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} /(p)\right)$,

$$
v_{1}^{p^{i}} t_{1}^{p j+1} \cong v_{1}^{p^{i+1}} t_{1}^{p^{i}}, \quad \text { so } \quad v_{1}^{p^{i+2}-p^{i+1}} t_{1}^{p^{i+1}} \cong v_{1}^{p^{i+2}-1} t_{1}
$$

This element is the $\bmod (p)$ reduction of $p^{-i-2} \delta_{0}\left(v_{1}^{p^{i+2}}\right)$ and is therefore in $\operatorname{ker} \delta_{0}$. Hence $\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p^{i+1}}\right)=\delta_{0}\left(t_{1}^{p^{i+2}}\right)=b_{i+1}$.

This definition of $\beta_{p^{i+1} / p^{i+1}}$ differs from that of 5.4.5, where for $i>0$ it is defined to be $\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(v_{2}^{p^{2}}-v_{1}^{p^{2}-1} v_{2}^{p^{2}-p+1}\right)^{p^{i-1}}$.

In principle one can compute this element explicitly in the cobar complex (A1.2.11) and reduce $\bmod I_{3}$, but that would be very messy. A much easier method can be devised using Yoneda's interpretation of elements in Ext groups as equivalence classes of exact sequences (see, for example, Chapter IV of Hilton and Stammbach [1]) as in 5.1.20(b). Consider the following diagram.
![img-56.jpeg](img-56.jpeg)

The top row is obtained by splicing 6.4.14 and 6.4.15 and it corresponds to an element in $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}\right), B P_{*}\right)$. Composing this element with

$$
v_{2}^{a_{i, j}} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{i+3-2 j}\right)\right)
$$

gives $\beta_{a_{i, j} / p^{i+3-2 j}}$.
We let $p_{1}$ be the standard surjection. It follows from Yoneda's result that if we choose $B P_{*} B P$-comodules $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$, and comodule maps $p_{2}$ and $p_{3}$ such that the diagram commutes and the bottom row is exact, then the latter will determine the element of

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}}^{2} B P\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{i+3-2 j}\right), B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)\right)
$$

which, when composed with $v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}$, will give the $\bmod I_{3}$ reduction of $\beta_{a_{i, j} / p^{i+3-2 j}}$. We choose $M_{1}=B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, v_{1}^{2}, p v_{2}\right)$ and $M_{2}=B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2+p^{i+3-2 j}}\right)$ and let $p_{2}$ and $p_{3}$ be the standard surjections. It is easy to check that $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$ are comodules over $B P_{*}(B P)$, i.e., that the corresponding ideals in $B P_{*}$ are invariant. (The ideal used to define $M_{1}$ is simply $I_{2}^{2}+I_{1} I_{3}$.) Moreover, the resulting diagram has the desired properties.

The resulting bottom row of 6.4.17 is the splice of the two following short exact sequences.

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}\right) \xrightarrow{p} B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, p v_{2}, v_{1}^{2}\right) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

(6.4.19) $0 \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}} B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2+p^{i+3-2 j}}\right) \rightarrow B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}\right) \rightarrow 0$.

Let $\delta_{0}^{\prime}, \delta_{1}^{\prime}$ denote the corresponding connecting homomorphisms. The elements we are interested in then are $\delta_{0}^{\prime} \delta_{1}^{\prime}\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}\right)$.

To compute $\delta_{1}^{\prime}\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}\right)$ we use the formula $d\left(v_{2}^{n}\right)=\left(v_{2}+v_{1} v_{1} t_{1}^{n}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1}\right)^{n}-v_{2}^{n}$, implied by 6.4.16, in the cobar construction for $B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2+p^{i+3-2 j}}\right)$. Recall that

$$
a_{i, j}=\left(p^{i+2}+p^{i+3-2 j}\right) /(p+1) \quad 1 \leq j \leq[(i+3) / 2]
$$

Hence $a_{i, j}=p^{i+3-2 j} \bmod \left(p^{i+4-2 j}\right)$ and $d\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}\right)=v_{2}^{b_{i, j}} v_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}\left[t_{1}^{p^{i+4-2 j}}\right]$, so

$$
\delta_{1}^{\prime}\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}\right)=v_{2}^{b_{i, j}}\left[t_{1}^{p^{i+3-2 j}}\right]
$$

where $b_{i, j}=a_{i, j}-p^{i+3-2 j}=\left(p^{i+2}-p^{i+4-2 j}\right) /(p+1)$.
For $j=1, b_{i, 1}=0$ and

$$
\delta_{0}^{\prime} \delta_{1}^{\prime}\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, 1}}\right)=-\sum_{0<k<p} \frac{1}{p}\binom{p}{k}\left[t_{1}^{k p^{i}} \mid t_{1}^{(p-k) p^{i}}\right]=-b_{i+1}
$$

For $j>1, b_{i, j}$ is divisible by $p$ and $d\left(v_{2}^{b_{i, j}}\right) \equiv 0 \bmod \left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, v_{1}^{2}\right)$ and

$$
v_{2}^{b_{i, j}} d\left(t_{1}^{p^{i+4-2 j}}\right) \equiv 0 \quad \bmod \left(p v_{2}\right)
$$

so $\delta_{1}^{\prime} v_{2}^{a_{i, j}} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}^{2}\right)\right)$ pulls back in 6.4.17 to an element of

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*} /\left(p^{2}, p v_{1}, p v_{2}, v^{2}\right)\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \delta_{0}^{\prime} \delta_{1}^{\prime}\left(v_{2}^{a_{i, j}}\right)=0
$$

completing the proof.
Proof of 6.4.13. Any element of $\operatorname{Ext}^{2, q p^{i+2}}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ can be written uniquely as $c b_{i+1}+x$ where $x$ is in the subgroup generated by the elements $\beta_{a_{i, j} / p^{i+3-2 j}}$ for $j>1$. In 5.4.6, we showed that $x$ maps to zero in the classical Adams $E_{2}$-term. Hence it suffices to show that no such $x$ can have the property

$$
d_{2 p-1}(x)=d_{2 p-1}\left(b_{i+1}\right)
$$

By 5.5.2 for $p \geq 5$ there is an 8 -cell spectrum $V(2)=M\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ with $B P_{*}(V(2))=B P_{*} /\left(p, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$, and a map $f: S^{0} \rightarrow V(2)$ inducing a surjection in $B P$ homology. $f$ also induces the standard map

$$
f_{*}: \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*} / I_{3}\right)
$$

Lemma 6.4.12 asserts that $f_{*}\left(\beta_{a_{i, j} / p^{i+3-2 j}}\right)=0$ for $j>1$, so $f_{*}\left(d_{2 p-1}(x)\right)=0$ where $x$ is as above. However, 6.4.1 and the proof of 6.4.4 show that

$$
g_{*}\left(d_{2 p-1}\left(b_{i+1}\right)\right) \neq 0
$$

where $g_{*}$ is induced by the obvious map

$$
g: B P_{*} \rightarrow v_{p-1}^{-1} B P_{*} / I_{p-1}
$$

Since $g$ factors through $B P_{*} / I_{3}$, this shows that $f_{*}\left(d_{2 p-1}\left(b_{i+1}\right)\right) \neq 0$, completing the proof.

# 5. The Spectra $T(m)$ 

In this section will we construct certain spectra $T(m)$ and study the corresponding chromatic spectral sequence. $T(m)$ satisfies

$$
B P_{*}(T(m))=B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{m}\right] \subset B P_{*}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

as a comodule algebra. These are used in Chapter 7 in a computation of the AdamsNovikov $E_{2}$-term. We will see there that the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for $T(m)$ is easy to compute through a range of dimensions that grows rapidly with $m$, and here we will show that its chromatic spectral sequence is very regular.

To construct the $T(m)$ recall that $B U=\Omega S U$ by Bott periodicity, so we have maps $\Omega S U(k) \rightarrow B U$ for each $k$. Let $X(k)$ be the Thom spectrum of

the corresponding vector bundle over $\Omega S U(k)$. An easy calculation shows that $H_{*}(X(k))=\mathbf{Z}\left[b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{k-1}\right] \subset H_{*}(M U)$. Our first result is
6.5.1. Splitting Theorem. For any prime $p, X(k)_{(p)}$ is equivalent to a wedge of suspensions of $T(m)$ with $m$ chosen so that $p^{m} \leq k<p^{m+1}$, and $B P_{*}(T(m))=$ $B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right] \subset B P_{*}(B P)$. Moreover $T(m)$ is a homotopy associative commutative ring spectrum.

From this we get a diagram

$$
S_{(p)}^{0}=T(0) \rightarrow T(1) \rightarrow T(2) \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow B P
$$

In Ravenel [8, §3] we show that after $p$-adic completion there are no essential maps from $T(i)$ to $T(j)$ if $i>j$ or from $B P$ to $T(i)$.

This theorem is an analog of 4.1.12, which says that $M U_{(p)}$ splits into a wedge of suspensions of $B P$, as is its proof. We start with the following generalization of 4.1.1.
6.5.2. Definition. Let $E$ be an associative commutative ring spectrum. A complex orientation of degree $k$ for $E$ is a class $x_{E} \in \widetilde{E}^{2}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{k}\right)$ whose restriction to $\widetilde{E}^{2}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{1}\right) \cong \pi_{0}(E)$ is 1 .

A complex orientation as in 4.1.1 is of degree $k$ for all $k>0$. This notion is relevant in view of
6.5.3. Lemma. $X(k)$ admits a complex orientation of degree $k$.

Proof. $X(k)$ is a commutative associative ring spectrum (up to homotopy) because $\Omega S U(k)$ is a double loop space. The standard map $\mathbf{C} P^{k-1} \rightarrow B U$ lifts to $\Omega S U(k)$. Thomifying gives a stable map $\mathbf{C} P^{k} \rightarrow X(k)$ with the desired properties.
$X(k)$ plays the role of $M U$ in the theory of spectra with orientation of degree $k$. The generalizations of lemmas 4.1.4, 4.1.7, 4.1.8, and 4.1.13 are straightforward. We have
6.5.4. Proposition. Let $E$ be an associative commutative ring spectrum with a complex orientation $x_{E} \in \widetilde{E}_{2}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{k}\right)$ of degree $k$.
(a) $E^{*}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{k}\right)=\pi_{*}(E)\left[x_{E}\right] /\left(x_{E}^{k+1}\right)$.
(b) $E^{*}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{k} \times \mathbf{C} P^{k}\right)=\pi_{*}(E)\left[x_{E} \otimes 1,1 \otimes x_{E}\right] /\left(x_{E}^{k+1} \otimes 1,1 \otimes x_{E}^{k+1}\right)$.
(c) For $0<i<k$ the map $t: \mathbf{C} P^{i} \times \mathbf{C} P^{k-i} \rightarrow \mathbf{C} P^{k}$ induces a formal group law $k$-chunk; i.e., the element $t^{*}\left(x_{E}\right)$ in the truncated power series ring

$$
\pi_{*}(E)\left[x_{E} \otimes 1,1 \otimes x_{E}\right] /\left(x_{E} \otimes 1,1 \otimes x_{E}\right)^{k+1}
$$

has properties analogous to an formal group law (A2.1.1).
(d) $E_{*}(X(k))=\pi_{*}(E)\left[b_{1}^{E}, \ldots, b_{k-1}^{E}\right]$ where $b_{i}^{E} \in E_{2 i}(X(k))$ is defined as in 4.1.7.
(e) With notation as in 4.1.8, in $(E \wedge X(k))^{2}\left(\mathbf{C} P^{k}\right)$ we have

$$
\hat{x}_{X(k)}=\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k-1} b_{i}^{E} \hat{x}_{E}^{i+1} \quad \text { where } \quad b_{0}=1
$$

This power series will be denoted by $g_{E}\left(\hat{x}_{E}\right)$.
