(f) There is a one-to-one correspondence between degree $k$ orientations of $E$ and multiplicative maps $X(k) \rightarrow E$ as in 4.1.13.

We do not have a generalization of 4.1.15, i.e., a convenient way of detecting maps $X(k) \rightarrow X(k)$, but we can get by without it. By 6.5.4(f) a multiplicative map $g: X(k)_{(p)} \rightarrow X(k)_{(p)}$ is determined by a polynomial $f(x)=\sum_{0 \leq i \leq k-1} f_{i} x^{i+1}$ with $f_{0}=1$ and $f_{i} \in \pi_{2 i}\left(X(k)_{(p)}\right)$. In this range of dimensions $\pi_{*}(X(k))$ is isomorphic to $\pi_{*}(M U)$, so we can take $f(x)$ to be the truncated form of the power series of A2.1.23. Then the calculations of 4.1.12 show that $g$ induces an idempotent in ordinary or $B P_{*}$-homology. In the absence of 4.1.15 it does not follow that $g$ itself is idempotent. Nevertheless we can define

$$
T(m)=\lim _{g} X(k)_{(p)}
$$

i.e., $T(m)$ is the mapping telescope of $g$. Then we can compose the map $X(k)_{(p)} \rightarrow$ $T(m)$ with various self-maps of $X(k)_{(p)}$ to construct the desired splitting, thereby proving 6.5.1.

Now we consider the chromatic spectral sequence for $T(m)$. Using the change-of-rings isomorphism 6.1.1, the input needed for the machinery of Section 5.1 is $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}(T(m))\right)$ where $K(n)_{*}(T(m))=K(n)_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right]$. Using notation as in 6.3.7, let $\Sigma(n, m+1)=\Sigma(n) /\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right)$. Then we have

# 6.5.5. ThEOREM. With notation as above we have 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}\right. & \left.K(n)_{*}(T(m))\right) \\
& =K(n)_{*}\left[u_{n+1}, \ldots, u_{n+m}\right] \otimes_{K(n)_{*}} \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n, m+1)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\operatorname{dim} u_{j}=\operatorname{dim} v_{j} . \quad$ Moreover $u_{j}$ maps to $v_{j}$ under the map to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}(B P)\right)=B(n)_{*}(6.1 .11)$ induced by $T(m) \rightarrow B P$. In other words its image in $K(n)_{*}(B P)$ coincides with that of $\eta_{R}\left(v_{j}\right) \in B P_{*}(B P)$ under the map $B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow K(n)_{*}(B P)$.

Applying 6.3.7 gives

### 6.5.6. Corollary. If $n<m+2$ and $n<2(p-1)(m+1) / p$ then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(n)}\left(K(n)_{*}, K(n)_{*}(T(m))\right) \\
& \quad=K(n)_{*}\left[u_{n+1}, \ldots, u_{n+m}\right] \otimes E\left(h_{k, j}: m+1 \leq k \leq m+n, \quad j \in \mathbf{Z} /(n)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of 6.5.5. The images of $\eta_{R}\left(v_{n+j}\right)$ (for $1 \leq j \leq m$ ) in $K(n)_{*}(T(m))$ are primitive and give the $u_{n+j}$. The image of $B P_{*}(T(m)) \rightarrow B P_{*}(B P) \rightarrow \Sigma(n)$ is the subalgebra generated by $\left\{t_{n}: n \leq m\right\}$. The result follows by a routine argument.

Now we will use the chromatic spectral sequence to compute $\operatorname{Ext}^{*}\left(B P_{*}(T(m))\right)$ for $s=0$ and 1 . We assume $m>0$ since $T(0)=S^{0}$, which was considered in 5.2.1 and 5.2.6. By 6.5.5 and 6.5.6 we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(0)}\left(K(0)_{*}, K(0)_{*}(T(m))\right)=\mathbf{Q}\left[u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right] \quad \text { and } \\
& \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma(1)}\left(K(1)_{*}, K(1)_{*}(T(m))\right)=K(1)_{*}\left[u_{2}, \ldots, u_{m+1}\right] \otimes E\left(h_{m+1,0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow M_{1}^{0} \otimes B P_{*}(T(m)) \xrightarrow{i} M^{1} \otimes B P_{*}(T(m)) \xrightarrow{p} M^{1} \otimes B P_{*}(T(m)) \rightarrow 0
$$

induces a six-term exact sequence of Ext groups with connecting homomorphism $\delta$. For $j \leq m, \eta_{R}\left(v_{j}\right) \in B P_{*}(T(m)) \subset B P_{*}(B P)$, so if $u$ is any monomial in these elements then $\delta\left(u / p^{i}\right)=0$ for all $i>0$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1} \otimes B P_{*}(T(m))\right)$ has a corresponding summand isomorphic to $\mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}(p)$. Hence in the chromatic spectral sequence, $E_{1}^{1,0}$ has a summand isomorphic to $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right] \otimes \mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}(p)$, which is precisely the image of $d_{1}: E_{1}^{0,0} \rightarrow E_{1}^{1,0}$, giving

# 6.5.9. Proposition. 

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*}(T(m))\right)=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right]
$$

Next we need to consider the divisibility of $u_{m+1}^{t} / p \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(M^{1} \otimes B P_{*}(T(m))\right)$. Note that $\eta_{R}\left(v_{m+1}\right)$ is not in $B P_{*}(T(m))$ but $\eta_{R}\left(v_{m+1}\right)-p t_{m+1}$ (where $v_{m+1}$ is Hazewinkel's generator given by A2.2.1) is, so we call this element $u_{m+1}$. It follows that in the cobar complex $C\left(B P_{*}(T(m))\right)$ (A1.2.11) $d\left(u_{m+1}\right)=p t_{m+1}$ and

$$
d\left(u_{m+1}^{t}\right) \equiv \operatorname{pt} u_{m+1}^{t-1} t_{m+1}+p^{2}\binom{t}{2} u_{m+1}^{t-2} t_{m+1}^{2} \quad \bmod \left(p^{2} t\right)
$$

where the second term is nonzero only when $p=2$ and $t$ is even. Thus the situation is similar to that for $m=0$ where we have $v_{1}=u_{1}$. Recall that in that case the presence of the second term caused $\mathrm{Ext}^{1}$ to behave differently at $p=2$. We will show that this does not happen for $m \geq 1$ and we have

### 6.5.11. TheOREM. For $m \geq 1$ and all primes $p$

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}(T(m))\right)=\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*}(T(m))\right) \otimes\left\{u_{m+1}^{t} / \mathrm{pt}: t>0\right\}
$$

Proof. For $p>2$ the result follows from 6.5.10 as in 5.2.6. Now recall the situation for $m=0, p=2$. For $t=2,6.5 .10$ gives $d\left(v_{1}^{2}\right)=4\left(v_{1} t_{1}+t_{1}^{2}\right)$ and we have $d\left(4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}\right) \equiv 4\left(v_{2} t_{1}+t_{1}^{2}\right) \bmod (8)$, so we get a cocycle $\left(v_{1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} v_{2}\right) / 8$. The analogous cocycle for $m \geq 1$ would be something like

$$
\left(u_{m+1}^{2}+4 v_{1}^{-1} u_{m+2}\right) / q
$$

where $u_{m+2}$ is related somehow to $v_{m+2}$. However, the relevant terms in $\eta_{R}\left(v_{m+2}\right)$ $\bmod (2)$ are $v_{1} t_{m+1}^{2}+v_{2}^{2^{m+1}} t_{m+1}$, which does not bear the resemblance to 6.5.10 for $m \geq 1$ that it does for $m=0$. In other words $u_{m+1}^{t-2} t_{m+1}^{2}$ is not cohomologous $\bmod (2)$ to $u_{m+1}^{t-1} t_{m+1}$, so the calculation for $p=2$ can proceed as it does for $p>2$.

Our last result is useful for computing the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term for $T(m)$ by the method used in Section 4.4.

### 6.5.12. TheOREM. For $t<2\left(p^{2 m+2}-1\right)$

$\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}(T(m)\right) / I_{m+1})=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[u_{m+1}, u_{m+2}, \ldots, u_{2 m+1}\right] \otimes E\left(h_{i, j}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{i, j}\right)$
with $i \geq m+1, i+j \leq 2 m+2, h_{i, j} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,2 p^{j}\left(p^{i}-1\right)}$ and $b_{i, j} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{2,2 p^{i+1}\left(p^{i}-1\right)}$.
6.5.13. EXAMPLE. For $m=1$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}\left(B P_{*}(T(1)\right) / I_{2}\right)=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[u_{2}, u_{3}\right] \otimes E\left(h_{2,0}, h_{2,1}, h_{2,2}, h_{3,0}, h_{3,1}\right) \\
 \otimes P\left(b_{2,0}, b_{2,1}, b_{3,0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in 6.5.1 for $t \leq 2\left(p^{4}-1\right)$

Proof of 6.5.12. By a routine change-of-rings argument (explained in Section 7.1) the Ext in question is the cohomology of $C_{\Gamma}\left(B P_{*} / I_{m+1}\right)$ (A1.2.11) where $\Gamma=B P_{*}(B P) /\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right)$. Then from 4.3 .15 and 4.3 .20 we can deduce that $v_{i}$ and $t_{i}$ are primitive for $m+1 \leq i \leq 2 m+1$. $h_{i, j}$ corresponds to $t_{i}^{p^{i}}$ and $b_{i, j}$ to $-\sum_{0<k<p} p^{-1}\left(\frac{p}{k}\right) t_{i}^{k p^{i}}\left|t_{i}^{(p-k) p^{i}}\right.$. The result follows by routine calculation.

# CHAPTER 7 

## Computing Stable Homotopy Groups with the Adams-Novikov Spectral Sequence

In this chapter we apply the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence to the motivating problem of this book, the stable homotopy groups of spheres. Our main accomplishment is to find the first thousand stems for $p=5$, the previous record being 760 by Aubry [1]. In Section 1 we describe the method of infinite descent for computing the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence $E_{2}$-term in a range of dimensions, namely to find it for the spectra $T(m)$ of Section 6.5 by downward induction on $m$. Recall $B P_{*}(T(m))=B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right]$ as a comodule, so $T(m)$ is equivalent to $B P$ in dimensions less than $\left|v_{m+1}\right|$. This starts our downward induction since we always restrict our attention to a finite range of dimensions.

In Section 2 we construct a resolution enabling us in theory to extract the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term for $S^{0}$ from that for $T(1)$. In practice we must proceed more slowly, computing for skeleta $T(1)^{\left(p^{\prime}-1\right) q}$ by downward induction on $i$. In Section 3 we do this down to $i=1$; see 7.5.1. $T(1)^{(p-1) q}$ is a complex with $p$ cells, its Adams-Novikov spectral sequence collapses in our range, and its homotopy is surprisingly regular.

In Section 4 we take the final step from $T(1)^{(p-1) q}$ to $S^{0}$. We have a spectral sequence (7.1.16) for this calculation and a practical procedure (7.1.18) for the required bookkeeping. We illustrate this method for $p=3$, but here our range of dimensions is not new; see Tangora [6] and Nakamura [3].

In Section 5 we describe the calculations for $p=5$, giving a running account of the more difficult differentials in the spectral sequence of 7.1.16 for that case. The results are tabulated in Appendix 3 and range up to the 1000-stem.

In more detail, the method in question involves the connective $p$-local ring spectra $T(m)$ of 6.5 , which satisfy

$$
B P_{*}(T(m))=B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right] \subset B P_{*}(B P)
$$

$T(0)$ is the $p$-local sphere spectrum, and there are maps

$$
S^{0}=T(0) \rightarrow T(1) \rightarrow T(2) \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow B P
$$

The map $T(m) \rightarrow B P$ is an equivalence below dimension $\left|v_{m+1}\right|-1=2 p^{m+1}-3$.
To descend from $\pi_{*}(T(m))$ to $\pi_{*}(T(m-1))$ we need some spectra interpolating between $T(m-1)$ and $T(m)$. Note that $B P_{*}(T(m))$ is a free module over $B P_{*}(T(m-1))$ on the generators $\left\{t_{m}^{j}: j \geq 0\right\}$. In Lemma 7.1.11 we show that for each $h$ there is a $T(m-1)$-module spectrum $T(m-1)_{h}$ with

$$
B P_{*}\left(T(m-1)_{h}\right)=B P_{*}(T(m-1))\left\{t_{m}^{j}: 0 \leq j \leq h\right\}
$$

We will be most interested in the case where $h$ is one less than a power of $p$, and we will denote $T(m)_{p^{\prime}-1}$ by $T(m)_{(i)}$.

We have inclusions

$$
T(m-1)=T(m-1)_{(0)} \rightarrow T(m-1)_{(1)} \rightarrow T(m-1)_{(2)} \rightarrow \cdots T(m)
$$

and the map $T(m-1)_{(i)} \rightarrow T(m)$ is an equivalence below dimension $p^{i}\left|t_{m}\right|-1=$ $2(h+1)\left(p^{m}-1\right)-1$.

For example when $m=i=0$, the spectrum $T(m)_{(i)}$ is $S^{0}$ while $T(m)_{p^{i+1}-1}$ is the $p$-cell complex

$$
Y=S^{0} \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{q} \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{2 q} \cdots \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{(p-1) q}
$$

where $q=2 p-2$.
In Theorem 7.1.16 we give a spectral sequence for computing $\pi_{*}\left(T(m-1)_{(i)}\right)$ in terms of $\pi_{*}\left(T(m-1)_{(i+1)}\right.$. Its $E_{1}$-term is

$$
E\left(h_{m, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m, i}\right) \otimes \pi_{*}\left(T(m-1)_{(i+1)}\right.
$$

where the elements

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{m, i} \in E_{1}^{1,2 p^{i}\left(p^{m}-1\right)} \\
& \text { and } \quad b_{m, i} \in E_{1}^{2,2 p^{i+1}\left(p^{m}-1\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

are permanent cycles.
In the case $m=i=0$ cited above, the $E_{1}$-term of this spectral sequence is

$$
E\left(h_{1,0}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{1,0}\right) \otimes \pi_{*}(Y)
$$

where $h_{1,0}$ and $b_{1,0}$ represent the homotopy elements $\alpha_{1}$ and $\beta_{1}\left(\alpha_{1}^{2}\right.$ for $\left.p=2\right)$ respectively.

Thus to compute $\pi_{*}\left(S^{0}\right)$ below dimension $p^{3}(2 p-2)$ we could proceed as follows. In this range we have

$$
B P \cong T(3) \cong T(2)_{(1)}
$$

We then use the spectral sequence of 7.1.16 to get down to $T(2)$, which is equivalent in this range to $T(1)_{(2)}$, then use it twice to get down to $T(1) \cong T(0)_{(3)}$, and so on. This would make for a total of six applications of 7.1.16. Fortunately we have some shortcuts that make this process easier.

The Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term for $T(m)$ is

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}(T(m))\right)
$$

From now on we will drop the first variable when writing such Ext groups, since we will never consider any value for it other than $B P_{*}$. There is a change-of-rings isomorphism that equates this group with

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

where

$$
\Gamma(m+1)=B P_{*}(B P) /\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right)=B P_{*}\left[t_{m+1}, t_{m+2}, \ldots\right]
$$

Using our knowledge of $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (Proposition 7.1.24) and $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (Theorem 7.1.31) in all dimensions, we will construct a 4 -term exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow D_{m+1}^{0} \rightarrow D_{m+1}^{1} \rightarrow E_{m+1}^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

of $\Gamma(m+1)$-comodules. The two $D_{m+1}^{i}$ are weak injective, meaning that all of their higher Ext groups (above $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}$ ) vanish (we study such comodules systematically at the end of Section 1), and below dimension $p^{2}\left|v_{m+1}\right|$

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}\left(D_{m+1}^{i}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{i}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

It follows that in that range

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{s}\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{s+2}\left(B P_{*}\right) \quad \text { for all } s \geq 0
$$

The comodule $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is $\left(2 p^{m+2}-2 p-1\right)$-connected. In Theorem 7.2.6 we determine its Ext groups (and hence those of $B P_{*}$ ) up to dimension $p^{2}\left|v_{m+1}\right|$. There are no Adams-Novikov differentials or nontrivial group extensions in this range (except in the case $m=0$ and $p=2$ ), so this also determines $\pi_{*}(T(m))$ in the same range.

Thus Theorem 7.2.6 gives us the homotopy of $T(0)_{(3)}$ in our range directly without any use of 7.1.16. In a future paper with Hirofume Nakai we will study the homotopy of $T(m)_{(2)}$ and the spectral sequence of 7.1.16 for the homotopy of $T(m)_{(1)}$ below dimension $p^{3}\left|v_{m+1}\right|$. There are still no room for Adams-Novikov differentials, so the homotopy and Ext calculations coincide. For $m=0$ this computation was the subject of Ravenel [11].

It is only when we pass from $T(m)_{(1)}$ to $T(m)_{(0)}=T(m)$ that we encounter Adams-Novikov differentials below dimension $p^{3}\left|v_{m+1}\right|$. For $m=0$ the first of these is the Toda differential

$$
d_{2 p-1}\left(\beta_{p / p}\right)=\alpha_{1} \beta_{1}^{p}
$$

of Toda [3] and Toda [2].

# 1. The method of infinite descent 

First we define some Hopf algebroids that we will need.
7.1.1. Definition. $\Gamma(m+1)$ is the quotient $B P_{*}(B P) /\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{m}\right)$,

$$
A(m)=B P_{*} \square_{\Gamma(m+1)} B P_{*}=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left[v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{m}\right]
$$

and

$$
G(m+1, k-1)=\Gamma(m+1) \square_{\Gamma(m+k+1)} B P_{*}=A(m+k)\left[t_{m+1}, t_{m+1} \ldots, t_{m+k}\right]
$$

We abbreviate $G(m+1,0)$ by $G(m+1)$, and is understood that $G(m+1, \infty)=$ $\Gamma(m+1)$.

In particular, $\Gamma(1)=B P_{*}(B P)$.
7.1.2. Proposition. $G(m+1, k-1) \rightarrow \Gamma(m+1) \rightarrow \Gamma(m+k+1)$ is a Hopf algebroid extension (A1.1.15). Given a left $\Gamma(m+1)$-comodule $M$ there is a CartanEilenberg spectral sequence (A1.3.14) converging to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)$ with

$$
\tilde{E}_{2}^{s, t}=\operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1, k-1)}^{s}(A(m+k), \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+k+1)}^{t}\left(B P_{*}, M\right))
$$

and $d_{r}: E_{r}^{s, t} \rightarrow \tilde{E}_{r}^{s+r, t-r+1}$. (We use the notation $\tilde{E}_{r}^{s, t}$ to distinguish the CartanEilenberg spectral sequence from the resolution spectral sequence.)

7.1.3. Corollary. Let $M$ be a $\Gamma(m+1)$-comodule concentrated in nonnegative dimensions. Then

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+k+1)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, G(m+1, k-1) \otimes_{A(m+k)} M\right)
$$

In particular, $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{s, t}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)$ for $t<2\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)$ is isomorphic to $M$ for $s=0$ and vanishes for $s>0$. Moreover for the spectrum $T(m)$ constructed in 6.5 and having $B P_{*}(T(m))=B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right]$,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}(T(m))\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)
$$

The following characterization of the Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence is a special case of (A1.3.16).
7.1.4. Lemma. The Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence of 7.1.2 is the one associated with the decreasing filtration of the cobar complex $C_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)$ (see below) defined by saying that

$$
\gamma_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes \gamma_{s} \otimes m \in C_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{*}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)
$$

is in $F^{i}$ if $i$ of the $\gamma$ 's project trivially to $\Gamma(m+k+1)$.
The method of infinite descent for computing $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)$ for a connective comodule $M$ (e.g. the BP-homology of a connective spectrum) is to compute over Ext over $\Gamma(m+1)$ by downward induction on $m$. To calculate through a fixed range of dimensions $k$, we choose $m$ so that $k \leq 2\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)$ and use 7.1.3 to start the induction. For the inductive step we could use the Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence of 7.1.2, but it is more efficient to use a different spectral sequence, which we now describe.
7.1.5. Definition. A comodule $M$ over a Hopf algebroid $(A, \Gamma)$ is weak injective (through a range of dimensions) if $\operatorname{Ext}^{s}(M)=0$ for $s>0$ (through the same range).

We will study such comodules in the at the end of this section.
7.1.6. Definition. For a left $G(m+1, k-1)$-comodule $M$ let

$$
\widehat{r}_{j}: M \rightarrow \Sigma^{j\left|t_{m+1}\right|} M
$$

be the group homomorphism defined by

$$
M \xrightarrow{\psi_{M}} G(m+1, k-1) \otimes M \xrightarrow{\rho_{j} \otimes M} \Sigma^{j\left|t_{m+1}\right|} M
$$

where $\rho_{j}: G(m+1, k-1) \rightarrow A(m+k)$ is the $A(m+k)$-linear map sending $t_{m+1}^{j}$ to 1 and all other monomials in the $t_{m+i}$ to 0 .

We will refer to this map as a Quillen operation. When $m=0$ we denote it simply by $r_{j}$.

It follows that

$$
\psi(x)=\sum_{j} t_{m+1}^{j} \otimes \widehat{r}_{j}(x)+\ldots
$$

where the missing terms involve $t_{\ell}$ for $\ell>m+1$.
The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 1.10.
7.1.7. Lemma. The Quillen operation $\widehat{r}_{j}$ of 7.1.6 is a comodule map and for $j>0$ it induces the trivial endomorphism in Ext.

7.1.8. Definition. Let $T_{m}^{h} \subset G(m+1, k-1)$ denote the sub- $A(m+k)$ module generated by $\left\{t_{m+1}^{j}: 0 \leq j \leq h\right\}$. We will denote $T_{m}^{p^{i}-1}$ by $T_{m}^{(i)}$. A $G(m+1, k-1)$-comodule $M$ is $i$-free if the comodule tensor product $T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes_{A(m+k)} M$ is weak injective.

We have suppressed the index $k$ from the notation $T_{m}^{h}$ because it will usually be clear from the context. In the case $k=\infty$ the Ext group has the topological interpretation given in Lemma 7.1.11 below. The following lemma is useful in dealing with such comodules. It is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 1.12.
7.1.9. Lemma. For a left $G(m+1)$-comodule $M$, the group

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1)}^{0}\left(A(m+1), T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes_{A(m+k)} M\right)
$$

is isomorphic as an $A(m)$-module to

$$
L=\bigcap_{j \geq p^{i}} \operatorname{ker} \widehat{r}_{j} \subset M
$$

The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 1.14.
7.1.10. Lemma. Let $D$ be a weak injective comodule over $\Gamma(m+1)$. Then $T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes D$ is also weak injective with

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}\left(T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes D\right) \cong A(m)\left\{t_{m+1}^{j}: 0 \leq j \leq p^{i}-1\right\} \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}(D)
$$

Given $x_{0} \in \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}(D)$, the element isomorphic to $t_{m+1}^{j} \otimes x_{0}$ is

$$
\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}(-1)^{k}\binom{j}{k} t_{m+1}^{k} \otimes x_{j-k} \in T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes D
$$

where $x_{j} \in D$ satsifies

$$
\psi\left(x_{j}\right)=\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}\binom{j}{k} t_{m+1}^{j-k} \otimes x_{k}
$$

The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 1.15. The only case of it that we will need here is for $m=0$, where $T(0)_{h}$ is the $2(p-1) h$-skeleton of $T(1)$.
7.1.11. Lemma. For each nonnegative $m$ and $h$ there is a spectrum $T(m)_{h}$ where $B P_{*}\left(T(m)_{h}\right) \subset B P_{*}(B P)$ is a free module over

$$
B P_{*}(T(m))=B P_{*}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right]
$$

on generators $\left\{t_{m+1}^{j}: 0 \leq j \leq h\right\}$. Its Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term is

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\left(T(m)_{h}\right)\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, T_{m}^{h}\right)
$$

We will denote $T(m)_{p^{i}-1}$ by $T(m)_{(i)}$.
To pass from $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1, k-1)}\left(T_{m}^{(i+1)} \otimes M\right)$ to $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1, k-1)}\left(T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes M\right)$ we can make use of the tensor product (over $A(m+k)$ ) of $M$ with the long exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow T_{m}^{(i)} \xrightarrow{i} R^{0} \xrightarrow{d^{0}} R^{1} \xrightarrow{d^{1}} R^{2} \xrightarrow{d^{2}} \cdots
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{2 s+e} & =\Sigma^{(p s+e) 2 p^{i}\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)} T_{m}^{(i)} \quad \text { for } e=0,1 \\
\text { and } \quad d^{s} & =\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\widehat{r}_{p^{i}} & \text { for } s \text { even } \\
\widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i}} & \text { for } s \text { odd }
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

which leads to a spectral sequence as in (A1.3.2).
7.1.13. ThEOREM. For a $G(m+1, k-1)$-comodule $M$ there is a spectral sequence converging to $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1, k-1)}\left(M \otimes T_{m}^{(i)}\right)$ with

$$
E_{1}^{*, t}=E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{G(m+1, k-1)}^{t}\left(T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes M\right)
$$

with $h_{m+1, i} \in E_{1}^{1,0}, b_{m+1, i} \in E_{1}^{2,0}$, and $d_{r}: E_{r}^{*, t} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s+r, t-r+1}$. If $M$ is $(i+1)$-free in a range of dimensions, then the spectral sequence collapses from $E_{2}$ in the same range.

Moreover $d_{1}$ is induced by the action on $M$ of $\widehat{r}_{p^{i} \Delta_{m+1}}$ for $s$ even and $\widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i}}$ for $s$ odd.

The action of $d_{1}$ is as follows. Let

$$
x=\sum_{0 \leq j<p^{i+1}} t_{m+1}^{j} \otimes m_{j} \in T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes M
$$

Then $d_{1}$ is induced by the endomorphism

$$
x \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-\sum_{0 \leq k<p^{i}} \sum_{k \leq j<p^{i+1}}\binom{j}{k} t_{m+1}^{j-k} \otimes \widehat{r}_{\left(p^{i}-k\right)}\left(m_{j}\right) \quad \text { for } s \text { even } \\
-\sum_{0 \leq k<(p-1) p^{i}} \sum_{k \leq j<p^{i+1}}\binom{j}{k} t_{m+1}^{j-k} \otimes \widehat{r}_{\left((p-1) p^{i}-k\right)}\left(m_{j}\right) \quad \text { for } s \text { odd. }
\end{array}\right.
$$

We will refer to this as the small descent spectral sequence.
Proof. Additively this spectral sequence is a special case of the one in (A1.3.2) associated with $M$ tensored with the long exact sequence (7.1.12), and the collapsing for $(i+1)$-free $M$ follows from the fact that the spectral sequence is in that case concentrated on the horizontal axis.

For the identification of $d_{1}$, note that by (7.1.12) it is induced by the endomorphism

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\sum_{0 \leq j<p^{i+1}} \widehat{r}_{p^{i}}\left(t_{m+1}^{j}\right) \otimes m_{j} & \text { for } s \text { even } \\
\sum_{0 \leq j<p^{i+1}} \widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i}}\left(t_{m+1}^{j}\right) \otimes m_{j} & \text { for } s \text { odd }
\end{array}\right. \\
& =\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\sum_{p^{i} \leq j<p^{i+1}}\binom{j}{p^{i}} t_{m+1}^{j-p^{i}} \otimes m_{j} & \text { for } s \text { even } \\
\sum_{(p-1) p^{i} \leq j<p^{i+1}}\binom{j}{(p-1) p^{i}} t_{m+1}^{j-(p-1) p^{i}} \otimes m_{j} & \text { for } s \text { odd. }
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from Lemma 7.1.7 that $\widehat{r}_{p^{i} \Delta_{m+1}}$ and $\widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i} \Delta_{m+1}}$ each induce trivial endomorphisms in Ext, so $d_{1}$ is also induced by

$$
x \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-\widehat{r}_{p^{i}}(x)+\sum_{0 \leq j<p^{i+1}} \widehat{r}_{p^{i}}\left(t_{m+1}^{j}\right) \otimes m_{j} \quad \text { for } s \text { even } \\
-\widehat{r}_{\left(p_{1}\right) p^{i}}(x)+\sum_{0 \leq j<p^{i+1}} \widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i}}\left(t_{m+1}^{j}\right) \otimes m_{j} \quad \text { for } s \text { odd }
\end{array}\right.
$$

which leads to the stated formula.
The multiplicative structure requires some explanation. The elements $h_{m+1, i}$ and $b_{m+1, i}$ correspond under Yoneda's isomorphism Hilton and Stammbach [1, page 155] to the tensor product of $M$ with the exact sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 \rightarrow T_{m}^{(i)} & \rightarrow T_{m}^{2 p^{i}-1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T_{m}^{(i)} \rightarrow 0 \\
& \text { and } \\
0 \rightarrow T_{m}^{(i)} \rightarrow T_{m}^{(i+1)} & \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T_{m}^{(i+1)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i+1}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T_{m}^{(i)} \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively. Products of these elements correspond to the splices of the these. It follows that these two elements are permanent cycles and that the spectral sequence is one of modules over the algebra $E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m+1, i}\right)$.

In practice we will find higher differentials in this spectral sequence by computing in the cobar complex $C_{G(m+1, k-1)}\left(M \otimes T_{m}^{(i)}\right)$ or its subcomplex $C_{G(m+1, k-1)}(M)$. As explained in the proof of (A1.3.2), it can be embedded by a quasi-isomorphism (i.e., a map inducing an isomorphism in cohomology) into the double complex $B=\oplus_{s, t \geq 0} B^{s, t}$ defined by

$$
B^{s, t}=C_{G(m+1, k-1)}^{t}\left(M \otimes R^{s}\right)
$$

with coboundary

$$
\partial=d+(-1)^{s} d^{s}
$$

where $d$ is the coboundary operator in the cobar complex. Our spectral sequence is obtained from the filtration of $B$ by horizontal degree, i.e., the one defined by

$$
F^{r} B=\bigoplus_{s \geq r, t \geq 0} B^{s, t}
$$

Theorem 7.1.13 also has a topological counterpart in the case $M=B P_{*}$. Before stating it we need to define topological analogs of the operations $\widehat{r}_{p^{i}}$ and $\widehat{r}_{(p-1) p^{i}}$. One can show that there are cofiber sequences

$$
T(m)_{(i)} \rightarrow T(m)_{(i+1)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{p^{i}(p-1)-1}
$$

and

$$
T(m)_{p^{i}(p-1)-1} \rightarrow T(m)_{(i+1)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{(p-1) p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i)}
$$

We define

$$
T(m)_{(i+1)} \xrightarrow{\rho_{p^{i}}} \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i+1)}
$$

and

$$
T(m)_{(i+1)} \xrightarrow{\rho_{p^{i}(p-1)}} \Sigma^{(p-1) p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i+1)}
$$

to be the composites

$$
T(m)_{(i+1)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{p^{i}(p-1)-1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i+1)}
$$

and

$$
T(m)_{(i+1)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{(p-1) p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i)} \rightarrow \Sigma^{(p-1) p^{i}\left|t_{m+1}\right|} T(m)_{(i+1)}
$$

7.1.16. ThEOREM. Let $T(m)_{(i)}$ be the spectrum of Lemma 7.1.11. There is a spectral sequence converging to $\pi_{*}\left(T(m)_{(i)}\right)$ with
$E_{1}^{s, t}=E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes \pi_{*}\left(T(m)_{(i+1)}\right) \quad$ and $\quad d_{r}: E_{r}^{s, t} \rightarrow E_{r}^{s+r, t-r+1}$ with $h_{m+1, i} \in E_{1}^{1,2 p^{i}\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)}$ and $b_{m+1, i} \in E_{1}^{2,2 p^{i+1}\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)}$. Moreover $d_{1}$ is $\rho_{p^{i}}$ for $s$ even and $\rho_{(p-1) p^{i}}$ for $s$ odd. The elements $h_{m+1, i}$ and $b_{m+1, i}$ are permanent cycles, and the spectral sequence is one of modules over the ring

$$
R=E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m+1, i}\right)
$$

We will refer to this as the topological small descent spectral sequence.
Proof. This the spectral sequence based on the Adams diagram
![img-57.jpeg](img-57.jpeg)
where

$$
\begin{aligned}
a & =2 p^{i}\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)-1 \\
b & =2 p^{i+1}\left(p^{m+1}-1\right)-2 \\
X & =T(m)_{(i)} \\
X^{\prime} & =T(m)_{p^{i}(p-1)-1} \\
\text { and } \quad Y & =T(m)_{(i+1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will show that the elements $h_{m+1, i}$ and $b_{m+1, i}$ can each be realized by maps of the form

$$
S^{0} \longrightarrow X \xrightarrow{f} \Sigma^{-7} X
$$

For $h_{m+1, i}, f$ is the boundary map for the cofiber sequence

$$
T(m)^{(i)} \rightarrow T(m)^{2 p^{i}-1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{h+1} T(m)^{(i)}
$$

and for $b_{m+1, i}$ it is the composite (in either order) of the ones for (7.1.14) and $(7.1 .15)$.
7.1.17. EXAMPLE. When $m=i=0$, the spectrum $T(0)_{(0)}$ is $S^{0}$ while $T(0)_{(1)}$ is the $p$-cell complex

$$
Y=S^{0} \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{q} \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{2 q} \cdots \cup_{\alpha_{1}} e^{(p-1) q}
$$

where $q=2 p-2$. The $E_{1}$-term of the spectral sequence of Theorem 7.1.16 is

$$
E\left(h_{1,0}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{1,0}\right) \otimes \pi_{*}(Y)
$$

where $h_{1,0}$ and $b_{1,0}$ represent the homotopy elements $\alpha_{1}$ and $\beta_{1}$ ( $\alpha_{1}^{2}$ for $p=2$ ) respectively.

We will use this spectral sequence through a range of dimensions in the following way. For each spectrum $T(m)_{(i+1)}$ the elements of Adams-Novikov filtration 0 and 1 are all permanent cycles, so we ignore them, replacing $\pi_{*}\left(T(m)_{(i+1)}\right)$ by an appropriate subquotient of $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(T_{m}^{(i)} \otimes E_{m+1}^{2}\right)$. Let $\mathbf{N}$ be a list of generators of this group arranged by dimension. When an element $x$ has order greater than $p$, we also list its nontrivial multiples by powers of $p$. Thus

$$
\mathbf{N} \otimes E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{m+1, i}\right)
$$

contains a list of generators of the $E_{1}$-term in our range. Rather than construct similar lists for each $E_{r}$ term we use the following method.
7.1.18. Input/output Procedure. We make two lists I (input) and O (output). I is the subset of $\mathbf{N} \otimes E\left(h_{m+1, i}\right)$ that includes all elements in our range. Then $\mathbf{O}$ is constructed by dimensional induction starting with the empty list as follows. Assuming $\mathbf{O}$ has been constructed through dimensions $k-1$, add to it the $k$-dimensional elements of $\mathbf{I}$. If any of them supports a nontrivial differential in the spectral sequence, remove both the source and target from $\mathbf{O}$. (It may be necessary to alter the list of $(k-1)$-dimensional elements by a linear transformation so that each nontrivial target is a "basis" element.) Then if $k>\left|b_{m+1, i}\right|$, we append the product of $b_{m+1, i}$ with each element of $\mathbf{O}$ in dimension $k-\left|b_{m+1, i}\right|$. This completes the inductive step.

Note that each element in $E_{1}$ of filtration greater than 1 is divisible by $b_{m+1, i}$. Since the spectral sequence is one of $R$-modules, that same is true of each $E_{r}$. In 7.1.18 we compute the differentials originating in filtrations 0 and 1 . If $d_{r}(x)=y$ is one of them, there is no chance that for some minimal $t>0$

$$
d_{r^{\prime}}\left(x^{\prime}\right)=b_{m+1, i}^{t} y \quad \text { with } r^{\prime}<r
$$

because such an $x^{\prime}$ would have to be divisible by $b_{m+1, i}$. This justifies the removal of $b_{m+1, i}^{t} x$ and $b_{m+1, i}^{t} y$ for all $t \geq 0$ from consideration.

We will consider various $\Gamma(m+1)$-comodules $M$ and will abbreviate $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}\left(B P_{*}, M\right)$ by $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}(M)$ or simply $\operatorname{Ext}(M)$.

Excluding the case $m=0$ and $p=2$, we will construct a diagram of 4 -term exact sequences of $\Gamma(m+1)$-comodules
![img-58.jpeg](img-58.jpeg)
where each vertical map is a monomorphism, $M^{i}$ and $N^{2}$ are as in 5.1.5, the $D_{m+1}^{i}$ are weak injectives with $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(D_{m+1}^{0}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*}\right), \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(D_{m+1}^{1}\right)$ contains $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ (with equality holding for $m=0$ and $p$ odd), and $E_{m+1}^{1}=D_{m+1}^{0} / B P_{*}$. $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ are given in 7.1.24 and 7.1.31 respectively.

It follows that for $m=0$ and $p$ odd, there is an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{*}\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{s+2}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

and for $m>0$ there is a similar isomorphism below dimension $p^{2}\left|v_{m+1}\right|$ for all primes. $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is locally finite and $\left(p\left|v_{m+1}\right|-1\right)$-connected, which means that $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{s}$ for $s>1$ vanishes below dimension $p\left|v_{m+1}\right|$.

We will construct the map from $B P_{*}$ to the weak injective $D_{m+1}^{0}$, inducing an isomorphism in Ext ${ }^{0}$, explicitly in Theorem 7.1.28. For $m>0$ we cannot construct a similar map out of $E_{m+1}^{1}=D_{m+1}^{0} / B P_{*}$. Instead we will construct a map to a weak injective $D_{m+1}^{1}$ which enlarges Ext ${ }^{0}$ by as little as possible. We will do this by producing a comodule $E_{m+1}^{2} \subset E_{m+1}^{1} / v_{1}^{\infty}$ and using the induced extension
![img-59.jpeg](img-59.jpeg)

The comodule $E_{m+1}^{2}$ for $m>0$ will be described in the next section. For $m=0$ and $p$ odd, a map from $E_{1}^{1}$ to a weak injective $D_{1}^{1}$ inducing an isomorphism in Ext ${ }^{0}$ will be constructed in below in Lemma 7.2.1.

We will use the following notations for $m>0$. We put hats over the symbols in order to distinguish this notation from the usual one for elements in $\operatorname{Ext}_{B P_{*}(B P)}$. For $m=0$ we will use similar notation without the hats.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\widehat{v}_{i}=v_{m+i}, \quad \widehat{t}_{i}=t_{m+i}, \quad \omega=p^{m} \\
\widehat{h}_{i, j}=h_{m+i, j}, \quad \text { and } \quad \widehat{b}_{i, j}=b_{m+i, j}
\end{array}\right.
$$

We will show that in dimensions below $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|, E_{m+1}^{2}$ is the $A(m+1)$-module generated by the set of chromatic fractions

$$
\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{e_{2}}}{p^{e_{0}} v_{1}^{e_{1}}}: e_{0}, e_{1}>0, e_{2} \geq e_{0}+e_{1}-1\right\}
$$

and its Ext group in this range is

$$
A(m+1) / I_{2} \otimes E\left(\widehat{h}_{1,0}\right) \otimes P\left(\widehat{b}_{1,0}\right) \otimes\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{e_{2}}}{p v_{1}}: e_{2} \geq 1\right\}
$$

where $\widehat{h}_{1,0} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{1,2(p \omega-1)}$ corresponds to the primitive $\widehat{t}_{1} \in \Gamma(m+1)$, and $\widehat{b}_{1,0} \in$ Ext $^{1,2 p(p \omega-1)}$ is its transpotent. In both cases there is no power of $v_{1}$ in the numerator when $m=0$. These statements will be proved below as Theorem 7.2.6.

An Adams-Novikov differential for $T(m)$ originating in the 2 -line would have to land in filtration $2 p+1$, which is trivial in the is range of dimensions, so by proving 7.2 .6 we have determined $\pi_{*}(T(m))$ in this range.

Our first goal here is to compute Ext ${ }^{0}$ and Ext $^{1}$. The following generalization of the Morava-Landweber theorem (4.3.2) is straightforward.

# 7.1.24. Proposition. 

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / I_{n}\right)=A(n+m) / I_{n}
$$

For $n=0$ each of the generators is a permanent cycle.

Proof. The indicated elements are easily seen to be invariant in $\Gamma(m+1)$. In dimensions less that $\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|-1, T(m)$ is homotopy equivalent to $B P$, so the generators $v_{i}$ for $i \leq m$ are permanent cycles as claimed.

Now we will describe a map from $B P_{*}$ to a weak injective $D_{m+1}^{0}$ inducing an isomorphism in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0} . D_{m+1}^{0}$ is the sub- $A(m)$-algebra of $p^{-1} B P_{*}$ generated by certain elements $\widehat{\lambda}_{i}$ for $i>0$ congruent to $\widehat{v}_{i} / p$ modulo decomposables.

To describe them we need to recall the formula of Hazewinkel [4] (see A2.2.1) relating polynomial generators $v_{i} \in B P_{*}$ to the coefficients $\ell_{i}$ of the formal group law, namely

$$
p \ell_{i}=\sum_{0 \leq j<i} \ell_{j} v_{i-j}^{p^{j}} \quad \text { for } i>0
$$

This recursive formula expands to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ell_{1} & =\frac{v_{1}}{p} \\
\ell_{2} & =\frac{v_{2}}{p}+\frac{v_{1}^{p+1}}{p^{2}} \\
\ell_{3} & =\frac{v_{3}}{p}+\frac{v_{1} v_{2}^{p}}{p^{2}}+\frac{v_{2} v_{1}^{p^{2}}}{p^{2}}+\frac{v_{1}^{1+p+p^{2}}}{p^{3}} \\
& \vdots
\end{aligned}
$$

We need to define reduced log coefficients $\widehat{\ell}_{i}$ for $i>0$ obtained from the $\ell_{m+i}$ by subtracting the terms which are monomials in the $v_{j}$ for $j \leq m$. Thus for $m>0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\ell}_{1} & =\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}}{p} \\
\widehat{\ell}_{2} & =\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}+\frac{v_{1} \widehat{v}_{1}^{p}}{p^{2}}+\frac{\widehat{v}_{1} v_{1}^{p \omega}}{p^{2}} \\
& \vdots
\end{aligned}
$$

The analog of Hazewinkel's formula for these elements is

$$
p \widehat{\ell}_{i}=\sum_{0 \leq j<i} \ell_{j} \widehat{v}_{i-j}^{p^{j}}+\sum_{0<j<\min (i, m+1)} \widehat{\ell}_{i-j} v_{j}^{p^{i-j} \omega}
$$

We use these to define our generators $\widehat{\lambda}_{i}$ recursively for $i>0$ by

$$
\widehat{\lambda}_{i}=\widehat{\ell}_{i}-\sum_{0<j<i} \ell_{j} \widehat{\lambda}_{i-j}^{p^{j}}
$$

For $m=0$ we will denote these by $\lambda_{i}$.
The following is proved as Theorem 3.12 and equation (3.15) in Ravenel [12].
7.1.28. Theorem. The $B P_{*}$-module $D_{m+1}^{0} \subset p^{-1} B P_{*}$ described above is a subcomodule over $\Gamma(m+1)$ that is weak injective (7.1.5) with $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}=A(m)$. In it we have

$$
\eta_{R}\left(\widehat{\lambda}_{i}\right) \equiv \widehat{\lambda}_{i}+\widehat{t}_{i} \bmod \text { decomposables }
$$

Before proceeding further we need the following technical tool.

7.1.29. Definition. Let $H$ be a graded connected torsion abelian p-group of finite type, and let $H_{i}$ have order $p^{h_{i}}$. Then the Poincaré series for $H$ is

$$
g(H)=\Sigma h_{i} t^{i}
$$

7.1.30. EXAMPLE. Let $I \subset B P_{*}$ be the maximal ideal so that $B P_{*} / I=\mathbf{Z} /(p)$. Then the Poincaré series for $\Gamma(m+1) / I$ is

$$
G_{m}(t)=\prod_{i>0}\left(1-t^{\left|v_{m+i}\right|}\right)^{-1}
$$

We will abbreviate $t^{\left|v_{m+i}\right|}$ by $x_{i}$ and denote $x_{1}$ simply by $x$. When $m>0$ we will denote $t^{\left|v_{i}\right|}$ for $i \leq m$ by $y_{i}$ and $t^{\left|v_{1}\right|}$ simply by $y$.

For Ext ${ }^{1}$ we have
7.1.31. Theorem. Unless $m=0$ and $p=2$ (which is handled in (5.2.6)), $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(m+1)}^{1}\left(B P_{*}, B P_{*}\right)$ is the $A(m)$-module generated by the set

$$
\left\{\delta_{0}\left(\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{j}}{j p}\right): j>0\right\}
$$

where $\delta_{0}$ is the connecting homomorphism for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow M^{0} \rightarrow N^{1} \rightarrow 0
$$

as in (5.1.5). Its Poincaré series is

$$
g_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i-1}}}{1-x^{p^{i-1}}}
$$

where $x=t^{\left|v_{m+1}\right|}$. Moroever each of these elements is a permanent cycle.
Proof. The Ext calculation follows from (6.5.11) and (7.1.3). For the Poincaré series, note that the set of $A(m)$-module generators of order $p^{i}$ is

$$
\left\{\delta_{0}\left(\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{j p^{i-1}}}{p^{i}}\right): j>0\right\}
$$

and its Poincaré series is

$$
\frac{x^{p^{i-1}}}{1-x^{p^{i-1}}}
$$

To show that each of these elements is a permanent cycle, we will study the Bockstein spectral sequence converging to $\pi_{*}(T(m))$ with

$$
E_{1}=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[v_{0}\right] \otimes \pi_{*}(V(0) \wedge T(m))
$$

$V(0) \wedge T(m)$ is a ring spectrum in all cases except $m=0$ and $p=2$. We know that $T(m)$ is a ring spectrum for all $m$ and $p$ and that $V(0)$ is one for $p$ odd. The case $p=2$ and $m>0$ is dealt with in Lemma 3.18 of Ravenel [12].

Low dimensional calculations reveal that $\widehat{v}_{1} \in \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B P_{*} / p\right)$ is a homotopy element. The elements $\widehat{\alpha}_{j}=\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{j}}{p}$ can then be constructed in the usual way using the self-map of $V(0) \wedge T(m)$ inducing multiplictation by $\widehat{v}_{1}^{j}$ followed by the pinch map

$$
V(0) \wedge T(m) \rightarrow \Sigma T(m)
$$

In the Bockstein spectral sequence it follows that $\widehat{v}_{1}^{s p^{i}}$ survives to $E_{i+1}$, so $\widehat{\alpha}_{s p^{i}}$ is divisible (as a homotopy element) by $p^{i}$.

Now we will recall some results about weak injective comodules $M$ over a general Hopf algebroid $(A, \Gamma)$ over $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$. In most cases we will refer to Ravenel [12] for the proofs. We will abbreviate $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}(A, M)$ by $\operatorname{Ext}(M)$.

The definition 7.1.5 of a weak injective should be compared with other notions of injectivity. A comodule $I$ (or more generally an object in an abelian category) is injective if any homomorphism to it extends over monomorphisms, i.e., if one can always fill in the following diagram.
![img-60.jpeg](img-60.jpeg)

This definition is rather limiting. For example if $A$ is a free $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$-module, then an injective $I$ must be $p$-divisible since a homomorphism $A \rightarrow I$ must extend over $A \otimes \mathbf{Q}$.

There is also a notion of relative injectivity (A1.2.7) requiring $I$ to be a summand of $\Gamma \otimes_{A} I$, which implies that the diagram above can always be completed when $i$ is split over $A$. This implies weak injectivity as we have defined it here (see (A1.2.8)(b)), but we do not know if the converse is true. In any case the requirements of our definition can be said to hold only through a range of dimensions. The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 2.1.
7.1.32. Lemma. A connective comodule $M$ over $(A, \Gamma)$ is weak injective in a range of dimensions iff $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}(M)=0$ in the same range.

The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Lemma 2.2.

# 7.1.33. Lemma. Let 

$$
(D, \Phi) \rightarrow(A, \Gamma) \rightarrow(A, \Sigma)
$$

be an extension (A1.1.15) of graded connected Hopf algebroids of finite type, and suppose that $M$ is a weak injective comodule over $\Gamma$. Then $M$ is also weak injective over $\Sigma$, and $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma}^{0}(A, M)$ is weak injective over $\Phi$ with

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Phi}^{0}\left(D, \operatorname{Ext}_{\Sigma}^{0}(A, M)\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma}^{0}(A, M)
$$

Here is a method of recognizing weak injectives without computing any higher Ext groups. The following is proved in Ravenel [12] as Theorem 2.6.
7.1.34. Theorem. Let $(A, \Gamma)$ be a graded connected Hopf algebroid over $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$, and let $M$ be a connected torsion $\Gamma$-comodule of finite type. Let $I \subset A$ be the maximal ideal (so that $A / I=\mathbf{Z} /(p)$ ). Then

$$
g(M) \leq g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}(M)\right) g(\Gamma / I)
$$

meaning that each coefficient of the power series on the left is dominated by the corresponding one on the right, with equality holding if and only if $M$ is a weak injective (7.1.5).

It would be nice if for any comodule $M$ one could find a map $M \rightarrow W$ to a weak injective inducing an isomorphism in $\mathrm{Ext}^{0}$, but this is not always possible. In Ravenel [12, Example 2.8] we showed that it fails when $(A, \Gamma)=(A(1), G(1))$ and $M=A /\left(p^{2}\right)$.

For future reference will need the Poincaré series of $E_{m+1}^{1}=D_{m+1}^{0} / B P_{*}$. The following is proved as Lemma 3.16 in Ravenel [12].

# 7.1.35. Lemma. Let 

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{m}(t) & =\prod_{1 \leq i \leq m} \frac{1}{1-y_{i}} \\
\text { and } \quad G_{m}(t) & =\prod_{i>0} \frac{1}{1-x_{i}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(with $x_{i}$ and $y_{i}$ as in 7.1.30) the series for $A(m) /(p)$ and $\Gamma(m+1) / I$ respectively. Then the Poincaré series for $E_{m+1}^{1}=D_{m+1}^{0} / B P_{*}$ is

$$
g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x_{i}}{1-x_{i}}
$$

## 2. The comodule $E_{m+1}^{2}$

In this section we will describe the comodule $E_{m+1}^{2}$ needed above in (7.1.20) below dimension $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$. This will determine $\pi_{*}(T(m))$ below dimension $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|-3$. For $m=0$ and $p$ odd we can construct $D_{1}^{1}$ in all dimensions directly as follows.
7.2.1. Lemma. For $p$ odd there is a map $E_{1}^{1} \rightarrow D_{1}^{1}$ to a weak injective inducing an isomorphism in $\mathrm{Ext}^{0}$.

Proof. $M^{1}=v_{1}^{-1} E_{1}^{1}$ is not a weak injective for $m=0$ since $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{1}\left(M^{1}\right)=$ $\mathbf{Q} / \mathbf{Z}$ concentrated in degree 0 .

We will construct $D_{1}^{1}$ as a union of submodules of $M^{1}$ as follows. Let $K_{0}=$ $E_{1}^{1} \subset M^{1}$. For each $i \geq 0$ we will construct a diagram
![img-61.jpeg](img-61.jpeg)
in which each row and column is exact. $L_{i}^{\prime}$ will be the sub- $B P_{*}$-module of $L_{i}=$ $M^{1} / K_{i}$ generated by the positive dimensional part of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i}\right)$. It is a subcomodule of $L_{i}, K_{i+1}$ is defined to be the induced extension by $K_{i}$, and $L_{i+1}=M^{1} / K_{i+1}$. Hence $K_{i}, K_{i+1}$, and $L_{i}^{\prime}$ are connective while $L_{i}$ and $L_{i+1}$ are not.

We know that in positive dimensions $K_{0}=E_{1}^{1}$ has the same $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}$ as $M^{1}$. We will show by induction that the same is true for each $K_{i}$. In the long exact sequence of Ext groups associated with the right column, the map $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i}\right)$ is an isomorphism in positive dimensions, so the positive dimensional part of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i+1}\right)$ is contained in $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(L_{i}^{\prime}\right)$, which has higher connectivity than $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i}\right)$.

It follows that the connectivity of $L_{i}^{\prime}$ increases with $i$, and therefore the limit $K_{\infty}$ has finite type. The connectivity of the positive dimensional part of $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{i}\right)$

also increases with $i$, so $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(L_{\infty}\right)$ is trivial in positive dimensions. From the long exact sequence of Ext groups for the short exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow K_{\infty} \rightarrow M^{1} \rightarrow L_{\infty} \rightarrow 0
$$

we deduce that $\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(K_{\infty}\right)=0$, so $K_{\infty}$ is a weak injective by Lemma 7.1.32. It has the same $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}$ as $E_{1}^{1}$, so it is our $D_{1}^{1}$.

Now we are ready to study the hypothetical comodule $E_{m+1}^{2}$ of (7.1.19) for $m>0$.
7.2.2. Lemma. The Poincaré series for $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is at least

$$
g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i}}\left(1-y_{i}\right)}{\left(1-x^{p^{i}}\right)\left(1-x_{i+1}\right)}
$$

(where $g_{m}(t)$ and $G_{m}(t)$ are as in Lemma 7.1.35), with equality holding for $m=0$ and $p>2$. In dimensions less than $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$ it simplifies to

$$
g_{m+2}(t)\left(\frac{x^{p}(1-y)}{\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x^{p}\right)}\right)
$$

where $x, y, x_{i}$ and $y_{i}$ are as in 7.1.30.
We will see in Theorem 7.2.6 below that equality also holds in dimensions less than $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$.

Proof of 7.2.2. The relevant Poincaré series (excluding the case $m=0$ and $p=2)$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right) & =g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x_{i}}{\left(1-x_{i}\right)} \quad \text { by 7.1.35 } \\
& =g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t)\left(\frac{x}{1-x}+\sum_{i>0} \frac{x_{i+1}}{1-x_{i+1}}\right) \\
\text { and } \quad g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)\right) & =g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)\right) \\
& =g_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i-1}}}{1-x^{p^{i-1}}} \quad \text { by 7.1.31 } \\
& =g_{m}(t)\left(\frac{x}{1-x}+\sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i}}}{1-x^{p^{i}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

If there were a map $E_{m+1}^{1} \rightarrow D_{m+1}^{1}$ to a weak injective inducing an isomorphism in $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}$ (which there is for $m=0$ and $p$ odd by 7.2.1), we would have

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(D_{m+1}^{1}\right) & =G_{m}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)\right) \quad \text { by 7.1.34 } \\
& =G_{m}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)\right) \\
& =g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t)\left(\frac{x}{1-x}+\sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i}}}{1-x^{p^{i}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right) & \geq g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t)\left(\frac{x}{1-x}+\sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i}}}{1-x^{p^{i}}}\right)-g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right) \\
& =g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0}\left(\frac{x^{p^{i}}}{1-x^{p^{i}}}-\frac{x_{i+1}}{1-x_{i+1}}\right) \\
& =g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t) \sum_{i>0} \frac{x^{p^{i}}\left(1-y_{i}\right)}{\left(1-x^{p^{i}}\right)\left(1-x_{i+1}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

In our range of dimensions we can replace $g_{m}(t) G_{m}(t)$ by $g_{m+2}(t)$, and only the first term of the last sum is relevant. Hence we have

$$
g\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right) \equiv g_{m+2}(t)\left(\frac{x^{p}(1-y)}{\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x^{p}\right)}\right) \quad \bmod \left(t^{p^{2}\left|\bar{v}_{1}\right|}\right)
$$

7.2.3. Corollary. For a locally finite bounded below subcomodule

$$
E \subset E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)
$$

let $D$ denote the induced (as in (7.1.20)) extension by $E_{m+1}^{1}$ shown in the following commutative diagram with exact rows.
![img-62.jpeg](img-62.jpeg)

Let $K$ denote the kernel of the connecting homomorphism

$$
\delta: \operatorname{Ext}^{0}(E) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)
$$

Then $D$ is weak injective if and only if the Poincaré series $g(E)$ is $g(K) G_{m}(t)$ plus the series specified in Lemma 7.2.2. In particular it is weak injective if $\delta$ is a monomorphism and $g(E)$ is the specifed series.

Proof. The specified series is $G_{m}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)\right)-g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)$, and

$$
g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}(D)\right)=g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)\right)+g(K)
$$

Hence our hypothesis implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(D) & =g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)+g(E) \\
& =g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)+G_{m}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)\right)-g\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)+g(K) G_{m}(t) \\
& =G_{m}(t)\left(g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{1}\right)+g(K)\right)\right. \\
& =G_{m}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}(D)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equivalent to the weak injectivity of $D$ by Theorem 7.1.34.
Now we need to identify some elements in $E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$.
7.2.4. Lemma. The comodule $E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ contains the sets

(a)

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\frac{1}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{e_{1}-e_{0}}}: e_{1}>e_{0} \geq 0\right\} \quad \text { for } m=0 \\
\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{1+e_{0}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}: e_{0}, e_{1} \geq 0\right\} \quad \text { for } m>0
\end{array}\right.
$$

(b)

$$
\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}: e_{0}, e_{1} \geq 0\right\}
$$

These generators will be discussed further in Theorem 7.2.6 below.
Proof. (i) The element in question is the image of $v_{1}^{-1-e_{1}} \widehat{\lambda}_{1}^{1+e_{0}}$.
(ii) In $D_{m+1}^{0}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\lambda}_{2} & =\widehat{\ell}_{2}-\ell_{1} \widehat{\lambda}_{1}^{p} \\
& =\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}-\frac{v_{1} \widehat{\lambda}_{1}^{p}}{p}+ \begin{cases}\frac{v_{1} \widehat{v}_{1}^{p}}{p^{2}}+\frac{v_{1}^{p \omega} \widehat{v}_{1}}{p^{2}} & \text { for } m=0 \\
\frac{v_{1}^{p+1}}{p^{2}} & \text { for } m>0\end{cases} \\
& =\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}+\frac{v_{1}}{p}\left(1-p^{p-1}\right) \widehat{\lambda}_{1}^{p}+\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
0 & \text { for } m=0 \\
v_{1}^{p \omega} \widehat{\lambda}_{1} & \text { for } m>0
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

so

$$
\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}=\widehat{\lambda}_{2}+\frac{v_{1}}{p} \mu
$$

where

$$
\mu=\left(1-p^{p-1}\right) \widehat{\lambda}_{1}^{p}+\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
0 & \text { for } m=0 \\
v_{1}^{\omega-1} \widehat{\lambda}_{1} & \text { for } m>0
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence in $p^{-1} v_{1}^{-1} B P_{*}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} & =\frac{p^{e_{1}}}{v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}\left(\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}\right)^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}} \\
& =\frac{p^{e_{1}}}{v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}\left(\widehat{\lambda}_{2}+\frac{v_{1}}{p} \mu\right)^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}} \\
& =\frac{p^{e_{1}}}{v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} \sum_{k \geq 0}\binom{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}{k} \widehat{\lambda}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}-k} \frac{v_{1}^{k}}{p^{k}} \mu^{k} \\
& =\sum_{k \geq 0}\binom{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}{k} \frac{p^{e_{1}-k}}{v_{1}^{1+e_{1}-k}} \widehat{\lambda}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}-k} \mu^{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

The image of this element in $p^{-1} B P_{*} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ is

$$
\sum_{0 \leq k \leq e_{1}}\binom{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}{k} \frac{p^{e_{1}-k}}{v_{1}^{1+e_{1}-k}} \widehat{\lambda}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}-k} \mu^{k}
$$

The coefficient of each term is an integer, so the expression lies in $D_{m+1}^{0} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$, and its image in $E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ is the desired element.

We will now construct a comodule $E_{m+1}^{2} \subset E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ satisfying the conditions of Corollary 7.2.3 with $\delta$ monomorphic below dimension $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$.
7.2.6. ThEOREM. Let $E_{m+1}^{2} \subset E_{m+1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ be the $A(m+2)$-module generated by the set

$$
\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}: e_{0}, e_{1} \geq 0\right\}
$$

Below dimension $p^{2}\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$ it has the Poincaré series specified in Lemma 7.2.2, it is a comodule, it is 1-free, and its Ext group is

$$
A(m+1) / I_{2} \otimes E\left(\widehat{h}_{1,0}\right) \otimes P\left(\widehat{b}_{1,0}\right) \otimes\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{e_{2}}}{p v_{1}}: e_{2} \geq 1\right\}
$$

In particular Ext ${ }^{0}$ maps monomorphically to $\operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(B P_{*}\right)$ in that range.

Proof. Recall that the Poincaré series specified in Lemma 7.2.2 in this range is

$$
g_{m+2}(t)\left(\frac{x^{p}(1-y)}{\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x^{p}\right)}\right)=g\left(B P_{*} / I_{2}\right) \frac{x^{p}}{\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x^{p}\right)}
$$

Each generator of $E_{m+1}^{2}$ can be written as

$$
x_{e_{0}, e_{1}}=\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}^{1+e_{0}+e_{1}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}=\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p v_{1}}\left(\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p}\right)^{e_{0}}\left(\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{v_{1}}\right)^{e_{1}}
$$

with $e_{0}, e_{1} \geq 0$. Since $\left|\frac{\widehat{v}_{2}}{p v_{1}}\right|=p\left|\widehat{v}_{1}\right|$, the Poincaré series for this set of generators is

$$
\frac{x^{p}}{\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x^{p}\right)}
$$

We can filter $E_{m+1}^{2}$ by defining $F_{i}$ to be the submodule generated by the $x_{e_{0}, e_{1}}$ with $e_{0}+e_{1} \leq i$. Then each subquotient is a direct sum of suspensions of $B P_{*} / I_{2}$, so the Poincaré series is as claimed.

To see that $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is a comodule, we will use the $I$-adic valuation as defined in the proof of Lemma 7.1.35. In our our range the set of elements with valuation at least -1 is the $A(m)$-submodule $M$ generated by

$$
\left\{\frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}: e_{0}, e_{1} \geq 0, i+j \geq 1+e_{0}+e_{1}\right\}
$$

while $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is generated by a similar set with $j \geq 1+e_{0}+e_{1}$. Thus it suffices to show that the decreasing filtration on $M$ defined by letting $F^{k} M$ be the submodule generated by all such generators with $j-e_{0}-e_{1} \geq k$ is a comodule filtration. For this observe that modulo $\Gamma(m+1) \otimes F^{1+j-e_{0}-e_{1}} M$ we have

$$
\frac{\eta_{R}\left(\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j}\right)}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} \equiv \frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i}\left(\widehat{v}_{2}+v_{1} \widehat{\widehat{v}}_{1}^{p}+p \widehat{\widehat{e}}_{2}\right)^{j}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} \in \Gamma(m+1) \otimes F^{j-e_{0}-e_{1}} M
$$

so $E_{m+1}^{2}=F^{1} M$ is a subcomodule.

We use the same filtration for the Ext computation. Assuming that $j \geq 1+$ $e_{0}+e_{1}>1$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\eta_{R}\left(\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j}\right)-\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} & \equiv \frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i}\left(\widehat{v}_{2}+v_{1} \widehat{l}_{1}^{0}+p \widehat{\mathfrak{e}}_{2}\right)^{j}-\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}} \\
& \equiv\binom{j}{e_{0}+e_{1}} \frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j-e_{0}-e_{1}}\left(v_{1} \widehat{l}_{1}^{0}+p \widehat{\mathfrak{e}}_{2}\right)^{e_{0}+e_{1}}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}+\ldots \\
& \equiv\left(e_{0}, e_{1}, j-e_{0}-e_{1}\right) \frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j-e_{0}-e_{1}} \widehat{l}_{1}^{e_{1}} \widehat{l}_{2}^{e_{0}}}{p v_{1}}+\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

where the missing terms involve higher powers of $\widehat{v}_{2}$. The multinomial coefficient $\left(e_{0}, e_{1}, j-e_{0}-e_{1}\right)$ is always nonzero since $j<p$. This means no linear combination of such elements is invariant, and the only invariant generators are the ones with $e_{0}=e_{1}=0$, so $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}$ is as claimed.

We will use this to show that $E_{m+1}^{2}$ is 1-free (as defined in 7.1.8), i.e., that $T_{m}^{p-1} \otimes_{B P_{*}} E_{m+1}^{2}$ is weak injective in this range. For $0 \leq k \leq p-1$ we have

$$
\frac{\psi\left(\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j} \widehat{l}_{1}^{k}\right)-\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j} \widehat{l}_{1}^{k}}{p^{1+e_{0}} v_{1}^{1+e_{1}}}=\left(e_{0}, e_{1}, j-e_{0}-e_{1}\right) \widehat{l}_{1}^{e_{1}+k} \widehat{l}_{2}^{e_{0}} \otimes \frac{\widehat{v}_{1}^{i} \widehat{v}_{2}^{j-e_{0}-e_{1}}}{p v_{1}}+\ldots
$$

This means that

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(T_{m}^{p-1} \otimes_{B P_{*}} E_{m+1}^{2}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right)
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\right) & =g_{m+1}(t)(1-y) \frac{x^{p}}{1-x_{2}} \\
\text { so } \quad g\left(E_{m+1}^{2}\right) & =g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\right) \frac{1}{\left(1-x^{p}\right)\left(1-x_{2}\right)} \\
\text { and } \quad g\left(T_{m}^{p-1} \otimes_{B P_{*}} E_{m+1}^{2}\right) & =g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\right) \frac{1}{(1-x)\left(1-x_{2}\right)} \\
& =g\left(\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\right) G_{m}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

This makes $T_{m}^{p-1} \otimes_{B P_{*}} E_{m+1}^{2}$ weak injective in this range by Theorem 7.1.34.

# 3. The homotopy of $T(0)_{(2)}$ and $T(0)_{(1)}$ 

In this section we will determine the Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}\left(B P_{*}\left(T(0)_{(2)}\right)\right)
$$

and $\pi_{*}\left(T(0)_{(2)}\right)$ in dimensions less than $\left(p^{3}+p\right)\left|v_{1}\right|-3$. This is lower than the range of the previous section for reasons that will be explained below in Lemma 7.3.5. All assertions about Ext groups and related objects will apply only in that range.

We will then state a theorem (7.3.15) about differentials in the spectral sequence of (7.2.13) for $j=1$, which we will prove in the next section.

Our starting point is the determination in Corollary 7.2 .7 of $\pi_{*}(T(1))$ and its Adams-Novikov $E_{2}$-term through a larger range, roughly $p^{2}\left|v_{2}\right|$. There is an equivalence

$$
T(1) \cong T(0)_{p^{3}+p^{2}-1}
$$

so we could use the small descent spectral sequence of Theorem 7.1.13 and the topological small descent spectral sequence 7.1.16 (which turn out to be the same up to regrading) to get what we want. It turns out that we can finesse this by standard algebra.

Theorem 7.2.12 gives a Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence converging to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}$ whose $E_{2}$-term is expressed in terms of $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1)}(B)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1)}\left(\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{s}\right)$ for $s \geq 2$.

First we have the following partial result about $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1)}(B)$.

$$

\end{array}\right.
$$

For $p^{j-1}<i<p^{j}+p^{j-1}$, choose $k$ so that $0<i-k p^{j-1} \leq p^{j-1}$. Then the coefficients of $\beta$ and $\beta^{\prime}$ above are units in every case except for $r_{k p^{j}}\left(\beta_{p^{j} / p^{j}}\right)$. It follows that for each element in $B$, applying $r_{k p^{j}}$ for some $k$ will yield an element in $H^{0}(B)$. This means that in our range we have

$$
g(B)=\frac{g\left(H^{0}(B)\right)}{1-x^{p^{j}}}
$$

so $B$ is $j$-free if $H^{0}(B)$ is additively isomorphic to $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B^{\prime}\right)$.
Each element in $H^{0}(B)$ is killed by $r_{i}$ for $i \geq p^{j}$, so there is a corresponding invariant element in $T_{0}^{(j)} \otimes B^{\prime}$ by Lemma 7.1.9. On the other hand, (7.3.2) implies that no element in $B^{\prime}$ outside of $T_{0}^{(j)} \otimes H^{0}(B)$ is invariant, so $\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(B^{\prime}\right)$ is as desired.

The groups $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{s}$ for $s \geq 2$ in our range were determined in Theorem 7.2.6. Translated to the present context, it reads as follows.

7.3.3. ThEOREM. Below dimension $p^{2}\left|v_{2}\right|$, the group $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{2+\star}$ is

$$
E\left(h_{2,0}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{2,0}\right) \otimes U
$$

(where $U=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{2}$ ), or more explicitly

$$
A(1) / I_{2} \otimes E\left(h_{2,0}\right) \otimes P\left(b_{2,0}\right) \otimes\left\{\delta_{0} \delta_{1}\left(\frac{v_{3}^{i} v_{2}^{j}}{p v_{1}}\right): i>0, j \geq 0\right\}
$$

where $\delta_{0}$ and $\delta_{1}$ are the connecting homomorphisms for the short exact sequences

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow M^{0} \rightarrow N^{1} \rightarrow 0
$$

and

$$
0 \rightarrow N^{1} \rightarrow M^{1} \rightarrow N^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

respectively.
7.3.4. ThEOREM. For $i, j \geq 0$, let

$$
u_{i, j}=v_{2}^{j}\left(\frac{v_{3}^{i}}{i!p v_{1}}-\frac{v_{2}^{i+i p}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p}}\right) \in N^{2}
$$

where

$$
c_{i, j}=\prod_{1 \leq k \leq i}\binom{i+j+k p}{p}
$$

Then $u_{i, j}$ has the following properties.
(i) $u_{i, j}$ lies in $E_{1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$ and is invariant over $\Gamma(2)$, i.e., it lies in

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{0}\left(E_{1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)\right)
$$

(ii) Its image in $U$ is that of

$$
\frac{v_{3}^{i} v_{2}^{j}}{i!p v_{1}}
$$

(iii) For $i>0$

$$
r_{p^{2}}\left(u_{i, j}\right)=u_{i-1, j+1}
$$

where $u_{0, j}=0$.
(iv) For $j \geq 0$,

$$
r_{p}\left(u_{1, j}\right)=-\frac{j+1}{(p, j)} \beta_{j+p / p}
$$

We will denote $u_{1, j}$ by $u_{j}$. The coefficients $i!, c_{i, j}$ and $(p, j)$ are always nonzero modulo $p$ in our range except in the case

$$
u_{p^{2}-p-1}=\frac{v_{2}^{p^{2}-p-1} v_{3}}{p v_{1}}-\frac{v_{2}^{p^{2}}}{p^{2} v_{1}^{p+1}}
$$

Proof of Theorem 7.3.4. (i) Recall (7.2.5) that

$$
\frac{v_{2}}{p}=\lambda_{2}+\left(1-p^{p-1}\right) \lambda_{1}^{p+1}
$$

while the definition of $\lambda_{3}$ implies that

$$
\frac{v_{3}}{p} \equiv \lambda_{3} \bmod \left(v_{1}\right)
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{v_{2}^{j} v_{3}^{i}}{p v_{1}} & =\frac{p^{i+j-1} \lambda_{2}^{j} \lambda_{3}^{i}}{v_{1}} \\
& \in E_{1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right) \\
\text { and } \quad \frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p}}{p v_{1}^{1+i p}} & =p^{j+i+i p-1} \frac{\left(\lambda_{2}+\left(1-p^{p-1}\right) \lambda_{1}^{p+1}\right)^{j+i+i p}}{v_{1}^{1+i p}} \\
& \in E_{1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so $u_{i, j} \in E_{1}^{1} /\left(v_{1}^{\infty}\right)$.
The invariance of $u_{i, j}$ over $\Gamma(2)$ follows from the fact (Proposition 7.1.24) that $v_{2}$ is invariant modulo $(p)$ and $v_{3}$ is invariant modulo $I_{2}$.
(ii) We will show that the difference between the two elements maps trivially to $U$. It is a scalar multiple of

$$
e=\frac{v_{2}^{i+i p}}{p v_{1}^{1+i p}}
$$

which is the image of

$$
\frac{v_{1}^{-1-i p} v_{2}^{i+i p}}{p} \in M^{1}
$$

This is invariant over $\Gamma(2)$, so our element $e \in \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{0}\left(N^{2}\right)$ is in the image of $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{0}\left(M^{1}\right)$, so it maps trivally to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(2)}^{2}=U$.
(iii) Since

$$
\text { and } \quad \begin{aligned}
\eta_{R}\left(v_{3}\right) & \equiv v_{3}+v_{2} t_{1}^{p^{2}}-v_{2}^{p} t_{1} \quad \bmod I_{2} \\
\eta_{R}\left(v_{2}\right) & \equiv v_{2}+v_{1} t_{1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1} \quad \bmod I_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta_{R}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j} v_{3}^{i}}{i!p v_{1}}\right) & =\frac{v_{2}^{j}\left(v_{3}^{i}+i v_{2} v_{3}^{i-1} t_{1}^{p^{2}}+\ldots\right)}{i!p v_{1}} \\
\text { so } \quad r_{p^{2}}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j} v_{3}^{i}}{i!p v_{1}}\right) & =\frac{v_{2}^{j+1} v_{3}^{i-1}}{(i-1)!p v_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second term we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta_{R}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p}}\right) & =\frac{\left(v_{2}+v_{1} t_{1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p} t_{1}\right)^{j+i+i p}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p}} \\
& =\sum_{0 \leq k \leq i p}\binom{j+i+i p}{k} \frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p-k}\left(t_{1}^{p}-v_{1}^{p-1} t_{1}\right)^{k}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p-k}} \\
& =\sum_{0 \leq k \leq i p}\binom{j+i+i p}{k} \sum_{0 \leq \ell \leq k}(-1)^{\ell}\binom{k}{\ell} \frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p-k} t_{1}^{p(k-\ell)+\ell}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p-k-(p-1) \ell}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We need to collect the terms in which the exponent of $t_{1}$ is $p^{2}$, i.e. for which $(p-1) \ell=p(k-p)$. Hence $k-p$ must be divisible by $p-1$, so we can write

$k=p+(p-1) k^{\prime}$ and $\ell=p k^{\prime}$. This gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& r_{p^{2}}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p}}\right) \\
& =\sum_{0 \leq k^{\prime} \leq p}(-1)^{p k^{\prime}}\binom{j+i+i p}{p+(p-1) k^{\prime}}\binom{p+(p-1) k^{\prime}}{p k^{\prime}} \frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p-p-(p-1) k^{\prime}}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p-p-\left(p^{2}-1\right) k^{\prime}}} \\
& =\binom{j+i+i p}{p} \frac{v_{2}^{j+i+i p-p}}{c_{i, j} p v_{1}^{1+i p-p}} \\
& =\frac{v_{2}^{j+i+(i-1) p}}{c_{i-1, j+1} p v_{1}^{1+(i-1) p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the result follows.
(iv) Using the methods of (iii), we find that

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{p}\left(u_{1, j}\right) & =r_{p}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j} v_{3}}{p v_{1}}\right)-r_{p}\left(\frac{v_{2}^{j+p+1}}{c_{1, j} p v_{1}^{p+1}}\right) \\
& =-\binom{j+p+1}{1} \frac{v_{2}^{j+p}}{c_{1, j} p v_{1}^{p}} \\
& =-\frac{j+1}{(p, j)} \frac{v_{2}^{j+p}}{c_{1, j} p v_{1}^{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $U_{0} \subset v_{2}^{-1} U$ is the $A(2)$-submodule generated by

where

& P\left(b_{1,1}\right) \otimes\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\oplus \\

where $0 \leq i<p$, (omitting unnecessary subscripts)

and the operators $h_{i, j}, b_{i, j}$, etc. behave as if they had the following bidegrees.

7.3.15. TheOrem. The Cartan-Eilenberg spectral sequence of (7.2.13) for $j=1$ has the following differentials and no others in dimensions less than $\left(p^{3}+p\right)\left|v_{1}\right|$.
(i)

(ii)

d_{2 k+2}\left(h_{1,1} h_{2,0} b_{2,0}^{k} u_{p i^{\prime}-2-k}\right)=h_{1,1} b_{1,1}^{k+1} \beta_{p i^{\prime} / k+1}^{\prime} \quad \text { for } k<p-1

(iv)

$$

(v)

$$
d_{3}\left(h_{2,0}^{\varepsilon} b_{2,0}^{k} \gamma_{j}\right)=k h_{1,1} h_{2,0}^{\varepsilon} b_{1,1} b_{2,0}^{k-1} \gamma_{j}
$$

We will prove Theorem 7.3.15 in the next section. For a more explicit description of the resulting Ext group, see Theorem 7.5.1. An illustration of it for $p=5$ can be found in Figure 7.3.17. There are no Adams-Novikov differentials in this range. In the figure

Now that we have computed $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}\right)$, it is a simple matter to get to $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}\left(T_{0}^{(1)}\right)$ itself. We have the 4 -term exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow T_{0}^{(1)} \rightarrow T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes D_{1}^{0} \rightarrow T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes D_{1}^{1} \rightarrow T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

in which the two middle terms are weak injectives by Lemma 7.1.10 with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{0}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes D_{1}^{i}\right) & \cong \mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left\{t_{1}^{j}: 0 \leq j<p\right\} \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{0}\left(D_{1}^{i}\right) \\
& \cong \mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left\{t_{1}^{j}: 0 \leq j<p\right\} \otimes \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{1}\left(B P_{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We will compute Ext ${ }^{0}$ of the middle map of (7.3.16) using the description of the groups given in 7.1.10. Recall that $D_{1}^{0}$ contains all powers of $\lambda_{1}=p^{-1} v_{1}$. Then $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{0}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes D_{1}^{0}\right)$ is the free $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$-module on the set $\left\{z_{j}: 0 \leq j<p\right\}$ where

$$
z_{j}=\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}(-1)^{k}\binom{j}{k} t_{1}^{k} \otimes \lambda_{1}^{j-k}=t_{1}^{j} \otimes 1+\ldots
$$

The image of

$$
\begin{aligned}
p^{t} z_{j} & =\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}(-1)^{k} p^{t}\binom{j}{k} t_{1}^{k} \otimes \lambda_{1}^{j-k} \\
& =\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}(-1)^{k}\binom{j}{k} t_{1}^{k} \otimes p^{t+k-j} v_{1}^{j-k}
\end{aligned}
$$

in $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{0}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes D_{1}^{1}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{0 \leq k \leq j}(-1)^{k}\binom{j}{k} t_{1}^{k} \otimes \frac{v_{1}^{j-k}}{p^{j-k-t}} & =(-1)^{j-1-t}\binom{j}{t+1} t_{1}^{j-1-t} \otimes \alpha_{t+1}+\ldots \\
& =0 \quad \text { if } t \geq j
\end{aligned}
$$

From this we deduce that

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(T_{0}^{(1)}\right)=\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}\left\{p^{j} z_{j}: 0 \leq j<p\right\}
$$

and Ext ${ }^{0}$ of the third map of (7.3.16) sends

$$
t_{1}^{(1)} \otimes \alpha_{1}+\cdots \mapsto 1 \otimes \beta_{1}
$$

Thus the map

$$
\operatorname{Ext}^{0}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{2}\left(T_{0}^{(1)}\right)
$$

has a kernel, namely the $\mathbf{Z}_{(p)}$-summand generated by $\beta_{1}$, and for $s>2$,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{s}\left(T_{0}^{(1)}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}^{s-2}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}\right)
$$

which can be read off from Theorem 7.3.15.

# 4. The proof of Theorem 7.3.15 

Recall that our range of dimensions is now $\left(p^{3}+p\right)\left|v_{1}\right|$.
It is easy to see that all of the elements in Corollary 7.3.14 save those involving $u_{j}$ or $b_{2,0}$ are permanent cycles. Establishing the indicated differentials will ultimately be reduced to computing Ext groups for certain comodules over the Hopf algebra

$$
P(1)_{*}=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left[c\left(t_{1}\right), c\left(t_{2}\right)\right] /\left(c\left(t_{1}^{p^{2}}\right), c\left(t_{2}\right)^{p}\right)
$$

with coproduct inherited from that of $B P_{*}(B P)$, i.e., with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta\left(c\left(t_{1}\right)\right) & =c\left(t_{1}\right) \otimes 1+1 \otimes c\left(t_{1}\right) \\
\text { and } \quad \Delta\left(c\left(t_{2}\right)\right) & =c\left(t_{2}\right) \otimes 1+c\left(t_{1}\right)^{p} \otimes c\left(t_{1}\right)+1 \otimes c\left(t_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is dual to the subalgebra $P(1)$ of the Steenrod algebra generated by the reduced power operations $P^{1}$ and $P^{p}$. For a $P(1)_{*}$-comodule $M$, we will abbreviate $\operatorname{Ext}_{P(1)_{*}}(\mathbf{Z} /(p), M)$ by $\operatorname{Ext}_{P(1)_{*}}(M)$, or, when $M=\mathbf{Z} /(p)$, by simply $\operatorname{Ext}_{P(1)_{*}}$

In principle one could get at $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(1)}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}\right)$ in our range of dimensions (i.e., below dimension $\left.p^{3}\left|v_{1}\right|\right)$ by finding $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(3)}\left(T_{0}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}\right)$ and using the CartanEilenberg spectral sequence for the extension

$$
G(1,1) \rightarrow \Gamma(1) \rightarrow \Gamma(3)
$$

(Recall that $G(1,1)=A(2)\left[t_{1}, t_{2}\right]$.)
Consider our 4 -term exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow B P_{*} \rightarrow D_{1}^{0} \rightarrow D_{1}^{1} \rightarrow E_{1}^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

The two middle terms are weak injective over $\Gamma(1)$ and hence over $\Gamma(3)$. For the last term we have,

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(3)}^{s}\left(E_{1}^{2}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(3)}^{s+2} \quad \text { for } s>0
$$

The first generator for $s=1$ is $\frac{v_{4} t_{3}}{p v_{1}}$, which is out of our range. This means that the fourth term is also weak injective over $\Gamma(3)$ in our range.

For a $\Gamma(1)$-comodule $M$, we will denote the $G(1,1)$-comodule $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(3)}^{0}(M)$ by $\tilde{M}$. Applying $\operatorname{Ext}_{\Gamma(3)}^{0}(\cdot)$ to our 4 -term exact sequence yields a 4 -term exact (in our range) sequence of $G(1,1)$-comodules

$$
0 \rightarrow A(2) \rightarrow \tilde{D}_{1}^{0} \rightarrow \tilde{D}_{1}^{1} \rightarrow \tilde{E}_{1}^{2} \rightarrow 0
$$

Let $\tilde{D}_{1}^{2}$ be the $A(2)$-submodule of $\tilde{M}^{2}$ (where $M^{2}$ is the chromatic comodule) obtained by adjoining the elements

$$
\left\{\frac{v_{2}^{-j} v_{3}^{k}}{p v_{1}^{i}}: i, j>0, k \geq i+j\right\}
$$

to $\tilde{E}_{1}^{2}$, so we have a short exact sequence of $G(1,1)$-comodules

$$
0 \rightarrow \tilde{E}_{1}^{2} \rightarrow \tilde{D}_{1}^{2} \rightarrow \tilde{E}_{1}^{3} \rightarrow 0

where $\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ is the $A(2)$-submodule of $\tilde{N}^{3}$ generated by

g\left(\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)=\frac{x^{2 p^{2}+p}}{\left(1-x^{p^{2}}\right)\left(1-x_{2}^{p}\right)\left(1-x_{3}\right)}

7.4.3. Definition. Let $P$ be the left $G(1,1)$-comodule

$$
\begin{aligned}
P & =A(2)\left\{c\left(t_{1}^{i} t_{2}^{j}\right): 0 \leq i, p j<p^{2}\right\} \\
& =A(2)\left\{t_{1}^{i}\left(t_{2}-t_{1}^{p+1}\right)^{j}: 0 \leq i, p j<p^{2}\right\} \subset G(1,1)
\end{aligned}
$$

A $G(1,1)$-comodule $M$ is $P$-free (in a range of dimensions) if $P \otimes_{A(2)} M$ is weak injective (in the same range).
7.4.4. Lemma. $\tilde{D}_{1}^{2}$ and $\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ are $P$-free in our range, i.e. below dimension $p^{2}\left|v_{2}\right|$.

Proof. For $\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ we can show this by direct calculation. Up to unit scalar we have

$$
r_{(j-1) p^{2} \Delta_{1}+(i-1) p \Delta_{2}}\left(\frac{v_{3}^{k}}{p v_{1}^{i} v_{2}^{j}}\right)=\frac{v_{3}^{k+2-i-j}}{p v_{1} v_{2}}=\gamma_{k+2-i-j}
$$

so these elements form a basis for $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)$ and for $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(P \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)$. (Here $r_{a, b}$ denotes the Quillen operation dual to $t_{1}^{a} t_{2}^{b}$.) The Poincaré series for this Ext ${ }^{0}$ is

$$
\frac{x^{2 p^{2}+p}}{1-x_{3}}
$$

Meanwhile we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(P \otimes_{A(2)} \tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right) & =g(P(1)) g\left(\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right) \\
& =\frac{\left(1-x^{p^{2}}\right)\left(1-x_{2}^{p}\right)}{(1-x)\left(1-x_{2}\right)} \frac{x^{2 p^{2}+p}}{\left(1-x^{p^{2}}\right)\left(1-x_{2}^{p}\right)\left(1-x_{3}\right)} \\
& =\frac{x^{2 p^{2}+p}}{(1-x)\left(1-x_{2}\right)\left(1-x_{3}\right)} \\
& =g_{2}(t) g\left(\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so $\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ is $P$-free as claimed.
For $\tilde{D}_{1}^{2}$ we will first show that $P \otimes \tilde{D}_{1}^{2}$ is weak injective over $G(2)$. Then it will suffice to show that

$$
\operatorname{Ext}_{G(2)}^{0}\left(P \otimes \tilde{D}_{1}^{2}\right)
$$

is weak injective over $G(1)$, i.e. that $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(2)}^{0}\left(\tilde{D}_{1}^{2}\right)$ is 2 -free.
As a $G(2)$-comodule, $P$ is isomorphic to a direct sum of certain suspensions of $T_{1}^{(1)}$. We know by Theorem 7.2.6 that $T_{1}^{(1)} \otimes E_{2}^{2}$ is weak injective over $\Gamma(2)$ in our

range. The same is true of $T_{1}^{(1)} \otimes E_{1}^{2}$ since it has the same positively graded Ext groups over $\Gamma(2)$. Thus the same goes for $T_{1}^{(1)} \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{2}$ and $P \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{2}$ over $G(2)$. Since we already know that $P \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ is weak injective over $G(1,1)$ and hence over $G(2)$, this implies that $P \otimes \tilde{D}_{1}^{2}$ is weak injective over $G(2)$.

This means that it suffices to show that $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(2)}^{0}\left(\tilde{D}_{1}^{2}\right)$ is 2-free. For this we have the following diagram with exact rows and columns.

We will show that $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(P \otimes \tilde{D}_{1}^{2}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(P \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)$ each admit filtrations whose associated bigraded objects are comodules over $P(1)_{*}$, and analyzing them will lead to a proof of Theorem 7.3.15.

As in the above lemma, $\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}$ is easier to handle. We have

\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(P \otimes \tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)=\operatorname{Ext}_{G(1,1)}^{0}\left(\tilde{E}_{1}^{3}\right)=\mathbf{Z} /(p)\left\{\gamma_{k}: k \geq 2\right\}

No filtration is necessary here since it is annihilated by $I_{2}$, and we have
